description: HUNTINGTON, L. I., Dec. 2  Miss Louise Elizabeth Walsh and John Francis Walsh, who work in behalf of the blind, were married here this afternoon. The Rev. John Skelly performed the ceremony in St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Church.

title: AirCushion Trips to Capital Seen
description: Within a decade it should be technologically possible to travel between New York and Washington in 55 minutes in a 300mileanhour wheelless tracked aircushion vehicle, according to the head of the Federal Railroad Administra tion.

title: Pollution
description: Two months ago, state and local governments throughout the country were given renewed hope for the fu ture of their inland waters. Congress had overridden the President's veto and passed into law the most sweep ing and costly cleanwaters program ever voted by any nation. It author ized the spending of $11billion over a twoyear period for the construction of waste treatment plants and systems to remove the pollutants poisoning our lakes, streams and rivers.

title: Queens Planner Backs Local Role
description: Mrs. Claire Shulman, Who completed her first week as director of community boards of Queens last Fri day, believes that the future of city government will be focused on the community level.

title: School Bus Safety Is Stressed in Suffolk Study
description: School bus accidents in the populous five towns of west ern Suffolk County have more than tripled in the last seven years, according to a report by the county's Traffic Safe ty Board.

title: A Vitamin C Factory Opens in Belvidere
description: BELVIDERE  A fully computerized factory that is designed to turn out 10,000 tons of Vitamin C a year without fouling the air and waters around it has begun operation here on the banks of the Delaware River.

title: JAIL BREAK ADDS TO WARDEN'S WOES
description: DOYLESTOWN, Pa., Dec. 2 When 12 prisoners sawed through cellblock doors to es cape the Bucks County Prison, which has a national reputation for its innovations in criminal rehabilitation, they brought new problems to Warden John D. Case. The retired Marine Corps major was already un der fire for his handling of security problems at the 88 yearold prison.

title: Meskill Foresees Riderless Buses
description: HARTFORD, Dec. 2  If Connecticut's bus crisis con tinues much longer, it may prove not to be a crisis at all, according to Gov. Thomas J. Me skill.

title: Argentine Officer Cited on Bormann Not Listed on Rolls
description: BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 2  The Argentine federal police have not had on their rolls for at least two years any officer named Jos Juan Velasco, the name given to a key official source cited in recent published reports that Martin Bormann, Hitler's deputy, was alive and was living in South America.

title: C.L.U. SAYS POLICE USE ENTRAPMENT
description: Charging possible entrap ment and other violations of civil liberties, the New York Civil Liberties Union is offering to defend the men arrested in the Police Department's new Operation John, in which under cover policewomen in the Times Square area have charged the men with seeking to engage them as prostitutes.

title: Soviet Gymnasts Lead
description: NAGOYA, Japan, Dec. 2 (Reuters)Soviet gymnasts led after the first day in the Chunichi Cup international gymnastics competition today. Twentyyearold Nikolai An drianov, who was fourth in the Olympic Games individual event, took a narrow lead over Japanese contenders with a threeevent score of 28.40 points.

title: James P. Kovacs Weds Justine Perdunn
description: BRIELLE, N.J., Dec, 2 Miss Justine Rneau Perdunn, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Francis Perdunn of New York and Brielle, and James Paul Kovacs were married here this noon by the Rev. William H. Jewett at the Church in BrieIle (Re form Church in America).

title: MRS. JAMES M'DONOUGH
description: GLEN HEAD, L. I., Dec. 2 Mrs. Margaret C. McDonough, wife of James J. McDonough, former president of the Nassau Bar Association and the county's first Public Defender, died to day Community Hospital, Glen Cove. She was 60 years old and lived here at 3 Glen Lane.

title: State Employes Will Vote This Week
description: A battle between two unions to represent 78,000 state em ployes will be resolved this week in one of the largest rep resentation elections ever held for public workers.

title: Fire Official Killed
description: ORLANDO, Fla., Dec. 2 (UPI) An assistant fire chief was killed and six other firemen were injured today when fire destroyed an old, vacant build ing in the heart of the city. The assistant chief, George Book hardt, 40 years old, was killed when the walls of the building collapsed, burying him under the rubble.

title: Ma Bell led the way
description: In his article Japanese businessmen: The yen is mightier than the sword (Oct. 29), James Sterba credits the Sony Corporation with leading the way in commercial exploitation of the transistor while the inventor, Bell Tele phone Laboratories, didn't know what to do with it except sell it to the Pentagon.

title: Arcari Outpoints Argentine
description: TURIN, Italy, Dec. 2 (Re uters)Bruno Arcari of Italy retained his World Boxing Council junior welterweight boxing title tonight when he outpointed Everaldo Costa Azevedo of Argentina over 15 rounds.

title: A PartTime Mayor Satisfies Freeport
description: FREEPORT, L. I. Some one once suggested it might be interesting and democratic to find out whether residents here would prefer their mayors to serve fulltime in stead of parttime. So, last Nov. 7, the issue was put on the ?? Apparently, part timers are here to stay.

title: New Downstate Surgery Chief Aims for Impact Without Clamor
description: The new chief of surgery at Downstate Medical Center in Brooklyn has slipped into his job quietly, trying to have a maximum impact with a mini mal amount of expenditure, re sources and excitement

title: RESIDENTS SCORE A WELFARE HOTEL
description: A politician and his constitu ents shivered together yester day on the otherwise deserted sidewalk in front of a Harlem welfare hotel and assailed the hotel, its owners, tenants and the city for allowing it to exist.

title: A Pattern of Change
description: Change is the law of life. The study of history has an inherent fascination partly because men yearn to discover the laws which govern change in human affairs or at least some significant clues from the past which may help them understand and prepare for the changes which the future is sure to bring. Agreement on these laws, if they exist, is hard to come by and men differ in interpreting history's clues. Still the effort goes on.

title: SchoolBond Issue Facing Teaneck Voters Again
description: TEANECK  For the sec ond time in as many months, the more than 23,000 regis tered voters in this town are being asked to vote on a $13.5million school bond is sue. The proceeds would be used to enlarge and renovate Teaneck High School and thus relieve what adminis trators describe as serious overcrowding throughout their 7,700pupil system.

title: Robert B. Clark, Lawyer, Weds Betsy G. Gambrill in Bay State
description: WESTON, Mass., Dec. 2 Miss Bersy Greenwood Gam brill and Robert Brewster Clark were married here this afternoon in St. Peter's Epis copal Church. The bride's brother, the Rev. James H. Gambrill, rector of St. Ste phen's Memorial Church in Lynn, performed the cere mony.

title: GOVERNOR SCORES BANBRIDGE VOTES
description: Governor Rockefeller, irked by sharp criticism of some of his vetoes, said in Poughkeep sie the other day how legisla tors sometimes put themselves in a good posture with their constituents at his expense.

title: BIG Is Word This Week For Pair of Dog Shows
description: Big is the word for the two dog shows this week Boardwalk today and Phila delphia next Saturday.

title: Tours Show Homes in Holiday Dress
description: CALDWELL  Homes with distinctive personalities, in teresting to see at any time of the year, are particularly provocative when holiday motifs prevail.

title: More in State Enter College With 3 Years of High School
description: SOUTH ORANGEGuid ance counselors in the state are reporting that growing numbers of high school stu dents are skipping their sen ior years and entering col lege a year early.

title: Liechtenstein Votes Market Accord
description: GENEVA, Dec. 2Liech tenstein, the 62squaremile principality wedged between Switzerland and Austria, has agreed to a freetrade pact with the European Economic Community.

title: Guardsmen Help Clean a Vacant Lot in Brooklyn
description: A Brooklyn unit of the tional Guard, in an effort to strengthen relations with local communities, went into the Bushwick section yesterday to help clean up a vacant lot that posed It health hazard to res idents.

title: Church Converted To Spacious Home
description: Robert Brand and Gerry O'Regan were hunting on Staten Island for a house that would be unlike others on the block. So they bought a church.

title: Banker Joins Williams
description: WORCESTER, Mass., Dec. 2 (AP)  Francis H. Dewey 3d, president of the Mechanics Na tional Bank of Worcester, is resigning to become vice pres ident for administration and treasurer of Williams College. Mr. Dewey, who is also resign ing as chairman of the board of the bank's parent company, the Multibank Financial Corpo ration of Boston, said Thursday he would take over at Williams in April. He will succeed Charles A. Foehl Jr.

title: The Serengeti Lion
description: In north central Tanzania, border ed by Lake Victoria on the west, by Kenya on the north, by the Rift Val ley and the Crater Highlands on the east, lies a piece of Africa that haunts our collective memories and vibrates in our genes. The Serengeti

title: Italians Finish 1, 2, 3,
description: MONTGENEVRE, France, Dec. 2 (AP)Italians, led by Antonio Enzi, swept the first three places today in the men's downhill event of the interna tional autumn ski meet.

title: OPERATIC MEDEA IS GIVEN ON COAST
description: SAN DIEGO, Nov. 29Alva Henderson's Medea, which had its world premiere Friday night In San Diego's Civic Theater, has an unusually colorful history. This operatic setting of Robinson Jeffers's play is the first major compo sition by the 32yearold Cali fornian. He was inspired by Maria Callas's singing the title roles in Verdi's Lady Macbeth and Cherubini's Medea.

title: David Lorber Marries Jane de Moret Foster
description: Miss Jane de Moret Foster, who is descended from Philip Hone, New York's Mayor from 1826 to 1827, Was married here yesterday afternoon to David Martin Hall Barnes Lorber, who is descended from Whitehead Hicks, New York's Mayor from 1766 to 1776. The Right Rev. Anson Phelps Stokes, Episcopal Bishop of Massachusetts, as sisted by the Rev. Almus Thorpe, performed the cere mony in the chapel of St. James Episcopal Church, where Mrs. James M. Snow den and Miss Mary Hancock Peabody were honor attend ants. Miss Elizabeth Jean Blackford and Mrs. R. Fred erick Woolworth also at tended the bride. Nicola Foster, the bride's niece, was flower girl.

title: Teacup ears on a Greek vase?
description: As a quite wellknown art ist, and, until my retirement, associate professor of art and art appreciation at The City College of The City University of New York, I have no inten tion of belittling the Greek vase acquired by The Metro politan Museum of Art, de scribed eloquently by James R. Mellow (A new [6th century B.C.] Greek vase for New York, Nov. 12). What I do object to, however, is the total adoration expressed by Mr. Mellow and by Thomas P. F. Hoving, director of the Metro politan. This Sarpedon vase is beautiful, no doubt, to anyone acquainted with Greek vase painting. It is a superior piece of workcomparatively.

title: He Mixes Work and Play
description: MONTAGUE Can a man who has felt the frantic beat of New York, where he was the banquet manager at such wellknown hotels as the Americana and the Pierre, find happiness as the man ager of a small private club in North Jersey?

title: Shrewd Soviet Diplomacy
description: PARISIf one looks back on inter national developments over the past decade it is impossible to avoid the conclusion that Soviet policy has reg istered impressive gains. These are now on the road to being punctuated by EastWest multilateral conferences of which the Helsinki talks on Euro pean security are but the first.

title: Million in Brooklyn Are Foreign Stock
From ChickenRaising to Tourism, Uganda's Economy Is Paying for Expulsion of Asians
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Dec. 2In a village just outside Kampala in neighboring Uganda, an old man talked of having just lost his job of many years because his employer, an Asian, had been expelled. The old man was returning to his but and was trying to negotiate a loan to buy 500 chickens.

title: Mrs. Knauer Cites Success On Flood Victim Complaints
description: WILKESBARRE, Pa., Dec. 2 (AP)  Virginia H. Knauer, special assistant to the Presi dent for consumer affairs, said yesterday that her office here had handled 3,213 complaints of flood victims and success fully resolved 97 per cent of them.

title: 3 LOSE AUTHORITY IN INDIAN AFFAIRS
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 2Sec retary of the Interior Rogers C. B. Morton stripped three major officials of their author ity over Indian affairs today.

title: Fire Kills 35 Race Horses
description: SAINT JOHN, N. B., Dec. 2 (Reuters)Thirtyfive harness horses, valued at more than $200,000, were killed last night when fire swept through a new barn at the city's harness rac ing track.

title: Growing Parsippany: 6 Towns in One
description: The Talk of Parsippany

title: EUROPEAN MEASURE WOULD AID NEWSMEN
description: STRASBOURG, France, Dec. 2 (Reuters)A Council of Eu rope Committee of Human Rights has accepted a draft con vention to protect the rights of foreign press correspondents to operate freely abroad.

title: 2 Dead, 22 Missing In Japanese Storm
description: TOKYO, Dec. 2Two persons were killed and at least 22 are missing and presumed dead in a storm that struck Japan to day.

title: Last Apollo Wednesday; Scholars Assess Program
description: Now is the time to take longer strides, time for a great new American enter prise, time for this nation to take a clearly leading role in space achievement, which in many ways may hold the key to our future on earth.President Kennedy, announc ing the Apollo project on May 25, 1961.

title: Castrated: My eight months in prison
description: The door to the cell slammed shut and there I was behind bars. The 10year ordeal of courtroom histrionics, legalistic doubletalk and dashed hopes had ended at last. I found myself in the tiny lockup of the Federal District Court at Lewisburg, Pa. The date was Feb. 17, 1972.

title: Swiss Ambassador Represents 10 Nations in Cuba
description: GENEVA, Dec. 2When Sil vio Masnata, the Swiss Ambas sador to Havana, went to the Cuban Foreign Ministry last Saturday, he began negotiations on behalf of the United States on how to prevent the hijack ing of airliners to Cuba.

title: Bill to Disband the Swiss Cavalry Gains
description: GENEVA, Dec. 2The upper house of the Swiss Parliament proved less sentimental than the lower house this week by voting to disband the army's remaining 18 cavalry squad rons.

title: Rail Crossing Is Plaguing Saddle Brook
description: SADDLE BROOK The tracks of the New York, Sus quehanna & Western Railroad cut across this community from east to west, resembling a giant belt stretched taut over a mile and onehalf of light industries and pleasant middleclass housing.

title: Experts'
description: NEW BRUNSWICK  A booklet entitled Indoor Care of Christmas Trees and Greens has been prepared by three specialists of the Co operative Extension Service of the College of Agriculture and Environmental Science at Rutgers. They are Austin N. Lentz, specialist in farm for estry; Gena Thames, associate specialist in home furnishing, and William J. Roberts, asso ciate specialist in agricultural engineering. Their advice in cludes the following:

title: Blaze Halts IND Service From 59th to 125th Street
description: All IND subway service be tween 59th and 125th Streets was temporarily suspended yesterday morning after a fire broke out in the tunnel near 81st Street and Central Park West.

title: Pam S. Horvitz Plans June Bridal
description: SHAKER HEIGHTS, Ohio, Dec. 2Miss Pam Susan Hor vitz and Milton S. Schneider plan to be married June 30.

title: Oklahoma Defeats Oklahoma State, 3815, and Captures Big Eight Crown
AUGERT OF FRANCE VICTOR IN SKIING.
description: COURCHEVEL, France, Dec. 2 (UPI)JeanNoel Augert of France sped to a convincing victory today in the giant sla lom event, the first counting for this year's European Alpine ski cup championship. Adolf Roesti of Switzerland was second.

title: California Approves Property Tax Relief but Bars NoFault Plan
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Dec. 2 In a dramatic windup of the 1972 California Legislature early today, Gov. Ronald Rea gan won a sixyear fight for property tax relief but lost his efforts for a state nofault automobile insurance program.

title: Carolina Policeman Slain
description: ROWLAND, N.C., Dec. 2 (UPI)A rookie North Caro lina highway patrolman was slain; apparently with his own service revolver, after stopping a car five miles west of here today. L.T. Walton, 25 years old, a native of Holly Ridge, was shot at least three times, including once in the head, the police said.

title: NAVY FLEET MERGER TO AFFECT SAN DIEGO
description: SAN DIEGO, Dec. 2 (AP) The Navy said this week that the First Fleet would be abol ished Feb. 1 and that the Third Fleet, which was deactivated after World War II, would be created again with Pearl Har bor as its headquarters.

title: Miss Crown Bride Of Fellow Lawyer
description: Miss Michele Fleurette Crown, a lawyer in the anti trust section of the Federal Trade Commission in Wash ington, was married here last evening to Norman Robert Williams, who is with the general counsel's office of the Latin American bureau, at the Agency for Interna tional Development in Wash ington. Judge Guy Ribaudo of the Civil. Court performed the ceremony at his home.

title: Seat Belts Advertised With Love
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 2If motorists will not buckle their seat belts for any other reason, perhaps they will do so out of lovefor their families, their sweethearts or themselves. At least the theory is worth testing, in the estimation of the National Safety Council.

title: Evans and Gregory Columbia Football CoCaptains
description: Mike Evans and Ted Greg ory, two of the leading de fensive players in the Ivy League, have been elected co captains of the 1973 Columbia varsity football team. They succeed Don Jackson, Jesse Parks and Paul Kaliades.

title: A FunHouse Mirror
description: The Good Word

title: IndiaPakistan
description: WAGAH, IndiaThe sound of bag pipe music filled the air. Women threw rose and marigold petals. There were tears of joy all around.

title: Urban Renewal in Disguise
description: CLIFTON  Botany Vil lage here is chic shops, vest pocket parks, a shoppers' walk sheltered by an im mense canopy, good restau rants, landscaped parking lots  and renovated four room apartments at $135 a month.

title: INSTITUTE TO SCAN JEWS' PROBLEMS
description: HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Dec. 2 An institute devoted to ana lyzing and solving the problems of Jewish communities through out the world has been estab lished by the American Jewish Committee, a human relations agency.

title: D. Z. Hayes Weds Miss Pacheco Marques
description: Miss Martha Pacheco Mar ques, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sebastiao Pacheco Mar ques of Rio de Janeiro, was married here yesterday after noon to Dennis Zak Hayes, a New York film producer. He is the son of Mrs. Shirley Hayes, an announcer for the Municipal Broadcasting Sys tem's radio station WNYC, and James Hayes of West port, Conn., a producer with the Grey Advertising Agency. The Rev. Dale Lind, a Lu theran minister, performed the ceremony at the home of the bridegroom's mother.

title: BLACK EXPERIENCE
description: Letters:

title: Anita Marks Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Harold Marks of Riverdale, the Bronx, have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Anita Marjorie Marks, to Robert Alan Greenwald, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leo Greenwald of Flushing, Queens.

title: Son to the W. G. Ruebs
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 2A son was born on Nov. 18 to Mr. and Mrs. William Gerald Rueb of Washington in the George Washington Univer sity Hospital.

title: Opera: Rose of Persia
description: The standard Gilbert and Sullivan repertory is well taken care of here by the Light Opera of Manhattan (continuous) and the Village Light Opera (sporadic). The offbeat works are the pro vince and, one might say, obsession of Frederick S. Roffman. He recorded Ages Ago, in which Gilbert was partnered by the composer Frederick Clay. Last year, he produced a concert version of Sullivan's Haddon Hall, with a libretto by Sydney Grundy. Last spring he re vived The Rose of Persia, another Sullivan score, this time to a book by Captain Basil Hood. On Friday night, he repeated it in Cami Hall, againinconcert form.

title: President Nixon's Trump Cards
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 2I had the illusion, Henry Kissinger said pri vately before leaving for Paris, that maybe we could get through these peace negotiations without heart break, but that was probably expect ing too much. The war has been heartbreaking from the beginning.

title: Letter to the Editor 9  No Title
description: One cannot read of Professor Hug gins's recent visit to the slave castles of West Africa without being deeply moved by this latest reminder of man's long record of inhumanity to man. In the course of his article, Professor Hug gins mentioned all the European peo ples involved in the slave traffic: Danes, Swedes, Frenchmen, Portuguese, Span iards, Britons and, of course, Americans. All the more striking, then, is the omis sion of the Arabs from this catalogue of infamy.

title: The Greening of the Garden
description: Has this become an age of austerity with acres of pam pered plants and wellfed lawns only for the wealthy? Can it be that the lack of the green that is not chlorophyll has now blighted the gardens of America? There is evidence of this in the trend of book titles this season which seems to stress frugalness and sim plicity in gardening.

title: Caroline Small Campbell Married
description: YARMOUTH, Me., Dec. 2 Miss Caroline Small Camp bell and Robert Gibson Knott Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Knott of New York, were married here this afternoon at the home of the bride's mother, Mrs. Robert Camp bell, who also has a home in Tarrytown, N. Y.

title: Court to Hear Sex Complaint
description: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 2 (UPI) Judge John Morgan Davis of Federal District Court has agreed to hear a prison in mate's complaint that seven years without a woman is cruel and unusual punish ment. Judge Davis approved Wednesday a petition by Mac key R. Choice, 44 years old, for a public defender to handle his case in the Federal court.

title: 70 LEFTIST PICKETS BACK KAW AIDA PLAN
description: NEWARK, Dec 2 (AP)  Seventy members of two leftist groups demonstrated today in support of the Kawaida Towers housing project, drawing jeers from a smaller number of the project's opponents.

title: Government in Australia Voted Out After 23 Years
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Sunday, Dec. 3The Australian Labor party ousted the conservative Government of Prime Minister William McMahon by a com fortable majority in national elections yesterday.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: ONCE AGAIN the spending pattern of the American Consumer is being carefully scrutinized in eco nomic circlesnot that it is too lackadaisical but rather because it may become overly exuberant. In the closing weeks of 1972, some high Government officials and others are beginning to proclaim a new theme with a bit of awe and some apprehension. The economy, they say, is even stronger than previously trumpeted and is gaining vigor from rising consumer, business and Government spending. The danger is that the ration could be too enriched.

title: U.N. Study Assails Gap In Arms and Aid Funds
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. Dec. 2 (AP)World arms spending has reached $200 billioon a year, while only $8billion goes to help poor nations, a United Nations study says.

title: Gilt of Storm Windows Helps an Indian Church.
description: CHARLEVOIX, Mich., Dec. 2When parishioners en tered the Greensky Indian Church near here for last Sunday's services, they found an unexpected and warming preChristmas gift, left by a person or persons unknown,

title: Cooking by the Book
description: This last summer and fall, when I was in Europe, I made it a point to go into any book store I came across to look at the cookbooks. I can report that the countries where one eats best, such as Belgium and Switzerland, produce very few of them, and those where one eats poorly, such as Germany and England, produce lots. As in Americathere is a direct relation between the quality of food and that of cookbooks. The first goes down as the sec ond goes up.

title: Princeton Hot Line Is an Answer for Those With Problems
description: PRINCETON  The Hot Line, a community tele phone service introduced here two years ago to help combat drug abuse among young people, is no longer concerned mainly with drugs or, for that matter, exclusively with young people.

title: Please, just a nice place to sit
description: A tough town for shmoozing

title: ERIKSON TO GIVE JEFFERSON TALKS
description: Erik H. Erikson, the psycho analyst and scholar, has been named Jefferson Lecturer in the Humanities for 1973 by the National Endowment for the Humanities.

title: Lebanon to Hire Women For High Police Posts
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 2. (Agence FrancePresse)  Le banon is about to acquire her first women police superintend ents.

title: Indonesia Rice Yield Down; 60 Said to Die of Starvation
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Dec. 2 (AP)Indonesia's rice crop, plagued by drought, is expected to fall about 425,000 tons short of the 12millionton de mand and already about 60 people have reportedly died of starvation.

title: Rivenes Named A.A.U. President
description: KANSAS CITY, Dec. 2 (AP) David G. Rivenes, 60year old Miles City, Mont., televi sion executive, assumed to day the presidency of the Amateur Athletic Union of the United States.

title: Letter to the Editor 11  No Title
description: Letters:

title: BASEBALL HEADS FOR KEY PARLEY
description: HONOLULU, Dec. 2The baseball brass headed for the hills, the islands or home to day after a oneweek conven tion that either changed the face of their game or plunged it toward a devastating strike by the players.

title: East Orange Acts to Avoid Racism Over Housing Proposals
description: EAST ORANGE  Two proposed housing projects here are troubling this pleas ant Essex County community.

title: A SURVEY OF PAPERS IN NEW ENGLAND SET
description: AMHERST, Mass., Dec. 2 (AP)  The Markle Foundation of New York has awarded a $45,252 grant to the University of Massachusetts for a survey and evaluation of 106 New England daily newspapers.

title: A Victory on Schedule
description: SYDNEY, Sunday, Dec, 3 Gough Whitlam led the Labor party to victory yesterday ac cording to a timetable he had set himself. In 1966, when he was a leader of the Labor party in Parliament, he predicted that it would take six years for the party to return to power.

title: Frustrations at the Canton Fair
description: CANTON, China During the Canton Export Com modities Fair, which ended Nov. 15, an American new comer and a French veteran of many previous fairs were discussing at dinner the read ing matter they had brought with them. After the Ameri can said that he was reading Charles Dickens's Bleak House, the Frenchman ex claimed, How right you were not to bring Great Ex pectations.

title: Letter to the Editor 6  No Title
description: Letters:

title: Congress
description: WASHINGTON  President Nixon moved boldly last week to challenge the new Democraticcontrolled Con gress. His stated intent: to slash away at the ambitious antipollution program approved by the last Congress.

title: Celtics Score Game's First 10 Points and Go On to Beat 76ers, 131 to 120.
Antipoverty Program Is Found To Aggravate Ethnic Tensions
description: The city's antipoverty pro grams provided only minimal gains for the poor and even heightened community racial and ethnic conflict, according to a study of how one such program has operated in the Tremont area of the Bronx.

title: Auto Given to School
description: FAIRFIELD, Ohio, Dec. 2 (UPI)One of the three dozen Chevrolet cars abandoned on the General Motors Corporation assembly line for several months during a strike last summer has been given to Fair field High School. The school will use the 1972 Camaro in its vocational education auto mechanics training program.

title: Children's Theater Producer Loves Teaching
description: EAST BRUNSWICK Sit ting in the center of the al most empty auditorium, Elliott Taubenslag was com pletely engrossed in his stu dents as they rehearsed for their December production of Guys and Dolls.

title: 3 Counties Ask an F.P.C. Judge To Drop Out of Blue Ridge Case
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 2At torneys for three counties in North Carolina and Virginia have asked an administrative law judge of the Federal Power Commission to disqualify him self from hearings on a license for the controversial Blue Ridge hydroelectric project on the New River The requests allege prejudice.

title: Are you frightened of freaks?
description: Most players react strongly to freak distributional hands, regarding them as exciting but scary, like monster movies. Average players usually dis like such hands because they do not know how to bid them. What they fail to realize is that the experts are little bet ter off. On a freak science is at a minimum, guesswork and luck at a maximum.

title: Kawaida Towers Issue Is Clouding the Future of a Troubled and Divided Newark
description: NEWARK  The Kawaida Towers housing project is looming larger than its pro posed 16 stories in the po litical life of this racially troubled city.

title: Miss Marotta Engaged
description: ELMONT, L. I., Dec. 2 Mr. and Mrs. Charles C. Ma rotta have announced the en gagement of their daughter, Miss Juliette Marotta, to James J. Russo, son of James Russo of Boston and the late Mrs. Russo. Miss Marotta, whose father is a vice presi dent of the First National City Bank of New York, is a junior at Hofstra University. Her fianc, an electrical con tractor in Boston, is a gradu ate of the Franklin Technical Institute there.

title: White winter ahead
description: Good tidings for dry cleaners

title: Chinese Tell of Creating New Rice or Wheat Strains
description: PEKING, Dec. 2 (Agence FrancePresse)  Chinese geneticists recently discovered a new process that permits the creation of new varieties of wheat or rice, while reducing the time normally required to achieve this, the monthly magazine China Pictorial re ports.

title: MARTIAL LAW JAMS PRISONS IN TURKEY
description: ANKARA, Turkey, Dec. 2 (AP)In 19 months of martial law, the Turkish Government has packed prisons with leftists and sharply limited leftist political activity.

title: V.A. Hospital's Beds Go Begging
description: NORTHPORT, L.I. The new $20million Veterans Ad ministration hospital here has the most advanced medical equipment and is staffed, in part, by faculty members of the School of Medicine of the State University of New York at Stony Brook  yet 100 of its 470 beds go un used every day.

title: AllYearSchool Plan Studied
description: TRENTON A Board of Education member from Mid dlesex County listened at tentively as speakers at Glassboro State College de scribed how well yearround schools worked in their dis tricts.

title: A Look at a BurntOut Case of a Peculiar Sort
description: FIFTEEN years ago, the French artist Andr Masson was a contro versial figure in Amer ican art. In the late fifties, American painting, especially the works of the New York School of Abstract Expres sionists, had become a major influence on the international art scene. One of the hotly debated issues of the time was whether Masson, who had spent several years in America during World War II, had been one of the princi pal inventors of that style. Whether Masson's early au tomatic writing stylede veloped under the in fluence of Surrealismtook precedence over the drip painting method introduced by Jackson Pollock was an issue that gave rise to a good many chauvinistic claims by both French and American critics. But like many burn ing issues in artpolitics, that one burned itself out rather rapidly.

title: Drivers Briefed on New Signs
description: TRENTONThe New Jer sey Division of Motor Ve hicles and the Department of Transportation have begun a program to acquaint motor ists with the international signs now used on the state's roads.

title: Dance
description: KATHERINE DUNHAM the name perhaps means less now than once it didwas a true original of American dance. She had a company, of dancers, singers and musi cians, and they would per form what were in effect big spectacular Broadway revues. I saw the company many times during its first season in London in 1948. It was a show called Caribbean Rhapsody, and it was an as tonishing theatrical mlange.

title: FAMINE IS FEARED IN AFRICAN AREA
description: NIAMEY, Niger, Nov. 21  Look at this millet, Moham med Elban said. Touch it, feel it and you will see why we fear the coming monthswhy we fear a famine.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: Without a Camelot to spur him on, man is no more than a beast of burden, his load made more onerous by a nag ging spirit that sometimes tells him there must be some thing better.

title: Refugee Grant for Zambia
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, Dec. 2 (Agence FrancePresse)The Zambian Government will re ceive a $400,000 grant from the United Nations High Com mission for Refugees. Dr. Hugh Idoyaga, the United Nations representative here, said the money would be spent next year and that improve ments in refugee camp class rooms and teachers' housing were in store. Zambia has an estimated 40,000 political ref ugees, most from South Africa, Rhodesia and Mozambique.

title: Hoffa as prison reformer
description: While he waits to snap the legal chains that bar a return to top rank in the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, James R. Hoffa devotes his attention to try ing to arouse people to the importance of doing some thing fundamental about correcting the hellholes we call correctional institu tions. The best  known alumnus of the Federal pen itentiary in Lewisburg, Pa., has testified before Senate and House committees on the need for recognizing that the bestiality of the existing penal system not only degrades prisoners but also imperils society by sending men out more bit ter, more disturbed and more skilled in crime than when they went in.

title: BREZHNEV BACKS KADAR'S REFORM
description: BUDAPEST, Dec. 2The So viet Union today firmly sup ported Hungary's economic re form policy, a recent target of criticism by orthodox Commu nists in Eastern Europe.

title: HONG KONG KEEPS WATCH ON CHINA
description: HONG KONG, Dec. 2  The Chinawatching role of the big Japanese consulate  general here will not diminish with the opening up of a Japanese em bassy in Peking, scheduled for January.

title: When Will the Black Male Make It in Opera?
description: HAVE you ever seen a black Don Jose or Rodolfo or Tristan? Leontyne Price, for one, has wondered why she hasn't and recently re marked, It just isn't possible that there are not as many distinctive black male voices as female.

title: Rules for the Unruly
description: The first round of negotiations on reform of the world monetary system, which wound up in Washington last week, has confirmed that the task will be long and hard, not only because of conflicting national interests but also because of the excruciating technical complexities involved.

title: Politics, Economics and Skyjacking
description: FIDEL CASTRO and the United States State Department are at last talking, courtesy of the Swiss Embassy in Havana, about a bilateral treaty on air piracy that may provide for extradition of hijackers as well as the return of the planes, pas sengers and ransom money. And in Washington, Federal officials are talk ing about the security measures they have taken and are taking to prevent hijacking. There appears to be more reason for hope in the Havana discus sions than in the Washington talks, and once again the question of what to do about air hijacking appears to come down to economics, politics and money.

title: The Far East (in Fort Lee)
description: FORT LEEIt's a long way from Taiwan to Fort Lee, but Minoru Yamada is a determined man. He speaks slowly in heavily accented English, smiling patiently as his wife, Mitsuko, translates Japanese into English.

title: Nixon ShakeUp For the Team
description: The Nation

title: UNESCO TO SET UP NEW HERITAGE AID
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 2The first systematic effort to protect major features of the world's cultural and nat ural heritage is being planned by the United Nations Educa tional, Scientific and Cultural Organization.

title: New Sounds in Radio Ads
description: There are folks around who feel that the best radio advertising today is being produced by radio people not advertising people. But, then, why not? How many hot shots in agencies want to do anything but television?

title: That First Postwar Season
description: PALM BEACH for me is always associated with a fullpage Helena Rubinstein ad that appeared in the January, 1946, Social Spectator, a copy of which I picked up somewhere on Worth Avenue at a time when I was enjoying an out siderinsider's relationship with the island resort. The ad in question was entitled Triumph Over Time and the reference was to estrogenic hormone cream and oil, the magical or imagi nary properties of which products, especially as administered in Miss Rubinstein's. Worth Avenue salon, guaranteed a high hearted disregard for time. The heroine of the ad was an ex quisitely coiffed and ermined woman whose heart could not have been higher and for whom time had clearly ceased to be a problem. Bemused as I was with the place, I saw her as a sym bolic figure whose real reference was to the island itself. So transposed, the ad ceased to be hyperbolic.

title: AntiSST Block Set to Fight Against Revival of Project
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 (UPI) A coalition of environmental ists that helped kill the super sonic transport plane last year has set up an office on Capitol Hill to lobby against an expect ed Administration attempt to revive the project in the new 93d Congress.

title: Apostle to American Indian Is Cited for Beatification
description: ROME, Dec. 2 (AP)Docu ments on the life and writings of an American bishop who was called the apostle of the Ottawas and Chippewas have reached the Vatican for his pos sible beatification.

title: 2 West Point Heroes Nearly Went to Navy
description: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 2 Bob Hines and Scott Beaty, two of Army's heroes in to day's 2315 victory over Navy, nearly went to Navy four years ago. Each had re ceived appointments to both academies.

title: Sports Pages
description: The literary season in sports this winter is arriving on wheels and ice skates. The heroes drive Ferraris, bodycheck Bobby Orr. negotiate through lawyers for the kind of money best fetched by Ferraris and Orrs. The authors dramatize the man at the wheel, describe how he lives and often dies, instruct us on the slap shot, warn us on the power play. In so many words: auto racing and hockey are leading the league in printed words this Christmastide.

title: Guardsmen Lose Wig Plea
description: COLUMBIA, S. C., Dec. 2 (UPI)A United States District Judge has turned clown a re quest by five National Guards men for an injunction permit ting them to wear wigs to con ceal their long hair during Guard drills. Judge Robert F. Chapman said yesterday that the men had entered the Guard voluntarily to avoid active serv ice at a time when the country was at war. They bought the whole ball game voluntarily, he said. They cannot pick and choose the military regulations they choose to follow.

title: David Litwin, Newark Lawyer And Civil Rights Activist, Dies
description: ORANGE, N. J., Dec. 2  David M. Litwin, a Newark lawyer and member of the State Assembly from 1928 to 1931, died on Thursday at Newark Beth Israel Medical Center. He was 76 years old and lived at 235 Austen Road.

title: MOSCOW HONORS CAUCASUS TRIBES
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 2  The Soviet Union has just marked the 50th anniversary of the autonomy of two ethnic groups in the Caucasus Mountains that were among the country's non peoples not so long ago.

title: Waiting for the Pretty Girls
description: ASOLEMNLY frisky, coolly surreal enter tainment known as Dr. Selavy's Magic Thea ter exercises such initial au thority over its audience that it is a pity its selfpossession is not put to sturdier use.

title: A.D. Makes 1972 Good Year for U S. C.
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 2 Anthony Davis is the great est I've ever seen on kick off returns in college, Ara Parsegian, Notre Dame's coach, said today after the Southern California sopho more had run back kicks for touchdowns of 97 and 96 yards and scored four oth er times against the Irish.

title: Amnesty Unit Makes Appeal On 200,000 Held by Saigon
description: LONDON, Dec. 2 (AP)Am nesty International says that it has told President Nixon and Premier Pham Van Dong of North Vietnam it is concerned about safeguards to be pro vided for 200.000 civilians held in South Vietnam when the war ends.

title: Saigon Expects CeaseFire Pact in Week With a Formal Signature About Dec. 15
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 2Henry A. Kissinger and Le Duc Tho are expected to ar rive at a final negotiated peace settlement, substantially along the lines disclosed in October, after two or three days of talks in Paris next week, ac cording to informed South Viet namese sources close to the ne gotiations.

title: Headliners
description: For the Cassandras of the world, (left, a ver sion of the original), the Shreveport, La., City Coun cil last week provided a glimpse of man's distant futureperhaps as distant as 1984. Concerned over a local Population Explosion, the council took the first step toward passing an ordinance that would, among other things, keep females with amorous intent at home and levy fines on families that got too big. Of course, the females are canines, and the family limit (24 births a year) applies to dogs and cats. But it gave many a citizen pause.

title: A.H.S.A. Tightening Program On Drugging of Show Horses
description: A drug long known to be harmfuland in some cases fatalto horses recently has been found in some mounts competing in the show ring.

title: Grants Made for News Fellowships at Two Colleges
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 (AP) Grants to the University of Michigan and Stanford Univer sity to establish fellowship pro grams for professional journal ists were announced this week by Ronald S. Berman, chairman of the National Endowment for the Humanities.

title: DEATHS OF REFUGEES REPORTED IN ZAMBIA
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, Dec. 2 (AP)Nine Jehovah's Witnesses from Malawi are dying every day in the teeming Sinda Misale refugee camp near the Zambia Malawi frontier, a Zambian Cabinet member reports. Nine teen thousand members of the sect are estimated to have fled to the Zambian camp since Dr. Kamuzu Banda, the President of Malawi, ordered a nation wide crackdown on the out lawed sect two months ago.

title: Nastase Defeats Smith, 63, 62, 36, 26, 63, in Masters Tennis Final
description: BARCELONA, Spain, Sunday, Dec. 3 (AP)Ilie Nastase of Rumania defeated Stan Smith of Sea Pines, S. C., 63, 62, 36, 26, 63, early this morn ing and won the Masters ten nis tournament for the second straight year.

title: City Consumer Unit Plans to Introduce 26 Bills in Albany
description: Druggists would have to post prescription prices publicly and automobile, television and ap pliance repairmen would need city licenses, under a package of consumer legislation the Lindsay administration will in troduce in Albany.

title: Maine Plans Center To Watch Wildlife From Salt Marshes
description: SCARBOROUGH, Me., Dec. 2 A nature center will be opened here next spring in the Scarborough Marshes, which supply a resting area for mi grating shorebirds and a tem porary home for American egrets, glossy ibis and snowy owls in season.

title: Bay State Deer Season
description: BOSTON, Dec. 2 (AP)The Massachusetts deer hunting season will open Monday at 6:30 A.M. for all antlered deer. Anterless deer may be hunted only by holders of special per mits, the state said.

title: BRITISH EMIGRANTS EXCEED IMMIGRANTS
description: LONDON, Dec. 2 (Reuters) More people have left Britain in recent years than have ar rived as immigrants, a Govern ment report has disclosed.

title: Deborah Weil Sets Nuptials
description: MOUNT KISCO, N. Y., Dec. 2Miss Deborah Well and Samuel Parker Harrington, who were graduated from the Milton (Mass.) Academy, will be married in February. Their engagement has been made known by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Frank A. Well of New York.

title: Gleason Wins a 14th Term As Head of Longshoremen
description: Thomas W. Gleason, presi dent of the International Long shoremen's Association, was elected last night to his 14th threeyear term.

title: Meskill Maps a Conservative Program
description: HARTFORD, Dec. 2With a Republicancontrolled and presumably cooperative Gen eral Assembly to work with, Gov. Thomas J. Meskill says he expects in the next two years to see enacted such leg islation as a widened and newly defined death penalty, mandatory jail terms for first offenses of drunken driving and less cumbersome wiretap laws.

title: Arrabal's Theater of Panic:
description: PARIS: One of the curiosities of avantgarde theater is that while more and more is written about it, there is actually less output than there was 50 years ago. Also, the emphasis has shifted. Today, a discussion of the theatrical avantgarde must concern itself with ensembles and directors rather than playwrights. The avantgarde leaders of the midfifties, Beckett, Ionesco, Genet, Pinter, Albee, are today settled into a cultural mainstream which is amazingly unruffled by newer tributaries. In England, despite a rash of under30 playwrights, I can think of only oneHeathcote Williamswho would be properly classified as avantgarde. In Germany, there are Peter Handke and Rainer Fass binder. In America, an avantgarde writer is more often than not, a young man still working off the influences of Beckett or Genet, but in most cases, the more interesting new writers (John Guare, Israel Horovitz, Jason Miller) are traditionally, rather than experimentally, based.

title: Miss Susan B. Lester Engaged
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Dec. 2Miss Susan B. Lester and William B. Hauser plan to be married in May. Miss Lester is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James S. Lester of Greenwich and her fianc is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip M. Hauser of Chicago.

title: Lone Foe Of APlant Withdraws From Case
Torch Rites Mark Hanukkah
description: ENGLEWOODTwo torch relays in Bergen County to day will be part of the com munity celebrations marking the eightday Jewish holiday of Hanukkah, which ends Friday.

title: 12 Youths in Paris Disrupt ProArab Youth Conference
description: PARIS, Dec. 2 (Reuters)A dozen masked and armed youths burst today into an in ternational proArab conference sponsored by European and Arab youths here today, smash ed translation equipment and injured delegates.

title: Don't Pooh What They Did to Winnie
description: Movies

description: Music

title: CARL HAESSLER, LABOR WRITER, 84
description: DETROIT, Dec. 2Carl Haes sler, a labor newsman and old line socialist whose writings en couraged sitdown, strikers in the worker turbulence of the 1930's, died yesterday. He was 84 years old.

title: Express Subway In Paris Is Fast, But Impersonal
description: PARIS, Dec. 2At the Auber station of the Rseau Express Rgional of the Paris subway, there are seven levels, three miles of corridors, 73 escalators, 15 elevators, and a control center in a plastic bubble that looks like the space capsule.

title: 29 Rescued Off Philippines
description: MANILA, Dec. 2 (AP)Two big United States Air Force helicopters picked up 29 per sons from two lifeboats on heavy seas some 540 miles northeast of Manila today after their commercial vessel sank, a Clark Air Base spokesman re ported.

description: SMALL events have changed the course of history. Would you be lieve that a butterfly led to major changes in world horticulture and to the art of glass gardens?

title: L. I. Team Awaits More Bits of Moon
description: STONY BROOK, L. I. While preparations are being completed in Florida for the Apollo 17 blastoff Wednesday, Long Island geologists who have been studying the rocks brought back from previous Apollo flights are eagerly an ticipating the mission's return.

title: L.I.R.R. Talks Resumed, But No Progress Is Made
description: After meeting for several hours without any announced progress, the negotiators in the stalemated Long Island Rail Road strike talks recessed their negotiations last evening until this afternoon.

title: $25.5 Million Coast Speedway Can't Pay Rent
description: ONTARIO, Calif., Dec. 2 (AP)Ontario Motor Speed way opened with fanfare as beautiful $25.5million racing plant three years ago, but to day can't pay the rent.

description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Dec. 2A young Protestant housewife was shot in the kitchen of her home tonight in East Belfast, and died later in a hospital.

description: Everyone associated with Fight for Sight, Inc., of 41 West 57th Street, New York City, was distressed by an advertisement in The Times on Nov. 19.

Gardens
description: A WHOLE new concept of indoor gardening has developed from the re alization that if plants are to flovrish as they did for grandmother, different meth ods must be used to fit mod em homes and city living. Consequently, the trend of growing under fluorescent lights, terrarium gardens and the increasing need for mini ature plants to fit into these limited quarters.

description: Not since Peter Pan, the pirates and the uneasy band of Indians chased each other in circles around the Never Never Land had there been a scenario quite like it. Last week fe male antichauvinist authoreditor Midge Decter went after the women's libbers, who have been after her with a vengeance since publication of The New Chastity and Other Arguments Against Women's Liberation. Mean while, a growing rhetorical backlash from the male element threatened to gum up equalityinhiring programs on college campuses, and maternity

title: T.V.A. COMPLETING A POLLUTION GAUGE
description: CUMBERLAND CITY, Tenn., Dec, 2The new $390million Cumberland Steam Plant, larg est coalfired facility of the Tennessee Valley Authority, is completing the installation of an environmental monitoring system that will be a model for others.

title: And a Partridge in a Pear Tree
description: Every Christmas needs a beautiful holiday book, and Brian Wildsmith's THE TWELVE DAYS OF CHRIST MAS (Watts, $3.95) is the Beautiful Christmas Book for this season. In spite of the fact that his style is so familiar (has, in fact, spawned a whole school of illustration), Wild smith's paintings with their geometric designs and brilliant patchworked colors remain unique; his treatment of his subject is continually surpris ing and original. The song begins almost comically with the partridge staring quizzically out at the world from inside a large pear to which a kind of trunk has been added. As the days and presents and verses pile up, the momentum of the paint ings increases until the 12 lords a leaping seem to have enough energy to remain suspended indefinitely. The text is wrapped between eight pages of giantsized Christmas tree ornaments; and the impression over all is of having been invited to a gallery for a special Christmas ex hibition.

description: Television

title: Seattle Has Soviet Sister
description: SEATTLE, Dec. 2 (UPI) Mayor Wes Uhlman announced this week that Seattle had be come the first United States city to develop a sistercity relationship with a community in the Soviet Union. He said a formal agreement would be signed next year with Tash kent.

description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 2  As far as state, local and research officials are con cerned, Los Angeles will defi nitely fail to meet the Federal air quality standards required by 1975.

description: TOKYO, Dec. 2 (Reuters) The Tokyo metropolitan gov ernment reports that a majority of Tokyo residents oppose the continued presence of United States military bases in the area.

title: Nepal Will Get Chinese Aid On Road and Irrigation Jobs
description: KATMANDU, Nepal, Dec, 2 (Agence FrancePresse)China will assist Nepal with a number of highway and irrigation proj ects, Premier Kirti Nidhi Bista said on his return from a two week visit to China.

description: It was very cold Thurs day night and the dozen or so carmen and mechanics who stood outside a repair shop of the Long Island Rail Road in Jamaica, Queens, made a brave show of putting up with the elements. But then the cold was joined by a driving rain and the men felt bitter.

title: A. F. Fleitas 2d, Julienne Hogan Are Wed Here

description: The independence of a company's public account ants, in appearances as well as in fact, is essential to the credibility of corporate fi nancial reporting.

They have been fighting to prevent obstruc tion of a unique view of the gothic Cathedral of Bourges, one of the world's finest, by a new building.

description: OLD WESTBURY, L. I. Dec. 2New York Tech rallied from a 6point halftime deficit to defeat State University of Old Westbury, 8362, tonight. Hil ton Armstrong had 24 points for Tech.

description: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 2 (AP) Jack Lieberman's Miss Jo anna came from off the pace to capture the $28,050 Villager Stakes by four lengths today at Liberty Bell.

description: State and city govern ments are in better financial shape today than at any time since World War II, and this week they will get a $2.65 billion revenuesharing hand out from the Federal Gov ernment, which isn't all that flush with money itself.

title: Travel Notes: Will Preclearance Prevail?
description: MAY 15 is a date of great interest to airlines, the Customs Bureau and many air travelers. On that date, if active lobbying now under way in Congress has had no effect, the 20year experiment of preclearance will come to an end.

title: Brandt Partners Lose Seat
description: BONN, Dec. 2 (AP)A re count of the Nov. 19 elections, as required by law, has reduced Chancellor Willy Brandt's ma jority by one seat, it was an nounced today. The Federal, Election Office announced that the recount had given the Free Democrats the junior coalition partner 41 seats, one fewer than in the preliminary vote count. Brandt's Social Demo crats' total was unchanged. giving the coalition 271. Under the recount, the opposition Christian Democrats picked up a seat to make their total 177.

title: Eric Herz Makes His Recital Debut In Role of Flutist
description: Breathless is an adjective more appropriately associated with freshfaced ingnues than flute, playes. Eric Herz, who made his New York recital debut in the latter capacity Friday night at Carnegie Recital Hall, would seem to be a con scientious and sensitive artist. But his contributions to works for flute and harpsichord by Marcello, Boismortier, Bach and Telemann proved consistently small scaled, breathy and, in fast movements, harried.

title: $65,000 Holdup in Mexico
description: MEXICO CITY, Dec. 2 (Reu ters)Six masked men and a woman armed with submachine guns held up the office of the Americanowned Sunbeam elec tric appliance factory here to day and escaped with the equivalent of $65,000, the police said. The raiders reportedly described themselves as a left wing guerrilla squad and said they needed the money to carry on the struggle.

title: YOUNG POLES FACE COMPULSORY WORK
description: WARSAW, Dec. 2 (Reuters) The Polish Communist Party has publicly called for compul sory work for idle young people to combat demoralization and depravity.

title: Camp Life Is Easy For All But the Owner
description: FOSTER, R.I.A stroller from, say, Mars or Albania might have wondered what all the hundreds of people were doing out here in the wilds of western Rhode Island last summer, sitting out in a clearing in the woods on folding aluminum chairs, surrounded by electric stoves, refrigerators, radios, television sets, lamps, hair dryers, cheesesandwich grills, waffle irons and toasters.

description: There was a time, not too long ago, when suburban home owners would brag proudly about the doityourself proj ects they had completed when ever they could find someone to listen. They would eagerly describe the new floor cover ing they had put down, the room that had been freshly painted, the wood panels they had recently installed, or the finished basement that was be ing laboriously completed aft er months of sparetime effort.

description: PARIS  It may still be a long time before Europe gets a single currency, but 33 countries of the Continent all the major nations except the Soviet Union, East Ger many and Poland  are be ing linked in a common check system.

description: PARIS, Dec. 2 (UPI)The first player strike in French soccer history was called to day by the Union of Profes sional Footballers.

description: NEWARKA drugabuse prevention program, now in its second year, is showing positive results in the New ark schools, according to Mrs. Patricia Joyner, drug coordi nator for the Newark Board of Education.

description: MAHWAHZoning ordi nances are under attack throughout New Jersey, but nowhere is the assault more concerted and more aggres sive than in this north Ber gen community. It seeks to attract industry while enact ing restrictive housing regu lations that keep out the plants' workers.

title: U.S.C. Unanimous Pick For MacArthur Bowl
description: Southern California, which completed an undefeated and untied regular season yester day, was the unanimous choice of the National Foot ball Foundation Awards Com mittee as the 1972 recipient of the MacArthur Bowl. Dick Kazmaier, the chairman of the committee, made the an nouncement immediately aft er U.S.C. routed Notre Dame, 4523.

title: JOSE LIMON DIES; DANCE PIONEER, 64
description: FLEMINGTON, N. J., Dec. 2 Jos Arcadia Limn, concert dancer and choreographer, died tonight at Hunterdon Medical Center after a brief illness. He was 64 years old and resided in nearby Stockton.

title: HURRICANE SEASON AT A 42YEAR LOW
description: MIAMI, Dec. 2 (AP)  A combination of mysterious weather conditions made the 1972 hurricane season, which ended Thursday, the quietest in 42 years, says the director of the National Hurricane Cen ter.

title: Trudeau in London
description: LONDON, Dec. 2 (Reuters)  Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau of Canada arrived to day for talks on Canada's trade with Britain.

title: Pieta
description: Four centuries ago, the young sculp tor worked into the open left palm of the marble Madonna a oneletter signatureM for Michelangelo. But it was not until last week that the world learned of the masterartist's modest monogram, which so ingenious ly follows the natural marks of the skin lines of his famed Piet group.

title: B'klyn Cathedral Is Made Official
description: St. James procathedral, which is celebrating its 150th anniversary, has been redes ignated as a cathedral by the Bishop Francis J. Mu gavero after more than a hundred years as a Pro (meaning in place of) cathedral for the Roman Catholic diocese of Brooklyn.

title: New Products
description: APORTABLE pumping system with its own builtin motor should prove useful to many homeowners and doityour selfers. Consisting of a com pact but powerful 115volt motor and pump, the unit in cludes a sevenfoot inlet hose with standard garden hose fittings and an accessory called a Puddle Gulper. This is a flat bottom suction at tachment with a builtin strainer that can be used for pumping out flooded base ments and similar areas down to the last few drops. The attachment can also be dropped into a lake or pond to strain the water when nec essary to draw water from these sources.

title: Princeton Whistles Melodies That Stand the Test of Time
description: PRINCETONIf you listen closely, the tune being whistled by the man who just passed you on Nassau Street may well be Mozart, instead of the latest pop hit.

title: Saints Are Inoffensive

title: DISTRICTS DRAM BY COUNCIL UNIT
description: The expanded 43member City Council, which will be elected next November, is ex pected to include two new blacks and two Puerto Ricans, according to a reapportion ment plan worked out by a special Council committee.

title: Nicklaus Has 67 for 203 And Leads by Two Shots
description: LAKE BUENA VISTA, Fla., Dec. 2With one round to go to complete his most significant year on the pro golf circuit, Jack Nicklaus led the $150,000 Walt Disney open tourney to day by two strokes with a 54 hole aggregate of 203.

title: Woman Is Sheriff, But Her Husband Wears the Guns
description: HENNEPIN, Ill., Dec. 2 (UPI) During two years in office, the Sheriff of Putnam County has never made an arrest or carried a gun.

title: Ireland

The Parliament struggled in crisis, the fate of the Government hung in the balance, and then, late Friday night, the city rocked with explosions that killed two people and injured more than 100.

title: Eddie Albert's Boy and How He Grew

title: Job Aid for Disabled in Essex

title: The House of More Money

title: Much Ado About Waterston
description: SAM WATERSTON is long and angular, with a shock of brown hair, and amused dark eyes. He is wearing a gray sweatshirt streaked by bleach, and fancy tennis sneakers, and the living room of his subleased West Side apartment is full of green plants and clutter. There's a high draftsman's table piled with papers over by the windows, and above it hangs a cork bulletin board to which is pinned a picture of a pret ty model, and a notice of a Vedanta Society meeting.

title: Carolina Policeman Slain
description: ROWLAND, N.C., Dec. 2 (UPI)A rookie North Caro lina highway patrolman was slain, apparently with his own service revolver, after stopping a car five miles west of here today. L.T. Walton, 25 years old, a native of Holly Ridge, was shot at least three times, including once in the head, the police said.

title: The Last Transaction
description: HONOLULU, Dec. 2 (UN) The 20th transaction was con cluded today when Rich Reese, a first basemanoutfielder, was purchased from the Minnesota Twins by the Detroit Tigers and sent to Toledo of the Inter national League.

title: Son for Mrs. Brenner
description: A son was born to Mr. and Mrs. David K. Brenner of New York at Doctors Hospi tal Nov. 14. The child has been named John Leonard. Mrs. Brenner is the former Miss Cynthia Jo Harris of Baldwin, L. I.

title: Marjoe? Maybe
description: MARJOE: Bad But Not Evil (Chelsea CHE 1005). It's not unu sual for a film star to make pop records, but Marjoe has got to be unique. From his improbable evan gellcal career to national prominence in a docusmen tary film expos of himself, and now on to his first out ing as a pop singer, every step in this man's public life has been carefully planned to build on what's come be fore. His new album, taste lessly but predictably, makes much of his exmanofGod status, including only two songs that do not have some spiritual or quasiauto biographical axe to grind.

title: HEARING STUDIES HOUSING CONFLICT
description: Conflicts perennially arise be cause of residential commu nity's concern for housing on the one hand and, on the other, the need of health and educa tional institutions to expand in landscarce Manhattan. New legal approaches to help resolve these conflicts were explored at a legislative hearing here last week.

title: Susan Irwin Bride Of Richard Sachs
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 Miss Susan Forsythe Irwin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas B. Irwin of Old Lyme, Conn., was married here this evening to Richard Charles Sachs, son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving H. Sachs of Yardley, Pa., and Belgrade Lakes, Me. The Rev. Joseph Rainey, a Methodist minister and a chaplain of the Amer ican University, performed the ceremony in the univer sity's Kay Spiritual Life Cen ter.

title: Larry Zimmer to Wed Jennifer L. Riley
description: GARDEN CITY, L. I., Dec. 2Mrs. William Joseph Riley Jr. has announced the en gagement of her daughter, Miss Jennifer Lavington Riley, to Larry Robert Zim mer. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Arnold Robert Zimmer of Bloomington, Ill. A wed ding next May is planned.

title: Isn't It Time We Put the Children First?
description: WHEN we consider alternative methods of financing children's television, it is important to keep in mind where the money is coming from now. We and our chil dren are supplying it.

title: Suzanne Portello to Be Bride in June
description: SAN BERNARDINO, Calif., Dec. 2Mrs. Ruth H. Por tello has announced the en gagement of her daughter, Miss Suzanne Portello, to Vincent Francis Scotto, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank V. Scotto of Brooklyn, New York.

title: Sable Seeks a Law To Bar Group Libel Of Religion, Race
description: The State Commissioner of Human Rights, Jack M. Sable, plans to propose a group libel law to protect racial, religious and ethnic groups from defama tion.

title: Britain
description: LONDON In 1961, hundreds of babies were born in Britain with ter rible deformitieslacking arms, legs, shoulder bones. Their mothers had taken a supposedly harmless tranquil izer called thalidomide.

title: Designing America
description: In none of the arts, wrote Con stance Rourke, has our fun native inheritance been clarified. It has been our misfortune to create brief ly, hastily, insecurely, and then to press on to some new and not al ways understood objective, with the result that the arts in this country have shown many brave beginnings and few developments, and even these have often been casually bur ied and are to be found now only by excavation, like the artifacts of a forgotten city.

title: Cape May Ferry Raises Fares, Trims Jib
description: CAPE MAYThe ferryboat system linking Cape May and Lewes, Del., has been operat ing at a deficit since it be gan in 1964. In fact, it is doing only half the business projected by engineers of the Delaware River and Bay Au thority, which runs the serv ice.

title: Cope to Play a Benefit in Newark
description: NEWARK  Stardust on loan from Broadway will sparkle on Broad Street here Tuesday evening in an effort to raise social consciousness in this racially tense city as well as funds for the Greater Newark Urban Coalition.

title: Baltimore to Bid Unitas Adieu Today
description: The fans of the Baltimore Coltsas rabid and loyal as any audience can bewill have a chance to say good by to John Unitas today al though it is difficult to de termine how they will make their feelings known. The Colts meet Buffalo in their final home game, but Unitas,

title: Letters to the Editor
description: I am appalled that Mrs. E. H. Roberts [Letters, Nov. 19] feels that she can speak for most married women who work. She seems to feel that banks are correct in as suming that women are irre sponsible and, having once assumed a debt, will relin quish responsibility at will. Yet even according to her reasoning, a woman would continue to work until a mortgage was paid off, if necessary.

title: DANGER SIGNALS
description: If Broadway theater prices are a major cause of shrink ing audiences, then Off Broadway is ignoring these danger signals with a reck less unconcern. While I have been able to buy a $4 or even a $3 seat in a Broadway house, the lowest price Off Broadway is generally $5.50.

title: Council to Discuss Massage Parlors In Public Hearing
description: Legislation aimed at driving socalled massage parlors out of the cityparticularly in the Times Square areawill be taken up at a City Council com mittee hearing tomorrow.

title: AROUND THE Garden
description: Protect rosebushes with a six to eightinch mound of soil from another part of the garden Mulch peren nials Oil tools Clean, oil, and store the lawn mower Make holiday trimmings.

title: Superior New Left?
description: Prof. R. E. Miller [letter Nov. 26] in reply to your Nov. 12 editorial on Mr. Nixon's interview suggests that national paternalism is concomitant with our present Government's modus operandi. I think he has mis takenly labeled this trend as a cause.

title: Sentenced to Clean Cars
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Dec. 2 (AP)Michael Hair, 17 years old, is to spend the next eight Saturdays scrubbing, wax ing and cleaning police cars. The youth was ordered yester day to take care of the cars by Court of Record Judge W. Clayton Johnson after being found guilty on a charge of stealing a motorcycle.

title: Bormann
description: Is Martin Bormann alive in South America, or isn't he? That was the speculation all last week as The Daily Express of London published a series of articles on the latest story about Adolf Hitler's wartime deputy.

title: Mental Patients
description: Over a period of months, the young child has seen his mother lapse again and again into apathetic silences. He watches her sit for hours, staring blankly at a wall; finally, she be comes totally silent, refusing even to eat. An ambulance draws up to the door, and mother is taken away to the hospital.

title: Katzenbach
description: On Nov. 12, The New York Times Business and Finance Section carried a long article about persons who have left high public offices, military and civilian, for posts in the private sector  posts in which, so the article suggests, they are expected to trade on their connections with friends still wielding official author ity in Washington.

title: From Rural Greece to the Cities of Middle America
description: THERE are two ways to photograph Greece: in color, and in back and white. Color is best for the modern holiday maker's Greece of swimming, sunning, scenemaking, and maybe, one afternoon, when there is nothing better to do, a bit of exploring of the sun baked rubble that passes for classical antiquity. In fact, the holiday maker's Greece, with its neverfailing sum mer sunlight, its quaint little whitewashed townscapes, its orange islands and indigo seas, is the perfect subject for color photography, and if it did not exist, it would hive to be invented, like Disney land.

title: ROBERT C. LEFORT
description: EAST HAMPTON, L. I., Dec. 2Robert Collet LeFort, who retired as vice president of Greeff Fabrics, Inc., in 1970, died at his home here yester day. He was 66 years old.

title: State Offers Special Sale on Trees and Bushes
description: RIDGE, L. I.The State Department of Environmen tal Conservation is making an offer to Long Island homeowners that it hopes few will want to refuse. The offer consists of bargain priced trees and shrubs espe cially adapted to the island's generally inhospitable soil.

title: CITY PLANS A RISE IN CAPITAL BUDGET
description: A record $2.607billion cap ital budget was proposed for the city next year as the City Planning Commission dramati cally altered its outlook from the crisis warning of a year ago.

title: EDMUND J. DAVIS
description: YONKERS, Dec. 2Edmund J. Davis, a realestate man here for 45 years, died today at the Yonkers Professional Hospital. He was 82 years old and lived at 217 Valentine Lane.

title: Sex Discrimination Charged To Coast Antipoverty Group
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 2 (UPI)The organization for the Federal campaign against poverty, one purpose of which is to eliminate job discrimina tion, is sexist, according to the National Organization for Wo men (NOW).

title: Views of the Review
description: Whether I am in agreement or disagreement with the con tent of Robert Reinhold's ar ticle, The Popkin Casean Ominous Chill, in The Week in Review, Nov. 26, is not the purpose of this letter. My attention was caught by the opening sentence: Manacled, wrapped in chains, Professor Samuel L. Popkin of Harvard was led off to prison.

title: Enter the Poor Millionaire
description: TO the close observer it is clear that economic democracy is encroaching upon Palm Beach. The small, or poor, mil lionaire now enjoys the rights and privileges once monop olized by the big, or rich, millionaire. As one old resident remarked, The hoi is more polloi than it ever was.

title: A Radical Rabbi Turns to Farming
description: JACKSON TOWNSHIP  Rabbi Philip Schechter, who is alive and well and administering his brand of freeform Judaism in near by Englishtown, Westport, Conn., and Tappan, N.Y., re cently purchased a farm here.

title: Miss Royer Plans to Be Wed
description: WESTFIELD, N. J., Dec. 2 Miss Rebecca Louise Royer and Peter Neal Michaelson will be married here on Jan. 6.

title: Fire on Penn Central Delays Passengers to New Haven
description: NORWALK, Conn., Dec. 2 A fire that started last night on a Penn Central commuter train bound for New Haven moments after the train stopped here shortly after 7 P.M. halted traffic on the eastbound tracks for nearly an hour.

title: Issues in the L. I. R. R. Dispute
description: PARTICIPANTSThe Long Island Rail Road and 12 unions representing 5,000 carmen, teamsters, clerks, elec trical workers, sheet metal workers and other nonoperating employes, as well as some supervisors.

title: NADER STUDY FINDS AEROSOLCAN PERIL
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 (AP)  A Ralph Nader group ac cused the makers of aerosol cans today of creating explosive devices and urged that Fed eral law provide triple dam ages for victims of the bursting containers.

title: The Fallen Astronaut
description: Among the artifacts of man left on the moon is a tiny aluminum statue called the Fallen Astronaut, which lies in the dust near Hadley Rille. The smooth, abstract figure was placed in a small crater on Aug. 2, 1971, together with a plaque, as a small memorial to the 14 astronauts and cosmo nauts who have been killed. Ironically, now seems a symbol of what has happened to the men who took it there, the crew of Apollo 15.

title: Artichoke's Taste Effects Confirmed by a Scientist
description: Dr. Linda Bartoshuk, a Yale University psychologist, has scientifically confirmed what many laymen have observed: that some beverages taste sweet after one has eaten artichokes.

title: Combining Business With Breakfast
description: There's a senior vice presi dent of the First National City Bank who doesn't deny exporting it to Japan. One of his counterparts at the Chase Manhattan Bank has been credited (and blamed) for sowing it in the City of Lon don. Some of those who trained under John A. Blum when he was a senior vice president of Macy's insist that he made the useful (or damnable) practice germinate in New York.

title: More Flood Funds Urged
description: WILKESBARRE, Pa., Dec. 2 (AP)A total of $1.6million for 11 more renewal projects in the flooddevastated north eastern Pennsylvania region has been advanced by the United States Department of Housing and Urban Develop ment.

title: Letter to the Editor 8  No Title
description: Letters:

title: Comedown from the moon What has happened to the astronauts
description: HOUSTON: Will you keep a piece of moon for yourself? Neil Armstrong was asked at a gathering of magazine writers prior to the journey that marked man's first lunar landing. It was a beautiful question, thought Norman Mailer, among those pres ent, who wondered whether the astronaut would ever have the desire to steal one of the rocks. In keeping with the clean, patriotic and rather stolid image of the astronaut, Armstrong's answer, as recorded by Mailer, was: At this time, no plans have been made. No, that's not a prerogative we have available to us.

title: Brooklyn Museum Is Toyland
description: The animals march in two by twohorses, giraffes, even peacocks (but no kan garoo). More than 200 of them, carved and painted by hand, line up before a splen did Noah's Ark from 19th century Germany, one of the highlights of the antique toy collection now on view in the lobby of the Brooklyn Museum.

title: Whalers Vanquish Nordiques, 7 to 2, On 4 Early Goals
Monmouth May See Clam Curbs Eased
description: TRENTON  The Mon mouth County shellfish indus try, handicapped by pollution its members estimate has cost them $7million in lost sales since 1960, may get some relief soon.

title: SEX BOOKLET STIRS CATHOLIC DISPUTE
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 2A booklet discussing bith control, abortion and homosexuality, which is being distributed by the student government of Georgetown University, has be come the center of a contro versy between Roman Catholic church officials and advocates of academic freedom for Cath olic educational institutions,

title: Christians' Evangelizing Alarms Jewish Leaders
description: Jewish leaders are express ing alarm over the growing evangelistic efforts of Christian churches.

title: Still, Photography
description: We're still catching up with the art of photography, and so the pub lication of a major book on a rela tively littleknown master is an important event. ANDRE KERTESZ: Sixty Years of Photography, 1912 1972 (Grossman, $19.95), easily the most extraordinary photography book of the year, is such an event.

title: Millions in School Aid Found Unused
description: An audit conducted by the of fice of State Controller Arthur Levitt shows that the city's Board of Education did not use some $34million in state edu cation funds earmarked for pov erty areas in the city during a threeyear period beginning July 1, 1968, and ended June 30, 1971.

title: Welfare Recipient Total Up, But Payment Cost Is Down
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 2  The number of public assistance re cipients increased from June to July while expenditures de creased slightly for the same period, according to figures re leased today by the Depart ment of Health, Education and Welfare.

title: The Leap Into Space
description: The primitive and the space man what could be more obvious, and how can these bedfellows so violently yoked together be a symbol unique for our own age? Was not man at every point on the long corridor of history in slow transition from his savage state? Perhaps, but previous ages had not brought these contraries within their near horizon. They could not be haunted by the image of the space man because their technology, had not come close enough to making his possibility actual.

title: Stacy Elias Engaged To William F. Cohen
description: HARRISON, N. Y., Dec. 2 Mr. and Mrs. Gerald M. Elias have announced the engage ment of their daughter, Miss Stacy Ellen Elias, to William Finaly Cohen, son of Mrs. Alexander Westreich of New York and Irving Cohen of Paterson, N. J.

title: Bengals Favored by 1
description: CINCINNATI, Dec. 2 Al ready assured of at least a breakeven record for the season, the New York Giants begin pursuit of bigger dreams tomorrow when they play the Cincinnati Bengals in the first of three games they don't figure to win.

title: Dance
description: Coming to the end of its season, the Alvin Ailey Dance Theater is still cruising hap pily along, wringing every nuance of feeling from its repertory. On Friday eve ning at the City Center, the company gave a softly poetic performance of The Lark Ascending and a vigorous reading of Mary Lou's Mass.

title: Words and Pictures
