description: Every year, a few ambitious ly conceived art books limp into the office too late for in clusion in a preChristmas roundup, but I doubt that any tardy volumes this year will compete with Peter Tomory's THE LIFE AND ART OF HENRY FUSELI (Praeger, $25) as a model for what a study of an individual artist should be, or with Pierre du Bourguet's EARLY CHRISTIAN ART (Mor rowReynal, $29.95 to Dec. 31, then $35) as an interpretative summary of a major section of art history. They are my per sonal award winners among books other than those on 20th century art (which are rounded up elsewhere) by the measures of excellence applied to all the books mentioned herein de scending order of importance: first, contribution to knowledge and understanding of the sub ject; second, adequate illustra tions; third, general attractive ness and clarity of design, in cluding better than adequate illustrations.

title: L. I. U. Loses Opener, 7775
description: George Washington Uni versity reeled off the last 10 points of the game, including Haviland Harper's gamewin ning layup with 28 seconds to go, and defeated Long Island University, 7775, last night.

title: MARCOS FOSTERS CHARTER DEBATE
description: MANILA, Dec. 2President Ferdinand E. Marcos has ap pealed to Filipino voters to get out and vote next Jan. 15 in a referendum on the nation's proposed new constitution.

title: SPOTLIGHT
description: I.T.T., once basically a communications company, now has one of the world's largest baking operations. Beatrice Foods makes camp ers as well as food. And if your youngster gets a Lionel model train this Christmas, it will be manufactured by General Mills, the makers of Cheerios. The Lionel Cor poration has learned a new game.

title: A Pride of Old Marks New Furniture
description: CHESTER  Artists and writers sign their work, but not many craftsmen sign theirs any more. Herb Seck is one who does, and affixed to the bottom of every major piece of his handcrafted Col onial furniture reproductions a Shaker desk, a bookcase, a trestle table, a Welsh cup boardis his mark: Hand wrought by H. T. Seck Jr. of Stratford House, Route 24, Chester, N. J., for In the blank goes the cus tomer's name.

title: Scientist Tells of Value Of the Apollo Program
description: STONY BROOK, L. I.Dr. Neville Carter, one of the members of the team at State University of New York here that is studying samples of moon rocks, had the following to say about the ultimate value of the Apollo pro gram:

title: Italian Airline Pilots Complain Flight Recorder Is Really a Spy
description: ROME, Dec. 2The strong est trade union of Italian commercial airline pilots has announced that the Govern ment has accepted its de mand to open discussions on the use of the flight recorder, the standard device on air craft that stores operational data.

title: Simplicity
description: No cricket chirps, no katydid rasps at the night. There is no bee hum, no bird song. The early clamor of the crows has subsided to an occasional caw at midday. Jays go about their winter business in silence. The birds at the dooryard feeders are quiet birds, more intent on stoking inner fires than on claiming mates or territory. There is no song for the sheer joy of singing.

title: The Johnson Fund Is Widening Vistas
description: PRINCETON  It's amaz ing how much more attention people pay to what I say when I say the same things that I said a year ago, Dr. David E. Rogers, president of the Robert Wood Johnson Foundation, said as he re laxed recently in his com fortable office on the For restal campus of Princeton University.

title: Hudson Guild Here Honors Retiring Executive Director
description: H. Daniel Carpenter, who will retire this year as executive director of the Hudson Guild, was honored last night at the guild's annual John L. Elliott dinner in the organization's headquarters, 441 West 26th Street.

title: $10,000 Bribe Reported Made to N.F.L. Player
description: Jim Kensil, executive di rector of the National Foot ball League, confirmed yes terday that an attempted bribe of an N.F.L. player last season was being investi gated by the Federal Bureau of Investigation and a Con gressional committee.

title: Wicker to Receive Award Of a Civil Liberties Group
description: Tom Wicker, associate editor and columnist for The New York Times, has been chosen to receive the National Emer gency Civil Liberties Com mittee's annual Torn Paine Award for upholding the prin ciples of the Bill of Rights.

title: McConnell To Direct U.S. Center For Courts
description: TRENTON Edward B. McConnell, who announced Tuesday that he would leave his post as administrative di rector of the New Jer sey Courts on July 1, will become director of the Na tional Center for State Courts.

title: Federal Policy
description: A behindthescenes battle is be ing waged between the executive and legislative branches in Wash ington over future control of Fed eral education policies. The outcome could have serious impact on the kinds of programs and the amounts of aid that flow from Washington to the local classroom level.

title: Christmas Cards by Retarded Sold
description: WOODBRIDGE  Mentally retarded children and adults labor painstakingly in work shops set up throughout the country to teach them the skills they need to get jobs in the outside world. But until nowit has been diffi cult to find something for them to make that can be sold commercially.

title: THE HOPE CHANGES OUTLOOK IN BRAZIL
description: NATAL, Brazil  The Amer ican hospital ship Hope has brought about significant changes in sanitation practices and in concepts of nursing and nutrition during a 10month port call here, according to the Dep uty Governor of the northeast ern state of Rio Grande do Norte.

title: Lag in Reading Scores Blamed On Teachers and Establishment
description: Prof. Kenneth B. Clark, a member of the State Board of Regents, last week put the blame for declining reading scores among the city's minor itygroup children on teachers who do not teach, unions that block reforms and what he said was the indifference of the state's educational Estab lishment.

title: TAILOR LAW'S USE URGED ON WOMEN
description: SYRACUSE, Dec. 2  Dr. Kurt R. Schmeller, president of Queensborough Community College, told a conference on women and higher education that the quickest way to eli minate sex discrimination in the state's colleges and univer sities was to use the full weight of the Taylor Law.

title: Marijuana
description: If William F. Buckley Jr. favors de criminalizing marijuana use, can the nation be far behind?

title: TRAIN WRECK IS LAID TO A LOCKED WHEEL
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 (UPI) Federal safety experts said today that a train wreck that killed 11 persons and injured 163 others last year was caused by a locked locomotive wheel that slid almost 40 miles before derailing at a switch at Tonti, Ill.

title: Cowboys Activate Back
description: DALLAS, Dec. 2 (UPI)The Dallas Cowboys today activated Mike Montgomery, a running back, from the taxi squad and placed a defensive end, Tody Smith, on the move list. A spokesman for the Cowboys said Smith was in Presby terian Hospital here undergoing tests for mononucleosis.

title: Kissinger, Due in Paris, Sees President
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 Henry A. Kissinger received his final instructionsand some words of encouragementfrom President Nixon today as he prepared to leave for Paris to morrow for what the Adminis tration hopes will be the con clusive round of negotiations with North Vietnam on an In dochina settlement.

title: Parents Are on Team at Memorial's Day Hospital for Children With Cancer
description: One day last October, Mrs. Jane Smith was told by her son's kindergarten teacher that the normally active 5yearold who likes to climb trees and fight the class bullies had act ed withdrawn that day. He had refused to go outside with his classmates during recess.

title: Theater in New Haven
description: THE city of New Haven, Connecticut, contains no less than two flourishing resident professional theaters. This may not sound like an as tronomical number, but it is really quite impressive for such a small city, even if the small city does contain a large university. Each of the two theaters, moreover, has achieved its own kind of distinction, and the two of them complement each other nicely.

title: The Literary Cocktail Party
description: I can think of three illusions that the general public has about writers. The first is that anyone who has had a book published is automatically rich. Second is that an author has limitless number of copies of his book at his disposal to deal out like a deck of cards to relatives, friends and casual acquaintances. And, third, every time a book is published there's a literary cocktail party thrown for the author, a myth which dis integrates when you consider that there are some 33,000 new books making their bow each year.

title: To the Financial Editor:
description: LETTERS

title: CORNELL BOOTERS TOP HARVARD, 20
description: Cornell upset Harvard, How ard beat Pennsylvania and the University of California, Los Angeles downed San Jose State yesterday and gained the Na tional Collegiate Athletic As sociation soccer semifinals in the Orange Bowl, Dec. 27. The final will be played two days later.

title: METRO MAGIC
description: Letters:

title: Holy Cross Routed By Boston College
Amex Fills In Listed Companies
description: Traditionally, a stock ex change has had a somewhat distant relationship with the companies whose stocks it trades.

title: Rosewall Reaches Final
description: BRISBANE, Australia, Dec. 2, (Reuters)  Ken Rosewall cruised through his Queensland grasscourt men's semifinal watch today, defeating Ross Case, an Australian Davis Cup

title: A Hidden Economy Is Booming in Italy
description: ROME, Dec. 2Isn't the Gov ernment worrying about the combined effects of the unend ing strikes, absenteeism in in dustry and rising unemploy ment? a high official was asked the other day.

title: Why His GodEndures
description: IN the 46 years since it opened, Eugene O'Neill's The Great God Brown has been revived oncein 1959and is about to be revived on Broadway again. It is scheduled to open at the Lyceum next Sunday.

title: Jan Laura Fullgraf Is Betrothed
description: CINCINNATI, Dec. 2Miss Jan Laura Fullgraf, a depart ment manager for the Bloom ingdale's store in Short Hills, N. J., plans to be married here in February to Steven Warner Golann, an assistant vice president with the New York investment house of Halsey, Stuart & Co

title: Japan Camera Show Friday
description: THE 19th Annual New York Japan Camera Show will be held next Friday, Saturday and Sunday at the McAlpin Hotel, Broadway at 34th Street, with a great many leading manu facturers of Japanese cam eras and accessories display ing their newest products some for the first time.

title: World's. Largest Floating Restaurant Deemed No Ship, Merely a Structure
description: HONOLULU, Dec. 2The Coast Guard ruled last week that, whatever it is, the World's Largest Floating Restaurant here is not a ship.

title: Blue Chips Thriving Over 1,000 Altitude
description: The DowJones industrial average showed last week that it is alive and well in the heady atmosphere above 1,000.

title: Green Stamps End Life in Incinerator
description: METUCHEN Have you ever wondered what happens to your books of S. & H. Green Stamps after you re deem them for merchandise? They eventually wind up at the Sperry and Hutchinson Company's plant on Route 27, where they are burned in a smokeless, nonpolluting in cinerator.

title: GERMAN SCIENTIST IS HELD 8 MONTHS
description: HEIDELBERG, West Ger many  Prof. Heinz August Filthuth, a West German nu clear physicist suspected of misappropriating university funds, has entered his ninth month of pretrial detention with scant hope of an early start of proceedings.

title: At Crystal Charity Ball, Even the Texans Outdid Themselves
description: DALLAS, Dec. 2  After the ball was oververy early today in the morning's tini est hours  an exhausted, middleaged, Texas million aire and his wife came limp ing off a down escalator into the spacious lobby of the Fairmont Hotel.

title: Vergil on Peace
description: Letters to the Editor

title: Masters of the Plantation
description: ON the island of Jamaica there is a village called Ducken field, in the coastal township of Golden Grove, and 40 years ago my father left his Vermont farm for a job on a sugar plantation there. He took his family with him, though with reluctance, for the journey was simply one my father's periodic departures from the farm to a salaried, position in the tropics, and he looked upon these spells away from home as a punishment. To be gone from the farm, the low white farmhouse and the dazzling white blossoms of its apple trees in the spring, was, in my father's view, a kind of penance he had to pay for his failure to wrench a living out of Vermont's stingy soil. He took his family with him because lie could not afford to leave us behind; but it is easier, and more satisfying, to do penance alone.

title: DANCE IN DISPUTE IN SOUTH AFRICA
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Af rica, Dec. 2Dancing by whites and blacks together is, at best, a startling novelty in this Country.

title: New Law May Spur ShakeUp in States' Water Pollution Staffs
description: A new Federal law aimed at eliminating conflicts of interest in the regulation of water pol lution may force administra tive shakeups in half the states.

title: A stew with avocados, bananas, cilantro andzucchini
description: The ABC's of puchero Though it was created in the warm climate of Mexico, this puchero (it's stew with a Spanish accent) is an ideal winter main dish for chilly yankees. It combines chicken, ham and chorizo (the delicious spicy sausage now uni versally available in New York's Span ish markets) with a host of fruits and vegetables, from corn to avocado, and fried potatoes and bananas on the side.

title: KARPOV REGAINS TIE IN CHESS TOURNEY
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Dec. 2 (UPI)Anotoly Karpov of the Soviet Union regained a first place tie in the Church's Fried Chicken international chess tournament today with vic tories over Svetozar Gligoric of Yugoslavia and Kenneth Smith of Dallas.

title: Columbia B.C. to Celebrate
description: A dinner to celebrate the 100th anniversary of the Co lumbia Boat Club, the parent organization of Columbia row ing, will be held Wednesday at 6 P.M. at the Columbia Uni versity Club, 4 West 43d Street.

title: Mrs. Fenwick Plans to Be Citizen Advocate in New Job
description: TRENTON New Jersey's newly designated Consumer Affairs Director said last week that she would use her job as one that will clearly be that of an advocate for the state's citizens.

title: William Carver Alden Weds Nancy King Bierce in Vermont
description: NEWFANE, Vt., Dec. 2 The First Congregational Church was the setting here this afternoon for the mar riage of Miss Nancy King Bierce to William Carver Alden of Brookline, son of Mr. and Mrs. Hollis Emery Alden of Worcester, Mass.

title: The Colorful Indians of Peru: in Truth, a Sad Story of Neglect
description: HIGH In the Andes Mountains of Peru, on a bright Sunday after noon, a group of Indians make their way along a narrow, dusty road. Two women, one spinning brightly dyed alpaca wool on a pyramidshaped spool, the other knitting a woolen gar ment, lead the procession.

title: Prof. Popkin and the Issue of Free Inquiry
description: The jailing of Prof. Samuel L. Popkin in manacles for refusing to reveal the names of those with whom he had discussed the Pentagon Papers, though he told the grand jury that he knew nothing of the circumstance of their release, should extend the present chill beyond the community of scholars.

title: Miners to the PollsUnder a Watchful Eye
description: The Nation

title: Miss Alison Scott Plans Marriage
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 2 Col. Norman McLean Scott Jr., Army Medical Corps, and Mrs. Scott have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Alison Joan Scott, to Joseph Edward Hayes, son of Brig. Gen. George J. Hayes, Army Med ical Corps, and Mrs. Hayes of Alexandria, Va. Colonel and Mrs. Scott reside at the Presidio here, where the wed ding is planned for Dec. 30.

title: Maximizing Christmas Sales
description: U.S. BUSINESS ROUNDUP

title: Dublin, A roused by Bombs, Planning I.R.A. Arrests
description: DUBLIN, Dec. 2The Irish Government prepared today for a series of arrests of members of the outlawed Irish Republi can Army following explosions last night that killed two per sons and injured 126.

title: Ship Taking Grain to Soviet
description: HOUSTON, Dec. 2 (AP)  A 65,523ton freighter, the Na tional Defender, sailed from the port of Houston today with the first wheat to be carried in an Americanowned ship in an agreement for the sale of $750 million worth of United Sttaes wheat to the Soviet Union.

title: Public Schools
description: The 1963 Supreme Court decision barring prayer and Bible reading in public schools has created many problems. The ruling has been widely defied.

title: First Amendment
description: Preservation of freedom of speech and of the press, Justice Brandeis once said, is in the special keeping of the [Supreme] Court. Traditionally, it has been the courts that have staved off effortsby legislators and executives, both Federal and stateto abridge these rights.

title: Monetary Rules
description: WASHINGTON  A fresh idea has come to the surface in international economic dis cussions here.

title: KISSINGER TO STAY AS NIXON'S ADVISER ON FOREIGN POLICY
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., Dec. 2 President Nixon announced today that Henry A. Kissinger would continue to serve as his adviser on national security af fairs in the second Nixon Ad ministration and that a num ber of other toplevel White House staff members would also remain in their present jobs.

title: Author? Archie Bunker, No Less
description: It's no secret to millions of fans of All in the Family that Carroll. O'Connor, as its Archie Bunker, has never written anything more impressive than a small check. But in reality O'Connor is something of an author and has sold an original story and screen treatment, The Great Robin son, to producers Philip Waxman and Jerome Minskoff.

title: 50 PERISH IN FIRE IN SEOUL THEATER
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Sun day, Dec. 3The police an nounced this morning that 50 persons were killed and 76 others injured last night when a raging fire swept Seoul's Citizens Hall, a municipal thea ter in the heart of the city.

title: Aesop Revised, or the Luck of the Orthopterae
description: LIFE is imperfect, and the most imperfect thing about it is the incon sistent relationship be tween effort and reward. Peo ple who don't work even half as hard as you do are always getting twice as far. Contrary to Aesop's moral fable, the grasshopper is always win ning. During that long, hot summer while industrious lit tle Johnny Formicida is busy piling up breadcrumbs, Percy Orthoptera gets a tip on the market from a flashy friend over a long, cool drink and is all set for a winter of caviar.

title: Small Claims
description: Law

title: HENRY STREET GETS NEW HEAD OF BOARD
description: Cecil B. Lyon, former United States Ambassador to Chile and Ceylon, has been elected chair man of the board of directors of the Henry Street Settlement, it was announced last week.

title: What's New in the Camera World
description: THE 15th and 16th vol umes in the Life Library of Photography have been released by Time Life Books (distributed by Morgan and Morgan, Inc., 400 Warburton Avenue, Hastings onHudson, New York 10706). The first volume is titled Frontiers of Photography, the second is Travel Photog graphy, and both are priced at $9.95. As with previous editions in this series, both are beautifully illustrated and handsomely put together on slick paper which does maxi mum justice to the illustra tions.

title: Views of the Review
description: I read with great interest the article Sickle Cell: Re sentment Complicates the Case by Harry Schwartz in The Week in Review, Nov. 5. As a black physician and mother I have had personal experience with the whole supermarket mentality sur rounding this new craze to perform genetic screening for sickle cell anemia.

title: Army, U.S.C Win
description: Army rallied to beat Navy, 23 to 15, in the 73d football game between the service academies before a crowd of 95,774 in Philadelphia yes terday. Southern California stayed unbeaten by trouncing Notre Dame, 4523, in Los Angeles. But Alabama was upset by Auburn at Birming ham, 1716, for its first de feat. Details in Section 5.

title: ProMcGovern Union Scores Nixon on Economic Controls
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 (UPI) A major labor union that sup ported Senator Goerge Mc Govern for President says that President Nixon should make his economic controls fair and equitable or drop them altogether.

title: GALLANT FOX WON BY CRAFTY INHALE
description: Autobiography and Crafty Khale engaged in a tense stretch duel in the $56,200 Gal lant Fox Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday. They went across the finish line in that order of the 1mile race, but the result did not stand.

title: Audit by Beame Finds Further Irregularities in Operation of Youth Services Agency Under Gross
description: A man whose previous job was listed as professional bowler was picked to head an organization doing $1.5 million worth of work for the city's Youth Services Agency under former Commissioner Ted Gross, Controller Abraham D. Beame said yesterday.

title: Priest to Head a Task Force
description: The Rev. Mark D. Corrigan, the Boston Roman Catholic priest who is working as New York City's deputy adminis trator, has been appointed chairman of the Urban Action Task force for the Parkchester Westchester area of the Bronx.

title: Tenants and MBR's
description: An examination of the sample owner's MBR used to illustrate the article City Battling Rent Turmoil [Nov. 19] clearly reveals one of the reasons tenants are incensed by the 1970 rent  control amendment:

title: HANOI PLANS WAYS TO HELP VETERANS
description: HANOI, North Vietnam, Dec. 2 (Agence FrancePresse)The North Vietnamese Government has introduced a series of new measures aimed at reintegrat ing war veterans into society, the North Vietnamese press re ports.

title: Community Boards
description: Viva el Boicot! The rallying cry sounded throughout the East Har lem section of New York City last week it not only signaled another massive parent protest against the school system, but it also focused attention on the question: Is decen tralization working?

title: Ellis Island Murals Still Welcoming New Citizens
description: The doors swing wide at the United States Courthouse and Federal Building in the Borough Hall section of Brooklyn Tuesday morning when some 1,200 persons ar rive for the weekly Immigra tion and Naturalization pro ceedings.

title: Letter to the Editor 2  No Title
description: The Popkin case is being muddled by stress on the fact that he is a scholar. The two questions asked him, which he declined to answer, had nothing to do with his scholarship; they were explicitly directed to his nonscholarly activities as a citizen.

title: T.V.A. Plans 9% Increase In Wholesale Power Rates
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Dec. 2 (AP)  The Tennessee Valley Authority has announced that it will raise its wholesale power rates 9 per cent, beginning in January.

title: U.S. Approves Job Safety Proposals Made by Montana and South Carolina
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 2  In what one official called a land mark action, the Department of Labor has formally approved the first two proposals by states to upgrade their job safety laws by bringing them into line with Federal standards under the twoyearold Federal Occupa tional Safety and Health Act.

title: Troubles Beset Man Who Drove Car Into Jet to Block Hijacking
description: ST. LOUIS, Dec. 2To friends and business associates, there wasn't much that set David John Hanley apart from other young men seeking suc cess and financial security.

title: State's Camper Sales Booming
description: FARMINGDALEAsAs great er numbers of outdoor en thusiasts join the ranks of campers, sales of recreational vehicles in New Jersey have boomed.

title: National Urban Fellows Now Seeking Applicants
description: The National Urban Fellows program is now seeking appli cants for the year beginning next July, during which the fellows will study urban affairs briefly at Yale University and then spend 10 months working for high city officials across the country.

title: Workers at Sears Get Ethnic Treats
NEW FRONT SET UP FOR PALESTINIANS
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 2 An organization to provide Pal estinian guerrillas with protec tion and support is to be set up by Arab leftists and Commu nists with the backing of the world Communist movement.

title: Miss Alexandra Wetherill Bride Of John G. Tuten Jr., a Lawyer
description: WHITEMARSH, Pa., Dec. 2Miss Alexandra Wether ill, daughter of Elkins Wether ill, president of the PBW (Philadelphia  Baltimore  Washington) Stock Exchange, Inc., was married here this afternoon to John. Cole Tuten Jr., who is with the Philadel phia law firm of. Montgom ery, McCracken, Walker & Rhoads.

title: American Party Elects
description: DALLAS, Dec. 2 (AP)Tom Anderson, the farm magazine publisher who sought the Vice Presidency on the American party ticket last month, was elected chairman of the party today. Mr. Anderson, of Gat lingburg, Tenn., defeated Wil liam Shearer of Lemon Grove, Calif., for the fouryear post. John G. Schmitz, the party's Presidential candidate, did not seek the chairmanship.

title: LOS ANGELES RACE HAS EARLY LINEUP
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 2With the Presidential election cam paign barely in the past, eager aspirants for Mayor of Los An geles are starting to appear on billboards and TV screens.

title: As a Dancer, an Eagle
description: As a man he was austere, grave and kindly. There was a courtliness to his every gesture, and he moved through the world like a prince. As a dancer he was an eagle. As a choreographer he was extremely gifted and fluent. He was never a par ticularly innovative artist,

title: Five Significant Books of 1972
description: The Children Of Pride

title: McClellan Vote Certified
description: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Dec. 2 (AP)The Secretary of State's office says that Senator John L. McClellan, Democrat of Ar kansas, received more than 60 per cent of the vote in the Nov. 7 general election in his suc cessful bid for a sixth term. The certified vote showed Sen ator McClellan with 386,398 votes to 248,238 votes for the Republican nominee, Wayne Babbitt.

title: PORTUGAL EASES CURBS ON CRITICS
description: LISBON, Nov. 25  The Portuguese Goverment has softened its treatment of politi cal opponents but the reform of penal procedures has had no discernible effect on the atmo sphere here,

title: Mr. Nixon's Pigeonhole Government
description: George P. Shultz has been, almost from its beginning, one of the most able and respected men in the Nixon Administration, but it is still some what surprising to see him so clearly designated as first among the equals in the President's secondterm Cabinet.

title: Letter to the Editor 10  No Title
description: Mr. Krauss's romance with the Paris Metro is bright and clever, but I wonder whether he has chanced to take these trains during rush hours or made the 15minute underground trudges required by some of those darling and convenient correspondences. The picturesqueness about which he rhapsodizes is a good deal less striking at such times.

title: Celler Honored by 1,000 At Brookdale Anniversary
description: More than 1,000 people were present last night in the Amer icana Hotel at the 51st anniver sary dinner of the Brookdale Hospital Medical Center. One of the features of the dinner was a tribute to retiring Rep resentative Emanuel Celler.

title: Criminals At Large
description: Looking over the output of mystery  crime  suspense  es pionage books published since June 4the date of the last semiannual roundup in these pagesit is easy to see where the action is. Most of the best titles come under a category best described as societal. The apparatus of the traditional de tective story might or might not be called into play, but the emphasis is elsewhere: on global issues, on the problem of the individual in a crazy world, on race, on the underprivileged.

title: A New Plan To Combine High School And College
description: A new kind of educational Institution called the mid dle collegecombining the last three years of high school with the first two college yearswill be developed at the La Guardia Community College in Long Island City, Queens.

title: ENTHUSIASTS FILL GARDEN FOR OLDIES
description: An Evening of Solid Gold at Madison Square Garden on Friday evening revived a set of slick musical formulas familiar to anyone who was listening to AM radio in the mid1960's.

title: The Uncannily Talented Miss M
description: SHE is campy but she is not camp. In her act, she toots her way through a swing ver sion of Boogie Woogie Bu gle Boy but she is not one of the professional nostalgia mongerers. When she sings the Shangri Las' Leader of the Pack, she lovingly ar ticulates every one of those biker girl's nasal inflections but she is no mere parodist. Bette Midler is a bona fide original: rock and roll's first electric chanteuse, the first white showwoman of the current pop era.

title: Italians Here Search for Their Identity
description: What does it mean to be an ethnic?

title: Melinda T. Gowell Affianced
description: PITTSBURGH, Dec. 2Mr. and Mrs. John Gowell of Pittsburgh and Wakefield, R. I., have announced the en gagement of their daughter, Miss Melinda Taylor Gowell, to John Michael Rackoff, son of Mr. and Mrs. S. Raymond Rackoff, also of Pittsburgh. A June wedding is planned.

title: JUNGLE FRAUD
description: Letters:

title: China Backs Japan On Disputed Isles
description: PEKING, Dec. 2China to day for the first time took a clear stand behind Japanese territorial demands on four is lands in the southern Kurile group, annexed by the Soviet Union at the end of World War II.

title: Machinist Is Guilty In Plane Hijacking That Killed Three
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 2 (AP)Lubomir Peichev, a 29 yearold Bulgarianborn ma chinist, was convicted today of charges stemming from the July 5 hijacking of a Pacific South west Airlines jet in which a passenger and two hijackers were killed.

title: One Man in the Maze of Justice
description: The complaint room on the fourth floor of the Criminal Court Building in Manhat tan is a drab place with in stitutional yellow cinderblock walls and 88 green, molded plastic chairs.

title: Yankee Stadium; Fifty Years of Drama. By Joseph Durso. Illustrated. 155 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $12.50.
description: Back in the days of small hotels and pianissimo pop music, each American city had its ball park. Although certain basics obtained everywhere dirt, grass and the outfield sign pushing Glooble Beer  each park bespoke a certain individ uality. A man watching a ball game retained a sense of place.

title: Social Announcements
description: Anniversaries

title: Police Act on Rise in Murders
Jane Byrd Sargeant To Wed in January
description: NEWPORT NEWS, Va., Dec. 2The engagement of Miss Jane Byrd Sargeant to Ian Arrison McCurdy, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arrison McCur dy of Cold Spring Harbor, L. I., has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. George Harris Sargeant Jr. of Newport News.

title: WAR FRUSTRATES '64 VIETNAM HERO
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Dec. 2 (AP)The smalltown boy who won the first Medal of Honor in Vietnam looks back with mixed feelings of frustration and achievement as the long est war in American history seems to be drawing to a close.

title: 2 Hemophilic Brothers Get 50 Christmas Gifts
description: Because a private in a New Jersey Army Reserve unit thought it would make a nice Christmas present, 50 of his fellow reservists gave a pint of blood each yesterday to two hemophilic brothers.

title: Letter to the Editor 7  No Title
description: What did we do to you, Mr. Sterba, to deserve such sweeping, scathing criti cism as Worst Airline Service  Qantas? We have always prided our selves on our good inflight service, clean aircraft and courteous crew, and our safety record is second to none. Constructive criticism is always wel come, and I would be glad to receive a specific complaint. As a former journal ist, I know I would have been hauled across the coals for such a sweeping generalization, without qualification.

title: Cornell, Harvard, B.U., Rated Tops in Hockey
description: America's college hockey coaches, finally heeding the call of the professionals have adopted the pro rule that al lows checking all over the ice, a tactic designed to separate the men from the boys.

title: Music: A Bright lolanthe
description: Seeing and hearing Iolan the in the Village Light Opera Group's new produc tion, one would never dream that this Gilbert and. Sullivan classic passed its 90th birth day last month.

title: TEACHERS NEEDED TO HELP NAVAJOS
description: ALBUQUERQUE, Dec. 2Ed ucators responsible for the in struction of Navajo Indians in the Southwest were told here this week that 1,200 bilingual teachers were needed for more than 50,000 Navajo children but that fewer than 100 quali fied and properly trained teach ers were available.

title: Jazz: Relativity Suite
description: For five nights during the past week, the Jazz Compos ers Orchestra has been at work in New York Univer sity's Eisner  Lubin Audito rium on the south side of Washington Square. From Monday through Thursday, Don Cherry was holding workshops, open to the pub lic, at which he rehearsed the orchestra in his Rela tivity Suite, commissioned by the Jazz Composers Or chestra Association in 1970. On the final night, Friday, the orchestra played the work in concert.

title: Opposite Thumbs for Asian Hand
description: In reference to A Young Asia Hand Points an Accusing Finger (With Love) by James P. Sterba (Travel Section, Oct. 29), I offer the Japanese proverb, Saru mo ki kara ochiru, or Even monkeys fall from trees. I think it applies to Mr. Sterba's Asian expertise.

title: Verdict Believed Near in Coast Trial of Feminist Charged With Practice of Medicine Without License
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 2The trial of Carol Downer, a femi nist accused of practicing med icine without a license, has ended its second week, with a verdict expected to be handed down Monday.

title: Two on Snowmobile Drown
description: VERONA, N. Y., Dec. 2 (AP) Two men drowned in this Oneida County community early today after their snowmobile plunged through thin ice on the surface of a small pond near their homes. The state police identified the victims as Lynn J. Dibble. 41 years old, of Ver non, and his brother, Lawrence, 32, of the adjoining town of Verona.

title: Miss Rittling Planning Bridal
description: BUFFALO, Dec. 2Mr. and Mrs. Joseph B. Rittling have announced the engagement of their daughter Miss Catherine K. Rittling, to James L. Crane 3d of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Crane Jr. of Buffalo.

title: Former Ramparts Publisher Has New Radical Idea
description: MENLO PARK, Calif., Dec. 2 Edward M. Keating, whose Ramparts magazine was in the vanguard of the early antiwar movement, is working on a comeback as a radical thinker.

title: Tennessee's Cry
description: News of the Rialto

title: What's Higher Than Highest? Wait and See
description: Architecture

title: Soviet Union
description: MOSCOW A young political prisoner died a few weeks ago in the Soviet Union's principal labor camp, which is located in the Mordvinian Autonomous Republic, east of Moscow, and where about 15,000 inmates are believed to be held.

title: A Subway Ride to East Berlin
description: TOMORROW night Kazuko Hillyer International, Inc., and Town Hall will present the second in a series of five chambermusic concerts. This one will be by an assorted group of artists, including the contralto Maureen Forrester. Other ensembles in the series are the Tokyo String Quartet, Berlin String Quartet from East Germany, Composers String Quartet and Adelaide Woodwind Quintet from Australia. Be hind this wideranging assemblage is one of concert management's more ex otic figures, Kazuko Hillyer, a Japanese woman, who calls herself the black sheep of her family, has just expanded her organization in order to keep it small and who has a reputation in the music business as a determined, strong willed impresario belying her fragile ap pearance.

title: Fresco Found Under 6 Paint Layers in Church Cleanup
description: When 75 parishioners of St. Joseph's Church in Greenwich Village volunteered early this year to clean up their 140yearold landmark building, they planned simply to wash down walls and perhaps throw out some cumbersome furniture.

title: DR. BETHEL FLEMING
description: WENATCHEE, Wash., Dec. 3 Dr. Bethel Harris Fleming, a Methodist missionary in India and Nepal for 37 years, died Nov. 25 at the Central Washington Deaconess Hospital after suffering critical injuries in fall earlier last month. She was 70 years old.

title: Bruce Beckmann Weds Ann Kotler
description: EAST NORWICH, L.I., Dec. 3  Miss Ann Kotler and Bruce Beckmann were married here this afternoon at the Pine Hollow Country Club by Rabbi Jacob Polish.

title: A SUMMONS MARS HOLIDAY CUSTOM
description: As 800 disabled people shopped at Alexander's department store in the Bronx yesterday in what is an annual holiday tradition there, a policeman served a summons on the store for violating Sabbath closing laws.

title: Reports Say Security Men Foiled Plot to Oust Sadat
description: Egyptian security men have foiled an attempted coup by rightwing antiSoviet Egyptian Air Force officers and pilots, according to reports reaching New York.

title: Health of Astronauts Pays Price for Flight
description: CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Dec. 3What no man can ever forget, after watching any Apollo launching, is that riding atop that raging pillar of fire are three human beings  relatively fragile creatures embarking on a voyage for which nothing on earth can have totally prepared them.

title: The Hard Men
description: LONDON, Dec. 3When they visit the Republic of Ireland, tourists find relief from the strident and the mechanical in their own societies. It is all so quiet, so oldfashioned, so gentle. In the rain of a nice soft day, waiting out a trout or sitting by a turf fire, Ireland is tranquillity.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: NEW CANAAN, Conn., Dec. 3 (AP)The team of Bob Kingsbury of Scarsdale, N. Y., and John Mangan of Rye, N.Y., the 1972 national champions, today won the annual Connecticut invitation platform tennis doubles championship at the Lake Club.

title: NEW TALKS BEGUN IN L.I.R.R. STRIKE
description: Still far apart on the question of raises for 5,000 nonoperating employes, labor and management began another round of negotiations yesterday in an effort to end the strike on the Long Island Rail Road.

title: At the Metropolitan Museum, A Louis XVI Salon Reflects OnceUponaTime Elegance
description: Few household would or could indulge themselves in the kind of remodeling recently and expensively bestowed upon a Louis XVI salon at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. But then, the museum runs a quite special household and has such friends as the Charles B. Wrightsmans to pick up the tab.

title: Miss Florence Beechler Is Wed
description: Miss Florence Phillis Beechler, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Glenn Curtis Beechler of New York, was married here yesterday afternoon to Dr. Louis Jerome Steinfelder. He is the son of Dr. Jacob Jerome Steinfelder also of New York, and the late Mrs. Steinfelder.

title: United Parade Days
description: Letters to the Editor

title: FOX TERRIER WINS TOP SHOW AWARD
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Dec. 3A smooth fox terrier, Ch. Boreham Baranova, who won't be 2 years old until New Year's Day, celebrated early when she was named best of 3,395 dogs at the Boardwalk Kennel Club show today.

title: Miss Chung, Violinist, Proves Superb Musician
description: Like so many young musicians today, KyungWha Chung, a violinist of prodigious technical accomplishment and musical talent, moves easily through an extraordinarily wideranging variety of styles. Her Hunter College Assembly Hall concert yesterday afternoon for instance, encompassed such diverse fare as Bach (the D minor Partita), Schoenberg (the Phantasy) and SaintSans (Sonata No. 1) with a pleasant baroque trifle (Mondonville's Sonata in C) thrown in for good measure.

title: Friend in The White House?
description: When President Nixon squeaked to his first victory four years ago, organized labor's secret service kept feeding panicky communiques to the A.F.L.C.I.O. high command about bigbusiness pressure on the White House to break up union monopolies and return labor to a pastoral state of impotence. Now that a triumphantly reelected Nixon is moving for permanent realignment of American politics, with bluecollar workers as a principal building block in his new majority, the chiefs of many giant corporations are doing at least as much worrying about the President's intentions as the stanchest of the Democrats in labor's divided hierarchy.

title: A SUMMONS MARS HOLIDAY CUSTOM
description: As 800 disabled people shopped at Alexander's department store in the Bronx yesterday in what is an annual holiday tradition there, a policeman served a summons on the store for violating Sabbath closing laws.

title: Keres's Loss Puts Karpov in Top Place In a Chess Tourney
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Dec. 3 (UPI)Lajos Portisch of Hungary defeated Paul Keres of the Soviet Union tonight in the 11th round of the Church's Fried Chicken international chess tournament. The loss was the first for Keres, who had been in a firstplace tie with Anatoly Karpov of the Soviet Union.

title: Calley Lawyers to Charge Influence by Army in Case
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 (Reuters)Lawyers for First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. will argue before three judges tomorrow that the 29yearold officer's trial on Mylai murder Charges was unfair because of influ ence by the Army.

title: U.S.C. Solidifies Its Top Ranking
description: Six touchdowns by Anthony Davis of Southern California and three Alabama kicks that were blocked by Auburn Saturday made it almost certain that Southern California will be selected national champion by all the groups that name college football's top team at season's end.

title: Israel Planning to Compensate Arabs Who Lost Land in 1948
description: JERUSALEM, Dec. 3 (AP)A $100million plan to compensate some of the Arabs who lost property in 1948 with the establishment of Israel was approved today by the Israeli Government.

title: AUTHORITY DEBTS TOTAL $9BILLION
description: State Controller Arthur Levitt said yesterday that 34 public authorities had $8.9billion in debts outstanding  more than two and a half times the state's $3.4billion debt and that much of this might have to be shouldered by taxpayers.

title: Houthakker Asks the U.S. To Act to Aid Competition
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3Prof. Hendrik S. Houthakker of Harvard, an ardent believer in competition and a former economic adviser to President Nixon, has proposed a procompetitive escapehatch from wageprice controls.

title: 3 Moviegoers Shot As Gunman Sprays Screaming Crowd
description: Shooting wildly into a screaming crowd of Brooklyn moviegoers, an unidentified young gunman last night wounded two men and a teenage boy, according to the police, who said the assailant escaped as scores of people fled the theater.

title: Criminal Court Budget Is $14.1Million a Year
description: The budget of the Criminal Court in the five boroughs for 197172 was $14,125,789. Slightly more than $3million of that amount went for the salaries of the 98 judges of the court, who are appointed by the Mayor to 10year terms at a salary of $30,750 a year.

title: KISSINGER ARRIVES IN PARIS TO BEGIN ADDITIONAL TALKS
description: PARIS, Monday, Dec. 4 Henry A. Kissinger, President Nixon's adviser on national security, arrived here last night to start another round of Vietnam ceasefire negotiations today.

title: Belfast Murder Is Third in Two Days
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Dec. 3  The body of a middleaged man, shot through the head, was found in a predominantly Roman Catholic area of Belfast today  the third assassination victim in little more than 24 hours.

title: 155 Killed as Spanish Jet Crashes in Canary Islands
description: SANTA CRUZ DE TENERIFE, Canary Islands, Dec 3A chartered Spanish jet airliner carrying a group of tourists from West Germany crashed shortly after takeoff on this resort island today, killing all 155 persons on board.

title: OffTrack Betting Studied
description: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 3 (AP) The debtridden Philadelphia School District is studying offtrack betting as a new source of income, the school board president, William Ross, said over the weekend. The proposal, which Mr. Ross said was in the planning stages, would have to be approved by the slate legislature before it could be put into practice.

title: Young Peronists in Clash With Policemen and Troops
description: BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 3 (Reuter)Policemen and troops clashed with groups of youthful supporters of the former Argentine President, Juan D. Peron, today in the suburb of San Miguel, 20 miles north of here, the national press agency reported. The agency said that 14 policemen had been injured.

title: Courting Shoppers
description: The next publishing attempt of Twenty First Century Communications (which just acquired Ingenue magazine from Dell) will be a monthly family magazine sent free to big spenders at major shopping centers.

title: Columbia U. Will Name Black Chief of Personnel
description: Donald L. Miller, deputy assistant secretary of defense for equal opportunity, will be appointed vice president for personnel management at Columbia University, making him the highestranking black administrator in Columbia's history, the university announced yesterday.

title: L.I.R.R. Still Struck
description: Long Island Rail Road riders again prepared to find alternative ways of getting to work today as negotiators in the strike, which began last Thursday, continued talks. Details, Page 66.

title: Nixon Extends Florida Stay
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., Dec. 3 (AP)President Nixon decided to extend his Florida stay until tomorrow, the Florida White House announced tonight. When he returns, the spokesman said, the President willgo to his Camp David retreat in Maryland, where he will receive reports on the Paris peace talks and resume secondterm reorganization planning.

title: Pittsburgh Near Title After Its 300 Victory
description: PITTSBURGH, Dec. 3The turning point in the PittsburghCleveland game today was the opening kickoff, Which Roy Gerela of the Steelers booted deep into a corner of the Browns' end zone so that Ken Brown had no chance to run it out. That set the tone and the Steelers later dictated the tempo as they won gloriously, 300.

title: J.A.L. to Pay Compensation
description: TOKYO, Dec. 3 (UPI)Japan Air Lines will pay $4,000 each to the families of 42 Japanese passengers killed in the crash of a J.A.L. DC8 jetliner in Moscow last week, a spokesman said today. The company said it also would pay. $1,000 to each of the nine surviving Japanese passengers.

title: A Boutique That Puts the Mastectomy Patient at Ease
description: SHOP TALK

title: Redskins, Raiders Triumph and Clinch Divisional Crowns
description: George Allen and his over the hill gang reached the summit yesterday. The Washington Redskins, rebuilt and restyled by two years of Allen's coaching, clinched their first National Football League divisional title in 27 years by beating the Philadelphia Eagles, 237.

title: Anthropologists Reassess Their Impact on People They Study
description: TORONTO, Dec. 3Enough indignities have been suffered by our ancestors in the name of research, Harvey McCue, an Ojibwa Indian, told a meeting of anthropologists here the other day. Anthropology as discipline can assist in sensing those aspects of contemporary society that discriminates against native people, but think it's time for a moratorium on further digging.

title: Suspect Gets Day in Court And Says One Word: Yes
description: It was Patrolman Stanley Cagney's second consecutive day in court. The day before, he had spent eight hours at the Criminal Court Building while Larry Boyd, the 34yearold suspect he had arrested on a robbery charge, was being funneled through the preliminary stages of the system of criminal justice.

title: Redskins' Kilmer Says Nixon Is Hurting Team.
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 (AP)The Washington Redskins' quarterback, Billy Kilmer, says President Nixon is so involved in the team's progress that he's really hurting us.

title: Playoff Chances Linger On for New York
description: CINCINNATI, Dec. 3 The Cincinnati defense was too strong for the New York Giants today, and the Bengals produced a 1310 victory that further reduced New York's chances of making the National Football League playoffs. The Giants even tried two quarterbacks.

title: HARRY PRICE
description: ENGLEWOOD, N.J., Dec. 3Harry Price, treasurer of Edward Boker, Inc., institutional wholesale food distributors, died today in Englewood Hospital. He was 64 years old and lived at 133 Huguenot Avenue.

title: Save the 7:30 Curtainand the Forum
description: Letters to the Editor

title: Coeds Finding a Welcome in R.O.T.C.
description: WEST LAFAYETTE, Ind., Dec. 3  Like cheerleaders watching a game that slightly scares them, the young women stood in small groups off to the side of the rifle range covering their ears as the men fired round after round during target practice in their Naval Reserve Officer Training Corps class.

title: LATE RANGER GOAL TOPS FLAMES, 32
description: Another of those nights made memorable by the antics of Emile Francis, the Rangers' coach and general manager, ended with the New Yorkers scoring a difficult 32 victory over the Atlanta Flames last night.

title: IMPERIALE AGREES TO LIMIT PICKETS
description: NEWARK, Dec. 3  Assentblyman Anthony Imperiale said he would obey the courtim posed limit of 200 pickets in tomorrow's protest at the site of the Kawaida Towers housing project, but he urged other supporters to come out as onlookers.

title: U.S. Amateur Nine Finishes 2d
description: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Dec. 3 (AP)Dick Smith, a lefthander, shut out Panama, 30, today in the world amateur baseball tournament as the United States wound up second to Cuba with a 132 wonlost record.

title: F.D.A. Aide Finds Few Toys Unsafe But Urges Caution
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 (UPI) The product safety director for the Food and Drug Administration said today that the hidden hazards in toysthe pins embedded in dolls or squeaker devices that could be swallowedhad been virtually eliminated from the market this year.

title: Cuba's Stand on Hijacking
description: Letters to the Editor

title: Bowie, Marlboro Tracks to Merge
description: BOWIE, Md., Dec. 3 (UPI)Owners of Bowie and Marlboro race tracks have announced an agreement for common ownership of the two suburban Washington tracks. The tracks plan to continue operations as in the past, with Bowie conducting mile racing and Marlboro conducting halfmile racing, said Bowie's assistant general manager, Al Karwacki. The Maryland Racing Commission will meet Dec. 14 to consider the merger.

title: Jersey Acts to Curb Potential Hazards When Drinking Age Drops to 18 Jan. 1
description: TRENTON  After years of trying to convince New York State of the dangers of an 18yearold minimum drinking age, New Jersey officials are quietly moving to lessen the same potential dangers in New Jersey before Jan. 1, when the state's legal drinking age is lowered to 18.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
U.C.L.A. Wins Water. Polo Title
description: ALBUQUERQUE, N. M., Dec. 3 (UPI)Eric Lindroth scored six goals last night to give the University of California, Los Angeles, a 15 victory over San Jose State and its second consecutive National Collegiate water polo championship.

title: GREEKS WIN, 30, IN SOCCER LEAGUE
description: Three of the five GermanAmerican Soccer League game's ended in ties, two of them scoreless, but the New York Ukrainians and the GreekAmericans posted easy victories over Clarkstown and Blue Star, respectively, yesterday.

title: Unsecular Man Crucified: I
description: Books of The Times

title: T. CARY WESCOTT
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Dec. 3T. Cary Wescott, former president or Ebasco Services, Inc., service subsidiary of Electric Bond and Share Company, died yesterday at St. Francis Hospital. He was 85 years old and lived at 7 Richards Road.

title: TIGERCATS TAKE GREY CUP, 13 TO 10
description: HAMILTON, Ontario, Dec. 3 (Reuter)Ian Sunter, a placekicker, left the bench on the last play to kick a field goal and give the Hamilton TigerCats a 1310 victory over the Saskatchewan Roughriders today: in the Grey Cup game for Canada's professional football championship.

title: U.S. Amateur Nine Finishes 2d
description: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Dec. 3 (AP)Dick Smith, a lefthander, shut out Panama, 30, today in the world amateur baseball tournament as the United States wound up second to Cuba with a 132 wonlost record.

title: POLICE IN BOSTON SEEK MISSING COED
description: BOSTON, Dec. 3The police are searching for a Boston University coed from Bedford Hills, N.Y., who they fear may be the fifth murder victim in a wave of violent crimes against young women in the Boston area.

title: L.I.R.R. Still Struck
description: Long Island Rail Road riders again prepared to find alternative ways of getting to work today as negotiators in the strike, which began last Thursday, continued talks. Details, Page 66.

title: Lindsay Begins Talks With Leaders in Israel
description: TEL AVIV, Dec. 3 (AP)Mayor Lindsay arrived in Israel today for an official fiveday visit and talks with Prime Minister Golda Meir, Defense Minister Moshe Dayan and other top leaders.

title: Alaska G.O.P. Candidate Picked for House Race
description: JUNEAU, Alaska, Dec. 3 (AP) The Alaska Republican Central Committee has unanimously selected State Senator Don Young to run for the Congressional seat now held by the missing Representative Nick Begich.

title: House Speaker Criticized
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 (UPI) Representative John Conyers Jr. criticized the Democratic party's Congressional leadership today, saying it was imperative that the Democrats select a new House Speaker to replace Representative Carl Albert of Oklahoma. The Michigan Democrat accused party leaders in the House of acquiescing to the Nixon Administration during the 92d Congress and of failing to fill the vacuum created by the Administration's lack of interest in domestic programs.

title: Ruckelshaus Defends Nixon On CleanWater Funds Cut
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 (UPI) William D. Ruckelshaus defended today the Nixon Administration's 55 per cent slash in water pollution funds as necessary to counteract impossible and irresponsible demands by Congress.

title: McMahon to Resign Tomorrow As Australian Prime Minister
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Dec. 3.Prime Minister William McMahon said today that he would resign on Tuesday, turning the office over to Gough. Whitlam of the Labor party.

title: Pakistan Issues Warning To Tribes in Baluchistan
description: RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, Dec. 3 (Reuters)Marauding tribesmen in remote Baluchistan Province were given an ultimatum today to hand over loot and hostages and withdraw from villages they have occupied.

title: Personal Finance
description: In a talk recently before a savings bank group, New York State's Superintendent of Banks, Harry W. Albright Jr., showed his consumer orientation. He attacked what he calls excessive late charges levied by some mortgage lenders when homeowners make payments late.

title: 2 Girls Found in Bay State
description: SHARON, Mass., Dec. 3 (AP) Two girls who lost their way when they took a shortcut to their homes were found early today cold and tired but otherwise satisfactory. A party of searchers came across the girls, 10yearold Nancy Karger and Elizabeth Nickel. 9, in the marshy area not far from their homes

title: Canadian First in Marathon
description: CULVER CITY, Calif., Dec. 3 (AP)Brian Armstrong of Toronto outran a field of 600 today to win the 25th Western Hemisphere marathon.

title: TaxLien Sale by Newark To Offer 1, 200 Properties
Special Session in Saigon
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, Dec. 4 (Reuters) South Vietnam's National Security Council went into special session today only hours before the secret Paris peace talks were about to resume.

title: London's Freeze Is a Cold Reality for the Workers on the Farms
description: STUDHAM, England,There are only a few ornaments In the living room of George Brown's cottage: a set of china foxhounds, a studded foxhead on the wall and a goldfish swimming murkily in a globe of water. The water is terribly cold.

title: PACERS CONQUER NETS BY 113110
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., Dec. 3The New York. Nets not only couldn't end their losing streak tonight against the Indiana Pacers, they could not extricate themselves from a selfmade firstperiod hole, bowing to the West Division leaders of the American Basketball Association, 113110, before 5,575 fans at Nassau Coliseum.

title: Letter to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Amphetamines Used by a Physician To Lift Moods of Famous Patients
description: For many years Dr. Max Jacobson, a 72yearold general practitioner in New York, has been injecting amphetaminethe powerful stimulant the drug culture calls speedinto the veins of dozens of the country's most celebrated artists, writers, politicians and jetsetters.

title: Apollo Countdown Continues as Threat Of Strike Is Ended
description: CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Dec. 3Preparations for the launching of Apollo 17, the last of the missions to land men on the moon, continued tonight after a threatened strike was averted.

title: Sabich Is Victor in Skiing; Killy and Palmer Both Fall
description: VAIL, Colo., Dec. 3Spider Sabich, last season's professional ski champion, regained his winning form today as he defeated JeanClaude Killy en route to taking the Benson & Hedges grand prix slalom event.

title: Gray Resting at His Home
description: NEW LONDON, Conn., Dec. 3  L. Patrick Gray 3d, acting director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, was released from Lawrence Memorial Hospital today after having undergone surgery Nov. 26 for an abdominal obstruction. Mr. Gray, who is 56 years old, went to his home in Stonington, where he is expected to continue recuperating for about a week.

title: Swiss Voters Back Common Market Tie
description: GENEVA. Dec. 3  Switzerland's voters firmly hitched their country today to Western Europe's drive for economic integration by overwhelmingly approving a free trade treaty with the European Economic Community.

title: Shorter Takes Marathon in Japan
description: FUKUOKA, Japan, Dec. 3 (AP)Frank Shorter, the Olympic marathon champion, galloped to an easy victory in the Fukuoka international marathon today despite suffering from stomach cramps.

title: Welfare Hearings Slated
description: Two days of open hearings on alternatives for the way rent allowances are issued for welfare clients were scheduled yesterday by Human Resources Administrator Jule M. Sugarman. He said he would hear witnesses Dec. 18 and 19 at the National Maritime Union Hall, 346 West 17th Street, from 10 A.M. to 8 P.M. each day.

title: Terror Strikes Dublin
description: I never thought it would come down here, a Dublin resident told a reporter after terrorist bombs last week had killed two and injured 126 in Ireland's capital. But it was always clear that the Republic could not be immune If the campaigns of violence continued indefinitely in Northern Ireland.

title: Marcel Stops Garcia to Keep Crown
description: PANAMA CITY, Fla., Dec. 3 (AP)Ernesto Marcel Panama stopped Enrique Garcia of Mexico in the sixth round last night to retain his World Boxing Association featherweight title. Marcel, at the 126pound limit, dropped the Mexican, 1241/2 for an 8count in the sixth round of the scheduled 15rounder. When the bell sounded the ring doctor examined Garcia, who suffered cuts around both eyes, and stopped the fight.

title: JOHN PAPPAS DIES; INDUSTRIALIST, 66
description: BOSTON, Dec. 3John C. Pappas, industrialist, shipping magnate, philanthropist and a former associate justice of the Glouchester District Court, died here today in Beth Israel Hospital at the age of 66.

title: The Voting Mystery
description: Of all the democracies, why does the United States consistently have the lowest voter participation in its national elections? The search for answers to this question leads not only to the circumstances of particular elections but also to the larger social context in which this country's politics evolve.

title: Shaking Off Ethnic Bonds
description: Once again scholarly and popular observers and community organizers are proudly celebrating America's ethnic diversity.

title: MRS. MEIR REJECTS RETURN TO '67 LINES
description: Premier Golda Meir of Israel, in an interview appearing today in Time magazine, said that President, Anwar elSadat of Egypt could open the Suez Canal any time of day or night, but she warned that Israel could not accept Mr. Sadat's demand that Israel return to her pre1967 borders as a precondition.

title: $5,000 Stolen During Mass
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Dec. 2 (AP)  Two young gunmen handcuffed a man and his son, tried unsuccessfully to handcuff two retired nuns and took bout $5,000 in money and checks today in the basement of a Roman Catholic church while mass was in progress. The police said the money had been collected at four weekend masses at Holy Spirit church.

title: Biaggi Says City Inmates Run Up Phone Bills in Abuse of Privileges
description: Representative Mario Biaggi Charged yesterday that administrative permissiveness in the Correction Department was permitting inmates in city houses of detention to run up thousands of dollars in longdistance calls on city telephones.

title: St. Thomas Episcopal Installs 11th Rector in Century and Half
description: The Rev. John G. B. Andrew was installed yesterday as the 11th rector in the 150year history of St. Thomas Episcopal Church, Fifth Avenue and 53d Street.

title: Buses From L.I. to City
description: Following is a list of bus services available to Nassau and Suffolk County commuters to subway stops in Queens:

title: Red Smith Gorilla Warfare
description: PITTSBURGH, Dec. 3On the fourth play from scrimmage, Cleveland's Bo Scott fumbled and the loose football wound up under the sternum of Andy Russell, a mustachebearing master of business administration who can hit a golf ball across the county line. Seven plays Pater, Roy Gerela sideswiped a 36yard field goal. This was a far, far betterthing than Gerela had ever done in a life that began 24 years ago in Powell River, British Columbia, and took him to high school in Honolulu, college in Las Cruces, N. M., and to the Houston Oilers for two seasons before the Pittsburgh Steelers picked him up on waivers.

title: Willoughby Abner Dead at 51; WellKnown National Mediator
description: Willoughby Abner, vice president of the American Arbitration Association and a prominent national mediator, died early yesterday of a heart attack in Washington. Mr. Abner, who would have been 52 years old on Wednesday, was stricken while celebrating his birthday at a staff party.

title: FOE AGAIN SHELLS BIENHOA AIR BASE
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, Dec. 4 (AP)Communistled forces launched their second rocket attack in four days on the big Bienhoa air base northoest of Saigon, where the United States is stockpiling aircraft to reinforce the South Vietnamese air force before a ceasefire, the Saigon command reported today.

title: Kostelanetz Conducts A Rousing Evening
description: The appropriate noisy vulgarity of Walton's Capriccio burlesco began Andre Kostelanetz's second concert of the season with the New York Philharmonic Saturday night; the emotional and sonic storms of Tchaikovsky's Francesca da Rimini ended it. In the middle came Ravel's lively Alborado del Gracioso and Rachmaninoff's Paganini Rhapsody for piano and orchestra, which has its fair share of fireworks. With Mr. Kostelanetz conducting these works for maximum effect, the evening was primarily a rousing one, which seemed to suit the capacity audience fine.

title: GOVERNORS BACK WESTWOOD RIVAL
description: ST. LOUIS, Dec. 3A resolute coalition of Southern and Western Governors committed the Democratic Governors Conference here today to the election of Robert Strauss of Texas as the chairman of their party when the Democratic National Committee meets in Washington next weekend.

title: Eban Emphasizes Gains For Jordanin in Negottation
description: JERUSALEM, Dec. 3  Foreign Minister Abba Eban said this weekend that Jordan could gain a great deal in negotiations with Israel, including peace, population, territory and a special status for the Moslem places of Jerusalem.

title: American Party Chiefs Bar A 1976 Drive For Wallace
description: DALLAS, Dec. 3 (UPI)American party leaders said today that if Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama decided to seek the Presidency in 1976 he would have to find a vehicle other than the American party, which he established in 1968 for his Presidential campaign.

title: 200 Top Concerns Increase Their Role In Nation's Output
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3The share of total manufacturing output in the United States economy held by the 50 largest companies has not increased in more than a decade, but the share of the 200 largest companies has risen noticeably, new Government figures disclosed today.

title: Brooklyn Cab Driver Shot By Robber He Tried to Trap
description: A gunman locked is the back seat of a taxi he was trying to rob shortly before 7 o'clock yesterday morning climbed out of the window of the cab and shot its fleeing driver in the leg.

title: U.S.C. Solidifies Its Top Ranking
description: Six touchdowns by Anthony Davis of Southern California and three Alabama kicks that were blocked by Auburn Saturday made it almost certain that Southern California will be selected national champion by all the groups that name college football's top team at season's end.

title: Jamal's Jazz Thrust Turns From Forays To Frontal Attacks
description: Ahmad Jamal has been polishing his dramatic, stylized jazz piano work for the better part of 20 years. During all these years he has clung to a distinctive concept for his trio, setting his bassist out front as the core around which the group builds its performances.

title: EXSTERN GANG HEAD DENIES TRUMAN PLOT
description: TEL AVIV, Dec. 3 (AP)A former commander of a Jewish terrorist organization denied today that his group tried to assassinate President Truman with a letter bomb 25 years ago.

title: Brandt and HoneckerWho Won What?
description: Letters to the Editor

title: BARD LINE IN PARIS HINTED BY HANOI
description: HONG KONG, Dec. 3The official North Vietnamese newspaper Nhan Dan warned in an editorial today that any attempt by the United States to revise the Vietnam peace agreements as announced by Hanoi last month would mean that Washington's real intention was to scrap the accord and continue the war.

title: Yacht Designer Dies
description: L. Francis Herreshoff, the dean of American yacht designers, died yesterday in Boston at the age of 82. An obituary appears on Page 42.

title: Eugene Coyle, Tenor. Sings OldFashioned Bill
description: Eugene Coyle, a native of Ireland who practices Brthopedic surgery in Hackensack, N.J., and is a tenor by vocation, ventured onto the stage of Carnegie Hall Saturday night for his first New York recital. The program was popular in the old  fashioned sensefamiliar opera arias, pop songs and lots of Neapolitan schmalz.

title: NET CAPITAL RULE PLANNED BY S.E.C.
description: BOCA BATON, Fla., Dec. 3The Securities and Exchange Commission has decided to require all brokerage houses to operate under uniform net capital regulations that would supersede the capital rules imposed by stock exchanges.

title: Winner in Australia Edward Gough Whitlam
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Dec. 3. Tall, handsome Gough Whitlam, the incoming Prime Minister of Australia, has never hesitated to do battle with friends as well as foes on questions of principle.

title: Jets Rally to Top Saints, 1817, on Final Play As Howfield Kicks Sixth Field Goal of Game
description: Bobby Howfield, celebrating his 36th birthday with Mrs. Selina Ashby, his 75yearold mother, sitting in the stands, made six of seven fieldgoal attempts yesterday to singlefootedly lead the New York Jets to an 1817 victory over the New Orleans Saints before a Shea Stadium crowd of 62,496.

title: C.B.S., Citing Sabotage, Cancels Telecast of Jets
description: The Columbia Broadcasting System canceled its scheduled telecast yesterday of the New York JetsNew Orleans Saints football game at Shea Stadium, charging that camera cables had been cut and disconnected and that employes had been assaulted.

title: Issues in the L.I.R.R. Dispute
description: PARTICIPANTSThe Long Island Rail Road and 12 unions representing 5,000 carmen, teamsters, clerks, electrical workers, sheet metal workers and other nonoperating employes, as well as some supervisors.

title: Harvard School Fills Post
description: BOSTON, Dec. 3 (AP)The appointment of Dr. Kurt J. Isselbacher of Newton Center as Mallinckrodt Professor of Medicine at Harvard Medical School was announced today by Dr. Robert H. Ebert, Dean of the Faculty of Medicine.

title: NICKLAUS BETTERS EARNINGS RECORD
description: LAKE BUENA VISTA, Fla., Dec. 3The fantastic land of Disney saluted a fantastic golfer today. With a 72hole total of 267 that was a record low for the 1972 pro tour, Jack Nicklaus increased his earnings to a record high for a year of $320,542. His score won the Walt Disney open tournament by a ninestroke margin.

title: Eban Emphasizes Gains For Jordan in Negotiation
description: JERUSALEM, Dec. 3  Foreign Minister Abba Eban said this weekend that Jordan could gain a great deal in negotiations with Israel, including peace, population, territory and a special status for the Moslem places of Jerusalem.

title: Yosemite Team Finds Body, Seeks Another
description: YOSEMITE, Calif., Dec. 3 (UPI)The body of a young man who plunged 1,430 feet down Yosemite Falls was retrieved tonight by rangers dodging huge chunks of falling ice.

title: Bridge: Legal Problems Can Accent Perversity of Game's Gods
JEWS' FAMILY TIES ARE HELD ERODING
description: HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Dec. 3An American Jewish interreligious leader warned today that a steady erosion of the Jewish family as a unit posed a grave threat to the cultural and religious life of the American Jewish community.

title: Space Program to Aim at Practical Needs
description: The national space program turned an important corner in 1972a year that, in a very real sense, was a year of decision. The decision to proceed with the development of the reusable space shuttle was a pivotal determination which not only governs the mechanics of our future space activities, but sets its operational tone as well.

title: ASH'S ROLE NOTED IN LAND DEALINGS
description: ELKO, Nev., Dec 3 (AP)President Nixon's new budget chief was one of several traders who acquired thousands of acres of public land in the West in a series of controver sial deals with the Interior Department.

title: Leader of Albania Says Soviet Wanted Bases There in '59
description: PEKING, Dec. 3 (Agence FrancePresse)  The Soviet Union considered setting up missile bases in Albania in 1959 during the era of Nikita S. Khrushchev, Hsinhua, the Chinese press agency, reported today.

title: RUPP'S SUCCESSOR VICTOR IN OPENER
description: The changing of the guard took place Saturday night at Kentucky. For the first time in 42 years Adolph Rupp, the man in the brown suit, was not the basketball coach of the Wildcats. In his place was Joe Hall, wearing the blue blazer of Kentucky, but just as active on the bench as Rupp had been.

title: Making of Much Ado: A March In Ragtime to Broadway and TV
description: Sam Waterston and Kathleen Widdoes in the Joseph Papp version of Much Ado About Nothing.

title: Howard C. Heyn, ExHead Of the A.P.'s Book Division
description: Howard C. Heyn, former head of the book division of The Associated Press, died last night in St. Elizabeth's Hospital after emergency surgery. He was 66 years old.

title: SovietEgypt Rift Persists, Causing Strains in Cairo
description: CAIRO, Dec. 3An Egyptian military delegation led by Gen. Hosni Mobarak of the air force has returned from Moscow amid indications that SovietEgyptian relations remain almost as distant as they were after President Anwar elSadat abruptly expelled 20,000 Soviet military advisers last July,

title: Catholic Group Names Aide
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 (AP) The Rev. David Baeten, chaplain of the Mercy Medical Center, Oshkosh, Wis., has been named director of the Division of Chaplain Services of the United States Catholic Conference, officials said today.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Gunman Captured In Midtown Chase

title: DR. R. H. SPAULDING OF N.Y.U., 79, DIES
description: FORT WORTH, Dec. 3 (AP)Dr. Roland H. Spaulding, professor emeritus of aviation at New York University, died toclay at a hospital. He was 79 years old.

title: Colonial Charm Top 2YearOld
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 3 (AP)Colonial Charm and Ricci Reenie Time have won the 2yearold harness horse of the year titles, the United States Trotting Association announced. Colonial Charm, a filly, was voted the best 2yearold trotter by 116 of the 185 United States Harness Writers Association members. Arnie Almahurst was second with 38 votes.

title: Nationals Beat Aeros, 54
description: OTTAWA, Ontario, Dec. 3 (AP)  Wayne Carleton scored three goals and Bob Charlebois scored at 4:32 of an overtime tonight as the Ottawa Nationals edged the Houston Aeros, 54.

title: Hunters Restricted
description: FAIRFIELD, N. J., Dec. 3There has been a strange reaction from hunters this season despite the plethora game, the respectable weather and the abundance of open spaces.

title: ADS FOR TV SETS HELD MISLEADING
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3Advertisers of television sets failed to prove nearly 70 per cent of the representations that the Federal Trade Commission questioned last year in its campaign to substantiate ad vertising claims according to a study made public today.

title: Stage: The Bar That Never Closes
description: The new musical that opened last night at the Astor Place Theater, The Bar That Never Closes, has a great deal to commend it. It is more a revue or a cabaret, perhaps, than a musical. Yet it has a strange flavor to it. It suggests, rather jauntily, a sense of despair and desolation. It is not perfect, but liked it a lot.

title: Manhattan Handles 40% Of Cases but Is Fastest
description: Justice in the Criminal Court in Manhattan is speedier than in the other boroughs although it handles the most casesnearly 40 per cent of the citywide total.

title: A.B.C. Studies Vandalism and Apollo 17
description: Fact and conjecture are rather confusingly crammed into Countdown to 2001, a kind of minipreview of the Apollo 17 launching and one of two 30minute documentaries that will be shown tonight on American Broadcasting Company television. The brevity of the first program, starting at 8, is the main trouble.

title: Pants Have Come a Long Way And They're Coming Further
description: Pants were for working in the garden, driving the children to school or doing the chores on Saturday. That was just five years ago.

title: Amphetamines Used by a Physician To Lift Moods of Famous Patients
description: For many years Dr: Max Jacobson, a 72yearold general practitioner in New York, has been injecting amphetaminethe powerful stimulant the drug culture calls speedrinto the veins of dozens of the country's most celebrated artists, writers, politicians and jetsetters.

title: Married Deacons Viewed as Replacing Priests
description: HOUSTON, Dec. 3Married Roman Catholic deacons, who are now permitted to perform all priestly functions except saying mass, hearing confessions and giving last rites, will constitute all the pastors of the church by the end of this century, a noted, priest has predicted.

title: U.S. Seeks to Check On Sludge Dumping By Towns at Shore
Rich ExDemocratic Insurgent Due to Get Vacant Council Seat
description: Frederick W. Richmond, the 49yearold industrialistphilanthropist who began his New York political career as an insurgent, is expected to be named by Brooklyn's regular Democratic organization to fill a City Council vacancy.

title: Italy's Cabinet Faces Intraparty Trouble
description: ROME, Dec. 3Premier Giulio Andreotti's fivemonthold centrist Government is facing rough weather:

title: SUPPLENESS MARKS WIEDER PIANO STYLE
description: Grace Wieder, who appeared Saturday night at Carnegie Recital Hall, is a calm, commonsense pianist. She chooses moderate tempos, works within a generally limited dynamic range and lets everything flow forward with a singing legato. This is by no means to imply that she is a salon artist, a ladies pianist. Her style, on the contrary, is characterized above all by a kind of placid strength, with phrases delineated by heavy, measured accents.

title: Marcos Said to Approve Some Easing of Curfew
description: MANILA, Dec. 3 (UPI)President Ferdinand E. Marcos has allowed, on a selective basis, the conditional lifting of the martial law curfew of midnight to 4 A.M., a proGovernment television station reported today.

title: PETERSON CITES IFS ON GAS FROM SOVIET
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 (AP)  Commerce Secretary Peter G. Peterson says it could be 1977 or 1978 before any natural gas from the Soviet Union is delivered to the United States, even though a proposed deal may be closed in the next few months.

title: Tabulation of Levitt Debt Figures
description: Following is a tabulation reported by State Controller Arthur Levitt of $5.039billion in authority debt backed by state involvement as of last June 30 (in millions):

title: Colonial Charm Top 2YearOld
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 3 (AP)Colonial Charm and Ricci Reenie Time have won the 2yearold harness horse of the year titles, the United States Trotting Association announced. Colonial Charm, a filly, was voted the best 2yearold trotter by 116 of the 185 United States Harness Writers Association members. Arnie Almahurst was second with 38 votes.

title: Senate Republicans Meet To Pick Brydges's Successor
description: The members of the Republican majority in the State Senate will meet in Albany today to pick a new majority leader to fill a vacancy created by the retirement of Senator Earl W. Brydges, Republican of Niagara Falls.

title: Corduroy Council Elects
description: Patricia Boyers, formerly fabric editor of Seventeen Magazine has been named director of the Corduroy Council of America. Jean Driscoll has been appointed executive secretary of the group. The council is the promotional agency for manufacturers of corduroy.

title: Running of Csonka and Morris Helps Subdue Patriots, 3721
