description: HARTFORD, Dec. 8 (UPI) The police say a former union official with reputed under world connections apparently tried to kill himself in a Bloomfield cemetery.

title: Memorial for an Admired Art Talent
description: The American artist Eva Hesse died on May 29, 1970, at the age of 34. Her career was tragically brief, and her work difficult to appreciate. Yet she was astonishingly productive.

title: Basketballs Will Bounce Day and Night at Garden
description: You can't tell the players without a scorecard, and there'll be dozens of numbers for spectators to identify today and tonight at Madison Square Garden.

title: Carbide Suing Borg Units
description: The Union Carbide Corpora tion said yesterday that it had filed a suit in the Federal Dis trict Court of Toledo, Ohio, against the BorgWarner Cor poration and the SundBorg Corporation charging them with innfringement of a Carbide pat ent covering the method and apparatus for injection molding foamed plastic articles. A Borg Warner spokesman said the company would contest the suit.

title: DEMOCRATS READY FOR BATTLE TODAY
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8Fac tions of the Democratic party set the ground rules tonight for their first test of strength in the battle for the party cham manship here tomorrow.

title: 50,000 Pupils Attend Danang AntiRed Rally
description: DANANG, Vietnam, Dec. 8 (AP)About 50,000 school children, waving small South Vietnamese flags and chant ing antiCommunist slogans, filled the Danang stadium to day for a rally in support of the Government. Schools were closed so that they could attend.

title: Peru Seeks to Overcome Anchovy Fishing Crisis
description: LIMA, Peru  The Peruvian military government has begun this week to try to overcome a sea of trouble that has all but destroyed its major industry and export this year.

title: C.A.B. WILL CANCEL AIR FARE DISCOUNT
description: Contending that domestic discount fares on airplanes for young people and families dis criminate against the traveling public at large, the Civil Aero nautics Board declared yester day its intention to cancel such fares.

title: LAKES THREATEN MIDWEST SHORES
description: SAULT STE. MARIE, Mich., Dec. 8Federal and state ex perts have warned that winter storms and ensuing floods will damage hundreds of miles of shoreland along the Great Lakes.

title: Business Briefs
description: The Hudson Bay Mining and Smelting Company said in Toronto yesterday that it had raised the domestic price for copper to 50.5 cents a pound from 49.75 cents a pound in Canadian funds.

title: Alfred McCann Jr. Dies at 64; Talked on Food for WOR Radio
description: YONKERS, N. Y., Dec. 8 Alfred W. McCann Jr., who conducted a daily report on food over WOR radio for the last 41 years, died today in Lawrence Hospital, Bronxville. He was 64 years old and lived at 1 Rock Place.

title: Dated Publishing Strategy Linked to Downfall of Life
description: Life magazine, once the na tion's leading national adver tising medium, is sharing the fate of other oncegreat, mass circulation, generalinterest magazinesLook, the weekly Saturday Evening Post, Col lier's and Liberty.

title: Astronauts Refine Aim on Moon And Inspect the Landing Vehicle
description: HOUSTON, Saturday, Dec. 9 The Apollo 17 astronauts re fined their aim on the moon yesterday and made the first inspection tour of the attached lunar module, the vehicle for their planned landing on the moon next Monday.

title: Acadia Files Petition
description: The Acadia Company, Inc., a converter of textiles, yesterday filed a petition under Chapter XI of the Bankruptcy Act in Federal Court here listing lia bilities of $8,640,242 and assets of $8,446,996. In accordance with an agreement reached with its creditors' committee, un secured creditors are to receive 20 per cent of their claims while certain priority creditors will get 100 per cent.

title: THIRD MARKET HIT BY BIG BOARD HEAD
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 8 (AP)  James J. Needham, chairman of the New York Stock Ex change, asked heads of major financial institutions today to trade stocks only in the open markets.

title: 4 Indicted in Hijacking
description: ARLINGTON, Va., Dec. 8 (AP) Four men accused of hijack ing an Eastern Air Lines jet to Cuba have been indicted by an Arlington grand jury on charges of murder and attempted rob bery in the slaying of a police man and banker manager here Oct. 25. Charles Tuller, 49 years old; his sons, Bryce and Jonathan, and a friend, William W. Graham, were indicted.

title: People in Sports: Hospital Bound
description: Doctors made it official yesterday: Johnny Bench, of the Cincinnati Reds, will un dergo surgery Monday for removal of a spot on one lung. Bench is scheduled to enter Christ Hospital in Cin cinnati today.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: On Nov. 28 The Times carried a let ter from Philip S. Hughes, Director of the Office of Federal Elections, critic izing an advertisement the A.C.L.U. ran in The Times on Oct. 27. The ad vertisement was headed It Took a Court Order to Get This Advertise ment Printed.

title: Contempt Charge Dropped Against Memphis Newsman
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Dec. 8 (AP)Contempt charges against Joseph Weiler, a Memphis newspaperman, will be dropped, says the chairman of the state Senate General Welfare and Environment Committee.

title: Barenboim's Baton Adds Fascination
description: Daniel Barenboim, whose only week of subscription concerts with the New York Philharmonic this season be gan on Thursday night, had set up what looked like a conventional program. There was Haydn's Symphony No. 86 in D. Stravinsky's Fire bird Suite and Tchaikovsky's Pathetique Symphony. Mr. Barenboim, however, has a way of not making anything sound conventional, and the concert turned into a fasci nating, occasionally exhila rating experience.

title: Books of The Times
description: DORIS HUMPHREY: AN ARTIST FIRST. An autobiography edited and completed by Selma Jeanne Cohen. 305 pages. Wesleyan University Press. $12.50.

title: Fire at Plimouth Plantation
description: PLYMOUTH, Mass., Dec. 8 (AP)A twoalarm fire exten sively damaged the reception building at Plimouth Planta tion last night and caused a loss estimated in excess of several hundred thousand dol lars. Plimoth Plantation is a recreation of the original Pil grim settlement.

title: Honeymoon Gets Slow Start
description: TOKYO (AP)  Enthusiasts giving a honeymoon couple a sendoff got their paper stream ers tangled in overhead power lines and delayed four of Ja pan's super express bullet trains.

title: EAST HARLEM ENDS SCHOOL BOYCOTT
description: East Harlem parents an nounced yesterday that they would end their twoweek boy cott of 14 schools and send their children hack to classes on Monday.

title: Soviet to Expand Aid
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 8 (AP)The Soviet Union has agreed to ex pand its economic aid to Chile, a diplomatic adviser to visiting President Allende reported to day.

title: Lewis Easily Beats Backus And Retains World Title
description: SYRACUSE, Dec. 9 (AP) Hedgemon Lewis of Los An geles scored an easy victory over Billy Backus in their 15 round rematch tonight for New York State's version of the wel terweight world boxing crown.

title: Hanoi Press Notes Meetings
description: HANOI, North Vietnam, Dec. 8 (Agence FrancePresse)for the first time the Hanoi press referred indirectly today to the secret peace negotiations.

title: Art: Enlarged Detail as a Picture
description: A phenomenon of the re vival of interest in realism is that all of a sudden there are any number of young art ists who can draw from the model with photographic ac curacy. Academic drawing of this kind was supposed to have become a lost art dur ing those years covering about three college genera tions when art students were taught to cultivate their sen sibilities and abjure all tra ditional craftsmanship. But the craft of representational draftsmanship has somehow survided  perhaps it is simply a natural talent, not really needing trainingand the realist painter's problem now has reverted to what it was during the 19th century, which is, simply, how to em ploy an exceptional degree of conventional skill as a tool for individual expression.

title: Bureaus' Disputes Said to Aid Heroin Smuggling
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8A yearlong study by the General Accounting Office said today that the smuggling of heroin into the United Statesprimar ily through New York City was an unresolved problem hampered in part by jurisdic tional disputes among Federal agencies.

title: A.B.A. Board to Meet
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Dec. 8 (AP)The American Basket ball Association board of trus tees will meet here Monday and Tuesday to discuss expan sion, the merger bill with the National Basketball Associa tion, national television, labor negotiations, management pen sion plan and playoff proce dures.

title: Thieu to Address Congress in Saigon
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 8President Nguyen Van Thieu is preparing to address a special joint session of both houses of South Vietnam's Na tional Assembly next Tues day, authoritative Government sources said today.

title: Haitian Folklore Inspires Sculptures
description: The devils, monsters and sirens that provide the dis tinctive imagery for the sculptures of the Haitan art ist Murat Brierre, now on view at the Roko Gallery, 90 East 10th Street, are derived from the island's folklore and voodoo cults, subjects I am not competent to dis cuss. But simply as powerful graphic images, the sculp tures work marvelously well. Mr. Brierre, who is 34 years old, creates large and intri cate metal cutouts. The metal comes from steel oil drums, the most readily available source of the material on the island. The patina of rust the sculptures have acquired of fers a kind of brusque coun terpoint to the ingenious forms.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (AP)The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation probably will earn enough to pay off the Gov ernmentguaranteed loans Congress authorized after a storm of debate in 1971, the General Accounting Office reported today.

title: Remodeling Japan
description: With their twelfth general election since the end of World War II, Japan's voters tomorrow will be stepping onto a new plateau of national development. Obsessed no longer with rebuilding their oncedevastated country, their society and their pride, they are concerned now about how to consolidate and rationalize what they have already built.

title: Florida Becomes First to Reinstate The Death Penalty
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Dec. 8 (AP)  Gov. Reubin Askew signed the death penalty into law today making Florida the first state in the nation to restore capital punishment.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: As Anthony Lewis noted (column Nov. 25) in connection with the Popkin incarceration, the law should try to balance the social interests involved on one hand the claim to privacy and, on the other, the duty of a citizen to testify. It is axiomatic that no nation can endure upon volunteered evidence alone. To assure its survival, inquiry judicial or legislativemay not be thwarted by taciturn witnesses.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Recently, many of us were openly critical of Dr. Scribner's behavior in Canarsie. Unfortunately, some of my fellows have seized upon this incident to call for his removal or for the denial of a renewal of Dr. Scribner's contract.

title: CONYERS TO SEEK POST OF SPEAKER
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8Rep resentative John Convers Jr. of of Michigan announced today that he would challenge Carl Albert of Oklahoma for the post of Speaker of the House.

title: People and Business
description: There aren't too many men who have spent 50 years on Wall Street, and 39 as a reg istered representative, but that describes Yale Cooper. The 68yearold broker, who still puts in a full day on the job as manager of the 580 Fifth Avenue office of Bruns, Nordeman & Co., began his career in the financial com munity in December, 1922, as a messenger for Hirsch, Lili enthal & Co., which later be came Hirsch & Co.

title: CRASH TAKES LIFE OF CONGRESSMAN
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 George Washington Collins, who was killed in the crash of an airliner in Chicago today, was first elected to Congress from Chicago's Sixth District in 1970, becoming one of the few black members of the House to represent a district with a sizable white constitu ency.

title: Gifts to Poor Mailed To Post Office Here
description: Please use this money, the letter from a young wom an to postal authorities here began, to make some child's Christmas one good day in his life  I hate Christmas time because it only empha sizes the gap between rich and poor.

title: Stocks Steady as the Dow Slips by 0.07
description: Stock prices traced an even course yesterday, as the market consoliidated after setting rec ords in leading averages during the two previous sessions.

title: IRISH VOTE TO END FAVORED STATUS FOR THE CHURCH
description: DUBLIN, Dec. 8Irish voters have decided overwhelmingly to abolish the special posi tion of the Roman Catholic Church in the Constitution.

title: Bridge: How to Spot the Three Kings Of an Opponent and Still Win
description: Avoiding an opening lead away from a king in a suit contract is an article of faith with many average players. This is not a bad rule of thumb, for such a lead will often present the declarer with a trick. It usually takes an expert who can draw the right inferences from the bidding to spot the right moment for an attacking lead from the king.

title: PRICES ARE MIXED ON AMEX AND OTC
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthe counter market finished mixed yesterday in slower trading. Brokers attributed the indif ferent performance to profit taking.

title: Notes on People
description: I could not hear horns honking or telephones ring ing, said Mrs. Luci Johnson Nugent, the daughter of for mer President Johnson, as she prepared to leave a hos pital in Austin, Tex. Mrs. Nugent said an operation on her left car had been 100 per cent successful. She also said she had tired herself out while campaigning for Bare foot Sanders for Senate. I was down to 98 pounds, said Mrs. Nugent. I was run down. I had burned the can ale at both ends  now I'm going to have to pace myself. I'm going to have to rearrange my priorities. My family will come first.

title: State Plans a Massive Survey Of Rush Hour on L.I. Highways
description: The state Department of Transportation will conduct a massive traffic survey on three Long Island highways next week, even though the roads may be clogged with drivers wno ordinarily take the ??

title: NEW JERSEY
description: NEWARK, Dec. 8Bruno J. Lucarelli, the contractor for the controversial Kawaida Towers housing project, has offered to suspend construction until Jan. 2 if demonstrators will stop picketing so that construction Workers can complete the un derpinning work on adjoining buildings.

title: Knicks to Meet 76ers
description: Cleanup crews will barely have time to sweep the col lege's peanut shells out of the Garden aisles before a fresh crowd starts arriving for the 8 o'clock game between the Knicks and 76ers.

title: Town Where Sudan Uprising Began Is Now a Way Station for Refugees
description: TORIT, the SudanThe one room hut with the hiphigh mud wall and the step roof made of oil canisters was in habited by 43 women, men and children belonging to about 10 families.

title: Trio's Concert Postponed
description: A concert scheduled for to night by Alexander Schneider, Leslie Parnas and Murray Per ahia at Washington Irving High School has been postponed un til March 31. Tickets will be honored on the later date.

title: Kuhn Rebuts Charge He Broke Confidence
description: Bowie Kuhn, the baseball commissioner, denied yester day he had breached an understanding between play ers and club owners when he disclosed the owner's pro posals in Hawaii last week.

title: Peace Talks Continue
description: The secret talks on a Viet nam ceasefire continued in Paris yesterday, but there was no sign of an early breakthrough. Page 3.

title: Dutch Fireanns Blast Kills 2
description: MUIDEN, the Netherlands, Dec. 8 (Reuters)An explosion in the gunpowder drying room of the Netherlands' largest ex plosives factory killed at least two persons today and injured 18 others. The blast tore the roof off the building and shat tered heavy machinery. Both the dead were Moroccans.

title: 3 Senators Press Halt in Strip Mining
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8  Three leading Senate Demo crats joined today in denounc ing as administrative arro gance the apparent refusal of Secretary of the Interior Rog ers C. B. Morton to honor a Senate request for a mora torium on the ieasing of Gov ernment controlled coal re serves in the Far West, where energy and environmental groups are engaged in a dispute over strip mining.

title: Commuters Begin to Find Change in Routine Tiring
description: ST. JAMES, L. I., Dec. 8  Long Island commuters, after a week of struggling with the problem of getting to and from New York in the railroad strike, are beginning to feel the strain.

title: TALKS ARE EXTENDED BY COFFEE COUNCIL
description: LONDON, Dec. 8 (UPI)  Members of the International Coffee Organization extended negotiations today for a mar keting plan for the last nine months of the 197273 coffee year.

title: Tears and Reminiscing Meet News of Closing
description: Listen, listen, said the young man with his necktie askew in the Life editorial office on the 29th floor of the TimeLife Building.

title: Passion Play Fills Life of Small Town in Brazil and Brings Tourists
description: NOVA JERUSALEM, Bra zil  The villagers used to throw insults and stones at Judas for betraying Jesus but all this has changed since the miracle.

title: TRUMAN'S HEART SHOWS SLIGHT GAIN
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Dec. 8 Doctors reported today that Harry S. Truman had shown slight improvement in his struggle with lung congestion and heart irregularity, but em phasized that he remained critically ill.

title: Stars Take 12895 Victory

title: NETS TOP SQUIRES ON CARTER'S SHOT
Rail TonMileage Up 13%
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8The Association of American Rail roads reported freight traffic on United States railroads in the latest week was an esti mated 16.3 billion tonmiles, 13 per cent above the corre sponding 1971 week, The A.A.R. also reported rail car loadings in the latest week totaled 536,130, up 11.3 per cent from 1971.

title: Merger News

title: Earthquake in Wyoming
description: THERMOPOLIS, Wyo., Dec. 8 (AP)An earthquake cen tered at Thermopolis shook this community for five seconds to day and was felt as far away as Lander, but only minor dam age was reported. The National Earthquake Center at Boulder, Colo., said that the quake at 11:47 A.M. measured 4 on the Richter scale.

title: LoanShark Ring Broken, Ledgers Seized in Suffolk

title: New Procedures Tested In Obscenity Arrests
description: The owner of a Times Square bookstore was arrest ed on an obscenity charge last night in what the police described as the first test of new procedure to satisfy a recent court decision that a policeman is not qualified to make a legal judgement of obscenity in seizing peep show films.

title: License Denied ScottoAided Concern
description: The New York Court of Ap peals has upheld a Waterfront Commission decision to deny a stevedoring license to the port's largest marinecarpentry com pany, whose principals alleged ly obtained a $245,000 loan with the aid of Anthony Scotto, the Brooklyn longshore union leader.

title: The Invocation
description: BAL HARBOUR, Fla.Almighty God, we thank Thee for a free land where private property is a sacred reality. For millions it is not. Among us, Lord, are millions who own no home, no land, and no business. Owning nailing, they demand everything from a paternal government. Dear Lord, we fear they are potential victims for the panacea of Socialism.

title: Algerian Company Agrees To Sell Gas to the U.S.
description: ALGIERS, Dec. 8  The Al geria Oil and Gas Company (Sonatrach) signed a contract yesterday in Algiers for the sale of 4.5 billion cubic meters of Algerian natural gas a year to tthe Tanhamble Eastern Pipe line Company over a 20year period.

title: U.M.W. Election Differences Stay Above the Ground
description: DUTY, Va., Dec. 8When the siren screamed, the electric carts rattled into the big hole in the mountain. For the next eight hours, the miners on the night shift would work side by side.

title: Sports of The Times
description: As he goes from city to city, most people see him only on the varnished courts of the National Basketball Asso ciation arenas. And he is something to see. In a game of redwoods, he is a scrub pine, but Nate (Tiny) Archibald is leading the N.B.A. in scoring with a 34point average and in assists with an average of more than 11 a game. In the programs, he is listed at 6 feet 1 inch and 160 pounds, but he appears smaller. On the backs of the Kansas City Omaha Kings' red, white and blue uniforms, the players' names are sewn under the numbers. Under his 10 the lettering resembles a wide mod belt on a shirt that is too big for him as he darts between bigger players, flicking his lefthanded jump shot or hanging suspended on his drives. He performs without expres sion, as if he were a mechanical toy. But even with a thin mustache on his boyish face, he appears younger than 24.

title: R.I.P. Life
description: Life is dead, victim of competition from TV and of the murderous pressure of skyrocketing production and distribution costs that killed Look magazine only fifteen months ago. Ironically, Henry R. Luce's pioneering ven ture in photojournalism will close its 36year career with a yearend double issue on the joys of Christmas, a lugubrious goingaway remembrance for the hundreds of talented editors, photographers and other staff mem bers jolted onto the idle list.

title: $40,000 Payroll Stolen
description: The $40,000 payroll of the Central Brooklyn Model Cities office was stolen yesterday at 2:22 P.M. by a lone gunman outside the agent's offices at 150 Hinsdale Street in the East New York section. The robber fired one shot, which hit a window in the car with three women employes who were delivering the payroll, then grabbed the payroll envelope and fled with the checks.

title: G.M. ASKS PRICE RISE OF 3% ON '73 MODELS
description: DETROIT, Dec. 8 (AP)The General Motors Corporation asked the Price Commission to day for permission to raise prices 3 per cent on its 1973 model cars and trucks and options.

title: U.S. Is Continuing Aid to the Chilean Armed Forces
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8Ad ministration officials said to day that the United States was continuing military aid to Chile under a $10million credit agreement despite its refusal to help finance Chilean food imports and economic projects.

title: The Medical Police
description: My personal experience enables me to understand a serious danger threat ening many Soviet intellectuals. Five times I was confined against my will in psychiatric institutions in the U.S.S.R. In 1949 I was arrested for the first time; certain poems I had written and recited to friends were considered antiSoviet. Arrested in Chernovits, interrogated in Moscow's Lubyanka Prison, sent to the Serbsky Institute for psychiatric examination, I was then held in Leningrad Prison Psychiatric Hospital for a year before being banished to Karaganda. Under Stalin, confinement in a mental hos pital probably saved me, as well as others, from the worse fate of long terms in labor camps.

description: $1.7Billion Rise Asked for Colleges

title: President Whatsizname
description: The old hoax about John Hanson as first President of the United States, which for more than seventy years has been used to cement Maryland's large SwedishAmerican population to the Republican party, has now resurfaced. The United States Postal Service (no longer in politics) has put out a duo of memorial postal cards respectively labeled John Hanson  Patriot, and, to glorify him by association, Paul Revere  Patriot. This exal tation of Hanson is based on a per version of history that would strike the Founding Fathers dumb with amazement.

description: John Butler is one of those curious American choreog raphers who are better known outside America than inside America. This is not, of course, entirely true, be cause Mr. Butler is repre sented in many American repertories. However, a great deal of his work is done in Europe and now, occa sionally, in Israel.

In car own ership per capita, a significant figure once notably high here, France, Sweden, Germany, Switzerland and Denmark are now higher and others approaching.

title: Screen: Stan Vanderbeek's Underground Shorts:Retrospective Offered At the Film Forum 15 Years Are Covered in Valuable Show
description: A good demonstration of the kind of service that a small independent movie theater can perform is offered by the 15-year retrospective of Stan Vanderbeek's work that opened last night at the Film Forum.Of course, Vanderbeek lends himself to such treatment. Of the 11 films on the program, the longest ("You Do." made in 1971) runs for only 12 minutes. But it is always valuable to see what has been going on in an artist's mind over a long period of great productivity. In this case, I only wish that more had been going on.Stan Vanderbeek, born in 1931, belongs in the middle generation of the independent American cinema, and he has long been one of its best-known film makers. I suspect that a good many New York moviegoers who may never have heard of underground film know something of collage animation solely through a slightly famous and very funny "no smoking" trailer that Vanderbeek did about 10 years ago for the Bleecker Street Cinema.Collage animation, an animation of previously drawn or photographed pictures, is probably Vanderbeek's most widely seen specialty. But he is a very active experimentalist in film-making (and film projection, as in his bubble-shaped Movie-Drome, built at Stony Point, N.Y.), and the Film Forum show includes various kinds of computerized animation, as well as two films, "Summit" (1963) and "Video Space" (1972), that combine live actors and dancers with animation.The problem is that, for all the experimentation, there seems to have been relatively little growth in personal vision. Despite its exploitation of new electronic technology, "Who Ho Rays," made in 1972, is if anything safer and less inventive than "Mankinda," made in 1957, very nearly at the start of Vanderbeek's career.But at least one of the recent films, "Symmetricks," an elaboration of brilliant white lines and flashes against a black background, made in collaboration with Wade Shaw at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, is very good. And "Poem Field #8," one of several films made together with the computer scientist Ken Knowlton in the mid-1960's, has an agreeable decorative agility that suggests considerable delight in the medium.My favorite, however, is an early film, "See Saw Seems" (1962). It is full of graceful transformations by which, for example, a footbridge becomes an eye that opens to a path that leads to a glowing flower that becomes a body that becomes a gentle landscape, and so on and on. It is all like a pleasant footnote to surrealist art. And it is perhaps in such a minor, by no means dishonorable, position that Stan Vanderbeek belongs.

title: Man in the News

Ster ling Cary, told a visitor the other day, I think we're in serious trouble as a nation. I saw the recent Presidential election as Amer ica's way of say ing no to the needs of urban cities and minor ities and yes to a lot of fears and prejudices that represent some of the lowest passions. I don't know when I felt we were more polarized along racial lines.

description: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 8 (UPI) The director of a Govern mentsupported society for ex convicts was arrested yester day on charges of directing a bank robbery. Turner De vaughan, 25 years old, execu tive director of the Barbwire Society, was taken in custody after an alleged accomplice named him as planner of a $3,728 robbery on Nov. 28.

title: W. R. Grace to Sell Back Marine Midland Stock
description: W. R. Grace & Co., the diversified chemical giant, an nounced yesterday that it would sell back to Marine Midland Banks, Inc., 277,406 shares of Marine Midland convertible preferred stock for $72 a share, or a total of $19.97million. This will rep resent an aftertax book loss to Grace of $7.4million.

title: Australians Are Expected To Leave Vietnam Soon
description: CANBERRA, Australia, Dec. 8 (Reuters)  Most of the 128 advisers in the Australian Army assistance group in South Viet nam should be home by the end of next month, one of the election pledges of the new Labor Government, authorita tive sources said here.

title: WINE TALK
description: American restaurateurs have long been notorious for their outrageous markups on wine. Recently, however, there have been encouraging signs that this practice is changing. Even with the astronomical increases in wine prices, many restaurants have been try ing to offer at least a few lowerpriced bottles, or inexpensive wines in carafes.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Dec. 8Yogi Berra and a few other football fans will be in the Atlantic City Convention Hall tomorrow afternoon for the annual Boardwalk Bowl game, this one between the University of Massachusetts and the University of California, Davis.

title: U,S. INDIAN BUREAU ACCUSED OF LAPSE
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8  A leader of the militant Indians who seized the Bureau of In dian Affairs headquarters here last month alleged today that documents taken from office files during the occupation showed that bureau officials had helped a white man with a criminal record for fraud enter a business partnership with a tribe of South Dakota Sioux without checking on the man's background.

title: VANDERBILT DOWNS COLUMBIA, 70 TO 61
description: NASHVILLE, Tenn., Dec. 8 (AP)Unbeaten Vanderbilt moved into the final of its in vitation basketball tournament with a 7061 victory over sur prisingly tough Columbia to night.

title: Pistons Beat Kings, 113100
description: DETROIT, Dec. 8 (AP)Bob Lanier and Dave Bing led a finalperiod surge tonight as the Detroit Pistons beat the Kansas CityOmaha Kings, 113 100, for their fifth victory in their last six games. Lanier scored 37 points and hauled in 21 rebounds. Bing had 27 points. The Kings' Nate Archi bald, the league's top scorer, finished with 32 points.

title: Another West Side Building Target of Prostitution Drive
description: Another West Side residen tial building became the target yesterday of the city's stepped up drive against prostitution and other sexoriented crimes in midtown Manhattan.

title: U.S. Keeps Up Its Bombing of DMZ Area
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sat urday, Dec. 9 (AP)North Viet namese supply routes in and near the demilitarized zone came under heavy United States bombing yesterday for the second day.

title: MRS. HOWARD E. GIBB
description: STUART, Fla., Dec. 8Mrs. Martha Schmidt Gibb, a land scape architect and writer, died Wednesday of cancer at the Baptist Hospital in Miami. She was 57 years old and lived at Sewell Point.

title: LEBANESE TROOPS FIGHT GUERRILLAS
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 8 Lebanese troops and Pales tinian guerrillas clashed in southern Lebanon today and casualties were reported on both sides. Each accused the other of starting the shooting.

title: KNICKS DEFEATED BY BRAVES, 9189
description: BUFFALO, Dec. 8In the words of the poet of north western New York State, the Knicks were buffaloed again tonight. For, the fourth time in six gaines here since the Braves joined the National Basketball Association, Buffalo tripped up the Knicks, 9189, at Memorial Auditorium.

title: HAWKS CONQUER BULLETS, 134115
description: ATLANTA, Dec. 8 (AP) Pete Maravich and Lou Hudson combined for 71 points tonight, leading the Atlanta Hawks to a 134115 National Basketball Association victory over the Baltimore Bullets. It was At lanta's fifth straight victory.Maravich scored 37 points and Hudson 34 as the Hawks took first place in the Central Division from the Bullets by a half game.The Hawks led, 5956, at the half before breaking the game open with a 3712 spurt in the third period.

title: CITY HEALTH AGENCY CITES FOOD PLACES
description: The Health Services Admin istration cited 22 more food processing establishments yes terday for failing, without valid reasons, to correct violations of the city's Health Code found on two subsequent visits by health inspectors.

title: Volpe to Brinegar
description: It is entirely possible that Claude S. Brinegar will turn out to be an excellent Secretary of Transportation and an adornment to the Cabinet. Stranger things have hap pened. Coming from as unlikely a background, Walter Hickel turned out to be an enlightened Secretary of the Interior, and John A. Volpe, the retiring Secretary of Transportation, made a good fight for busting the highway trust in spite of his early preoccupation with the building of highways. Nevertheless, Mr. Brinegar's appointment is viewed by those concerned for the environment with a skepticism bordering on dismay.

title: UNION IS ENJOINED IN OUSTER OF AIDE
description: A Federal judge has issued a preliminary injunction barring the painters' union here from ousting one of its top officials, a reformer who has earned a reputation as a foe of corrup tion.

title: SAIGON CLARIFIES STAND ON PRISONERS
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 8The spokesman for the South Vietnamese Foreign Min istry issued a clarification to day of a statement made in an interview with Foreign Minis ter Tran Van Lam. A dispatch based on the interview ap peared in today's issue of The New York Times.

title: Good Wishes From Soviet
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 8 (AP)The Soviet press wished the Apollo 17 crew men luck and success today on their moon flight. The Communist party newspaper Pravda said, Let's wish them success. Komsomolskaya Prav da, the Communist youth move ment paper, said, Three very courageous men from earth are flying to the moon. Let them have good luck on that difficult road.

title: Antiques: Key Sale of French Pieces
description: One would think they were Remhrandts, not Rieseners, by their sixfigure estimates and the feverpitch excite ment expressed over some of the choicest offerings in Mr. and Mrs. Deane Johnson's collection, which will be sold this afternoon at Sotheby Parke Bernet.

title: It's JetsandRaiders Showtime
description: If you're trying to remem member the last time the Jets won a football game from the Raiders in Oakland, forget it. It never happened.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: Restaurants are rated for their food (four stars to none) and for their atmosphere, serv ice and decor (four triangles to none.)

title: Fencik Wins Hertz Award As No. 1 Freshman at Yale
description: John Fencik of Barrington, Ill., won the Bobby Hertz Award as the most valuable player on Yale's freshman football team this season.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: O NEOF OUR leading Wall Street firms entertained a group of middlemanagement Russians last week and the conversation at one table turned to bridges and how to build them. With a fine sense of selfmockery, the Russians recounted tales of bureaucratic bungling, lost plans and endless committees and then inquired earnestly:

title: Durante in Hospital
description: SANTA MONICA, Calif., Dec. 9 (AP)Jimmy Durante, the 79yearold singercomedian, was reported to be in satisfac tory condition today at St. John's Hospital, where he was taken for observation after a fall at his Beverly Hills home. Mr. Durante had been admitted to the hospital for exhaustion last month but was subse quently released.

title: HANS WARMBRUNN
description: Hans Warmbrunn, vice pres ident and treasurer of H. D. Sheldon & Company, Inc., ex ports and imports, died of heart attack Wednesday at his home, 11050 68th Drive, For est Hills, Queens. His age was 61.

title: Law
description: Can an ample girl from a bottomless bar in the West find happiness as the life of a liquorless party?

title: Diagnosis: U.S. medicine is alive and pretty well
description: The debate in America about our healthcare system suffers from the low quality of discus sion about the key issues. Plagued by both political expediency and semantic traps (like health care is a right), our national leaders often fail to address the problems with either logic or candor.

title: Maude Didn't Leave 'em All Laughing
description: ON television a few weeks ago the 47 yearold title character of a situation comedy chose to have an abortion. In the dustfree, nonallergenic, flameproof, tidy world of television, Maude's abor tion was major surgery.

title: Forage, Maple Up, Wins Discovery by 6 Lengths
Big Son Upsets Samfire In Lincoln Downs Feature
description: LINCOLN, R. I., Dec. 9 (AP) Big Son rallied from far back and snapped Samfire's sixrace winning streak today in taking the $7,500 Burrillville Handicap in a photo finish before 9,437 fans at Lincoln Downs.

title: Rutgers Triumphs, 8672
description: STORRS, Conn., Dec. 9Led by a freshman, Phil Sellers, who scored 23 points and pulled down 16 rebounds, Rutgers de feated Connecticut 8672, to night.

title: Priscilla Ford Married to Carl E. Lincoln
description: In Christ Chapel of the Riverside Church here yes terday afternoon, Miss Pris cilla Ida Ford, daughter of Mrs, Robert L. Polk and Ben jamin Ford, both of New York, became the bride of Carl Eric Lincoln. He is the son of Mrs. Charles Lincoln of New York and the late Mr. Lincoln, a lawyer.

title: World News Briefs
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 9A truck, rammed the entrance arch of the American Embassy here yesterday morning, just miss ing a busload of diplomats' chil dren, informed sources said to day.

title: How about a Rolls Royce by mail?
description: Christmas Club payment No. 1 is already due  God help us one and all, Tiny Tim  for 1973. The Catalogue of Catalogues can help you with that problem, as well as the more immediate one of 1972. To read it is to enjoy a cut rate status trip, for there are buys here you won't find at your neighborhood shopping mall. I buy my shoes at John Lobb in London. My angling equipment comes from Hardy's, my Bond Street blue note paper from Smythson's. Try that bit of gamesmanship on some one who saw Alan Bates as Butley in London last year.

title: Embroidery Field In Midst of a Boom
description: UNION CITY  Not since 195960 has the demand for eyelet fabric been so great. And this spells good news for the residents of Union City and eight other towns in the sixmilelong strip of Hudson and Bergen Counties that runs from Jersey City north to the George Wash ington Bridge. For it is an area in which the embroidery industry is a major employer and an important element in the local economy.

title: Padre's Indicate Move Is Possible
description: SAN DIEGO, Dec. 9  The San Diego honeymoon with major league baseball is definitely over and the bride  nee Padres  could go home to stepmother. But in Washington?

title: Shorter Reviews
description: An account of George Wash ington's career as a soldier in the Revolution (with little at tention to his service in the French and Indian War and the Whiskey Rebellion), which draws upon the author's re search in writing biographies of Henry Knox and Daniel Mor gan, also on Freeman's and Flexner's biographies of Wash ington. The book is written in a straightforward style, is moderately critical of Washing ton, and not in any sense original. It will be most use ful to readers fond of military history who don't know much about military history.

title: Movie Mailbag
description: As a board member and former president of the New York Society for the Deaf, am writing on behalf of the deaf to urge that advertise ments of foreign films be re quired to state whether the films are captioned or wheth er the voices are dubbed in; and to ask that film critics give this information.

title: Double troubles of Northern Ireland A visit with the Protestant militants
description: BELFAST: The Shankill Road runs downhill for a mile or so toward the harbor, through the Protes tant workingclass district to which it gives its name. It is a drab thoroughfare of two and three story buildings occupied by small shopsbutchers, bakers, drapers, news agents, ironmongers. There are bars on the corners and gaunt, gray churches that somehow suggest unanswered, perhaps un asked, prayers, every three or four blocks. At the lower end stand factories, many of them long abandoned.

title: Ithaca Going on Road
description: Ithaca College's hockey team will wind up the home portion of its 1972 schedule this week, facing the University of Buffalo on Wednesday and Penn State on Saturday.

title: Hero Without Honor
description: World War I is Mr. White house's thing, in fact and fic tion, and this novel finds him up in the air again with the opencockpit flying machines of the R.F.C. and the Richtofen Circus. The pretext for assem bling this thumbnail history of aerial combat is an unheroic hero named Maxwell Kenyon, who leaves Newark to enlist in the B.E.F. in 1914, and becomes successively a machine gunner, an aerial gunner and a fighter pilot.

title: He Operates on Ham Radio
description: I was talking to Jack Lon don the other night. No, it could not have been the one you are thinking about. He is dead.

title: Letters:
description: The suggestion that a visit to Al bany, N.Y., has the same appeal as a visit to a leper colony (Is Albany a Capital Offense? by Linda Pembrook, Travel Section, Nov. 19) fails to con vey the real attractions this capital city has for the determined tourist. True, some of these attractions occur at rather widely spaced intervals  four years, in some cases, sort of like Oberammergaubut, common or rare, they are a source of endless merriment to native and visitor alike. Furthermore, most of them are free (at least to those who are not New York State taxpay ers). For you out there who don't have the price of a charter fare to London

title: G. M. Hayes Jr. to Wed Miss Jennifer Potter
description: CLINTON, N.Y., Dec. 9 Mr. and Mrs. Donald Brand reth Potter have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jennifer Van Cleaf Potter, to Gordon Mil lard Hayes Jr. He is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Hayes of Clin ton. The wedding is planned for July.

title: The Nation
description: If this strike ends tomorrow, said veteran Long Island Rail Road com muter Herb Greenberg, you won't see more than 50 per cent of the passengers coming back to the line.

title: Hollywood Her World
description: In the first week of April, 1939, an anxious world was hanging on the news from Lon don, Berlin and Rome as it seemed likely that Europe might again plunge into war. At the end of that fearful week Louella Parsons wrote:

title: Blues Down Flames
description: ST. LOUIS, Dec. 9 (AP) Garry Unger blasted home a short rebound in the first pe riod tonight and the St. Louis Blues hung and posted their first home game of the season. They defeated the Atlanta Flames, 21.

title: Notes: Pay Now, Go Later
description: ONE way to attract capital is to persuade a customer to pay for his purchases in advance and then spread those purchases over a long period. This device has been used in the tourist industry in various ways, one being the prepayment of leases on vacation apartments, but now the principle has been given a new twist something called the vacation license. The sponsors of this paynowgolater plan, who say they are the only people offering such a service, invite vacation ers to pay, say, $2,500 and receive re sort accommodations for one week each year for a minimum of 40 years at a stipulated resort. What makes their idea different, the promoters say, is that no investment is involved; the customer is merely buying the right to his vaca tion accommodations. The financial prin ciple, of course, remains the same: The prepaid fees provide the sponsors with capital to finance new construction, building costs being the biggest over head in the hotel business.

title: To evoke the spirit of Christmas Past
description: Goose for Christmas is a tradition that has largely disappeared. Let us try to revive it this year, not merely for reasons of nostalgia, but for a change from turkey and because a good roast goose, or better yet a gos ling, makes a rich and special meal. A small goose is essential, and it is preferable to cook two of them rather than one huge one for a large crowd. Old geese have given their breed a bad name. The two stuffings offer a choice of classic methods.

title: School Consortium a Success
description: GLADSTONE  An initia tive taken in 1971 by two pri vate schools with a few hun dred pupils each has since blossomed into a 20,000stu dent alliance designed to pool resources and ideas, save money by reducing duplica tion and offer educational op portunities beyond the reach of many schools alone.

title: Portrait of the artist as a spoiled child
description: When Richard Aldington undertook a study of D. H. Lawrence in 1927, Lawrence wrote that he would be in terested to see the result, but expect ed it to be more about Richard than about me. Since then it seems to have become a rule that the Law rence critic develops passionate feel ings about his subject and feels ob liged to cast his own deepest convic tions onto the scale where Law rence's achievement is weighed. Emile Delavenay is no exception, even though one of his announced in tentions is to offer a quasiscientific environmental study that will de scribe and circumscribe Lawrence with reference to  the specific features of the time and place of his psychological and intellectual forma tion. But his book goes beyond sim ple description to become a remark ably hostile and tendentious repre sentation both of Lawrence's intrin sic qualities and of the milieu in which they found expression.

title: Congress Can Save Itself
description: Once more, on the eve of a new Congress, reformers on Capitol Hill are preparing to challenge those encrusted practices that have increasingly discredited the national legislature. Reform, which barely got started in the last session and has a long way to go, must comeand soon if Congress is to recover its former status as a coequal branch of Government.

title: If You Go
description: looking for a local centennial celebration this coming year, you'll probably head west, to the Great Plains and beyond. That's where villages and towns, some of which grew into cities, were being settled in the eighteensev enties. There is no list of small town centennials, although the League of Municipalities is now working on one.

title: This Man Jesus; By David Melton. Illustrated by the author. 57 pp. New York: McGrawHill Book Co. $3.95. (Ages 7 to 10); Jesus; What Manner of Man Is This? By Richard Hanser. 192 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $4.95. (Ages 12 and Up)
description: More books have been written about the Man of Galilee than any other person in history, and here are two more, Neither of them unveils any really new facts about the great est story ever toldthe Fifth Gospel that could do so exists, alas, only in Irving Wallace fiction  so one is tempted to conclude that these latest books for the younger set are merely two publishers' timely replies to the current Jesus revolution.

title: Coffee, Tea or Milk? Bring Your Own
description: THE shock can be traumatic if you have come into Atlanta from the West Coast on a 747, regally wal lowing in all the amenities of mod ern conveyorbelt air travel: inflight movie, piano bar, Miss America Stew ardesses, fullcourse champagne dinner, the works. Out in Los Angeles they had never even heard of Air South, except to assure you that, according to a time table, it had the quickest connection in Atlanta for St. Simons Island, 250 miles away on the warm Georgia coast. So you trudge the maze of corridors of Atlanta's Hartsfield International Air port until you reach the very last Eastern Air Lines gate, and sud denly it is the late nineteenforties again, Parked at the ramp is a tiny twinengine 15seater, cowering in the shadow of a San Franciscobound 747, upstaged even by the truck pumping gas into its stubby wings. A college student is taking tickets, calling many of the passengers by their first names. The copilot is stowing baggage. The captain is playing games with some body's baby.

title: Arthur Miller, Stuck With The Book
description: THHERE are two games of tugofwar going on throughout The Crea tion of the World and Other Business; one between God and the devil, the other between Arthur Miller and Arthur Miller.

title: High School Seniors Taste College Life
description: FRANKLIN TOWNSHIP Somerset County College has joined two other county col leges in the state in an ex periment that introduces high school seniors to a college environment before gradula tion.

title: Post for Moynihan Reported
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (AP) President Nixon plans to name Daniel Patrick Moynihan as Ambassador to India, diplo matic sources reported today.

title: Article 14  No Title
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 9 (AP)The Quebec Nordiques got brilliant goaltending from Jaques Leme lin and held off a determined Chicago drive in the third period tonight to score a 42 victory.

title: Two letters were more than two names
description: A voice from the past, a ghost in fact, still defining it self. She cut her name down to two letters long ago, 60 years ago now; and her sense of herself became a few glimpsed postures, the quester on the shore, the supplicant, the weaver of spells. To be so much less was still to be more than Hilda Doolittle from Beth lehem, Pa., daughter to the professor of astronomy at the state university, baptized Mo ravian, amateur of Greek. In her seventies she was yearn ing to be more still, to be whole. She invokes Isis/Iris:

title: Sandra Haynie Triumphs
description: JOHANNESBURG, Dec. 9 (Reuters)Sandra Haynie of Fort Worth, Tex., won the Ladies Sealy golf championship here today with a finalround 70 for a total of 205. Pam Bar nett of Charlotte, N. C., was second with 220.

title: U.S.SOVIET PARLEY ASKS U.N. UPGRADING
description: HANOVER, N. H., Dec. 9 (AP)Leading citizens of the United States and the Soviet Union wound up a fiveday conference here with a call for increased use of the United Nations, creation of a joint SovietAmerican chamber of commerce, and rejection of chemical, biological and nuclear warfare.

title: McKay: Rose Bowl Reward for U.S.C.
description: The struggle to be the No. 1 college football team in the nation is over and the Rose Bowl game with Ohio State on Jan. 1 is a prize for a job well done, according to John McKay, coach of the unde feated and No. 1 team, South ern California.

title: Broker's Refuge Blossoms Into Palatial Gardens
description: ANNANDALE  Water cress Farm, which embraces some of New Jersey's most magnificent gardens, is the work of a former Wall Street broker and selfmade horti cul turist.

title: Canadians Are Disturbed by a U.S. Invasion Through the Use of Data Banks
description: OTTAWA, Dec. 9A group of Federal communications ex perts said this week that Can ada was threatened with a new American invasion through the storage in United States data banks of personal infor mation about thousands of Canadians.

title: Apollo 17: Maneuvering for Descent to the Moon
description: Because of the easterly land ing site, the path that the Apol lo 17 astronauts will follow in lowering their lunar orbit before descending to the moon has been changed in one significant respect from previous flights.

title: Teachers Approve Holiday
description: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 9 (AP) Philadelphia's 285,000 public school children will get a Christmas vacation this year after all. Teachers voted this week by a 2to1 margin to change the schedule so that students will get Dec. 26 and 27 as well as Christmas day off. Originally, the pupils were to have enjoyed only Dec. 25 off because of schedule short ening from the threeweek teachers' strike in September.

title: Hi, boss, said the judge to Meade Esposito
description: One day a couple of weeks ago I was having lunch with Meade H. Esposito at Foffe's Restaurant on Montague Street in Brooklyn Heights, where Mr. Esposito combines political business with gastro nomic pleasure nearly every day. As I was about to sample the main dishit was the Veal Esposito, and it had been highly recommendeda clutch of State Supreme Court justices stopped to say hello. As the leader of the Kings County Democracy, Mr. Esposito has more to say than anyone els about who does and does not become a judge in that part of the world, and friendly judicial greetings are his due.

title: Roman Catholic Deacons Now Number Thousand
description: ROME, DEC. 9About a thousand men, most of them married, are serving as perma nent deacons in the Roman Catholic Church throughout the world.

title: L.I.R.R. WORKERS ASK JOBLESS PAY
description: Somberlooking strikers and other strikebound Long Island Rail Road workers streamed into three field offices yester day to file for unemployment benefits from the Railway Re tirement Board as the 10day old walkout continued with no negotiations and no settlement in sight.

title: Dr. Louis Hausman, Taught At Cornell Medical College
description: Dr. Louis Hausman, profes sor emeritus of clinical medi cine at Cornell Medical College, died of a coronary attack Thursday evening at his home, 1100 Park Avenue. He was 82 years old.

title: Chess. The BooBoo Brigade Gets 2 More HighLevel Recruits
description: Double errorsin which a blunder by one side is an swered with a blunder by the otherare very rare in high level chess, which makes them that much more comi cal and perplexing. But though they are rare, they occur even on the highest of levels, as Bobby Fischer and Boris Spasky proved in the 14th game of their world championship match in Rey kjavik, Iceland, last summer; Fischer let a pawn slip through his fingers on the 21st move and Spassky re turned it gratis on the 27th.

title: WELFARE APPROVED FOR 44 TEXAS NUNS
description: HOUSTON, Dec. 9,  The State Welfare Department has approved the granting of an nual welfare benefits of $70, 224 to 44 elderly Dominican nuns here, according to the Houston Post.

title: Cambodians Report Gain
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Dec. 9 (AP)  Three battalions of Cambodian infantrymen report edly pushed through Route 4 today, breaking the Commu nists' grip on a vital road link ing this capital with the sea port of Kompong Som.

title: Movie Mailbag
description: Rage, directed and su perbly acted by George C. Scott, is based upon a Utah incident of a few years ago when escaped gas resulting from some military exercises at the Dougway Proving Grounds killed a large num ber of sheep and the military attempted to suppress infor mation related thereto. In Rage, the incident takes place in Wyoming and, not only sheep, but a man (Scott) and his son are fatalities. Vincent Canby, in his review of. Rage, wrote,  Scott makes what may be the first entertainment film that is apt to inspire sympathy for several notoften appreciated minority groups  incompe tent army officers, nervegas manufacturers (and their families) and even bumbling health officials.

title: 10 Nations in Title Bobsled
description: LAKE PLACID, N. Y., Dec. 9 (AP)Teams from 10 countries have entered the world bobsled championships scheduled to start Feb. 10 at Mt. Van Hoe venberg in the Adirondacks, the only bobsled run in North America. Officials said today that Canada and Switzerland had yet to indicate whether they will compete.

title: Bullets Down Kings
description: BALTIMORE, Dec. 9 (AP) The Baltimore Bullets scored 45 points in the first quarter, then held off Nate Archibald and the Kansas CityOmaha Kings in the fourth quarter to night to gain a 120112 victory.

title: WAR ZONE CARRIER A FLOATING SCHOOL
description: ABOARD U.S.S. RANGER, in the Pacific, Dec. 9 (AP) When sailors aboard the air craft carrier Ranger off Vietnam finish their day's duty, they go to school, at Top Gun Uni versity.

title: Photography
description: PERHAPS the most sat isfying photography book of the year is Sean Callahan's The Photographs of Margaret BourkeWhite (New York Graphic Society, $15). The reason is very simple: BourkeWhite's photographs are seen in the book exact ly the way they were orig inally intended to be seen: in reproduction, and with all the enhancements of artful layout and sequencing.

title: A novel of large risks and achievement
description: The Sunlight Dialogues is an enormous book in both size and conception. Since it is also John Gardner's third novel in three years (I haven't read his first, The Resur rection, published in 1966), I as sume that it has been in the works for quite a while and that Gardner's The Wreckage of Agathon (1970) and Grendel (1971), which isolate and explore certain of its motifs and ideas, were in effect spinoffs from the larger enterprise.

title: Of Luce and God
description: To the Editor:

title: Pop
description: BONNIE RAITT: Give It Up (Warner Bros. BS 2643). Could Bonnie Raitt be the woman to fill the gap left by Janis Jop lin's death? Not that Raitt sounds like Joplin, but she's a talented singer who exudes a captivating energy. In addi tion, she plays a mean guitar and doesn't limit herself to either tender ballads or throatbusting rockers. This second album shows that John Raitt's daughter has the style and originality in I that could make her the premier female vocalist of today's rock.

title: Drama Mailbag.; What Is Your Choice?
description: A RE You Now or Have You Ever Been is a very special play. No wonder Mel Gussow got himself into pretzels, worrying about whether the actors were good mimics, whether Eric Bentley had edited as if serving up slice of life, etc.especially since, on opening night, there had been, in the audience, real witnesses witnessing themselves.

title: Mary McBride Plans May Nuptials
description: SOUTH NORWALK, Conn., Dec. 9Miss Mary Frances McBride and Bruce Edward Konrad have made plans to be married next May.

title: Sports Aide Says Israelis Are in Bad Physical Shape
description: JERUSALEM, Dec. 9 (UPI) The Education Ministry has found that Israelis are in ter rible physical shape.

title: Article 6  No Title
description: STEELEYE SPAN: Below the Salt (Chrysalis CHR 1008). There is very often a large overlap between that which is authentic and that which is dull. The mention of an album of medieval and Elizabethan songs and a cou ple of jigs will probably gen erate lumps of ice in the hearts of many a pop music fan, and not without cause. The love of authenticity can easily become an ingrown thing, with the performer car ing more devotedly for his material than for his audi ence.

title: Lottery Winnings Unclaimed
description: BOSTON, Dec. 9 (AP)More than $1.5million has been left unclaimed in the Massachu setts State Lottery, according to Dr. William E. Perrault, lot tery director.

title: Elizabeth Hein Wed to George Fear Jr.
description: ENGLEWOOD, N.J., Dec. 9Miss Elizabeth Ellen Hein, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Hein, was married here this afternoon, to George Edwin Fear Jr., son of Mrs. Arthur Felstead of Conan daigua, N.Y. The ceremony was performed in the home of the bride's parents, by Judge John Mooney of the Bergen County Juvenile and Domestic Relations Court in Hackensack.

title: William Compton Jr. Dies; An Aide of Kidder Peabody
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Dec. 9 William Randolph Compton Jr., in recent years with the investment firm of Kidder, Pea body & Co at the White Plains office, died Thursday in Green wich Hospital. He was 74 years old. During World War II, Mr. Compton was chief of the cork division of the War Production Board and after the war be came executive secretary of the Cork Institute of America and of the Institute of Thread Machinery.

title: Boston Coeds Fearful After Slayings
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 9 The number of women hitch hiking without male compan ions has declined sharply in the Boston area as the police press their investigation of the slay ings of four collegeage women, at least three of whom are be lieved to have been hitchhiking.

title: Home Improvement
description: A CEDARLINED closet has for years been very high on the most wanted list of those homeowners who don't al ready have one. The aromat ic smell of the cedar wood inside a closet of this kind is not only an effective moth repellent, it also lends a pleasant, fresh  smelling aroma to clothing, blankets and other items that are stored there.

title: Camellias to No. Dakota
description: SACRAMENTO, Dec. 9 (UPI) Jay Gustafson, the quarter back, passed for two touch downs and scored another on a short run today to lead North Dakota University to a 3821 victory over Cal Poly of San Luis Obispo in the Camellia Bowl. The game was for the National Collegiate Athletic As sociation's Collegiate Division Western region title.

title: Students' Demands For Change Stir Black Colleges in the South
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 9The slayings last month of two stu dents at Southern University in Baton Rouge, La., were a dramatic example of growing student unrest that is shaking the foundations of black col leges throughout the South.

title: ECONOMIC GROWTH DECLINES IN CHINA
description: HONG KONG, Dec. 4China's economic growth this year will not quite measure up to last year's performance, observers here believe.

title: Antique Cars Keep Their Owners on the Go
description: MORRISTOWN  You paid money for that? Such was Mrs. Lawrence Ashley's greeting to waht now, five years later, is her husband's impeccably re stored 1928 fourcylinder Chevrolet and an entry in numerous antiquecar shows and competitions.

title: New Deal for Aborigines
description: In a world where divisions between races seem to be widening and politicians are backpedaling on guarantees of equal rights and opportunities for all ethnic groups, the conduct of Australia's new Prime Minister should not go unmarked. When he launched the Labor party campaign last month, Gough Whitlam stressed his deep chagrin at the country's past treatment of its aborigines and made clear what he proposed to do about it if he came to power.

title: Chess Made a Name for Iceland, Which It ally Needed
description: REYKJAVIK, Iceland Oddity loves company, creates its own entourage. If you are afflicted with a rare disease, people turn up in your acquaintance who have, had it too; a flower you thought rare has been blooming all the time in a neighbor's garden; you plan a trip to a strange place and suddenly meet people who have already been there.

title: Helen Langley Barnes Is Bride In Pittsburgh of Peter Vantine
description: PITTSBURGH, Dec. 9 The Shadyside Presbyterian Church was the setting here this afternoon for the mar riage of Miss Helen Langley Barnes, daughter of Mrs. Mary Dilworth Barnes of Pittsburgh and the late Rich ard Langley Barnes, to Peter Michael Vantine, son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Raymond Van tine of Whitehall. The Rev. Robert Holland performed the ceremony.

title: Yule Lights Discouraged
description: DES MOINES, Iowa, Dec. 9 (AP)The annual Christmas home lighting contest, spon sored for years by the Jaycees and Iowa Power and Light Company, has been canceled this year. A power company official said Wednesday that one of the reasons is concern for wise use of energy.

title: Katherine M. Albert Affianced To Robert Paul Westpheling 3d
description: RYE, N. Y., Dec. 9Mr. and Mrs. John H. Albert have announced the engagerhent of their daughter, Miss Kath erine Marie Albert, to Robert Paul Westpheling 3d, son og Mr. and Mrs. Westpheling Jr. of Fulton, Ky. The wedding will take place here on March 31.

title: DEADLOCK REPORTED BY COFFEE COUNCIL
description: LONDON, (UPI)  A special eightnation committee seeking agreement on marketing of the world's coffee supplies for the first nine months of 1973 broke off talks tonight with a report that they were deadlocked over both quotas and prices.

title: JUSTICE INSTITUTE POSES QUESTIONS
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 There is something to the idea of having a National Institute of Justice.

title: STATE UNIT BACKS ELECTRIC HEATING
description: Despite the shortage of elec tric power now, a State Public Service Department staff report released yesterday concluded that heating buildings in the city with electricity is not such a bad thing in the long run.

title: Bare Ruined Chairs
description: John Gardner's review of Garry Wills's Bare Ruined Choirs. Doubt, Prophecy and Radical Religion is both amusing and preposterous, but probably less so than the book itself. Surely both men are ac quainted with the widely known fact that we understand only what we love.

title: The British Concede Defeat By Disease Infecting Elms
description: LONDON, Dec. 9The Gov ernment has decided to aban don efforts to contain a dis ease that has destroyed nearly 1.5 million elm trees in south ern Britain.

title: A jester about sorrow, but not always
description: No biographer has yet given us an unclouded look at Robert Frost's inner life, and perhaps none ever will. Despite all the posthumous books, we know not much more now than when he was alive, 10 years ago, ex cept that he was never the Universal Grandfather he was sometimes taken for. He came on with a careerist, even a paranoid streak that had him nar rowing his eyes at imaginary enemies and guarding his reputation as jeal ously as a harem.

title: Art
description: IN the current number of the Journal of the Ar chives of American Art (Volume 12, No. 2), there Is an interesting excerpt from a taped interview with Fair field Porter that Paul Cum mings conducted in 1968. (The material is drawn from the archives' oral history project.) In the course of this interview, Mr. Porter speaks of an encounter between Clement Greenberg and Wil lem, de Kooning at a time when the latter had already begun to paint his Women paintings, and of the effect of this encounter on Mr. Por ter's work artist.

title: SoltiC.S.O. means S.R.O.
description: For the last few years, critics who find time hanging heavy on their hands have been whiling it away by telling us about the decline of the sym phony orchestra. Audiences are reputed to be aging and bored, programs are naught but familiar drivel, financial status is sliding from disastrous to castas trophic. In Boston and Cleveland, where subscrip tions were once handed down from generation to generation with the reverence now accorded pro football season tickets, managements have been advertising the availability of seats, and it is by no means uncommon to find a couple of hundred empty cushions at what were once S.R.O. events. Failing the invention of imaginative gimmicks to attract the young, we are told, the orchestra will go the way of the mastodon, and the conductor will die out like the Tyrannosiurus before him. Leonard Bernstein has publicly despaired of finding the right gimmick.

title: Susan Allan Fiancee of John Evans
description: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., Dec. 9Dr. and Mrs. John Hamilton Allan have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susan Blair Allan, to John Derby Evans, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward S. Evans Jr. former ly of Grosse Pointe, Mich.

title: Miss Moore, Fashion Editor, Is a Bride Here
description: Miss Catherine Berger Moore, fashion editor of Town & Country magazine, was married here yesterday noon to S. Joseph Tankoos Jr., a real estate investor and former owner of Delmonico's, the hotel. The Rev. Kenneth O. Jones, a Presbyterian min ister, performed the ceremo ny at the home of Mr. and Mrs. John P. Birkelund, friends of the couple.

title: A Town Supervisor in Westchester Proposes to Raise His Salary $8,500, but Taxpayers Object
description: CHAPPAQUA, N. Y., Dec. 9 The Town Supervisor of New Castle has proposed an $8,500 raise for himself because he says a fulltime chairman of the board of a $290million corporation deserves it.

title: T. M. Barritt to Wed Miss Williams
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 9  Dr. George H. Williams, presi dent of American University, and Mrs. Williams have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Beth Williams, to Thomas More Barritt son of Dr. and Mrs. A. Sidney Barritt of Brooklyn and Hampton Bays, L. I.

title: Woman Is a Stay at Home
description: SPARTANBURG, S.C. (AP) Although Mrs. Elsie Holland has filed an estimated 7,000 passport applications on behalf of area travelers in her 11 years with the Spartanburg County Clerk of Court's office, she herself has never been out side the United States.

title: St. Louis Soccer Victor
description: ATHENS, Ohio, Dec. 9 (UPI) St. Louis University defeated Ohio University, 31, today in the third round of the National Collegiate soccer champion ship.

title: Article 9  No Title
description: ITHACA, N. Y., Dec. 9 (AP) Cornell's hockey team routed Brown, 82, tonight. The Big Red took advantage of seven consecutive Brown penalties to blow the game open. Doug Mar rett and Steve Bajinski led Cor nell with two goals each.

title: MARKETS IN REVIEW
description: The DowJones industrial average, which has made a habit lately of marching on to record closing highs, did it again last week. On Thursday the Dow finished at 1,033.26up more than 9 points for the weekand it ended on Friday by just falling short of a new record.

title: Lithographer, at 80, Draws on the Past
description: SOUTH ORANGEIn the 18th century, the artists An tonio Canaletto and Fran cesco Guardi recorded the canals, plazas and churches of Venice for later genera tions.

title: John Miert to Wed Miss Bennett
description: FAIRFIELD, Conn., Dec. 9  Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Donald Bennett have an nounced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Geral dine Aim Bennett, to John Paul Miert of Greenwich, son of Mrs. Andrew Miert of By ram and the late Mr. Miert.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: The Soviets and the Germans, as well as the Western allies, have an appraisal of West Berlin and its fu ture different from the one C. L. Sulz berger expressed in his column in The Times of Nov. 26. The leaders in the Kremlin consider the city important enough to protect in their adherence to the recent fourpower agreement. This pact reaffirms more strongly than any statement since 1949 the respon sibility which they share for the city.

title: Letters:
description: Nowhere in the Goreme article by Jason Marks (In Goreme, a Turkish Flag Flies Over an Otherworldly Land scape, Travel Section, Nov. 5) is there a single word about Armenians. Those church caves he described are Arme nian church caves, but the word Ar menian has been erased from the Turk ish language.

title: Miss Getsinger Fiancee
description: Mr. and Mrs. Gordon T. Getsinger of Ronda, N.C., and Edgartown, Mass., have an nounced here the engagement of their daughter, Miss Karen Bunker Getsinger, to Timothy Metcalf Bontecou, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jesse Bontecou of Milibrook, N. Y.

title: TRANSPORTATION
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 The railroad that sings Christ mas carols is doing very well.

title: Edith Emily Schneider Married In Garden City to Jean L. Rogues
description: GARDEN CITY, L. I., Dec. 9In the Cathedral of the incarnation here this after noon, Miss Edith Emily Schneider, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick H. Schnei der, was married to Jean Louis Rogues, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Rogues of Tou louse, France.

title: Integration: The Lost Momentum
description: We need no reminder that momen tum has been lost in desegregating the schools, that partisan political ad vantage has superseded principle as the arbiter of racial discrimination, and that children continue to be victims of an adult society that imposes its preju dice on the next generation. The ques tion is, What do we do now?

title: Break in Phone Cable Curbs U. N. Activities
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 9 (AP)A telephone cable break cut at least 600 circuits into the United Na tions yesterday tying the world organization in knots and providing many diplomats an excuse to give up early for the weekend.

title: All Dead on Pakistan Plane
description: RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, Dec. 9 (Reuters)The wreckage of the Pakistani airliner that crashed in the foothills of the Himalayas yesterday was found today, and authorities said that none of the 33 aboard had sur vived. There were no foreign ers among the 28 passengers and 5 crewmen, a spokesman for Pakistan International Air lines said.

title: 2 NIXON AIDES GET SUBCABINET JOBS
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 President Nixon announced to day the nomination of two staff aides for key Administration subCabinet posts and also is sued, through his spokesman, a strong defense of Claude S. Brinegar, his nominee as Secre tary of Transportation.

title: Schools Push Togetherness
description: ENGLEWOODThe Engle wood School for Boys and Dwight School, a neighboring institution for girls, will cap a 10year process of growing closer together by naming one headmaster for the two schools next year.

title: U.S. DEPORTATION OF SYRIAN FOUGHT
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex. Dec. 9 A man who says he is a for mer Arab guerrilla leader is in prison here awaiting a decision by the United States Govern ment on his request for asylum. He said that if he is deported to his native country, Syria, he would face certain death.

title: Yugoslav Bridge Completed
description: TITOGRAD, Yugoslavia, Dec. 9 (AP)Europe's highest bridge was completed yesterday, 14 miles north of Titograd in southernmost Yugoslavia. The bridge spans two mountains, stands 720 feet over a canyon, is 1,640 feet long and was built for a railroad line now under construction.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: The call for a reconsidera tion of the 4 per cent un employment goal should come as no surprise, given our inability to achieve that objective even in periods of sustained growth and pros perity.

title: Indiana Beats Kentucky
description: BLOOMINGTON, Ind., Dec. 9 (UPI)John Kamstra, a sopho more, hit two layups and John Ritter sank two free throws in the final 2 minutes today to lead Indiana to a 6458 victory over Kentucky.

title: Tradition Shelved By Triangle Club
description: PRINCETON  Princeton University's Triangle Club, the undergraduate organiza tion that has been staging an original musical show every year since 1893, is sending this year's produc tion, Blue Genes, on a Christmas tour that will take the company as far west as Kansas City.

title: World News Briefs
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Dec. 8 The United States has called on South Korea for the second time in less than 10 days to buy more American goods to help improve Seoul's trade defi cit, estimated at $250million this year.

title: Sister Jane Takes Over at St. Joseph's
description: PATERSONA blueeyed, 37yearold Sister of Charity has been named administra tor of St. Joseph's Hospital here, the nation's oldest in dustrial city.

title: Howard Grubbs Retires
description: DALLAS, Dec. 9 (UPI) Howard Grubbs, executive sec retary of the Southwest Con ference since 1930, announced his retirement today, effective Sept. 1, 1973

title: Art
description: FOR many decades be fore World War II, the School of Paris gave birth to some of the most wonderful moments in the history of painting. Aft er the war, it collapsed ut terly. We have had 20 years to accustom ourselves to the debacle, but it still rather boggles the mind. For not only did the tradition of modern Parisian masters stretching from Ingres and Delacroix to Picasso and Matisse come to a dead halt, but even accomplishments of a minor sort began to prove elusive. The best of a lack luster generation  like de Stal or Tapis  failed to realize a fraction of their early promise, and many of their compatriots hadn't much promise to start with and made careers of produc the most depressing Junk.

title: SOVIET PLEDGES SUPPORT TO CHILE
description: MOSCOW, Sunday, Dec. 10 The Soviet Union today pledged continued political and eco nomic support for Chile as President Salvador Allende Gos sens ended a fourday visit.

title: A New Anticrime Plan Is Tested in Brooklyn
description: A new kind of crimefight ing idea called cop on the block  a program de signed to test the feasibility of having police officers spend part of their normal work scheddle on foot patrol is under way in the Bed fordStuyvesant section of Brooklyn, at the 81st Police Precinct.

title: Letters
description: We would like to call at tention to an unfortunate omission in Christopher Mun nion's otherwise fine article, If Idi Amin of Uganda is a madman, he's a cunning one, (Nov. 12).

title: Women's Legal Fund Urges Revision of the Rape Laws
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (AP) The Women's Legal Defense Fund has called for revision of rape laws, saying that rape is the only violent crime in which victims are required to convince the jury that they vigorously tried to fight off their attacker.

title: Fish Market In Cresskill Also Serves As Caterer
description: CRESSKILL  John Kel sey runs a successful fish market here (it is called Skip's), caters everything from breakfasts for 25 to weddings for 500 and, on his two days off during what is often a 90hour work week, heads for Montauk Point, L.I., to tend to his boats and lobster pots.

title: Pop
description: GUESS WHO: Live at the Paramount (RCA LSP 4779), The Guess Who are one of the alltime great pop groups. They made a string of eight or ten bit singles that were unbeatable  catchy, alive, wellstrurtured, intelligent  the kind of records that make you turn up your radio the first time you hear them and sing along on the choruses the second time.

title: Nicklaus Files Entry In Los Angeles Open
description: LOS ANGELES (AP)Jack Nicklaus has entered the Glen Campbell Los Angeles open for the first time in six years.

title: Golden Swingers
description: Connie and her dilettante writer husband Peter have re conditioned an abandoned mon astery at Cuernavaca as an amusing hideaway. Jane and Hal, their closest friends and also happily married, arrive for an extended visit. These four are all terribly familiar with Mondrian, vitello tonnato. Braque, CapodiMonte, des sert plates, Zurbarn, German, Spanish, the Beauvais Tapes tries, Salade Gadski, Eugne Berman ashtrays, etc.a knowledge they continually share with one another in their conversation and with the reader in their thoughts. (Some times, to be certain that their points get across, they skillfully append brief explanations to their references; the same goes for their pleasantries. In addi tion, Jane talks rather like a fe male Sheridan Whiteside, even borrowing his famous entrance line when other words fan her.)

title: Eucalyptus Tree Seen as Source of Pulp
description: LABELLE, Fla., Dec. 9An experiment is under way in southern Florida to plant and harvest Australian eucalyptus trees as raw material for the pulp and paper mills of north ern Florida.

title: ALFRED T. GLASSETT, A CIVIL ENGINEER, 72
description: POMPANO BEACH, Fla., Dec. 9Alfred T. Glassett, construc tion executive and former pres ident of the W. J. Barney Cor poration of New York, died last Sunday at his home here. He was 72 years old.

title: Views of Review; Hirschfeld (correct)
description: The article in The Week in Review, Dec. 3, under the heading PietaThe Mark of the Master, was not fit to print as is because of the gross mis spelling of Al Hirschfeld as Hershfeld.
