I was shocked to realize that such an editor could be found in The Times, which has been printing the name of our great caricaturist thousands of times in the Sunday Arts and Leisure section.

title: Toll in Chicago Crash Rises to 45 as 2 More Bodies Are Found
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 9Firemen digging through the wreckage of a United Air Lines plane and the rubble of the houses it crashed into yesterday found two more bodies today.

title: Gulls Called Menace to School in Kings Park
description: KINGS PARK, L. I.In a scene reminiscent of the Al fred Hitchcock film, The Birds, hundreds of gulls are infesting the Indian Head ele mentary school groundsat tracted by a controversial Smithtown garbage dump lo cated next door.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: We read that India's Foreign Mini ster has made a statement In Parlia ment that in effect proposes friend ship and cooperation with the United States. While Swaran Singh's state ment is certainly welcome, our peo ple in Washington should not be over come by euphoria, in view of the rec ord of unfriendly moves and state ments by Indian leaders critical of this country.

title: Headliners
description: Not for the first time, Santa Clausin the person of St. Nicholaslast week set a standard for the exchange of Christmas presents. To wit: It is more blessed to be given than to receive. In a ceremony Tuesday, his feast day, relics of St. Nicholas, including tiny fragments of his skull, were presented to a Greek Orthodox church in Queens by the Roman Catholic Church, St. Nicholas was a fourthcentury bishop in Asia Minor, but after the schism between Eastern and Western branches of the church, his body was trans ported to Italy. Legends of his good works, combined with elements from German folklore, led eventually to the cre ation of Santa Claus.

title: Tenants Warned On Window Gates
description: The city's Housing and Development Administration has cautioned the public against the hazards of illegal fireescape window gates and has urged manufacturers to produce cheaper, legal ones.

title: Art
description: IT Is unlikely that large numbers of people are going to beat a path from New York to New Brunswick, N. J., to see Thomas Hart Benton: A Retrospective of His Early Years, 19071929 at the Rutgers University Art Gal lery. But I found it an ab sorbing exhibition, partly for reasons having to do with experience in a preWorld War II art school, where confusions that seem to have beset Mr. Benton much ear lier were still being spawned.

title: M.M. Ratner to Wed Miss Bonnie H. Sher
description: Mr. and Mrs. Louis K. Sher of New York, Beverly Hills, Calif., and Hallandale, Fla., have announced the engage ment of their daughter, Miss Bonnie Hope Sher, to Mi chael M. Ratner, son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Ratner of Minneapolis.

title: Fundamentals
description: As December carries the year toward its close and daylight shrinks toward its minimum, the earth is re vealed in all its ageless dignity. Spring gave it a fresh ness and a budding sense of green. Summer clad the hills with leaves that hid the scars of time. Autumn dazzled the eye with color and bespangled even the winds.

title: LETTERS
description: Roger Klein's smug brush off of consumerism (Nov. 26) is nauseating.

title: Lemaire Paces 21 Canadien Victory Over Seals
description: MONTREAL, Dec. 9 (UPI) Jacques Lemaire scored his 24th goal and added an assist tonight as the Montreal Cana diens defeated the California Golden Seals, 21.

title: Cemeteries Open Gates To Recreational Pursuits
description: HILLSIDE, Ill., Dec. 9The winds of change are beginning to blow past the ponderous gates of the hitherto sacro sanct graveyardmaking it more of a place for the living.

title: MAN FOUND HANGED IN A BROOKLYN JAIL
description: A 27yearold inmate at the Brooklyn House of Detention committed suicide yesterday by hanging himself, prison offi cials reported.

title: While Misnamed Greenland Plays fog a Draw With the Ice
description: ALMOST an even 1,000 years ago a quarrelsome Viking named Eirike Porvaldsson (Eric the Red) managed to get himself expelled (on charges of manslaughter) first from his native Norway and then from his island of exile, Iceland. Forced to move even farther west, to the southwest tip of another, vaster island, and being a budding huckster, he brazen ly dubbed the icy, rocky, thoroughly inhospitable new place Greenland. Then he returned to Iceland, gathered up boatloads of families with their livestock and took them to settle in Greenland, where they naive ly believed they would find warm pastures and forests.

title: Drama Mailbag.
description: With plays by Gorky and O'Neill presently on Broad way, it seems timely to re call that our leading play wright greatly admired the Russian author. When O'Neill won the Nobel Prize in 1936 (chiefly, he thought, for Mourning Becomes Elec tra), he agreed with Sin clair Lewis, another Nobel laureate, that it was a damned shame Gorky never got the prize. When he died [early in 1936] I wrote a trib ute for the Soviet magazine in New York which exactly expressed my opinion that he had been the top of all living writers.

title: LETTERS
description: The way he writes, you wonder it Roger Klein is a real human being living in a real U.S.A., buying real cars and appliances, trying to live a fruitful, safe, healthy, fi nancially efficient life, like the rest of us aggravated mortals.

title: Sabbath Law Put to Test By Stores In Nassau
description: CEDARHURST, L. I.  A controversy over whether merchants should be open on Sundays has reached the boil ing stage in this South Shore community, where customers often come from all over the island to shop.

title: Television
description: TRANSFERRING theatri cal productions to tele vision has always pre sented problems. The experience of sitting in a theater is entirely different from the experience of watch ing a small screen at home. Adjustments have to be made. The problems are tied to the quality and quantity of those adjustments.

title: L. I. Town Meeting Tomorrow
description: Governor Rockefeller's statewide town meetings conclude tomorrow with visits to Hauppauge and Binghamton to listen to tax payers' complaints and to ideas Mr. Rockefeller says may be considered in the preparation of his 1973 legis lative program and annual message to the Legislature.

title: Brennan Reflects On '68 Accusation
description: PRINCETON  Governor Cahill signed into law last week a bill establishing a permanent statewide grand jury. The jury, which has been described as an effective tool in combating organized crime and public corruption in New Jersey, was set up on a temporary basis in 1968.

title: Shorter Reviews
description: A selection of Miss Van Horne's syndicated columns, which appear here in The New York Post. Always a pleasure to read, she is a witty and so cially sensitive writer, although with a weakness for the excited superlative.

title: The World
description: WASHINGTON  When Salvador Allende Gossens, the Socialist Presi dent of Chile, arrived in New York last Sunday, there was no American official on hand to welcome him. The White House apparently even ignored a message of greetings radioed by Mr. Allende to President Nixon when the plane entered United States air space.

title: TRANSPORTATION
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 9Exces sive speed by one train and failure to follow prescribed safety procedures by the crew of the other were blamed this week for the col lision of two Illinois Central Gulf Railroad commuter trains Oct. 30.

title: Village Church Rebuilding After Fire
description: Out of its own ashes, St. John's of the Village, a 125 yearold church, is rising again.

title: Hempstead and U.S. Agree on Housing
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I.  A lengthy controversy between officials of The Town of Hempstead and the United States Department of Hous ing and Urban Development was resolved last week when an agreement was reached on proposals for 325 Federally subsidized housing units.

title: Apllo
description: HOUSTONPacing out the endless cycle of months, waxing from the finest nail paring to the full, shining disk that makes magic the night, the moon for most of humanity was a mythical thing, an object for poets, lovers, dreamers.

title: Marjorie Kramer, a Painter, Bride
description: Miss Marjorie Anne Kramer and Samuel James Thurston were married here yesterday afternoon in the chapel of the Unitarian Church of All Souls by the Rev. Walter Donald Kring.

title: JEWISH SCHOLAR HONORED BY PEERS
description: It takes about 50 years for an idea to break through and become vogue, 90  year  old Prof. Horace Meyer Kallen re marked. No one likes an in truder, particularly when he is upsetting the commonplace.

title: All classified advertisements are accepted at the discretion of the publisher.
description: Each Tuesday night, after he turns in his cab, Boris Bernard, actor, cab driver, and premier composer of personal ads, goes to Benchley's saloon to wait for The Village Voice and do a little serious hanging out. They get the first copies down there, of the new issue. Don't ask me why, but you can see people wait ing for the apartment ads. But it's not apartments Boris is looking for, it's friends:

title: Miss Quinn Engaged
description: CHADDS FORD, Pa., Dec. 9Mr. and Mrs. William G. Quinn have announced the engagement of their daugh ter, Miss AnneRoss Quinn, to Scott W. Tilden, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sydney G. Tilden of Brookville, L. I.

title: Continuous growth or no growth? What the ecologists can teach the economists
description: The intensifying debate between the pessimists and the optimists reached a peak recently with the publication of The Limits to Growth, a report prepared by an M.I.T. team headed by systems analyst Dennis L. Meadows for the Club of Rome's Project on the Predicament of Mankind. The authors, using an admittedly simplified world mod el, fed data into a computer and concluded with some confidence that, under the assumption of no major change in the present system, population and industrial growth will certainly stop within the next century, at the latest. In taking excep tion to this conclusion, those who are optimistic about future economic and population growth point out what Meadows's team had already ad mitted: the lack of hard data, the difficulty of modeling the effects of technological innovation and the impossibility of modeling changes in human value systems. In addition, some progrowth ad herents emphasize the potentially disastrous eco nomic consequences of a nogrowth policy; for in stance, Peter Passell and Leonard Ross, writing in this magazine last March 5, conclude: Quite simply, growth is the only way in which America will ever reduce poverty.

title: Love of Singing Stirs Oratorio Group
description: MONTCLAIR  The First Congregational Church will resound with the Hallelujah Chorus this afternoon, when the New Jersey Oratorio Society presents Handel's Messiah as its Christmas offering.

title: Blacks in Newark To Form 2 Banks
description: NEWARKTwo black groups in Newark, asking the state's largest black popula tion to share in our beliefs in the economic future of our community, have nearly completed their respective, though independent and ganize minoritycontrolled banks.

title: Music
description: ACCORDING to the bitchy inner circle of the mu sic business, Nicolai Gedda, while an ac knowledged great artist, is a dud when it comes to the ex tra curriculars of careermak ing. He'll never be box office. He doesn't know how to pro ject, said the tenor's sharp tongued former manager Ronald Wilford once in these pages. Gedda is not exactly considered a worldbeater in the art of giving interviews either. His press agent, while alluding to no problem, finds it, necessary to explain, for example, that Gedda has a wonderful sense of humor when he is relaxed. Coinci dentally, another insider re ports that the tenor does a hilarious imitation of Rich art Tucker, but take along some NoDozjust in case.

title: Movies
description: VINCENTE MINNELLI hasn't direct ed a movie since 140n a Clear Day You Can See Forever in 1970, but don't get the idea that he's sitting around singing the blues. As a matter of fact, Minnelli and independent producer Danny Dare are currently ne gotiating with Universal to do a movie biography of Bessie Smith, the great blues singer whose controversial death in an auto accident in the South in 1937 inspired Edward Albee's bitter Off Broadway play The Death of Bessie Smith in 1961. Minnelli's film will of course stress the musical side of the Bessie Smith story, although the dra matic aspects of her life and death will certainly not be ignored.

title: Gordon Watson, Mary M. Mapes Plan Marriage
description: SUFFERN, N. Y., Dec. 9 Miss Mary Marvin Mapes, the assistant to the executive vice president of SAMI, a subsidiary of Time Inc., and Gordon O. Watson, who is with the institutional sales department of Oppenheimer & Co., plan to be married March 3 in Tuxedo.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A Federal judge who authorized a $6million payout to medicine users last week in a massive antitrust damage settlement, approved similar rebates totaling nearly $890, 000 for 4,056 persons who bought the medicines in New York State.

title: Christmas Trees To Be Recycled By Raleigh, N.C.
description: RALEIGH, N.C., Dec. 9  Parks and recreation officials here are urging Raleigh citizens to trim their taxes by donating recyclable Christmas trees.

title: Swiss Cavalry Fights, And Loses, Last Battle
description: GENEVA, Dec. 9  The Swiss cavalry has lost its decisive battle. The lower house of the federal parlia ment has voted it out of ex istence.

title: Jodey P. Sills Is Betrothed
description: Miss Jodey Pamela Sills and Clifford Jay Kapel plan to be married Jan. 20.

title: HELDEN TENOR ROLES SUNG BY BRILIOTH
description: Helge Brilioth has already sung Parsifal, Florestan, Ae gisth and Tristan at the Metro politan Opera, and now, within five days, he is adding two of the Ring Heldentenor roles to his Met repertory: Siegmund in Die Walkiire Thursday night and the young Siegfried this coming Tuesday.

title: Social Announcements
description: Births

title: Kent State Beats Columbia
description: NASHVILLE, Dec. 9 CAP) Kent State took advantage of Columbia's secondhalf mis takes to gain a 6453 victory for third place in the Vander bilt invitation tournament to night.

title: Elizabeth Nickerson Is Betrothed
description: LINCOLN, Mass., Dec. 9 Mr. and Mrs. Albert L. Nick erson, formerly of Rye, N.Y., have announced the engage ment of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Nickerson, to Thomas Garfield Davis, son of Dr. and Mrs. Edwin W. Davis of Chevy Chase, Md.

title: Great Neck to Vote on Parks
description: GREAT NECK, L. I.  A surprisingly vigorous and controversial campaign has been waged here for the last four months for a commis sioner's seat on this district's Park Board. However, the election, which will be held Tuesday, has been over shadowed by a court case involving a citizen's right to view the board records.

title: Blazers Vanquish Nationals, 7 to 1, After Dogs Leave
description: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 9 (AP) Andre Lacroix scored one goal and had four assists to lead the Philadelphia Blazers to a 71 rout of the. Ottawa Na tionals in a delayed World Hockey Association game to night.

title: Approaching Lunar Orbit
description: If all goes on schedule, Apollo 17 will swing into lunar orbit today, and astronauts Cernan and Schmitt will make their perilous landing in the target area of the moon's northeast quadrant tomorrow.

title: Disclosure Of Donors In Elections Is Sought
description: TRENTON  During the last few years, the ways in which political parties and their candidates finance their election campaigns have come under increasing attack across the country.

title: Air Center Changing Name
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Dec. 9 (UPI)The Air Force has an nounced that it is changing the name of Lackland Military Training Center to the Air Force Military Training Center. The center provides basic train ing for 100,000 young men and women each year.

title: St. John's Wins, 10968
description: St. John's rolled up 22 straight points in the first 11 minutes and continued with scady offensive surge to beat Georgetown, 10968, before 3,765 people in Jamaica, Queens tonight. The Redmen had a 24 2 lead at one point in the first half.

title: Drama Mailbag
description: Why do liberal critics per sist in trying to read their bourgeois values into every Russian writer who has strayed from the party line? In the anticommunist fanta sies of his article, Gorky, a Totally Good Man,  Alfred Kazin tries to convert Maxim Gorky into a bourgeois liber al! But it won't wash, even in Kazin's detergent prose and shopkeeper ethos.

title: Gardens
description: MODERN hybrid amaryllis are tops ?? winter bloom. Although a single bulb may seem like a big in vestment, starting from $5 and up, it will last for years if given the necessary care. Each bulb will produce at least one 18inch spike crowned with four huge lily like flowers. A second spike often follows.

title: State Raises Cost of Day Care and City Says 15,000 Will Pay More
description: A statewide daycare payment schedule was ordered into ef fect yesterday that the city es timated would increase fees for probably half the 30,000 chil dren currently in programs here.

title: Settlement Reached in Walkout That Shut Wonder Bread Here
description: A tentative settlement was reached last night in the strike against the I.T.T. Continental Baking Company, makers of Wonder Bread and Hostess cakes.

title: PepsiCola Boycott Urged
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (AP) The Union of Councils for Soviet Jews has called a boy cott of PepsiCola to protest the recent trade agreement concluded by Pepsico, Inc., with the Soviet Government.

title: BLACK IN NEWARK WILL HEAD POLICE
description: NEWARK, Dec. 9  Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson announced today the appointment of Lieut. Edward L. Kerr as the first black director of the city's Po lice Department.

title: Mrs. Kaufman Has Child
description: MONTVILLE, N.J., Dec. 9 A daughter was born Nov. 27 to Mr. and Mrs. Peter Kaufman at the St. Barna bus Medical Center in Liv ingston. Mrs. Kaufman is the former Miss Barbara Chester of Brooklyn.

title: The Nation
description: There is a revolution under way  It is now spreading with amaz ing rapidity, and already our laws, institutions, and social structure are changing in consequence  This is the revolution of the new generation.

title: Article 8  No Title
description: NEW HAVEN, Dec. 9Bobby Kane scored three goals and picked up two assists as the Yale hockey team defeated Boston State, 85. Phil Clark had two goals and three assists for the Elis. John Cac camo had three goals for the losers, the victory was the sec ond straight for Yale.

title: National Press Club Elects
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (AP) Donald R. Larrabee, owner of the GriffinLarrabee News Bureau, was elected yesterday as president of the National Press Club. Mr. Larrabee de feated L. Edgar Prina of the Copley News Service.

title: Iris Lerner Betrothed
description: Miss Iris R. Lerner, a reg istered representative with David J. Greene & Co., stock brokers and investment ad visers, will be married in the spring to Steven R. Lapidus an assistant district attorney in Nassau County, assigned to the Trial Bureau. Their en gagement has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Jack Newton Lerner of New York and Cedarhurst, L.I. Mr. Lerner, a lawyer here, is an arbitrator in Small Claims Court, New York County. Mr. Lapidus is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Leopold Lapidus of Woodmere, L.I. His father is an accountant.

title: Music: La Tuna de Cayey at Hunter
description: When is a tuna not a fish? When it sings and dances, Spanish style.

title: Entertainment Offered On Fifth Avenue Today
description: Fifth Avenue will be a Holiday Promenade from 1 to 5 P.M. today, closed to traffic between 34th and 57th Streets and sprinkled with free entertainment.

title: BLIND MAN ACCUSED IN ATTEMPTED RAPE
description: A 21yearold blind man was charged last night with the at tempted rape of a woman on a street corner in the Jamaica section of Queens during the day.

title: Significance Of Findings Was Ignored
description: When Dr. James B. Her rick reported the first diag nosis of a heart attack 60 years ago and pointed out that the condition need not be fatal, the importance of the Chicago physician's find ing went unrecognized.

title: Review 1  No Title
description: Good for Graham Oakley! An Eng lishman with a background in adver tising, set design and children's book illustrating, he has succeeded in cre ating a book for childrennot chil dren of all ages, but children, ages 5 to 9, give or take a few birth days. THE CHURCH MOUSE (Athe neum, $5.95) is not another sly, tongue  in  chic production in sinuating mysterious levels. It is an intelligent book, combining simplicity and sophistication, and it doesn't condescend. It is a wellin tegrated picture story, with a text almost as special as the art work.

title: Music: Choral Concert
description: It is difficult to believe that a composer of Benjamin Britten's stature would waste his time imitating or parody ing Carl Orff's Carmina Burana, but to hear Britten's Cantata Academica is to be reminded so forcefully of Orff's work that it is almost impossible to believe other wise.

title: A Temporary Freeze Strikes Bay Meadows
description: SAN MATED, Calif., Dec. 9 (UPI)  For the first time in the 38year history of the track, there were no work outs this morning at Bay Meadows because both the main oval and the training track were frozen solid.

title: $100,000 in Jewelry Theft
description: Jewelry valued at $100,000 and $12,000 in cash were stolen from an eighthfloor apartment at 36 Sutton Place South, the police reported yes terday. The burglary victim, Mrs. Lilly Deajoni, a director of the Central Women's Center, an abortion clinic, was out of town.

title: Turkey to Restore Church
description: ISTANBUL, Turkey, Dec. 9 (Reuters)The world's oldest Christian church, founded by Saint Peter in the historic city of Antioch, is to be restored, tourism officials here have announced. The Church of St. Peter was founded by the apostle on his first missionary journey after the crucifixion when Christian converts began regular meetings in a cave in the hills above the city. It has long been out of use as a church, but has been preserved as a tourist site.

title: THE U.N. SPONSORS A TOUR OF HARLEM
description: Two dozen United Nations diplomats and diplomats' wives toured Harlem yesterday to see for themselves a part of New York City that they said fas cinated and intrigued foreign visitors, who seldom see it close up.

title: Post Tops Hunter, 7060
description: Ed Fields scored 25 points and led C. W. Post College to a 7060 victory over Hunter last night at the losers' gym. Glenn Jay scored 18 points to pace the losers, who now have a 31 wonlost record. Post is 32.

title: Radiation Level Down
description: BERKELEY, Calif., Dec. 9 (UPI)The State Department of Health said today that as a result of the ending of atmos pheric nuclear testing by the United States and the Soviet Union, the amount of radiation in the atmosphere over Cali fornia decreased to 0.13 pico curies per cubic meter in Octo ber. This compares with an average of 0.31 picocuries for the previous year.

title: Revenue Sharing Bonuses for L. I.
description: WASHINGTONThe Nas sau and Suffolk County governments will get sizable windfalls in the Federal revenuesharing checks that should arrive in the mail tomorrow but any good news for the county's taxpayers may not be apparent until 1974.

title: Discovery 60 Years Ago Changed Doctors' Minds on Heart Attack Survival
description: Sixty years ago last week, Dr. James B. Herrick reported to his medical colleagues on the case of a 55yearold banker who had been his patient in Chicagoa report, he later re called, that fell like a dud.

title: Also a Few Picassos
description: When a hierarchy of the arts was established in the High Renaissance, prints were rated as one of the lowliest forms of visual expression. Even though distinguished artists from the Mannerist period to the modern age have attempted through their own etchings, lithographs and drypoints to establish printmaking as a reputable art, its lot improved little until recently.

title: St. Louis to Give Public Housing To H. U. D. Instead of Closing It
description: ST. LOUIS, Dec. 9The defi cit ridden St. Louis Housing Authority has reversed an ear lier decision to close most pub lic housing projects here and decided instead to transfer their troublesome operations to the Federal Government.

title: Views of Review
description: May I refer to the controversy about sickle cell anemia regarding the Harry Schwartz article in The Week in Re view, Nov. 5, and the letter from Dr. Arlene Bennett, Dec. 3.

title: New & Novel
description: Denny, the hero of this ap pealing first novel, has quite a bit in common with Lennie the backward giant in Steinbeck's Of Mice And Men. Like Len nie, he is strong, simplemind ed, and unpredictable around women: disaster awaits him, once his libido has been kin dled by a high school nymphet. But Mr. Hill does not head for easy melodrama. Rather, he helps the reader to sense a qual ity of life that is sad, desper ate and ultimately hopeless.

title: Most Pentagon Phones Are Out for 22 Minutes
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (AP)  The largest office building in the worldthe Pentagon, with 28,000 em ployeswas without normal telephone service for 22 min utes this week. But the De fense Department headquar ters did not lose its secure lines providing links to mili tary installations, a spokes man said, and the Washing tonMoscow hot line did not cease functioning.

title: FLORIDA'S MEDICAID OPENED TO CUBANS
description: Miami, Dec. 9 (AP)Avoid ing a court challenge, the state of Florida has agreed to open its Medicaid rolls to 18,500 Cuban refugees who had been refused assistance.

title: Gallup Poll Finds 38% of Nonvoters Were Unregistered
description: The Gallup Poll, in its search to discover why the voter turn out in the November elections was so low, released figures yesterday showing that 38 per cent of the nonvoters said they either did not bother to register or that they were prevented from doing so by residency re quirements.

title: Plan for Printing College Courses In Papers to Widen
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 9The National Endowment for the Humanities has announced plans to expand its project to offer college  level courses through newspapers.

title: Antibias Encyclical Planned by Pius XI, U.S. Paper Says
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (UPI) Pope Pius XI asked an Amer ican Jesuit to write a draft papal pronouncement condemn ing racism and antiSemitism in 1938, The National Catholic Reporter said today.

title: WASHINGTON
description: LONDON, Dec. 9It's not quite true, of course, but in the minds of a great many British subjects (and even some of the larger predicates) the man who discovered America was not Christopher Columbus or any of those adventuresome Italians but an Englishborn American citizen, Alistair Cooke of the British Broadcasting Corporation.

title: LuxuryUnit Complex for North Bergen
description: NORTH BERGEN  This Hudson County municipality will be the site of a huge luxury apartment complex that will occupy 17.7 acres of landfill on the Hudson River, at the foot of the lower Pali sades. Construction of the $100million development is expected to start in the spring, according to the de veloper, Stuart Hoff.

title: WALL STREET
description: The stereotype of the fatbellied tycoon prowling the canyons of Wall Street in quest of gullible widows and orphans to victimize with his latest financial schemes is, better or worse, part of Americana.

title: Never Saw Bormann, Argentinian Declares
description: BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 7  The man who gained worldwide fame recently as the dogged Argentine intelligence officer who had tracked down Martin Bormann, the world's most wanted Nazi war criminal, says that he has never seen Bor mann, never, in fact, even looked for him and has no knowledge of whether he is dead or alive.

title: BAREXAM FEVER GONE, BUT NOT
description: It had been a long and frus trating four months, but for 2,001 of the 2,630 recent law school graduates who took the twoday, 14hour New York State bar examination last July, the frustration came to an ec static conclusion l ast week when the Board of Law Exam iners released the list of candi dates who passed

title: Judge to Hear Cases in Brooklyn Jail
description: State Supreme Court Justice Irwin Brownstein will become a jailhouse judge at the Brooklyn House of Detention for Men during the two weeks spanning Christmas in an effort to dispose of scores of criminal cases on his calendar and ease overcrowding at the prison.

title: Article 11  No Title
description: BOSTON, Dec. 9 (AP)Paul O'Neil scored three goals and a defenseman, Vic Stanfield, made five assists tonight as Boston University overpowered Prince ton, 61.

title: Sandy Hook Pilots Association Really a Family Affair
description: LEBANONCapt. Frank J. Boslet spent 15 years in rigorous training before being licensed to practice his demanding profession, one that dates back cen turies and requires him to be on call 24 hours a day, in cluding holidays.

title: World News Briefs
description: AGANA, Guam, Dec. 9A Pan American World Airways stew ardess was among three per sons killed when an Air Force C130 transport crashed and burned at Guam Naval Air Station today.

title: World News Briefs
description: MONTREAL, Dec. 9Jacques Rose was acquitted today of a charge of kidnapping Que bec's Labor Minister, Pierre Laporte.

title: Puerto Rican Schooling Low
description: Among Puerto Ricans in Brooklyn over the age of 25, only one in six has com pleted four years of high school, according to the latest available figures from the Census Bureau.

title: Golf Final to Mrs. Handley
description: PEBBLE BEACH, Calif., Dec. 9 (UPI)Mrs, Barbara Handley, a 33yearold housewife from nearby Carmel Valley, defeated Linda Maurer of Turlock, 3 and 1, today to win the California state women's amateur golf championsip for the second year in a row.

title: A New Convention Hall for Asbury Park
description: ASBURY PARKA three year, $1millionplus restora tion of the Convention Hall, which juts seaward from the Boardwalk and is the focal point of the milelong, city owned Beachfront Prome nade, will for all practical purposes be completed dur ing the holiday season.

title: French Pupils Now to Use BallPoint or Felt Pens
description: PARIS, Dec. 9 (AP)Erench schoolchildren have been told that they no longer have to use the steel pen points and the ink well.

title: TRUMAN, BETTER, TALKS TO FAMILY
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Dec. 9 Doctors treating former Presi dent Harry S. Truman said to night that, if he continued to gain in his struggle against lung congestion and heart irregular ity, they might list his condition tomorrow as serious instead of critical.

title: Article 7  No Title
description: THE PERSUASIONS: Spread The Word (Capitol ST11101). Ghetto kids don't have parents who can spare a few hundred dollars for an electric guitar like their sub urban counterparts. But they do possess an instrument far more versatile, and that's their voices in the late 50's a cappella groups from the city streets had a vogue and the Persuasions are perhaps the only group now practic ing that almost lost art. As on their other albums, these young men show how richly exhilarating a cappella music can be and how much more talent it takes to face the public without a wall of elec tric sound blurring any vocal inadequacies.

title: Juvenile, puerile, sophomoric, jejune, nuttyand funny
description: At a time when most college humor magazine writers had regretfully left the sophomoric to the sophomores (come on now, boys, that's enough of that) and gone on to become insurance salesmen or corporation lawyers, Doug Kenney and Henry Beard, veterans of The Harvard Lampoon, were on their way to New York to put humor on the map and make some money at it. It was a curiously chancy step to take, giving grownup status to a somewhat undergraduate concept; their idea was to put out a slick stepchild of the Harvard humor magazine and call it The National Lampoon.

title: Vietnam
description: PARISAll last week, Henry Kis singer and Le Duc Tho continued their secret negotiations for a Vietnam ceasefire. The world learned each day where the White House aide and the Hanoi emissary met, what time they entered whichever private house they used, what time they emerged. Tele vision and newspapers showed them shaking hands and smiling. There were pictures of the black cat that jumped on the roof of the white car used by Mr. Kissinger.

title: A superhawk remembers, explains and defends himself
description: W. W. Rostow has written some good books. This is not one of them. Rostow, who served as an adviser to Presidents Kennedy and Johnson, 196169, proposes to write the his tory of the years 195772, as one who has had a hand in making it. This is a perfectly legitimate under taking whose ancestry stretches from Thucydides and Julius Caesar to Churchill and Eisenhower. Others, such as Bismarck, have left us a kind of political autobiography by record ing their part in the events and re flecting upon it. Rostow has done neither but has combined the two.The hybrid form, of which this book is neither the first nor likely to be the last example, is bound to make for bad history. For the discipline of the historians' craft within which the historian must labor is vitiated by the author's concern to make sure that the reader does not miss the role he has played, and to justify it. Thus the perspective from which his tory is viewed becomes distorted. What ought to be at the periphery is moved into the center, and what is placed in the center could not pos sibly have been so central as it is made to appear. Much that deserves mention in a work of history is not mentioned at all, and some in formation is so trivial as to be out of place even in an autobiography.Thus we are told that the author was in his bath when President John son called him, and that President elect Kennedy came out of his bath when Rostow called upon him. I do not doubt that these are facts, but they certainly are not historic facts because they are of no interest to posterity. Twice Rostow quotes from remarks he made at a Pugwash Con ference, and he tells us what he said at the debriefing and that he was invited to dinner by one of the Rus sian participants. Many of us have had repeatedly similar experiences without being conscious of their his toric or even autobiographical signif icance. With Vietnam on his mind, Rostow tells us: I left the White House just before noon on Jan. 2, 1969 with the hope that Nixon would decide to stay the course. One al most sees darkness at noon closing in on the President's mansion.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTONDay after day, the biographies continued to roll off White House copying machines. Pres ident Nixon last week maintained his regimen of announcements about who would be where, and who wouldn't, in his second administration. And Ronald L. Ziegler, White House press secretary, sustained his role as Master of Cere monies. In what seemed like contin uous showings of the Ten Little In dians serial, he went on clearing his throat and dropping the daily ration of guaranteed frontpage stories into wait ing notebooks and tape recorders at Key Biscayne, the White House and Camp David.

title: Spanish Jews Still in Istanbul 500 Years After the Inquisition
description: ISTANBUL, Turkey, Dec. 2Under a stone archway leading into the maze of the world's largest bazaar here, ?? man with colored slides of this picturesque city ap proached some Spanish speaking tourists.

title: Recordings
description: CONTRARY to popular rumor, classical rec ordings are alive, well and selling. How else can one explain the fact that very few significant areas of Western music have not yet received recorded documen tation? Plans are afoot for Haydn's 107 symphonies, Bach's 200 odd cantatas, Ver di's 26 operasboxed sets of all sorts are popular now as never before, especially those carrying the cachet com plete. The advantages of in tegral editions are numerous: they allow one Musician to give his personal overview of an important segment of the repertory; budgetcon scious collectors find the bar gain price tags attractive; and tempting multipledisk packages, particularly at this time of season, solve any number of giftgiving prob lemsa point that has not gone unnoticed by the record companies, judging from the recent spate of largescale, re leases.

title: New Mexico School Officials Fighting Order to Disclose Names of Deprived
description: ROSWELL, N. M., Dec. 9 School officials of this south eastern New Mexico city have requested a stay of an order by a Federal judge that would require making public the names of the parents of children enrolled here in the Title I pro gram for educationally deprived youngsters.

title: Fossil Insect Found
description: HOBART, Tasmania, Dec. 9 (Reuters)A fossil insect esti mated to be 300 million years old has been found in Tasma nia, a University of Tasmania expedition announced here.

title: Study by Water Commission Is Critical of Large Federal Projects
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 9A major Federal report on the nation's water programs finds them tangled in old laws, inconsistent Federal policies, windfall profits, rampant and nonsensical subsidies and inef fective projects that cause more problems than they solve.

title: Two without a context
description: It is hard to know what in either contemporary literature or contem porary criticism can prepare the read er adequately for these two books. Each is the work of a fastidiously lit erate senior teacher and writer, and yet neither is an entirely complete book. This has nothing to do with both books being compilations of largely unrelated essays, nor conse quently with any lack of unity binding the essays together. Perhaps it is that the books somehow lack a context, as if their authors' great fame de pended on arguments and audiences not now readily heard or seen. Books are not like wine or like customs; they do not date in quite that way, simply because a book embodies an author's voice which ages but al ways somehow preserves a quick sense of the identity that speaks and the one that is spoken to.

title: New & Novel
description: The Ice Mirror is a long ramble about mountaineering (suicide division) which leaves this strange pastime as terrifying and as inexplicable as ever. Take the case of Robert Wishart, international ly known climber, who loses his nerve on the merciless face of the Eiger and is responsible for major injuries to two of his pals. There follows depres sion on the ground, the shakes when aloft, a de rigueur siege of impotence: he's still pretty mountainshy when an offer comes to return to Switzerland and climb the Eiger again this time in the winter bliz zard season!

title: David K. Sturges To Wed Miss Kobs
description: MADISON, Conn., Dec. 9 Mr. and Mrs. Erwin Freder ick Kobs of Madison have an flounced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Carol Elizabeth Kobs, to David Kountze Sturges, son of Mrs. Frederick Reginald Lack of Southport and the late Ed ward Baker Sturges.

title: Today's New Rock Crooners
description: OVER the last few years a type of rock figure has appeared whose roots go far deeper than those of rock. Most often he or she is described as the singersongwriter, the bal ladeer, minstrel, or folk rocker.

title: Pakistan to Pirate Books
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, Dec. 9 (AP)President Zulfikar Ali Bhutto has authorized local publishers to ignore foreign copyright laws and reproduce Englishlanguage college text books because the price of im ported books is beyond the

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Pleasure of Hunting Not in the Killing
description: A short while ago on a gray afternoon on the island of Martha's Vineyard, I sat with my back against a scrub oak that overlooked a marsh, waiting for black ducks to fly by.

title: In Yugoslavia, the Partisan Look
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 9If two Yugoslav clothing designers have cor rectly sensed the mood of the time, the streets of this coun try soon should be filled with tunics, greatcoats, boots and garrison caps patterned on the uniforms worn by Presi dent Tito's partisans during World War II.

title: Law Center Is Dedicated At University of Toledo
description: TOLEDO, Ohio, Dec. 9The new $3.2million Law Center of the University of Toledo College of Law was formally dedicated today by Robert W. Meserve, president of the American Bar Association.

title: SPOTLIGHT
description: It was bloodythat's the right word for it, bloody. You had to change the way peo ple think  and that's not easy. It takes a stick of intellectual dynamite to bust them loose from the past. It was traumatic as hell, on people, on the company.

title: FUEL OIL EMPLOYES REACH WAGE ACCORD
description: Negotiators for the city's major fuel oil companies and their employes reached a tenta tive contract settlement early yesterday. The present contract is to expire at midnight Fri day.

title: Everything You About Critics
description: I January, 1973, one letter begins, I will he teaching a course in the history and culture of the 1960s. After the dec ade closed, perhaps you identified the ten or fifteen developments in film.

title: Lightships Yielding To Sea Monsters
description: CAPE MAY  The Coast Guard affectionately calls them our sea monsters. The reference is to a new kind of unmanned naviga tional aid that is taking the place of the traditional big and expensive lightships and their crews.

title: News of Boating
description: Boat racers have it easy compared to race organizers. Take the Hennessy Grand Prix, the yearly ocean power boat race held annually in Point Pleasant, N. J. Sandy Satullo won the 181mile con test in something over three hours. The next day (July 20) the race committee got together and started planning next year's race. For them it's a 12month deal, and sometimes longer. Already the Grand Prix people have held three meetings, and the 1973 race isn't scheduled until July 18. Usually officials and spon sors get together at the Kings Grant Inn, the New Jersey race headquarters, or at Bill Wishnick's New York office, since he heads the New York Offshore Power Boat Racing Association, which conducts the famous contest.

title: Article 15  No Title
description: BAKERSFIELD, Calif., Dec. 9 (AP)  Fresno City College scored a 217 upset victory over previously unbeaten Pasadena City College today to win the California junior college foot ball championship in the Potato Bowl.

title: KNICKS VANQUISH HERS, 120 TO 109
description: The Philadelphia 76ers, last in their league but warmly re garded by compassionate men, were a match for the Knicks for 14 minutes last night, but then ran out of luck and wound up losing to the New Yorkers, 120109, at Madison Square Garden bef oresurprisingly a capacity crowd of 19,694.

title: Virginia Rynne Becomes Bride Of P. L. Richard
description: TUXEDO PARK, N. Y., Dec. 9Miss Virginia Ann Rynne, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William A, Rynne, was mar ried here this afternoon to Peter Lanman Richard, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Van Buren Richard of Glen Head, L. I., and York Harbor, Me.

title: Demilitarized Zone of Vietnam Under Heavy Bombing 3d Day
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sun day, Dec. 10 (AP)American B52's kept up heavy bombing of enemy supply and troop con centrations along the demili tarized zone for the third straight day yesterday.

description: CANTON, N. Y., Dec. R (AP) Colgate, helped by two goals from Greg Post, easily defeated St. Lawrence University, 63 tonight.

title: Suffolk Upheld on Zoning Veto Power
description: The State Court of Appeals has unanimously upheld Suffolk County's right to supersede the state's general municipal law and exercise a veto over cer tain disputed townzoning changes.

title: East Texas State on Top
description: COMMERCE, Tex., Dec. 9 East Texas State, capitalizing on nine turnovers, rallied for a 2118 victory over Carson Newman (Tenn.) today in the 17th National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics Cham pion Bowl.

title: Mrs. Lawrence Gillespie, Active in Newport Society
description: NEWPORT, R.I., Dec. 9 Mrs. Irene Muriel Sherman Gillespie, long prominent in the social summer colony here, died at her home last night. She was 86 years old.

title: W.C.HANDY JR.DEAD; MUSIC PUBLISHER, 68
description: William Christopher Handy ?? son of the blues composer and head of the Handy Brothers Music Company here, died Thursday in St. Luke's Hospital. He was 68 years old and lived at 250 West 100th Street.

title: Lettet From Washington To Madison Brings $20,000
description: A letter written by George Washington to James Madison on May 5, 1789, just six days after Washington's inaugura tion, was auctioned Thursday night for $20,000. This was the second highest auction price for a letter written by Washington.

title: DICKS BOOTS FIRST IN RACE AT CALDER
description: MIAMI, Dec. 9 (AP)Neil Hellman's Dicks Boots, rally ing from last place, caught heavily favored Royal and Re gal in the final strides to score a nose victory today in the $20,000added James Bright Memorial Handicap at Calder Race Course.

title: Harvard, Yale to Row on the Nile
description: Crews from Harvard and Yale have been rowing against each other for 120 years on bodies of water such as Lake Winnepesau kee, Lake Quinsigamond, and the Hudson, Thames, Hou satonic, Connecticut and Charles Rivers. Now it's the Nile  again.

title: Jets Will See Double Again Against Raider Zone
News of Dogs
description: Kipp's Trooper Rocham beau, a 4yearold, is the American Brittany Club's na tional field trial champion. The orange  and  white dog owned by Mr. and Mrs. Thomas F. Tivnan of Saddle River, N. J., gained the title at the field trials, Nov. 18 through 22, at Ardmore, Okla.

title: Celtics Crush Cavaliers
description: BOSTON, Dec. 9 (UPI)John Havlicek scored 23 points as the Boston Celtics routed the Cleveland Cavaliers, 12388, to night at the Boston Garden.

title: Late Listings for Today's TV
description: The following information about today's television programs was not available in time to appear in Section 2:

title: Alice Marie Nolen Marries at Home
description: Miss Alice Marie Nolen was married here yesterday afternoon to Dr. Alan S. Meyer, a sociologist and di rector of the Drug Education Center of the Public Educa tion Association. Jerome Nathanson, leader of the Ethical Culture Society, per formed the ceremony at the home of the bride, who is administrative assistant to Corliss and Helen Lamb Lamont, the authors.

title: Garbage in Paris Is Causing Stench In Strike's 4th Day
description: PARIS, Dec. 9The Paris garbagemen went out on strike three days ago and the streets are starting to smell a little in the damp December air.

title: Marcos May Quit if Charter Loses
description: MANILA, Dec. 9  President Ferdinand E. Marcos says that he will consider bowing out as leader of the Philippines if the voters reject the new constitu tion he is sponsoring in a pleb iscite scheduled for Jan. 15.

title: New Women's Center in the Oranges
description: ORANGE  Women seek ing help on problems rang ing from legal rights to per sonal matters are finding information and support at the Women's Center of the Y.W.C.A. of the Oranges.

title: Towns Get Bill for Water Plan
description: OAKDALE, L.I.The pro posed study of the water re sources of the South Fork will set taxpayers back $992,000.

title: Dance
description: IT IS curiously easy to take choreographers for granted. I have known Paul Taylor's work for about 10 years now, and yet I am continually being amazed by the freshness of his talent. His company has always been a favorite of mine and I never cease to look forward to his performances. Interestingly, they always seem that little bit better than I expected. This is particu larly true of the recent sea son at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, where it seemed to me that Taylor as a dancer, Taylor as a choreographer and perhaps most of all Tay lor as a company, all reached a new high. This is quite clearly one of the major dance companies of the world.

title: LIQUOR WALKOUT HITS NONSTRIKERS
description: Gilbert Ross has been a whole sale liquor salesman selling to retail stores, taverns and res taurants for eight years.

title: Gregory H. Ward Is the Fiance Of Sylvia Grace Sirignano
description: MOUNT VERNON, N. Y., Dec. 9Mr. and Mrs. Wil liam P. Sirignano of Mount Vernon and Martha's Vine yard, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sylvia Grace Sirignano, to Gregory H. Ward, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Ward of Santa Cruz, Calif.

title: Swiss Woman on High Court
description: BERNE, Dec. 9 (Reuters) Parliament has elected the first woman member of the 30judge Federal Tribunal, the only Swiss federal court. She is Mrs. Margrit BiglerEnggenberger, a 39yearold lawyer. Swiss women won the franchise two years ago.

title: Shorter Reviews
description: To the literature of the holo caust add Isaiah Trunk's mas sive Judenrat, a study of the Jewish councils that collabo rated in Eastern Europe with the Nazis. Mr. Trunk, a his torian of Polish Jewry, has done much new research in a subject that has not exactly been ignored. Unlike some scholars, he does not utterly condemn the councils but finds that they were subjected to unbearable psychic pressures by sadistic Nazi overlords.

title: A Christmas Pilgrimage
description: MORRISTOWN  It has become something of a tra dition for the Masterwork Chorus of this town to make an annual pilgrimage to Manhattan and perform Han del's Messiah for the bene fit of New York audiences.

title: Bridge
description: In one respect bridge re sembles chess: It is necessary to look ahead and foresee the moves that an opponent will make. But instead of the clear, precise predictions that are possible for a chess grandmaster, a bridge expert must work in a foggy atmos phere polluted by psycho logical elements.

title: Susan Caulo Betrothed
description: FRANKLIN LAKES, N. J., Dec. 9Mr. and Mrs. James R. Caulo have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susan Marie Caulo, to John Joseph Purcell, son of Mrs. William Purcell of Summit and the late Mrs. Purcell.

title: PHONE COMPANY SAID TO PRACTICE SEX BIAS
description: The New York State Division of Human Rights said last week that a preliminary investigation indicated the New York Tele phone Company probably dis criminates against women in hiring.

title: Letters To the Editor
description: Hardly was the ink mildewed on Dwight Macdonald's self preening frontpage review of Luce and His Empire, when you unleashed Wilfrid Sheed on your inside front page (The Good Word: More Light on Luce, Nov. 5) to give my book still another goingover. One would have thought it an overriding concern of the Book Review editor to avoid plac ing any author, however cul pable, in such double jeopardy.

title: Movie Mailbag
description: IWAS sorry to read Vin cent Canby's unfavorable review of Play It As It Lays, but I must say I'm appalled by the tone of Foster Hirsch's moviemaga zine admonitions to Tuesday Weld.

title: Drama Mailbag.
description: There's nothing like being one of the many students of the theater in New York who believe that the theater isn't dead; who cling to the hope that there is still artistic in tegrity in our professional theater; who were excited to find that three plays of stat ure (Mourning Becomes Electra, Medea, Uncle Vanya) were going to be mounted with our finest actors (Dewhurst, Papas, Scott); who were encouraged by the thought of Circle in the Square's opening a beau tifullydesigned new theater in the lately much bemoaned theater district, and then being devastated to learn that the management's egal itarian ticket policy does not even allow us to sit in the last row (where theater stu dents usually are wont to sit) for less than $7.95.

title: Linda Ann Curtis
description: Miss Linda Ann Curtis, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kurt L. Curtis of Kew Gar dens, Queens, was married last evening to Robert, Alan Sonderman, son of Mrs. Gerhard Eric Sonderman of Greenwich, Conn., and the late Mr. Sonderman. The Rev. George Raymond Kemp performed the Episcopal ceremony at the St. Moritz.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTONAn official from Ouachita Parish, Louisiana, showed up at 8 A.M. Friday morning in the Office of Revenue Sharing in the Treasury Department. The checks containing the Federal Government's first half yearly payment to state and local gov ernments, under the new revenueshar ing program, were just being sacked for mailing. But the Louisiana official already knew how much money was being sent to his parish (the equivalent of a county in other states) and he was sure there was a mistake. The amount of the check was $321,371, which was 16.5 per cent less than the estimate he had received last fall.

title: Canadians Rescue Pilot of Plane Lost A Month in Arctic
description: YELLOWKNIFE, Northwest Territories, Dec. 8  Canadian rescuers today found the pilot of a twinengine airplane that crashed in the Canadian Arctic on Nov. 8. He was reported to be in excellent condition con sidering his ordeal.

title: WouldBe Bridegroom Jailed on Wedding Day
description: Thomas Boran was to have been married yesterday at a church in the Bronx. Instead, he found himself in jail  with his best man and two usherscharged with robbery and possession of a danger ous weapon.

title: Movies
description: IF John Huston never ac tually became a swamp pirate or a Tijuana poker shark, it is nonetheless easy to imagine him in those roles, He speaks with the rich, gentle authority of one who has experienced most that he has wished for in life, and much that he has not. In a business where tal ent tends to blossom early and all too quickly die, Hus ton has endured, a creative longevity that he attributes to the diversity of his life style. A lot of directors live almost cannibalistically, he says. They spend all their time in studios and around other motion picture makers. I've always been interested in variety.

title: WAR FOES ASSAIL PLANS ON P.O.W.'S
description: SAN DIEGO, Dec. 9Anti war activists are raising ques tions about military plans that would require each returning prisoner of war to spend at least several days, and perhaps weeks, at an overseas hospital before he sees his family or talks to newsmen.

title: ST. PETER'S TOPS KINGS, 98 TO 93
description: St. Peter's College, sparked by Harry Anderson's 24 points, recorded its third victory in four games last night with a 9893 overtime victory over Kings College of Pennsylvania at the Jersey City Armory.

title: U.S. BUSINESS ROUNDUP
description: Used car sales are run ning ahead of last year's pace and dealers around the country point to the growth of the two, three and even fourcar families as a factor.

title: Street Banker in Harlem
description: I guess one of the reasons I really like to work up in Harlem is that it's all up front.

title: Cowboys Win, 34 to 24, and Keep Wild Card Role from Giants
SmallCollege Soccer Won By So. IllinoisEdwardsville
description: EDWARDSVILLE, Ill., Dec. 9 (UPI)A goal by Chris Car enza and saves by Rick Benben in the goal gave Southern Il linois UniversityEdwardsville a 10 victory over Oneonta State University of New York today and the 1972 national national collegiate A.A. college division soccer championship.

title: Alice Kaufman to Wed
description: The engagement of Miss Alice Phoebe Kaufman to Donald Barry Schwartz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gabriel Schwartz of Woodbridge, Conn., has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Harry Z. Kaufman of Brook lyn. The prospective bride's father, a lawyer, was former ly an Assistant District At torney in Kings County.

title: Neededmore of our fine foreign policy
description: Eugene V. Rostow's Peace in the Balance is one of the first attempts by a former official of the Johnson Administration (Rostow was Under Secretary of State for Political Af fairs from 1966 to 1969) to analyze the arguments put forward by critics of recent United States foreign pol icy. It is an earnest but unconvincing performance.

title: Beame Assails Lindsay Plan for a Transit Fund
description: Controller Abraham D. Beame, staking out his political posi tion as the city's fiscal watch dog, assailed yesterday as a double borrowing scheme a proposed device to borrow money for transit construction.

title: Gonzales Reaches Final With Pasarell
description: Richard (Pancho) Gonzales won a suddendeath, finalset tiebreaker from Frew McMillan last night that defied logic and lengthened the legend of the graying 44yearold tennis great.

title: Is Anybody Here from Albion, Nebraska? Is Everybody?
description: Nebraska is, unfortunately, often passed by in the historical excitement over cowboys and Indians and the Gold Rush and Custer's Last Stand. But Nebraska is truly the Great Plains. My ancestorsrelatives whom I can re membercame west to Nebraska in caravans of covered wagons. They cut sod houses out of the virgin prairie grasses, gouged dugouts into the sides of reluctant hills. They battled grass hoppers and Indians and railroads, whitehot summer days and bonecrack ing winter cold. They helped build vil lages, towns and finally whole sprawl ing cities on that great prairie that joins horizon to horizon.

title: North Stars Blank Wings
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Dec. 9 (AP)Minnesota's third line struck for three first period goals tonight and rolled on to a 70 victory over the Detroit Red Wings. Dean Prentice scored twoi of the North Stars early goals. Cesare Maniago, goalie, posted the shutout.

title: The Talk of Ridgewood
description: RIDGEWOOD  The afflu ence of this community, long discussed by neighbors in Bergen and Passaic Counties, continues to dominate its way of life. With more than 10,300 of the 27,500 residents under the age of 19, Ridge wood reflects a youthful spirit in its business and communal life, and an approach to new problems that has the ear mark of today. While the young people complain there is not enough for them to do, lead ers of the community give much of their time to de veloping programs that will interest the youth.

title: Russians Maintain Chess Leadership In Texas Tourney
About Motor Sports
description: When Bobby Allison agreed to drive a Roger Penske car in the Indianapolis 500 next May, he had never handled an openwheel, opencockpit machine. Since then, he has tried itand just as he and Penske might have thought, he likes it. The idea of driv ing in the Indy 500 is not new to the 35 yearold Alabam an, who had it in the back of my mind since I was in high school, but the prospect of having a good ride is.

title: Views of Review
description: In The Week in Review, Nov. 12, on the education page, you assert that, All states except Hawaii raise school funds primarily through real estate taxes levied separately by each local school district.

title: Three Waes Haels For Holiday Cheer
description: TRENTON  During the Christmas season, people like to serve foods and drinks that have become a part of the symbols and pageantry of the holiday. Many of these traditional foods are centuries old.

title: Hasidic Jews, in Flowing Beards and Black Hats, Bring Religion to Golan Trenches
description: EL QUNEITRA, IsraeliOccu pied Syria, Dec. 5  Hasidic Jews bringing Hanukkah cheer to frontline Israeli troops this week made a bizarre picture as they sang and danced in bunkers and gun positions in volved in recent fighting with the Syrian Army.

title: Coins
description: THE silver anniversary of Queen Elizabeth II and Prince Philip has captured the romantic attention of people in many lands, just as did their mar riage on Nov. 20, 1947 in Westminster Abbey. It would seem just about everyone loves Britain's gracious Queen, who, as Princess Eliz abeth, married Lieut. Philip Mountbatten of the Royal Navyher handsome Greek born third cousin, 25 years ago.

title: Stamps
description: FOR those involved in the graphic arts, there's nothing like the odor of printer's ink, or the rumble of presses, or the slither and slide and clang of linecomposing machines. For those in graphic arts de voted to classic craftsthe hand engraver, for example, or the special presses that are slower in ejecting postage stamps or currency, a happy holiday is one passed in the company of the men and women activists in the an cient art of printing which, today, has made so many advances.

title: Elizabeth Widening Its Youth Job Plan
description: ELIZABETHWhat began late last spring as the Eliza beth Summer Youth Employ ment Coalition for 14to17 yearolds has grown to a yearround operation, with seven other communities added and more expected to join.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: The article Diplomacy No Aid for Some at U.N. [Nov. 26] asks why some coopera tive buildings are reluctant to sell apartments to foreign diplomats. Although the ar ticle gives some minor rea sons, it fails to mention the real and to mejustified reason: diplomatic immunity.

title: EAST BLOC TEST WORKS TOO WELL
description: WARSAW, Dec. 9One of postwar Eastern Europe's most radical experiments, the year old open border between East Germany and Poland, is being sharply curtailed as too much of a good thing.

title: Atlantic Sewage Plan Stirs Controversy
description: ATLANTIC CITY Twelve Atlantic County communities are being asked to support a proposal for a $64million re gional sewagetreatment sys tem. The proposed system, which, has arounsed contro versy, would feature a new secondarytreatment plant on City Island here and 30 miles of pipes leading to an ocean outlet two and onequarter miles off the Raleigh Avenue beach. The system would dump 30 million to 60 mil lion gallons of treated efflu ent a day into the Atlantic Ocean.

title: Rockets Strike Ulster Police Post
description: BELFAST, Northern Ire land, Dec. 9 (AP)Guerrillas attacked a police station with rockets and rifle fire today in their latest foray with Soviet made weapons.

title: Miss Elizabeth Mary Broburg Married to Tariq Khan Panni
description: PORT CHESTER, N. Y, Dec. 9Miss Elisabeth Mary Broburg and Tariq Khan Panni were married here this morning in St. Peter's Epis copal Church by the bride's father, Rev. Anselm Broburg, rector of the church. The Right Rev. Charles Alfred Voegeli, retired Bishop of Haiti, assisted.

title: The Nation
description: The two faces of Imamu Amid Barakacivic leader and revolutionary have been sharply etched this month.

title: Students Prowl the Streets to Learn About Cities
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 9 Larry Leathers and Lin da Hill, two suburban high school students on a mid night class field trip into San Francisco's seamy Ten derloin District, were, trying to interview a prostitute.

title: A $2.5Billion Program for Bell
description: NEWARK  According to the New Jersey Bell Tele phone Company, more tele phone calls per person are made in this state than in any other.

title: Students Serve the Needy
description: HACKENSACK  Chances are that most of the students elect to pursue the program because it reads like a snap threecredit course. But the majority, and Freddie Robin son of Paterson is typical, soon realize that since I've become involved, it's really cemented my commitment to volunteer work.

title: Massachusetts Beats California, Davis, 35 to 14
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Dec. 9 The National Collegiate Ath letic Association was saved the embarrassment of explain ing how a West Coast football team could be its East regional champion when the University of Massachusetts defeated the University of California, Davis, 3514, today in the ninth an nual Boardwalk Bowl game.

title: LETTERS
description: The article Debate on Outside Directors (Oct. 29) by former Associate Supreme Court Justice Arthur J. Gold berg concerns a subject of current interest and great in trinsic importance. Questions are now being raised insist ently in many quarters about the way in which public cor porations are governed.

title: Metuchen Woman Lives Life of Troubled Girls
description: METUCHEN  Mrs. Dee jay Schwartz, participating in a program geared to give interested citizens an un derstanding of what life is like for the poor and the troubled, recently lived for three days in the Trenton State Home for Girls.

title: Jobs Sought for 325 Employes of Life
description: Ralph Graves, the managing editor of Life magazine, said yesterday that two committees had been organized to seek jobs for 325 staff members who will be out of work when Life ceases publication after 36 years on Dec. 29.

title: NOW Urges Liberalizing Sex Statute To Aid Youth
description: RED BANK  The Mon mouth County chapter of the National Organization for Women urged last week that the State Legislature amend the contraception law so that control of venereal diseases and the birth rate can be more easily achieved, partli cularly by sexually active male teenagers.

title: A Homosexual Drama Enlightens Actors
description: YORKTOWN HEIGHTS, N. Y., Dec. 9Suburban fathers, play ing the roles of homosexuals in an amateur production of The Boys in the Band here, say the experience has changed their attitude toward other men.

title: Miss Brill, Editor, Is Wed to Lawyer
description: Miss Margot Price Brill, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lester H. Brill of Highland Park, III., was married here yesterday afternoon to Ed ward John Higgins Jr., son of Mrs. Higgins of Westfield, N. J., and the late Mr. Hig gins. Msgr. James Wilders performed the ceremony in the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: In all that is written about the rea sons for the poor turnout in American elections, no mention is ever made of the most important: elections are held on a fixed date, regardless of what is happening in the country or in the world. In other democracies, they are precipitated by a significant change in the balance of power, and people vote on issues while they are hot.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: I am in no position to evaluate the legal aspects of the President's action in reducing the amount of money authorized for expenditure in imple menting the Federal Water Pollution Control Act, but I feel that there are economic and technical factors which make Mr. Nixon's action a logical and responsible step in the light of the nation's longrange Interests.

title: 10 Die in Iran Bus Crash
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 9 (AP) Ten people were reported to have been killed and at least seven injured last night when a bus overturned on a road near Fasa, 480 miles south of Teheran. According to reports the driver lost control when his vehicle's brakes failed.

title: Library in Queens May Be Shut Down
description: When antipoverty pro grams, maximum feasible participation, community con trol and innovative pro grams were in vogue, the Langston Hughes Community Library and Cultural Center opened.

title: RULING RESTRICTS AIRPORT SEARCHES
description: A Federal District judge in Los Angeles has placed new limits on the right of Federal agents to search travelers at airports in the drive to prevent hijackings.

title: FINAL VOTE PLEA MADE BY TANAKA
description: TOKYO, Dec. 9Premier Kakuei Tanaka closed out three weeks of election campaigning this afternoon with a spirited promise to accomplish his ambi tious plans for remodeling the Japanese archipelago.

title: City Aide Heads Task Force
description: John H. Lotz, the city's Com merce and Industry Commis sioner, was named by Mayor Lindsay yesterday to be Urban Action Task Force chairman in the Long Island CityAstoria section of Queens.

title: Bormann Was Hitler's Top Deputy
description: Martin Bormann was the second most powerful man in Germany, under Hitler, in the closing years of World War II. He was Hitler's deputy and personal secretary, head of the Nazi party apparatus and a general of the SS (Elite Guard).

title: Real Note Takes Hessian Handicap at Liberty Bell Second Year in Row
description: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 9 (UPI) Racing to the front at the start, Roland Aristone Sr.'s Real Note led throughout the mile and 70 yards of the Hes sian Handicap at Liberty Bell Park today to win the $28,300 fixture for the second con secutive year.

title: Bonny Bagpipers Whose Bag Is Hatikvah
description: WHEN they play Hatikvah on the bagpipes you should maybe call a plumber. But they are possibly the only Jewish pipe band in the world, and since they play in Glasgow, their repertoire includes not only the Israeli national anthem but such local favorites as Scotland the Brave and The Tenth Battalion High land Light Infantry Crossing the Rhine.

title: 10 Democrats Vying to Get Funds for Mayoral Contest
description: A month after a Presidential election that siphoned millions of dollars from New York Democratic contributors, 10 Democratic candidates for May or are already competing with one another to raise a minimum of $500,000 each for the pri mary.

title: Athletes Scoring in Business on L.I.
description: MINEOLA, L. ICounty Executive Ralph G. Caso re cently got Bud Harrelson and Jerry Grote of the Mets to sign a contract, but not in their capacity as ball players.

title: Gift to Drinking Drivers
description: LEBANON, Ind., Dec. 9 (UPI) Lincoln Memory Gardens, which operates a cemetery, at Zionsville, said Thursday that motorists who register in ad vance as planning to drink and drive will receive a free grave if they are killed during the holidays.

title: Movie Mailbag
description: I am shocked at what The Times will print. Foster Hirsch's letter to Tuesday Weld seemed so unnecessarily pompous and cruel and, for its author, such en ego trip.

title: NADJARI HIRES 36 TO COMBAT GRAFT
description: Seven weeks after his ap pointment as the state's new anticorruption investigator, Maurice H. Nadjari has hired a professional staff of 36  12 lawyers, 23 investigators and a former newspaperman.

title: PLATITUDE TAKES 3D HUNTER TITLE
description: SOMERS, N. Y., Dec. 9 Joslyn Grunebaum's Platitude, with Jim Arnott riding, captured his third hunter championship in a row today at the Primrose Farm horse show.

title: Doris Duke's Collection of Southeast Asian Art Comes Home
description: SOMERVILLE, N. J., Dec. 9The benign Buddha, lac quered in gold, inset with semiprecious stones and framed by shockcolored pan els or Thai silk, gazed impas sively at the woman who brought him here.

title: LETTERS
description: Your article on consumers [Consumerism Gets the BrushOff], while informa tive, gives a misleading view of the feelings toward busi ness. It is true that business is currently in the spotlight and should give a much bet ter accounting for itself.

title: Hunter Wrestlers Triumph
description: Hunter College defeated C.C.N.Y., 413, in a City Univer sities of New York wrestling match at Hunter yesterday. The victory, Hunter's fourth against one loss, was highlighted by Hunter's three pins.

title: Susan Master Marries
description: MAPLEWOOD, N. J., Dec. 9Miss Susan Master, daugh ter of Dr. and Mrs. E. Byron Master of Maplewood, was married here this afternoon to Alan D. Burt, son of Mr. and Mrs. John H. Burt of Winchester, Mass. The Rev. Dr. William F. B. Rodda per formed the ceremony in the Morrow Methodist Memorial Church.

title: Crime Families Taking Control of Pornography
description: The following article was prepared by Ralph Blumenthal and Nicholas Gage.

title: Movies
description: MOVIEMAKERS, I'm told, are wondering why their audiences are smaller of late. No one asked me, but if someone did inquire as to why I don't go to movies so much any more, I'd say it has to do with rudeness and noise.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: FRANCE REDUCED her valueadded tax and will float a $1billion state loan to offset the resulting loss of rev enues in an antiinflation move. The Bank of England's floating bank rate rose  point to 8 per cent.  The Soviet Union started up the first commercial atomic breeder reactor.

title: Canucks Tie Leafs
description: TORONTO, Dec. 9 (UPI) Dave Balon's goal with 2 min utes 26 seconds left to play capped an uphill struggle by Vancouver as the Canucks ral lied three times to tie the To ronto Maple Leafs, 55, to night.

title: THE U.N. SPONSORS A TOUR OF HARLEM
description: Two dozen United Nations diplomats and diplomats' wives toured Harlem yesterday to see for themselves a part of New York City that they said fas cinated and intrigued foreign visitors, who seldom see it close up.

title: Hofstra Triumphs, 8173
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Dec. 9 Hofstra's center, John Far mer, wasn't supposed to play against Southampton College tonight but the injured sophomore led the Dutchmen to an 8173 victory by scoring 20 points and grabbing 15 re bounds, Farmer, with an ankle injury, entered the game with 5 minutes 27 seconds left in the first half with Hofstra trailing, 2118. Farmer scored 7 points and got 5 rebounds to give Hofstra a 3526 halftime lead.

title: Former Industrialists On U.S. Salary Panel
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (AP)  Chief Justice of the United States Warren E. Burger an nounced yesterday the ap pointments of Roger M. Blough of New York and William T. Gossett of Detroit to the Commission on Execu tive, Legislative and Judi cial Salaries.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: FORT LEEIn the Novem ber elections, this tradition ally Republican borough elect ed three Democrats to its Town Council. All had cam paigned on a platform of Trees, Yes More High Rises, No! although all live in luxury hikhrise apart ments.

title: Case on 2 Policemen Shot Here Ends in Mistrial
description: After two and a half days of deliberation, the jury in the case of Richard Moore, the 27 yearold Black Panther charged with attempting to murder two policemen, declared yesterday it was hopelessly deadlocked, and the judge declared a mistrial.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: I plead for consideration of the sincere conscientious objectors to war. I do not plead for amnesty, which must be hateful to those men who be lieve in a cause and whose actions draw attention to their convictions. Rather do I plead for their chosen punishment, whether it be exile or jail ing, to give them the opportunity to walk in dignity for that in which they truly believe.

title: Date of Brezhnev Visit Here Still Not Set, U.S. Aides Say
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 9Both White House and State Depart ment officials said today that no date had yet been set for the visit of Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet Communist party leader, to the United States.

title: Gloversville Church Burns
description: GLOVERSVILLE, N.Y., Dec. 9 (UPI)Fire destroyed a church more than a century old in Gloversville in Fulton County last night. Officials said the African Methodist Episcopal Zion Church was leveled by the blaze, the cause of which was unknown. The Rev. Mrs. Rose Marie Fletcher, pastor of the church, said the frame struc ture was built in the mid eighteenhundreds and had re cently been refurbished.

title: Newark Academy Ponders Future Role
description: LIVINGSTON  At New ark Academy, change is considered almost a synonym for success.

title: Charles W. Hamilton Dead; Retired Gulf Oil Official
description: MONTCLAIR, N. J., Dec. 9 Charles W. Hamilton, who re tired in 1958 as vice president of the Gulf Oil Corporation, for which he had directed foreign production, died today at his home, 10 Crestmont Road. He was 82 years old.

title: Drama Mailbag
description: Writing of Eric Bentley's Are You Now or Have You Ever Been, Mel Gussow says that he found it beyond beliefa judgment that I don't understand. I believed every moment of it. Like most theatergoers, I under stand that, even using words directly from the interroga tions of the House UnAmer ican Activities Committee, the dramatization of the original event takes on a new and deeper and equally valid truth. Mr. Bentley's presenta tion of those hearings does not cause them to lose im portance.

title: Shorter Reviews
description: A higherup in Czech intelli gence, department of dirty tricks, who defected after Dub cek was ousted, discusses black propagandathat is, the technique of disseminating forged documents to embarrass the enemy. The Czechs, firmly under Russian control, special ized in this work, which has had effects as far away as South America. The author, writing under a pseudonym, strenuously attempts to fore stall criticism that his book is itself a C.I.A. dirty trick. One tends to believe him.

title: Bonn Offer Reported
description: BONN, Dec. 9 (Reuters) West Germany has told North Vietnam that it wants to supply largescale aid towards recon struction after a ceasefire, the daughter of President Gustav Heinemann reported.

title: 11% of Cars in Jersey Fail In State Pollution Tests
description: TRENTON, Dec. 9 (AP)  The New Jersey Motor Ve hicle Director, Ray J. Marini, reported today that 11 per cent of the cars inspected last month failed the air pollution test, a drop of 7 per cent since the tests began in July.

title: COAST DOBERMAN IS BEST IN SHOW
Horse Show News
description: Three of the Long Island High Score Awards Associa tion's 1971 champions  Connie Wagstaff's Rimraff in the large pony competition, Patrick Rice's Devil's Dis ciple in the junior working hunter division and Hollan dia Farm's Double Dutch in the junior jumper racesuc cessfully defended their titles this year. The cham pions were deter mined by points accumulated in 20 shows on Long Island dur ing the season. The awards were made last week.

title: Letters
description: I read with interest and some concern the article by Edward M. Brecher and the editors of Consumer Reports entitled, So why do heroin addicts drop dead? (Nov. 19). It leaves an impression that addicts never die of an over dose of heroin but rather from something mysterious in the mixtures injected, of which heroin is the smallest compo nent.

title: The World
description: DUBLIN  Thirtyfive years ago Eamon De Valera, then Prime Minister and now President of Ireland, trans formed what was essentially a secular Constitution into one that specifically assigned a special position to the Roman Catholic Church. On Friday, Irish voters decided to repeal that pro vision in a referendum designed pri marily for a Protestant audience that lives elsewhere.

title: Save the Tiger
description: All I know about the dress business I learned from Jerome Weidman, but things don't seem to have changed all that much since I Can Get It For You Wholesale first reached the bookstores back in 1937. Mr. Shagan has simply transposed Seventh Avenue to Los Angeles, where it's still a sudden death business, awash with unpleas ant characters.

title: Letters:
description: As visitors, last summer, to the weird ly beautiful Goreme region of Turkey, we were delighted to read the article by Jason Marks. His amusing descrip tion of the lunarlike terrain correspond ed very closely to our own observations. However, we were struck by his fail ure to note any connection between the Goreme soil, which, he says, apparent ly is quite fertile, and the proliferation of pigeons.
