description: A coalition of Lincoin Center area residents says it will ask the Board of Estimate and the City Planning Commission to consider canceling approval of a $16million, 38story, housing project sponsored by the Mor mon Church because, they con tend, it would constitute a vio lation of racial equality.

title: Pacers' Rally Topples Conquistadors, 111 to 104
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Dec. 12 (AP) Mel Daniels and George Mc Ginnis scored 29 points apiece tonight for the Indiana Pacers in a 111104 American Basket ball Association victory over the San Diego Conquistadors.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: ADELAIDE, Australia, Dec. 14 (Agence FrancePresse) Alex Metreveli of the Soviet Union, the defender, rallied to defeat Syd Ball of Australia today and reach the quarter finals of the South Australian grasscourt tennis champion ships. Metreveli, who had not played a tournament since September, trailed, 57, 24, and was down game point on Ball's service before winning, 57, 75, 64.

title: From Americana to Zoology: Program for Gifted Children
description: RIDGEWOOD, N. J.To anyone who remembers 3 o'clock on Friday as the high point of the school week, the spectacle of hundreds of children joyously racing into classrooms on a Saturday morning might seem very strange.

title: Bomb on Runway Closes Pnompenh to Air Traffic
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Dec. 14 (AP)Pnompenh's airport was closed to foreign traffic today as demolition experts pondered what to do about a 250pound napalm bomb sitting on a runway.

title: TUQUI II IS FIRST BY HALF A LENGTH
description: Tuqui II contributed a classic distance performance in win ning the main event on the Aqueduct program yesterday, Coming from last place in the field of six in the 1mile con test, Tuqui made up ground in the stretch to register a half length triumph over Harry Gor don's Projective.

title: L. I. R. R. Unions Say 3c a Ride Would Cover Their Proposals
description: The 12 nonoperating unions on strike against the Long Is land Rail Road contended yes terday that their request for a 28 per cent pay increase would cost the average commuter only 3 cents a ride rather than doubling of the fares, as rail road officials have Maintained.

title: Apollo Flight Highlights
description: Following are the high lights of the revised Apollo 17 flight plan. The timetable is subject to change at any time during the mission. Times are Eastern standard.

title: Truman's Condition Now Very Serious
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Dec. 14 Doctors treating former Pres ident Harry S. Truman termed his condition very serious today after he lost more ground in his struggle against lung congestion, heart irregularity and kidney failure.

title: Spicy Finish to the Meal
description: In the menu below, the dish marked with an asterisk is followed by a recipe.

title: WHITE HOUSE TIED TO I.T.T. DATA CURB
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 William J. Casey, the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, told a House sub committee today that he had been advised by the White House not to turn over to the subcommittee documents con cerning the activities of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation.

title: PERON ENDS STAY IN BUENOS AIRES
description: BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 14  Juan Domingo Pern left Argen tina today and turned down any chance to become President again. He rejected a nomination that he was in any case ineli gible to accept under the rules laid down by the military Government.

title: TALKS ARE OPENED BY DRESSMAKERS
description: The International Ladies Gar ment Workers Union, in the opening round of negotiations yesterday, asked for a 25 per cent wage increase in a new threeyear contract covering 60,000 dressmakers in an eight state area.

title: Rockets Edge Squires
description: DENVER, Dec. 14 (AP)  Julius Keye set an American Basketball Association record last night with 12 blocked shots. The last one was the most cru cial as the Denver Rockets posted a 10399 victory over the Virginia Squires.

title: Louisiana Panel Links Deputies To Deaths of 2 at Southern U.
description: BATON ROUGE, La., Dec. 14 A stateappointed commis sion investigating the killing of two black Southern University students here last month said today that both were killed by a single shotgun blast from an area where sheriff's deputies were deployed.

title: EDWARDS'S HIT SONG PROVES HARD TO TOP
description: Some hit songs are impossible to top. Jonathan Edwards, who opened at the Bitter End on Wednesday evening and will remain there through Sunday, has just such a hit in his cata logue.

title: BROOKLYN PUPILS ROBBED OF $2,000
description: Two masked bandits yester day fled with $2,000 seized from students in a Brooklyn high school auditorium, and two hours later a fourth grade teacher in a Queens school was held up at knifepoint in her classroom.

title: Rookie Paces Chaps Victory
description: DALLAS, Dec. 14 (AP)  James Silas, a rookie, hit a pro high of 29 points tonight and Rich Jones, a forward, scored 9 key fourthquarter points to lead the Dallas Chaparrals to a 121113 victory of the Ken tucky Colonels.

title: FRANK COVELLO
description: HARTFORD, Dec. 14 (AP) Frank Covello, who retired as a Superior Court judge here, died Monday at St. Francis Hos pital. He was 73 years old and lived in West Hartford.

title: The Dance: Herodiade
description: Martha Graham is an artist much and sensibly concerned with past events. She sees the past as a mir ror to the soul; she contem plates and reflects. One of the very firstpossibly even the firstof her timepast works, is the nowadays littleknown Herodiade. In 1944 it made its debut on the same night as Appala chian Spring, which has be come world famous. But Herodiade, despite a Juil liard School revival during the early sixties, has become just one for the record books.

title: MEAD DIRECTORS APPROVE RESERVE
description: Directors of the Mead Cor poration, a producer of paper and other allied products, ap proved yesterday a $14million reserve to cover the cost of phasing out marginal opera tions to be charged against 1972 earnings.

title: Cattle Disease Disrupts East Europe
description: WARSAW, Dec. 14An out break of footandmouth disease in Eastern Europe is creating widespread travel disruption and mounting economic losses.

title: 13 Hurt as Train Derails
description: LAWRENCEVILLE, Va., Dec. 14 (UPI)  Thirteen persons were injured when a Seaboard Coast Line Railroad passenger train derailed last night in a remote area near this southern Virginia community. The train was carrying 195 passengers, many of them vacationers headed for Florida.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14  Representative Henry S. Reuss, Democrat of Wisconsin, said today that he would seek to have Congress write into the economic stabilization act a provision creating a costof living ombudsman.

title: Energy Is Doubled In Atom Smasher; Aid to Experiments
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14The world's largest machine for scientific experiments, a $250 million atom smasher that ac celerates atomic particles around a fourmile ring, has generated a proton beam with twice as much energy as the original design called for, the Atomic Energy Commission an nounced today.

title: AUTO MAKERS TOLD TO DOCUMENT ADS
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (UPI) The Government ordered 12 automobile makers today to back up more than 100 adver tisements ranging from General Motors' statement that steel beams in its Vega are com parable to highway guardrails to Volkswagen's contention that it gets superior gas mileage.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: TRENTON, Dec. 14  The Senate today gave final legis lative approval to two bills per mitting the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey to spend $650million on mass transit improvements.

title: Farewell to the Moon
description: The first men to visit the moon, Neil A. Armstrong and Edwin E. Aldrin Jr., landed there on July 20, 1969. Yes terday, less than three and a half years later, Eugene A. Cernan and Harrison H. Schmitt rocketed off the moon. They are the last men scheduled to visit earth's nearest celestial neighbor under the terms of the abbreviated Apollo program. Are they the last men who will ever visit the moon? Almost certainly not. It is a safe bet that history will regard the small band of Apollo pioneers as the Columbuses and Magellans of a new era that will eventually bind the earth and the moon into one human community on the model of the unity now existing between what men once called the New World and the Old.

title: Story Behind French Connection
description: The real story behind The French Connectionthe slightly fictionalized film account of the smashing of heroinsmuggling ringgoes back to 1962.

title: Chinese Scientists Praise Apollo Feat As U.S. Tour Ends
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 14 (UPI)With words of praise for America's moonlanding missions as achieving positive results, a delegation of main land Chinese scientists ended today a 24day tour of the United States.

title: EDUCATOR IS NAMED AN OFFICIAL OF B.B.C.
description: LONDON, Dec. 14  Sir Michael Swann, principal of Edinburgh University and a highly regarded biologist, was named chairman of the gover nors of the British Broadcasting Corporation today.

title: The searchee is not being deprived of his right to travel.
description: BOSTONTo the many absurd and prevalent apprehensions about the state of civil liberties in the United States (whatever happened to the one about Spiro Agnew studying how to annul the Presidential election in 1972?) we can now add another: searching air travelers may be a vio lation of the Fourth Amendment guarantee against unreasonable searches and seizures.

title: Mr. Hulot Stalks Into Town for Traffic
description: Jacques Tati, the French comic mime, holds tenacious ly to certain ideas about comedy that seem clearly heretical in comparison with almost anyone else's ideas on the subject.

title: Freshman Assemblyman Gets Lesson in Facts of Life in Albany
description: ALBANY, Dec. 14What's that? the young darkhaired man wearing a signet ring with the peace symbol embossed on it asked as he peered from a taxi slowly climbing State Street.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: NEWARK, Dec. 14  City Council President Louis M. Turco today called Mayor Ken neth A. Gibson's nomination of Police Lieut. Edward L. Kerr to be the city's first black police director another Eagle ton affair.

title: CHRYSLER PRICE RISE IS HELD UP BY PANEL
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (AP) The Price Commission sus pended today the Chrysler Cor poration's request to raise prices by an average 3.04 per cent on its 1973 passenger cars and trucks.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: NEWARK, Dec. 14  Her bert Abrecht, the construction superintendent, looked out of his shack on the Kawaida Tow ers housing site today and said the view was terrific. For the first time in more than a month there were no pickets.

title: $10Million Heroin Stolen From a Police Office Vault
description: Fiftyseven pounds of heroin with an estimated street value of $10million to $12mil lionhas been stolen from the Police Department, Commis sioner Patrick V. Murphy an nounced yesterday.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Geoffrey K. Burke commented in the letters column on your news story of Nov. 20 about life in the universe, but unfortunately doesn't know the whole story about the monkeys and the typewriters.

title: Head of Teamsters Lays Faults to Regional Chief
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 14 (UPI) Frank E. Fitzsimmons, presi dent of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, said today that he had acted to re move Harold Gibbons as head of the union's 13state Central Conference because Gibbons has not measured up to the work.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: Antipoverty Worker Slain in Newark

title: Business Briefs
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 14The Occidental Petroleum Corpo ration of Los Angeles announced an $80million agreement with the Soviet Union today, covering the sale of metal finishing equipment to the Russians in exchange for the purchase of nickel.

title: FASHION TALK
description: Maybe the high spot was Elsa Peretti in the dark green silk rain shirt over white pants. Maybe it was Naomi Sims, in the long yellow cash mere sweater dress with the halter neckline and the car digan tossed over her shoul ders. Or perhaps Pilar Crespi in the peach crepe dress wrapped tightly at the waist line, sauntering casually down the runway, careful not to catch the eye of her mother, Countess Consuelo Crespi, or her aunt, Gloria Schiff. Years ago, they were known as the O'Connor twins and they had their turns on the runway.

title: Many U.S. Concerns Hit By Grumman Work Halt
description: BETHPAGE, L. I., Dec. 14 The Grumman Corporation has sent stopwork orders to 136 corporations in 27 states as a result of its decision not to produce additional F14 fighters for the Navy without an increase in price.

title: RAIDERS WIN, 43, MOVE INTO SECOND
description: OTTAWA, Ontario, Dec. 14 (UPI)The New York Raiders took over second place in the World Hockey Association's East Division tonight with a 43 victory over the Ottawa Nationals.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: TRENTON, Dec. 14A tough campaign measure that would require candidates in local and state elections to report all con tributions and expenses exceed ing $100 was overwhelmingly approved in the State Senate tonight.

title: KNICKS PUT RIKER ON A FARM TEAM
description: The Knicks, who will play the Bulls tonight in Chicago, announced yesterday that they were sending Tom Riker, a rookie forward, to the Allen town Jets of the Eastern League.

title: HelpWanted Index Rises
description: The helpwanted advertising index in October rose to 104 per cent of the 1967 base pe riod, a gain of 5 points over the September reading, the Conference Board reported yes terday. The index now stands 24 points over the level of October, 1971.

title: CALIFORNIA VOTES SHIFT ON SCIENCE
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Dec. 14The State Board of Educa tion adopted a resolution today accepting science textbooks for the state's three million ele mentary school pupils but call ing for modifications to elimin ate what board members believe is scientific dogmat ism on the teaching of evolution.

title: U.S. Disavows Thieu Plan
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14  The White House formally dis sociated itself today from the ceasefire proposal made two days ago by President Nguyen Van Thieu of South Vietnam and said it would sup port only the plan that Henry A. Kissinger has been negotiating with the North Vietnamese in Paris.

title: NITTY GRITTY BAND OFFERS LIVELY TIME
description: The Nitty Gritty Dirt Band opened Wednesday night at Max's Kansas City, plays through tomorrow and is, to put it baldly, well worth hear ing. Not that their music con stitutes some immemorial con tribution to the artalthough their ebullient blending of country, bluegrass, cajun, rock and who knows what else does have both esthetic and socio logical significance. The real reason they are worth hearing is that they provide for an al most unadulterated good time.

title: Hundreds Ask City Plan Unit To Finance Favorite Projects
description: Hundreds of people came to City Hall from all five boroughs yesterday to plead with the City Planning Commission for money to save parks, build libraries, expand cultural fa cilities and, in general, make life in the city more congenial.

title: and National Parks
description: The appointment of Ronald H. Walker to head the National Park Service must come as a shock to anyone who may have taken at face value President Nixon's repeated expressions of interest in conserving the most striking vestiges of America's great natural heritage. It is not that conservationists or naturalists or ordinary lovers of the parks have reason to believe that Mr. Walker is hostile to their interests. It is rather that a moment of crisis for the national park system, the President has appointed a man without background, training or known attitude on the great philosophical issue involved.

title: Chief Denies Krupp Has Financial Woes
description: ESSEN, West Germany, Dec. 12Berthold Beitz, the top man at Krupp, vigorously defended himself today against asser tions that the vast concern was in trouble and that he was the cause.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: I read the letter of Prof. Gregory Henderson published Nov. 8. I, too, regret that the Republic of Korea was unable to make necessary constitu tional and structural changes without resorting to such a drastic measure.

title: Issues in the L.I.R.R. Dispute
description: PARTICIPANTSThe Long Island Rail Road and 12 unions representing 5,000 carmen, teamsters, clerks, elec trical workers, sheet metal workers and other nonoperating employes, as well as some supervisors.

title: Customs Area Opens at Newark Airport
description: NEWARK, Dec. 14  The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey opened a United States customs inspec tion area at Newark Airport today as the first step of a threephase program to con vert the airport into a full fledged international flight fa cility by 1976.

title: DOMESTIC COUNCIL GETS WIDER POWER
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 President Nixon announced to day that he was giving his Domestic Council expanded authority and appointing a new executive director to free John D. Ehrlichman, his chief do mestic affairs adviser, to take additional responsibilities the President.

title: THEFT OF REWARD IS LAID TO S.I. MAN
description: A neighbor of a missing 5 yearold Staten Island girl was indicted yesterday on charges of forgery and grand larceny involving a reward for her return.

title: Parkchester Condominium Authorized
description: The State Attorney Gen eral has authorized the own ers of Parkchester, the larg est rentalapartment complex in the country, to begin the process of converting the huge Bronx development into a condominium.

title: 2d Ship in Trouble
description: HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, Dec. 14 (Reuters)A Canadian heli copter was sent to pluck mem bers of the 18man crew from the container vessel Rumba Identified here as West German tonight after it began listing 200 miles southeast of Cape Race, Newfoundland.

title: MRS. H. GORGE HAAS
description: Mrs. Helen Gorge Haas, for many years an executive of R. H. Macy & Co., Inc., died at the New York Hospital yesterday after a long illness. She was 64 years old and lived at 325 East 79th Street.

title: Serious Food, Pleasant Experience
description: Restaurants reviewed on this page on Friday are rated both for their food (four stars to none) and for their atmosphere, service and d cor (four triangles to none).

title: About Pro Football
description: The San Francisco 49ers can clinch the eighth and last postseason playoff berth by defeating or tying the Minnesota Vikings tomorrow. If they do that, then the wagering point line will shift sharply for Sunday's games involving the 49ers' com petitors, the Lions and Falcons. Each is favored now by 3 points. The premise is that a team will not play as well if it has just been eliminated from a division race. Tele vised games tomorrow are Baltimore at Miami (Chan nel 4, 1 P.M.) and Minne sota at San Francisco (Chan nel 2, 4 P.M.) On Sunday it will be Kansas City at At lanta (Channel 4, 1 P.M.) and the Giants at Dallas (Channel 2, 4 P.M.) Here is a preview of all games with wonlosttied records in pa rentheses:

title: Fall Between Subway Cars Kills a Brooklyn Boy, 13
description: A 13yearold Brooklyn boy was killed yesterday by a sub way train when he apparently fell between cars after he tried to reenter the moving local train by climbing over the scis sors gate from the platform.

title: EARLE D. MULLARE
description: BOSTON, Dec. 14Earle D. Mullare, president of the Mul lare News Company, a news paper distributor in Brockton, died today in University Hos pital. He was 60 years old and lived in Brockton.

title: KENNECOTT SETS SETTLEMENT PACT
description: The Overseas Private Invest ment Corporation and the Ken necott Copper Corporation an nounced jointly yesterday that they had agreed on the terms of a $66.9million insurance set tlement on Kennecott's debt in vestment in the El Teniente copper mine in Chile. The mine was expropriated in 1971.

title: Market Place: Public's Role At Exchange
description: It was not so long ago that the New York Stock Ex change elected a new board of directors with 10 public members in a total of 21. The new body replaced a 33 member, exchangedominat ed board on which there had been only three public mem bers.

title: Cosmos No. 538
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 14 (UPI) The Soviet Union today launched No. 538 in its Cosmos series of unmanned earth satel lites, the Soviet press agency, Tass, reported.

title: Colo. State Retains Moore
description: FORT COLLINS, Colo., Dec. 14 (UPI)The Colorado State Board of Agriculture voted unanimously today to retain Colorado State University's athletic director, Perry C. Moore, and head football coach, Jerry Wampfler. A con troversy over Moore arose when head coaches said that Moore had interfered with their programs and had ruined the morale of their teams.

title: PEEPSHOW RAIDS BRING 8 ARRESTS
description: In a crackdown on peep shows along West 42d Street yesterday, the police arrested eight owners or operators of shows that were still in opera tion half an hour after shut downs had been ordered.

title: Grove City Names Coach
description: GROVE CITY, Pa., Dec. 14 (AP)  Grove City College offi cials have promoted Joe Kopin sky from assistant to head foot ball coach, succeeding Jack Behringer, who resigned recently to become athletic director.

title: Japanese Deny That Chou Offered Them Military Aid
description: TOKYO, Dec. 14 (Reuters) A Government spokesman to day denied a report in The New York Times that suggested that China might give military aid to Japan if Japan was attacked by the Soviet Union.

title: Sports of The Times
description: Reggie Jones, victim of the Great Olympic Robbery. was saluted formally yesterday for not hollering when they mugged him in Munich. The fistfighter from Newark, who was jobbed by the judges after punching the face of Russia's Valery Tregubov, received the Gustavus T. Kirby Sports manship Award along with Ken Shelley, the United States figure skating champion. The Boys' Athletic League, which hands out this citation only once every four years, chose he recipients because they are good at what they do and do it like gentlemen. In Sapporo, Japan, be fore the winter Olympics, Shelley volun teered to skate an exhibition after a Russian pair had refused for fear it would blunt their performance in the Games. The Russians then won the gold medal, with Shelley and Jo Jo Starbuck finishing fourth. Ken and Jo Johe was the first in 31 years to win both the national singles and pairsare professionals now with the Icecapades. Jones means to turn pro in Marchafter he has got hunk with Tregubov.

title: BASE AT BIENHOA IS SHELLED BY FOE
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Fri day, Dec. 15 (AP)  Enemy gunners fired rockets at Bien hoa air base and an outlying village 15 miles northeast of Saigon in a predawn attack to day.

title: Money Market Tightens; Interest Rates Increase
description: The money market tightened this week, the Federal Reserve System reported yesterday.

title: POLISH AIRLINE LINK TO CITY APPROVED
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (Reu ters)President Nixon has ap proved a permit for the Polish National Airlines, Lot, to begin scheduled flights between points in Poland and New York city, it was announced today.

title: Man in the News
description: On sunny weekend after norms from early spring to late fall, W. H. (Tex) James may be found at the helm of a 30foot sloop on Long Is land Sound, battling the wind and waves and fellow sailors of the Lardhmont Yacht Club. Those who have sailed with and against him say he is a tough, low key competitor who knows his boat and makes clear, fast and de cisive judgments that inspire confidence and loyalty in his crew.

title: MANHATTAN UPSET BY BROWN, 6154; FORDHAM VICTOR
Nadjari Subpoenas 9 Policemen in Alleged Payoff Scheme
description: Nine policemen from the pre cinct covering the Wall Street area have been subpoened by Maurice H. Nadjari, the special state anticorruption prosecutor, to appear today before a grand jury.

title: U.S. Disavows Thieu Plan
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14  The White House formally dis sociated itself today from the ceasefire proposal made two days ago by President Nguyen Van Thieu of South Vietnam and said it would sup port only the plan that Henry A. Kissinger has been negotiating with the North Vietnamese in Paris.

title: Soviet Silent on Case
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 14Some of the Soviet Union's leading leg islative and lawenforcement officials declined today to com ment on Dr. Chalidze's case.

title: House Builtin 1804 joins Historic Strip
description: Sagging and blackened af ter all these years, a historic brick home built in 1804 was moved gently into position yesterday as the end piece of a strip of Very Old New York, a few blocks north of the World Trade Center.

title: TENG TZUHUI DEAD; CHINESE DEPUTY, 75
description: TOKYO, Dec. 14 (AP)Teng Tzuhui, a former Chinese Dep uty Premier, died Sunday in China, Japan's Kyodo News Service reported today.

title: Brandt Inaugurated for a Second Term
description: BONN, Dec. 14  Willy Brandt was inaugurated today for a second term as Chancel lor of the Federal Republic of Germany after his election in the Bundestag.

title: Reporter in Contempt Case Being Held in Isolation
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 14  William Farr, the Los Angeles journalist jailed two weeks ago for refusing to reveal his news sources, is being held here in isolation.

title: Louisiana Panel Links Deputies To Deaths of 2 at Southern U.
description: BATON ROUGE, La., Dec. 14 A stateappointed commis sion investigating the killing of two black Southern University students here last month said today that both were killed by a single shotgun blast from an area where sheriff's deputies were deployed.

title: Time Spent on Moon A Record 75 Hours
description: HOUSTON, Dec. 14 (UPI) Capt. Eugene A. Cernan and Dr. Harrison H. Schmitt broke the record today for the most time spent on the moon.

title: Amnesty Reported Spurned
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 14 The daily newspaper, Al Mohar rer, which has Palestinian com mando connections, said today that nine Jordanian officers had been sentenced to death after a trial held in Amman behind closed doors a few days ago.

title: Couple Offers the Neediest $52 in Honor of P.O.W.'s
description: David and Sandra Scheraga of Stamford, Conn., sent The New York Times's Need iest Cases Fund $52 yester day along with a note hailing 1972 as a year of good fortune marking their sec ond wedding anniversary and the birth of their daughter.

title: Valdes Will Fight Watts At Felt Forum on Jan. 8
description: Rodrigo Valdes of Colombia will meet Bobby (Boogaloo) Watts of Philadelphia in a 10round middleweight bout at Madison Square Garden's Felt Forum on Jan. 8, the Garden's boxing department announced yesterday.

title: KNICKS PUT RIKER ON A FARM TEAR
description: The Knicks, who will play the Bulls tonight in Chicago, announced yesterday that they were sending Tom Riker, a rookie forward, to the Allen town Jets of the Eastern League.

title: Senator Smith, at 75, Declines to Celebrate
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (UPI)  Senator Margaret Chase Smith, Republican of Maine, quietly finishing the few remaining days of a long Congressional career, became 75 years old today but de clined to celebrate the anni versary.

title: Most Amex and OTC Stock Prices Show Declines
description: The majority of stocks fin ished lower yesterday on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthecounter market in slower trading.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: NEWARK Dec. 14Besides Phil Sellers, Ron Williams and Mike Dabney, all freshmen and starters at Rutgers, the Scarlet Knights have discovered that another freshman, Mike Palko, can play alongside Gene Armstead, the senior center. Palko proved his worth against Lehigh, and Rutgers will play him more Saturday against Temple.

title: Belgian Socialist Gets Mandate To Try to Form a Government
description: BRUSSELS, Dec. 14  Ed mond Leburton, the French speaking copresident of the Belgian Socialist party, accept ed a mandate from King Bau douin today to form a govern ment.

title: The Daily News Names New Publisher
description: W. H. James, a longtime executive of The Daily News, was named chief executive of ficer of the company and pub lisher of the paper yesterday.

title: VIACOM SETTLES ANTITRUST SUIT
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14The Justice Department announced today that it had settled its antitrust suit against a former subsidiary of the Columbia Broadcasting System, but not against C.B.S. itself or the other two major television networks.

title: Gary, Ind., Ends Pact With Concern Running School
description: GARY, Ind., Dec. 14 (AP)An experimental program in which a Palo Alto, Calif., company operated a Gary elementary school has been discontinued because it was not working, school officials said.

title: Australia Acts to Save Aboriginal Culture
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Dec. 14 Prime Minister Gough Whit lain announced today that the Government would reform the whiteadministered aboriginal educational system in a move to save the vanishing culture of the native Australian peo ple.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: The local activities of the Irish Re publican Army (in one or another of its forms) again being given promi nence in the news media should give cause for considerable heartsearching. The fundraising for terrorist groups is of national concern.

title: Two British Bands, New Here, Indicate Evolution in Rock
description: Two British rock bands per formed for the first time in the United States Wednesday night in Philharmonic Hall, and both of them had something to say. But to call either a rock band shows how mal leable the term has become, how far the primitive plunk ings of the fifties have evolved.

title: Brydges Feted in Albany On Eve of Retirement
description: ALBANY, Dec. 14  An overflow crowd of 1,250 friends and wellwishers held a testimonlal dinner here to night for the Senate majority leader, Earl W. Brydges, who is retiring from politics after serving 24 consecutive years as a Senator.

title: BASE AT BIENHOA IS SHELLED BY FOE
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Fri day, Dec. 15 (AP)  Enemy gunners fired rockets at Bien hoa air base and an outlying village 15 miles northeast of Saigon in a predawn attack to day.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Dec. 14 (UPI)Churchill Downs announced today an increase in entry fees for the Ken tucky Derby from $1,000 to $2,500, and in starting fees from $1,000 to $1,500, in a move that may keep future Derby fields from getting too cumbersome, The higher fees may discourage owners who feel their horses don't have much of a chance, but want to enter them for the thrill of running in America's most famous thoroughbred race.

title: Inmate Slain and 6 Hurt In a Prison Riot in Illinois
description: PONTIAC, Ill., Dec. 14 (AP) One inmate was killed to night and six were injured in a gang fight in the dining room of Pontiac State Prison.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE ELIZABETHAN RENAISSANCE: The Cul tural Achievement, By A, L. Rowse. 412 pages. Scribners. $12.50.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: TRENTON, Dec. 14  The Assembly approved today a bill calling for an additional $40 million in state aid to educa tion. Approval followed the fail ure, by one vote, of a Demo cratic move to hold the meas ure for amendent.

title: 2 Killed at Textile Mill
description: LEWISTON, Me., Dec. 14 (AP) Two persons were killed and 10 others injured by several explosions and a fire yesterday at the W. S. Libbey textile mill here.

title: Nixon Invites D'Avanzo To TreeLighting Fete
description: Anthony F. D'Avanzo, chairman of the conference committee of the 12 unions on strike against the Long Island Rail Road, said yes terday that he and his wife had received an invitation from President and Mrs Nixon to attend a recep tion at the White House this afternoon before the light ing of the Christmas tree.

title: Truman's Condition Now Very Serious
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Dec. 14 Doctors treating former Pres ident Harry S. Truman termed his condition very serious today after he lost more ground in his struggle against lung congestion, heart irregularity and kidney failure.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Your recent editorial Trenton and Washington is a breakthrough in that you suggest, for the first time in my memory, that the same standards of justice that apply in the rest of the country should apply for public figures in New Jersey. You seem almost on the verge of reconsidering your con stant encouragement of prosecutorial permissiveness and investigative insan ity which has blighted the political process in the Garden State.

title: The Screen:Museum Opens 'Here Comes Every Body'
description: The group encounter documentary called "Here Comes Every Body" is by far the most interesting feature of this kind I have seen. Some of these soul-baring talk sessions on film have been candid, crashing bores, in the name of truth and cinma vrit (alert the camera and shoot). As the first movie of an English director-producer, John Whitmore, the California-made project does credit to him and to the Whitney Museum, which unveiled the film yesterday for a seven-day run.For one thing, these people have something to say about themselves and one another. They are generally personable and intelligent. Their revelations and confessed hang-ups are tactfully prodded by a wise group director as they gather in a room and relax on the pool terrace of the Esalen Institute in Big Sur. Finally, as Mr. Whitmore's unobtrusive camera concentrates on seven or eight case historiesout of 16 participantsthey seem people worth knowing. Their tears, when they flow, matter. So do the exploding tensions and fears. Finally, they speak plain English, with explicit, obscene shortcuts.The one we especially liked was a fading, 44-year-old woman  warm-hearted, fatwho yearns for children, we learn, and "was once young and beautiful." In the most touching moment she wails, "Where has it all gone?"One genial young man, a frank homosexual, berates his hypersensitivity with a directness that is downright manly. An older, baldish man learns to cushion his strikeout hostility. Of the troubled couples, two attractive youngsters are as winning as they are candid.The whole thing leaves a frank, stimulating taste. An open-minded viewer  and listenershould come to care for the participants even as they learn to care for one another.

title: PERON ENDS STAY IN BUENOS AIRES
description: BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 14 Juan Domingo Pern left Argen tina today and turned down any chance to become President again. He rejected a nomination that he was in any case ineli gible to accept under the rules laid down by the military Government.

title: 31 Vehicles Crash in Fog
description: LIVERMORE, Calif., Dec. 14 (AP)An accident in dense fog involving 31 vehicles sent poi sonous hydrochloric acid fumes over a freeway east of San Francisco early today, the Cali fornia Highway Patrol said. At least 20 persons were reported injured. A military truck car rying 33 drums of hydrochloric acid was involved in the acci dent on Interstate 80, and several of the tanks ruptured, the patrol said.

title: Balky Lunar Antenna Retracts on Spaceship
description: HOUSTON, Dec. 14 (UPI) A 30foothigh lunar sounder antenna aboard the Apollo 17 command ship America, has been found to be in working order, ending fears that it would have to be blown off the craft.

title: Second Rape at Tufts
description: MEDFORD, Mass., Dec. 14 A 19yearold Tufts University sophomore was the victim of the second knifepoint rape here in 12 days, the university po lice reported today. The inci dent occurred Nov. 29 about 3:30 A.M. in a dormitory lounge, but was not reported until yes terday.

title: PAUL IMMO GULDEN
description: Paul Immo Gulden of Rum son, N. J., a partner in Mc Mullen & Hard, stockbrokers, died Wednesday at Riverview Hospital in Red Bank, N. J. His age was 72.

title: First Preakness Nominee
description: BALTIMORE, Dec. 14 (AP) Lou Rosenbush is the first nominee for the 98th running of the $150,000 added Preak ness at Pimlico Race Course May 19. Nathan Cohen the Pimlico vice president, nomi nated the Maryland 2yearold today.

title: U. S. Sailor a Hostage
description: BELFAST, Dec. 14  An American sailor was taken hos tage at gunpoint in London derry last night by three men who tried to rob the United States Navy's communications center there.

title: America and Challenger Are in a Good Tight Navy Formation
description: HOUSTON, Dec. 14 (AP) Following are excerpts of Apollo 17 conversations to day as the lunar module, with Capt. Eugene A. Cernan and Dr. Harrison H. (Jack) Schmitt, blasted off from the moon and linked up with the command module America, piloted by Comdr. Ronald E. Evans:

title: News Source Law Drafted
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (AP) Representative Stewart B. McKinney, Republican of Con necticut, said today that his staff was preparing a draft of a shield law to protect news men and their sources.

title: U.S. Is Sympathetic To Soviet Dissident If He Seeks to Stay
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14The State Department said today that the United States would give sympathetic consideration to any request to remain in the country made by Dr. Valery N. Chalidze, a prominent Soviet dissident, who was informed yesterday while in New York on a speaking tour that his citizenship had been revoked.

title: Cabaret
description: Redhaired Marlene Ver Planck, a tiny wisp of a girl, is, according to the guitarist Bucky Pizzarelli, not used to singing more than 28 sec onds. This is an allusion to her career for the last 12 years as a top singer of com mercial jingles for Campbell's Soup, Winston cigarettes and other products. Miss Ver Planck is now going for dis tance, singing songs that last for several minutes, in her nightclub debut at the Soera baja, 140 East 74th Street, where she has the very skill ful accompaniment of Mr. Pizzarelli.

title: Los Angeles Times Is Ordered To Give Court Tape of Interview
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 The Los Angeles Times was or dered today to produce in court next Tuesday its tape re cordings of an interview with Alfred C. Baldwin 3d, a princi pal Government witness in the Watergate bugging case.

title: Slowing of the Inflation In Europe Is Predicted
description: PARIS, Dec. 14 (UPI)  The skyrocketing inflation of nearly 10 per cent in Western Europe should slow within three to six months, a report by the Or ganization of Economic Coop eration and Development said today.

title: Controlled Growth
description: Toronto has elected a mayor whose whole emphasis in municipal politics is the development of a city in which people continue to have a sense of roots, a sense of place. David Crombie, the successful candidate, is the champion of controlled growth and of neighbor hood identity against those whose guiding stars have been the bulldozer and the highrise.

title: B52's Fly 33 Missions
description: SAIGON, Friday, Dec. 15 (UPI)  American B52 bomb ers flew 33 missions averaging three planes each over North and South Vietnam in the 24 hour period ended at noon yes terday, the United States com mand said. Fourteen of the mis sions were directed over the North  one short of the rec ord, of 15 set by the big bomb ers three weeks ago.

title: TESTIMONY ENDS IN RICORD'S TRIAL
description: The last of the testimony in the narcotics conspiracy trial of Auguste Joseph Ricord was presented yester day to a Federal jury, which heard the reputed heroin smuggler described as a man who loves animals and children.

title: Trash Left on Moon Totals $517.2Million
description: HOUSTON, Dec. 14 (UPI) The United States has left $517.2million worth of junk on the moon in its six land ings, according to space agency cost figures.

title: City Takes Disciplinary Action Against 344 Welfare Workers, Discharging 71, in Effort to End Abuses
description: An increased program to upgrade employe discipline and productivity among the city's welfare employes has led in the last two months to disci plinary actions against 344 workers, including 71 who were discharged. More than 700 cases were reported pending.

title: Tannen Chases Black Clouds as Well as Receivers
description: Steve Tannen has been in jured so often this season one might get the idea he's related to Joe Blfstk, the friend of Lil Abner who walks around with a black cloud hovering over his head and creates calamity wher ever he goes.

title: Eugene Berman, Painter and a Set Designer for the Met, Dies at 73
description: Eugene Berman, a celebrated neoromantic painter who cre ated a series of elaborate, dreamlike stage settings for ballet and opera, died at his home in Rome yesterday of internal hemorrhages, He was 73 years old.

title: Curbs Set in Madagascar Port After Riots Over School Reform
description: TANANARIVE, Madagascar, Dec. 14 (Agence FrancePresse) The Government of this Island nation off the southeastern coast of Africa declared a state of siege in and near the port city of Tamatave today after two days of rioting over edu cational reforms.

title: OLIVER P. BOLTON OF OHIO, 55, DIES
description: CLEVELAND, Dec. 14Oli ver P. Bolton, a former Repre sentative in Congress, died yes terday of heart failure at his winter home in Palm Beach, Fla. He was 55 years old.

title: DR. HENRY SMITH JR., A LANGUAGE EXPERT
description: BUFFALO, Dec. 14 (AP)Dr. Henry Lee Smith Jr., who estab lished the Foreign Service Insti tute's language school, died last evening. He was ?? years old.

title: Canadian Hijacker Gives Up, Freeing 4
description: MONTREAL, Dec. 14 (UPI) A young man forced his way aboard a jetliner in a Canadian mining town today, seized a stewardess at gunpoint and forced the plane to go to Mon treal, then to Ottawa and back to Montreal. There he held four crew members hostage for more than six hours before yielding to a plea from his father to free the hostages and surrender to the police.

title: OFFICIALS OPPOSE NIXON PLAN TO CUT TAX ON PROPERTY
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14  A group of Federal, state and local government officials re jected today President Nixon's idea that the Federal Govern ment provide the financial aid that would permit local govern ments to reduce property taxes.

title: CERNAN AND SCHMITT BLAST OFF AFTER THREE DAYS ON THE MOON AND LINK UP WITH COMMAND SHIP
description: HOUSTON, Dec. 14 Apollo 17's moon explorers blasted off from the surface and rejoined their orbiting command ship to night in the Apollo project's last departure from that desolate, cratered world.

title: Kahane Appeals to Court In Israel Citizenship Bid
description: JERUSALEM, Dec. 14 (AP) Rabbi Meir Kahane appealed to the Israeli Supreme Court to day, saying that the Govern ment was blocking his appli cation for Israeli citizenship in an effort to restrict his activ ities as head of the militant Jewish Defense League.

title: Administrative Judge Named
description: Supreme Court Justice John P. Cohalan Jr. was appointed administrative judge of Suffolk County yesterday, effective Jan. 1. He will succeed Justice David L. Glickman, who will reach the mandatory retirement age of 70 this year. Justice Glickman will continue on the bench as an acting justice for two years.

title: MICHIGAN GAS TAX WILL AID TRANSIT
description: LANSING, Mich., Dec. 14 The Michigan Legislature voted today to raise the state gaso line tax by 2 cents a gallon and to permit the diversion of onehalf cent of the increase or $21million a yearfor pub lic transit.

title: NEWSSOURCE BILL PASSED IN JERSEY
description: TRENTON, Dec. 14A bill described by its sponsors as the strongest in the country in protection of news sources won final legislative approval this evening.

title: Sanderson's Lawyer Denies Knowledge Of Deal by Blazers
description: Amid rumors that the Phila delphia Blazers were desperate ly attempting to trade Derek Sanderson and his $500,000a year contract, Sanderson's law yer said from Boston yesterday that if the deal made sense or could help the situation we would give it every considera tion.

title: I.C.C. Aide in Senate Post
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (AP) Senator Vance Hartke, Dem ocrat of Indiana, chairman of the Senate Commerce Surface Transportation subcommittee, announced today the appoint ment of John W. Bush, a for mer chairman of the Interstate Commerce Commission, as a staff expert.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: AUCKLAND, New Zealand, Dec. 14 (AP)George Archer of the United States and Bobby Shearer of Australia fired threeunderpar 68's to share the firstround lead today in the $12,000 New Zealand golf classic.

title: Bridge: Prize for BestPlayed Hand Might Spice Tourney Reports
description: Organizers of bridge tour naments might well follow the example of chess tourna ments and award a prize for the bestplayed hand. Pro vided the subjective problems of judging can be overcome, such a prize would provide good material for the jour nalists and good reading for the bridge public.

title: Arab Military Chiefs Fail To Set a Combined Plan
description: CAIRO, Dec. 14 (UPI) Eighteen Arab military chiefs ended a oneday meeting with out any announcement of suc cess in formulating a combined plan of action against Israel.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: In his letter to you published Dec. 1, Geoffrey K. Burke regrettably repeats an often stated theoretical probability. However, it is one which, on reflec tion, obviously would never come to be.

title: TV: Lennons' Concert
description: Surely no cause could be worthier than that of mental ly retarded children. But full enjoyment of a benefit rock concert staged by John Len non and Yoko Ono last Au gust at Madison Square Gar denand presented as an hour TV program tonight will require at least one tin ear and the conviction that Mr. and Mrs. Lennon can do or singno wrong.

title: Kennedy Airport Union Leader Is Guilty of Taking Free Rides
description: Harry Davidoff, secretary treasurer of a Teamsters Union local of groundservice em ployes at Kennedy International Airport, was convicted last night by a Federal court jury in Brooklyn on 21 of 23 counts of violating the TaftHartley Act.

title: Flyers Down Blues, 53, On 2 LastPeriod Goals
description: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 14 (AP)  A breakaway goal by Bill Clernent with less than 4 minutes to play broke a 33 tie and sent the Philadelphia Flyers to a 53 National Hockey League victory over the St. Louis Blues tonight.

title: The Proceedings in the U.N. Today
ALPHONSE V. ZVIRBLYS
description: Alphonse V. Zvirblys, assist ant director of the leasing divi sion of the City Real Estate Department, died Wednesday in Unity Hospital, Brooklyn, after surgery. He was 51 years old and lived at 195 Underhill Ave nue, Brooklyn.

title: Notes on People
description: On the fifth anniversary of his exile in Rome, King Con stantine of Greece was de scribed by friends as bored and disappointed with the way things have turned out for him since his aborted at tempt to depose the present Greek Government. Still, the 32yearold monarch draws a $580,000  a  year allowance from Greece, lives in a villa on the Via Latina and retains the title of King of the Hel lenes.

title: News of Skiing
description: It was 20 degrees above zero at Bromley Mountain's base late yesterday after noon, and Karl Pfeiffer, the Vermont resort's ski school director, reported by tele phone: I spent part of the afternoon on my hands and knees praying. He explained that Joel Myers, the Penn State University meteorologist who services most of the Northeast's major ski areas with weather forecasts, had pre dicted a possibility of a big snowstorm starting this af ternoon.

title: C.A.B. Chief Hints Move to Bar Uneconomic Atlantic Air Fares
description: Secor D. Browne, chairman of the Civil Aeronautics Board, said yesterday that his agency would use, if necessary, new authority granted by Congress to prevent foreign airlines from offering eneconomic fares during a threatened transAt lantic airline price war.

title: Business Briefs
description: TOKYO, Dec. 14Japan's balanceofpayments surplus totaled $680million in November, a decline from $935 million in the previous month, the Finance Ministry an nounced in a preliminary report today.

title: William Dieterle Is Dead at 79; A Director of Stage and Screen
description: MUNICH, West Germany, Dec. 15 (UPI)William Dieterle, a Germanborn screen and stage director, died Saturday at Otto ?? near here. He was 79 years old.

title: S.E.C. Imposes Penalty on Weis, Voisin
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 The Securities and Exchange Commission imposed penalties today on the brokerage firm of Weis, Voisin & Co. of New York, because of alleged frauds in connection with the sale of stock in the Dumont Corporation.

title: BOYLE IS OUSTED BY MINERS' VOTES AFTER LONG FIGHT
description: SILVER SPRING, Md., Dec. 15 Rankandfile insurgents in the United Mine Workers Union won a decisive victory today in the long struggle to oust the union's president, W. A. Boyle.

title: Port News
description: Rising prices of fuel oil may force a number of ship operators to resort to nuclear ship propulsion by early 1975, according to James J. Henry, a naval architect who is pres ident of the J. J. Henry Com pany, Inc., here. He said nu clear power was the best way to achieve speed in new ships with out excessive loss of cargo capacity through bulky propulsion ma chinery. The price of Bunker C fuel oil, he said, has doubled in recent years and may go as jiigh as $5 to $6 a barrel by 1975.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: E. J. (Buzzie) Bavasi said here yesterday that action would have to he taken quicklyperhaps within the next two weeksif San Diego's National League baseball fran chise was to be moved to Washington for the 1973 season.

title: COLONELS SURGE TURNS BACK NETS
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., Dec. 15 We try to keep Dan [Issel] and Artie [Gilmorel in there as long as we can. If they can establish the inside game, then we feel we can control the outcome.

title: TIMES ANNOUNCES PLAN TO CUT COSTS
description: The New York Times is in the midst of a costcutting program that has included elimination of some jobs and reduction of other expenses, Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, president and pub lisher, said yesterday in a let ter to the newspaper's 6,000 employes.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: LONDON, Dec. 15  The Burlington Magazine, an esteemed monthly dealing with the history and criticism of art, describes as sinister the policy of the Metropolitan Museum of Art in selling some of its paintings and using the proceeds to buy others.

title: Peronismo Sin Peron?
description: It is too early to write off Juan Pern as a political force in Argentina; but his 28day visit to his homeland the first in seventeen yearshas dramatically cut down the myth, leaving only the man and the politician. Many of his followers are disillusioned and the divisions in their disparate ranks are again surfacing.

title: Marlene Dietrich at 68 (or 71): Still a Terror, Still an Angel
description: When Marlene Dietrich lights up the television screen on Jan. 13, looking all peaches and creamy and sparkling in a $30,000 Jean Louis dress, she will sing I Wish You Love, the title of the Columbia Broadcasting System special.

title: Rhodesia Extends Draft Time
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Dec. 15The Rhodesian Government today announced that the pe riod of compulsory national service in its armed forces will be extended on January 1 from nine months to one year. In a radio and television interview, the Minister of Defense, John H. Howman, said that the main reason was the stretching of the line that is to be patrolled by Rhodesia's security forces.

title: Man, 20, Arrested
description: NORTH SYRACUSE. Dec. 15 (AP)The state police and agents of a task force here ar rested a 20yearold man on a bench warrant from Wyoming County charging the man with murder. A state police investi gator said the arrest stemmed from the Wyoming County situation, but referred all questions to Mr. Fischer's group.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: MONTPELIER, Vt., Dec. 15 (AP)The Arthur Rooney family added Vermont's only parimutuel track to its sport enterprise holdings today when the slate's Racing Commis sion gave a Rooneyowned corporation tentative approval for an operating license.

title: Mudslide in Kentucky
description: CUMBERLAND, Ky., Dec. 15 (UPI)Rock and mud slid down a mountain last night and forced 25 families from their homes here, but no injuries were reported. The slide fol lowed a week of heavy rain.

title: 1971 Operation Made Ron Johnson Go Like'72
description: The Giants have good rea son to he pleased with sev eral decisions they made this yearthe acquisition of Jack Gregory and Norm Snead, for example, and the drafting of Larry Jacobson and John Mendenhall. But they also have to be pleased with a de cision they didn't make last year. They didn't make it be cause Ron Johnson wouldn't let them make it.

title: U.S. and Chile to Open Talks Next Week
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15Ad ministration officials said today that the United States and Chile would begin highlevel talks here next Wednesday aimed at finding solutions to the increasing problems be tween them.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: In its Nov. 11 editorial The Abor tion Front, The Times once again aligns itself with those pledged to retain the 1970 New York State Abor tion Law. While The Times seeks to find some consolation in the results of the November election, it seems, rather, that the net effect both in New York State and nationwide was to indicate a strong trend away from abortion as a solution to social prob lems.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: I wish to take issue with your Nov. 17 editorial Imprisoned Press.

title: DELAY ASKED ON RULE ON ELKSMOOSE UNITS
description: HARTFORD, Dec. 14 (AP) A threejudge Federal panel was asked today to withhold a ruling on the taxexempt sta tus of Elks Club and Moose lodges in Connecticut until the United States Supreme Court decides the constitutionality of the tax exemptions.

title: Jabbar Stopped, Not Bucks
description: MILWAUKEE, Dec. 15 (AP)  Bob Dandridge scored 18 points, leading a balanced at tack that carried the Milwau kee Bucks to a 9882 victory over the Cleveland Cavaliers tonight. The Bucks are 100 against Cleveland since the Cays entered the league three years ago.

title: ROCKEFELLER BARS A REALTYTAX CUT
description: ALBANY, Dec. 15Governor Rockefeller gave short shrift today to a hope espoused by Assembly Speaker Perry B. Duryea that a revenue surplus at the end of the state fiscal year might be used to alleviate the tax burden on homeowners.

title: U. S., Puerto Rican Boxers To Meet in Jersey Dec. 23
description: The American amateur box ing team named to face the strong Puerto Rican team in the Paterson Armory next Sat urday will be looking to upset the favorites.

title: Green Haven Inmates Stay In Cells for Weapons Hunt
description: STORMVILLE, N. Y., Dec. 15 (AP)Inmates at Green Haven State Correctional Facility re mained locked in their cells today as correction officials tried to finish their search for weapons after finding a sig nificant number in the last two days.

title: Bulls' Late Rally Beats Knicks, 9086
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 15The Chicago Bulls outplayed the New York Knicks in the fourth quarter of a fastmoving de fensive battle tonight and scored a 9086 victory before 11,329 at the Chicago Stadium.

title: NOVEMBER OUTPUT OF INDUSTRY ROSE AN ADDITIONAL 1.1%
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15  Industrial production, now be ginning to increase rapidly, rose a further 1.1 per cent in November, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

title: Tho Leaves for Hanoi
description: PARIS, Dec. 15Le Duc Tho flew to Moscow today on his way home to Hanoi to report on his 15 negotiating sessions with Henry A. Kissinger.

title: Academy Official Elected
description: BOSTON, Dec. 15 (AP)Val leau Wilkie Jr., director of de velopment at Governor Drum mer Academy in Byfield, was elected president of the New England Association of Schools and Colleges today.

title: Sabotage at Pnompenh
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Sat urday, Dec. 16 (Agenee France Presse)Several vessels were blown up by plastic explosives in Pnompenh Harbor, and the Chrui Changwar naval base came under rocket fire last night, the government announ ced today.

title: Nixon and Kissinger Meet, But Are Silent on a Truce
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 Henry A. Kissinger met with President Nixon today for the fourth time in two days and conferred individually with other high Administration offi cials on the outlook for a negotiated settlement of the Vietnam war.

title: Blazers End Loss Streak
description: SEATTLE, Dec. 15 (AP)Sid ney Wicks scored the last 4 points with less than half a minute to go tonight as the Portland Trail Blazers beat the Seattle SuperSonics, 9695, to end a nine game losing streak.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Sports News Briefs
description: VAL GARDENA, Italy, Dec. 15 (AP)Roland Collombin of Switzerland had the fastest time today in trials for the men's World Ski Cup downhill here tomorrow. Collombin by 21 hundredths of a second. David Zwilling, another Aus registered 2 minutes 07.73 seconds over the 3,750meter (more than 2 miles) course, edging Karl Cordin of Austria ?? was third. Jim Hunter of Canada was fourth in 2:08.89 and Bob Cochran of Rutland, Vt., fifth in 2:09.07. Mike Lafferty of Eugene, Ore., was 10th in 2:09.72.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: SEABROOK, N. J., Dec. 15 (UPI)Seabrook Farms said to day it was proceeding on a precautionary basis until the Government completed tests on the bean samples.

title: Princeton Upsets 2dRanked Florida State, 6159
description: HUNTINGTON, W. Va., Dec. 15 (AP)Princeton upset sec ondranked Florida State, 6159, in the first round of the Marshall Memorial invitation basketball tournament tonight as Ted Manakas scored two free throws with two seconds to play.

title: ITS CHIEF DEFENDS HOUSING AGENCY
description: The head of the city's Hous ing and Development Ad ministration told a City Council committee yesterday that its proposed bill to dismantle the agency would make housing problems here worse instead of solving them.

title: AT HOME ABROAD
description: LONDON, Dec. 15There is won derful irony in the belief, now being expressed on all sides, that the United States can have peace in Vietnam if only it acts despite the objections of Nguyen Van Thieu, For American in dependence of Saigon has always been a prerequisite of any negotiated settle ment.

title: RICHARD F. MURRAY
description: Richard F. Murray, general manager and foreign manager of the American Society of Composers, Authors and Pub lishers from 1946 to 1962, died Tuesday in Sarasota, Fla., where he lived. His age was 74.

title: Griese Feels Backup Role Wil Continue in Playoffs
description: MIAMI, Dec. 15 (UPI)Bob Griese the Miami Dolphins quarterback said today he was resigned to backing up Earl Morrall through the champion ship playoff games.

title: Astronauts Will Get Raises Next Month
description: HOUSTON, Dec. 15 (UPI) The three Apollo 17 astro nauts will get raises next month under the President's order for increases for mem bers of the armed services and for most other Federal workers.

title: Sir Eugen MillingtonDrake, Envoy in Graf Spee Battle
description: LONDON, Dec. 15 (Reuters) Sir Eugen MillingtonDrake, the British diplomat who helped force the sinking of the Ger man pocket battleship Graf Spec in the River Plate in Uru guay in 1939, died Tuesday at the British Hospital in Paris. He was 83 years old.

title: Crusaders March to Victory
description: CLEVELAND, Ohio, Dec. 15 (AP)  Ron Buchanan scored two goals as the Cleveland Crusaders beat the Quebec Nor diques tonight, 63. The Nor diques took a 10 lead in the first period, but Billy Horton, a Cleveland defenseman, tied the score with his first goal as a professional.

title: Presidential Electors Chosen by Koreans
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Dec. 15South Koreans voted to day to elect 2,359 delegates to the National Conference for Unification, which will choose a new president.

title: Peddler Piddling
description: When Governor Rockefeller appointed Maurice H. Nadjari as the state's Super D.A. three months ago, the special prosecutor's mission was sharply defined by the circumstances that led to the creation of the new post. The Knapp Commission had called for extraordi nary and continuing efforts to root out official corrup tion. The situation in the city, particularly in the Police Department and the criminal justice system, was con sidered serious enough to justify the unusual step of superseding the regular district attorneys.

title: Leon MitkiewiczZolltek, Wartime Polish Delegate
description: Leon Mitkiewicz  Zolltek, who represented the Polish government in exile to the com bined Chiefs of Staff in Wash ington from 1943 to 1945, died Tuesday in Lenox Hill Hospi tal. He was 76 years old and lived at 531 East 81st Street.

title: NINE ARE ENTERED IN DISPLAY TODAY
description: The nation's longest major stakes race on the flat, the Dis play Handicap, will serve as the feature attraction on the program at Aqueduct today. If there is any kind of acceptable weather, which is rather un likely, a crowd of 35,000 may attend, for the card is the final one of the New York thorough bred racing season.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: A sharply increased avail ability of books and related educational materials is an urgent need of primary school systems in underde veloped nations, a fourday conference of 35 economists, educators and other experts from 12 nations concluded this week.

title: Kentucky, Oregon On Top
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., Dec. 15 (AP) Kentucky overwhelmed Nebraska, 8560, and Oregon rallied for a 7368 victory over Colorado State tonight in the first round of the Kentucky in vitation tournament.

title: A.B.A Picks TV Aid
description: Martin Carmichael, who was instrumental in getting the pro golf tour on television, has been named a TV consultant for the American Basketball Associ ation.

title: Kings Win in Overtime
description: OMAHA, Neb., Dec. 15 (AP) The Kansas CityOmaha Kings charged back from a 15point deficit to defeat the Detroit Pistons, 140.132, in overtime tonight. Dave Bing of the Pis tons sent the game into over time when he took an inbounds pass and fired from 30 feet, the ball banking off the glass and into the hoop with 2 seconds left.

title: Jet Forced Back to Field
description: MIAMI, Dec. 15 (UPI)  A Northwest Airlines 747 jetliner carrying 160 persons ran into a flock of birds as it took off here today, and then careened off a runway during an emer gency landing, injuring four passengers.

title: SingleRoomHotel Meeting Set Monday
description: Representatives of virtually every major local organization on the West Side will attend a communitywide meeting Mon day night to see what joint ac tion can be taken to force the city to improve conditions for tenants of singleroomoccu pancy buildings.

title: Agnew Sees Peace Hope
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (AP) Vice President Agnew, light ing the national Christmas tree today, said that the promise of peace burns brighter this Christmas than in recent years.

title: Screenwriter Jailed For a Threat to Nixon
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 15 (AP)  Norman Wexler, award  winning playwright and screenwriter, has been accused of threatening Pres ident Nixon's life and jailed pending a Federal hearing.

title: Teacher Wins Back Job Lost in Dispute With Board
description: MAHOPAC, N.Y., Dec. 15, (AP)  The Mahopac School Board voted 6 to 3 last night to reinstate a teacher who was dismissed 20 months ago be cause, she said, she had added a peace poster to a school Christmas display.

title: Cougars Conquer Squires by 11397 On Hot 2d Quarter
description: NORFOLK, Va., Dec. 15 (AP) The Carolina Cougars bolted to a 21point lead in the second quarter tonight and trounced the Virginia Squires, 11397, in an American Basketball Asso ciation game.

title: 4 Big Bakeries Fined for Price Fixing
description: Four major baking companies were fined a total of $175,000 in Federal Court here yester day for fixing bread prices in the New York region.

title: SelfHelp in Steel
description: The best insurance for a healthy steel industry able to expand its markets on a worldwide basis lies in joint efforts by the steel companies and their unionized work ers to make the industry more efficient. It does not lie in ultimately selfdefeating pressure for higher protective walls to shut foreign steel out of the American market.

title: Accord Will Permit Joint Displays and Facilitate Loans
description: PARIS, Dec. 15The Met ropolitan Museum of New York and the Louvre an nounced today a program of cooperation to make the treasures of two of the world's great museums available for joint exhibition.

title: BUILDING UNIONS TO TRAIN BLACKS
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 15The offi cers of 15 local building trades unions have joined with mem bers of the Chicago Contrac tors Association to train minor ity workers in construction skills and get them admitted to construction unions.

title: AMEX STIFFENS NEWLISTING RULE
description: The American Stock Ex change adopted yesterday stiffer listing standards for ap plicant companies engaged in the operation of race tracks and gambling casinos.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Dec. 15The first major Eastern indoor track and field meet of the season will be held at Princeton University's Jadwin Gym tomorrow when about 775 athletes from 37 colleges and universities compete in the second Princeton Relays.

title: Ricord Is Convicted of Plot To Smuggle Drugs to U.S.
description: Auguste Joseph Ricord was convicted in Federal District Court here yesterday of conspiring to smuggle narcotics, culminating a twoyear effort by the Government to sever the socalled LatinAmerican connection in international heroin trafficking.

title: Heaviest B52 Raids Strike at Supply Areas in North
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sat urday, Dec. 16American B52 bombers stepped up their raids on North Vietnam to a record of 16 missions during the 24 hour period ended at noon yes terday, United States military spokesmen reported.

title: Connecticut Bars Company From Selling Israeli Lots
description: HARTFORD, Dec. 15 (AP) The Connecticut Real Estate Commission refused yesterday to allow a Philadelphia com pany to advertise or sell in Connecticut home sites in Israel known as SabraCarmel Hills.

title: Treasury Bill Rates Mixed at Weekly Sale
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 Yields on 3month United States Treasury bills rose while yields on 6month bills remained unchanged in the Government's weekly competitive sale today of these shortterm securities.

title: People in Sports: Recovery Sign
description: What was on Johnny Bench's mind yesterday, 96 hours after lung surgery? I'll have to find a nurse, said the Cincinnati Reds' bachelor slugger. A couple of friends are nursesand they said they'd stay with me.

title: CubanChilean Communiqu
description: MIAMI, Dec. 15 (AP)Cuba and Chile issued a joint com muniqu today denouncing imperialist maneuvers that they said were designed to punish economically those countries that do not share North American social and ideological policies.

title: Peron Still Says No
description: BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 15 (AP)  The Justicialist convention cabled its nomination proclama tion to Mr. Pern in Asuncin, but he replied that his decision not to run was irreversible.

title: Screen: A Love Triangle:Montand Starred With Schneider in 'Cesar'
description: There has never been anything in the furiously energetic course of American movie-making to match the settled materialism of that particularly French phenomenon, an upper-bourgeois cinema, manifested in such films as Louis Malle's "Murmur of the Heart" or, much, less anarchically, in the work of Claude Sautet.Sautet is known here through some screenwriting credits but mainly through his own movie, "The Things of Life" (1969). Yesterday, his "Cesar and Rosalie," which comes billed as the rage of Paris opened at the Paris Theater in New York."Cesar and Rosalie" is a love triangle, with complications. Rosalie, formerly married to Antoine (her child's father), was actually in love with David, who let her marry Antoine and then disappeared.Now, after five years, David mysteriously reappears. But Rosalie is in love with Cesar, a middle-aged man whom she does not live with but often visits. Unavoidably, Rosalie is drawn back to David, then back to Cesar and so onand we have, in fairly rapid succession, arrangements of Cesar and Rosalie; David and Rosalie; Cesar, David and Rosalie; and even Cesar and David for a period when Rosalie figures that self-exile in Switzerland might be more sanitary.Cesar (Yves Montand) is a scrap-metal dealer, but with such success and on such a scale that his junkyard sounds like international finance. He is always calling on Rosalie to do translations. He is a self-made man: lean, cigar-smoking, fast-car driving, poker-playing, cognac-drinking, Bach-lovinga well-rounded diamond in the rough.David (Sami Frey) is a handsome young cartoonist, not rich (and not poor), but terribly well known.Everybody adores Rosalie (Romy Schneider), who is beautiful, wistful, agreeable, multilingual, moderately rich and very useful. No emotional crisis can keep Rosalie out of the kitchen, brewing up another pot of coffee or adding a last thoughtful dab of butter to the lobster amricaine. The lobster, of course, has been fresh caught.People live in decent, sometimes terrific apartments. When they are sad, they have good bars to drink in. There are pleasant townhouses and marvelous country houses. And at an important level, surroundings, backgrounds, familiesthe decent appurtenances of living with the upper middle classare what "Cesar and Rosalie" is all about.The love story is told with much lyricism, some passion and several bows to the style of "Jules and Jim" and "Two English Girls." But experiencing it all is somehow like exposure to very good, even subtle, table mannersimpressive but not too involving.There are real virtues in the film. Romy Schneider, for one, who has never been more calmly beautiful; and the exciting, fast country-driving sequences, of which there are several. As a director, Sautet is his best with automobiles, less good with small boats (apparently an interest of his), and with people fairly indifferent.The much-praised performance of Yves Montand seems less a characterization than a construction, carefully considered but very external. "Cesar and Rosalie" generally remains on the surface, catching clues and missing sources, like the type of slick magazine fiction to which it belongs.

title: AUTO MAKERS TOLD TO REMOVE DEVICE
description: DETROIT, Dec. 15  The En vironmental Protection Agency today ordered automobile manufacturers to stop installing devices aimed at turning off certain emission control equip ment.

title: Coast Newsmen File Suit To Free Jailed Reporter
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 15 (AP) Three newsmen have filed a Superior Court suit contending that Los Angeles County is spending public funds illegally to keep William Farr, a report er, in jail.

title: SOVIET AND CHINA BUY BRAZIL SUGAR
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 15 (AP) Brazil announced today she had sold 300,000 tons of sugar to the Soviet Union and 60,000 tons to China in her largest direct sales to the two Communist giants.

title: MRS. RICHARD GOODWIN
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 15 (AP)Mrs. Sandra Leverant Goodwin, wife of Richard N. Goodwin, a speechwriter for President John F. Kennedy, died yesterday.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: ENGLEWOOD, Dec. 15  Good morning, we've come to make an inspection, said John Ferraiola, spreading out copies of Chapter 12 of the State Sanitary Code.

title: Flag Law Unconstitutional
description: BOSTON, Dec. 15 (AP)The United States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit ruled yes terday that Massachusetts's 73 yearold flag desecration law was unconstitutional and upheld a lower court ruling that wear ling the flag on the seat of one's trousers is not a crime.

title: CELTICS HOLD OFF LAKERSBY 10298
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 15 (AP) Dave Cowens scored 31 points and played inspiring defense to lead the Boston Celtics to a 10298 victory over the Los An geles Lakers tonight in the Na tional Basketball Association. Cowens pulled down 19 re bounds and harassed Wilt Chamberlain as the Celtics won their seventh in a row and ran the N.B.A.'s best wonlost rec ord to 243.

title: Poseidon Missile Fired
description: CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Dec. 15 (AP)A submerged United States Navy nuclear submarine testfired today a Poseidon mis sile about 30 miles off the coast of this rocket launching facility. The official refused to say how far the missile had traveled or whether the test had been successful.

title: Sugar Units Named In Antitrust Study
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 15 (AP)A Federal Grand Jury is conducting an antitrust in vestigation into at least six major sugar companies, indus try spokesmen said today.

title: News Analysis
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 15If every citizen decided to preempt his share of the national parks at the same time, he would be standing on about onetenth of an acre, within a pebble's toss of the next person.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: WEST MILFORD, N.J., Dec. 15The colder weather has meant fewer patrons at the Warner Brothers Jungle Habi tat, the drivethrough zoo that opened to large crowds last summer, so there are fewer cars now to tie up traffic and disturb local residents. But the question of animal security is causing some new concern here.

title: WINE TALK
description: Why not a wine book for A gift this Christmas? There are some excellent ones around and because they are part textbook and part art book, they make great gifts.

title: 3 Goals in 21 Seconds
description: Bill Mosienko of the Chicago Black Hawks scored a National Hockey League record three goals in 21 seconds against the New York Rangers on March 23, 1952.

title: New England Development Agency to Be Revised
description: BOSTON, Dec. 15 (AP)  New England's governors unanimously ordered today an immediate freeze on the hiring of new personnel for the con troversial New England Re gional Commission and called for an evaluation of the fed erally funded development agency with a view toward re ducing its size and programs.

title: Choate and Andover Sextets Reach Lawrenceville Final
description: LAWRENCEVILLE, N. J., Dec. 15Choate defeated Taft 61 tonight, and Andover downed Kimball Union, 74, in the semifinal round of the Law renceville School invitation hockey tournament.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: With regard to Jeffery St. John's attack [OpEd Dec. 5] on futurists, specifically the Meadows, Meadows, Randers and Behrens study (The Lim its to Growth), I must take exception with his claim that they are unsci entific and intellectually dishonest. This is not true.

title: U.S. and Chile to Open Talks Next Week
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15Ad ministration officials said today that the United States and Chile would begin highlevel talks here next Wednesday aimed at finding solutions to the increasing problems be tween them.

title: Long Island Rail Walkout Beginning to Hurt Stores
description: The shutdown of the Long Island Rail Road, which had lit tle effect on departmentstore business shortly after the rail workers struck Nov. 30, is be ginning to hurt normal Christ mas business at a number of big stores in Nassau and Suf folk Counties.

title: Music: Superb Bartok
description: Pierre Boulez and the New York Philharmonic are sched uled to record Bartk's Con certo for Orchestra on Mon day, and if Thursday night's subscription performance can be taken as a fair indication, the disk could be a prize winner. Mr. Boulez conducted a remarkable performance of the Bartk, one that threw down the glove to the best that this listener has ever heard. Until now, one had thought that Fritz Reiner and the Chicago Symphony could never be equaled in this score, but Mr. Boulez planted his Bartk Concerto on that lofty level.

title: The Peace Talks: Questions and Answers
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15  With another round in the Paris negotiations ended and with Henry A. Kissinger back in Washington briefing officials, many important questions re main unanswered publicly, and uncertainty and confusion con tinue to surround the talks. Fol lowing are some of the ques tions and an attempt to define the situation that now exists:

title: Egan Links Slipshod Practices In Police Office to Heroin Theft
description: Edward R. Egan, the Frenck Connection detective who was dismissed because he allegedly mishandled drugs seized as evi dence, charged yesterday that slipshod procedures in the property clerk's office of they Police Department might have been behind the theft of $10 million worth of heroin from a police office vault.

title: Miners' Victory
description: Unionism is a stronghold of the oneparty system of government. Challengers of the entrenched leadership can expect vilification as selfish adventurers, agents of the employers and wreckers of the union's hardwon gains. Nowhere has this despotic tradition been more ingrained than in the United Mine Workers, once the most powerful of unions, now a scandalracked skeleton.

title: Rose Lanu Quong Is Dead; Chinese Actress and Author
description: Rose Lanu Quong, Chinese actress, author and lecturer, who gave solo shows here for many years, died Thursday in Midtown Hospital. She was 93 years old and lived at 240 West 73d Street.

title: It's Not FootandMouth in Britain
description: LONDON, Dec. 15  A disease that has caused the slaughter of more than a thousand head of livestock in England's Midlands in the last week was identified today as swine vesicular disease and not footandmouth disease, as had been suspected.

title: Swedish Ship Sinks in Crash
description: SIMRISHAMN, Sweden, Dec. 15 (Reuters)  The 1,504ton Swedish cargoship Nova sank today after a collision with the Greek oil tanker Theofano Li vanos in the Baltic. First re ports said that one man froom the Nova had been killed in the collision.

title: STALEY REELECTED BY FARMERS' GROUP
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Dec. 15 (AP)Oren Lee Staley, beating back the challenge of dissidents who had sought to depose him, was reelected today to an 18th year as president of the Na tional Farmers Organization.

title: Mystery of Visitor to Silverplating Plant
description: ALBANY, Dec. 15 (AP) An elderly man walked into the Oneida, Ltd., plant near Utica last March and intro duced himself as William Green, an inspector for the United States Labor Depart ment. He said he wanted to look over the operations of the silverware factory.

title: Ban on Long Hair Urged
description: EDMONTON, Alberta, Dec. 15 (Canadian Press)The proced ures committee of the Canadian Federation of Amateur Baseball wants to ban excessively long hair.
