Chairman Ron Hayter said yesterday that the longhair ban was sparked by a flood of complaints about the appear ance of the Ontario team, which, won the 1972 junior champion ship.

title: Chaps Edge Rackets
description: DALLAS, Dec. 15 (AP) Skeeter Swift hit a pair of free throws with 16 seconds left tonight, preserving the Cha parrals' narrow edge and Dallas beat the Denver Rockets, 10499.

title: AUBURN LAND SOLD TO JAPANESE GROUP
description: AUBURN, N.Y. Dec. 15 (AP) A 175acre parcel of land on Auburn's northwestern edge was sold today for $200,000 to Japanese business interests erecting a steel plant in this central New York city.

title: Notes on People
description: The new director of Women Marines is Col. Margaret A. Brewer, who has spent 20 of her 42 years with the corps. She will be the seventh di rector of the Women Marines, succeeding Col. Jeanette I. Sustad, who is retiring. Col onel Brewer, who is currently serving at the Marine Corps Development and Education Command at Quantico, Va., was born in Lansing, Mich., and is a graduate of the Uni versity of Michigan. As to her plans for command of the 2,000 women marines, Colonel Brewer said: Everything has happened so fast, I haven't had the chance to think about what I want to do yet.

title: Army Outclassed
description: LAWRENCE, Kan., Dec. 15 (AP)A sophomore, Rick Set tle, contributed 20 points and was a defensive standout as Kansas surpirsed Texas Tech, 6751, tonight in the Jayhawk basketball tournament opening round. Kansas will meet unde feated San Francisco, an 8770 firstgame victor over badly outclassed Army, in the final tomorrow night.

title: New England Resists Land Development Pressures
description: MONTPELIER, Vt., Dec. 15 That little place in the country may become a fad ing dream for many urban residents because of reaction to the explosive pressures for land development in the upper New England states.

title: Clerk in Governor's Office Confesses to Petit Larceny
description: A mail room and clerical employe at Governor Rocke feller's office at 22 West 55th Street has pleaded guilty to petit larceny in connection with a charge that he had completed travel vouchers worth at least $250, using fic titious names, for his own use.

title: Jersey Study Urges Full Legal Gambling
description: TRENTON, Dec. 15The chairman of the Legislative Gambling Study Commission announced today that it had voted to recommend that the gambling prohibition in the State Constitution be elimi nated and that the Governor and the Legislature be empow ered to legalize any form of gambling.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Your straightforward position [edi torial Dec. 6] on the Unionized Uni versity deals with an issue which is statewide and national in scope.

title: Big 2 Remain Unbeaten
description: GREENSBORO, N. C. Dec. 15 (UPI)North Carolina Stale weathered a second  half rally to defeat Wake Forest, 8883, and North Carolina rallied to beat Duke, 9186 tonight in the Big Four Tournament. The win ners, both unbeaten, will meet tonight in the final.

title: AMEX AND OTC SHOW MIXED TONE
description: Stocks on the American Stock Exchange and on the overthecounter market ended mixed yesterday in active trad ing.

title: The Lost Ones
description: kindle again before passing face and body. But enough will always subsist to spell for this little people the extinction soon or late of its last re maining fires.

title: PLAYOFF AT STAKE FOR 49ERS TODAY
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 15 (UPI)  The San Francisco 49ers shoot for their third straight National Football Con ference West title, while the disappointed Minnesota Vikings play for pride tomorrow when the clubs meet in the final regularseason game of the 1972 season.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: The recent oil spill in the East River causes me again to ask why, after almost three and a half centuries of hazardous use of the waters in and near Hell Gate for navigation, the rocks and ledges that are the worst of such hazards have not been removed, so that if a ship goes aground for any reason, what it encounters will truly be ground, and not rock capable of ripping through its hull.

title: An Indicted Suffolk Legislator Suspends Himself From a Job
description: HAUPPAUGE, LI., Dec. 15 The chairman of the Parks Committee of the Suffolk County Legislature, R. Thomas Strong, suspended himself as chairman of that committee today after being asked to do so by Michael J. Grant, the Legis lature's presiding officer.

title: Police Say That They Lost 24 More Pounds of Heroin
description: Twentyfour more pounds of heroin impounded during the celebrated French Connection case of a decade ago has been stolen from the Police Depart ment's cluttered propertystor age room in Manhattan.

title: Morocco Gives 4 ExMinisters Jail Terms for Taking Bribes
description: RABAT, Morocco, Dec. 15 Pour former Cabinet ministers who controlled the Moroccan economy were sentenced to prison terms ranging from 4 to 12 years today when convicted of accepting bribes from Euro pean and American companies who were awarded multimillion dollar contracts in Morocco.

title: Explosion Kills 21 In Coke Plant Test Off Weirton, W.Va.
description: WEIRTON, W. Va., Dec. 15 (AP)  Twentyone men were killed today in an explosion and fire at the Weirton Steel Division's new coke plant on Brown Island in the Ohio River.

title: APOLLO SURVEYS SURFACE OF MOON ON FINAL ORBITS
description: HOUSTON, Dec. 15Apollo 17 circled the moon today, sur veying its surface with cameras and remotesensing instruments and preparing for the rocket blast tomorrow that should start the astronauts on their re turn journey to earth.

title: JOSEPH C. SCHREINER
description: Dr. Joseph C. Schreiner, a general practitioner and sur geon who retired in 1970 after practicing mostly in Flushing, Queens, died Dec. 9 at Vero Beach, Fla. He was 81 years old and lived in Monsey, N. Y.

title: Space Engineers Of U.S. and Soviet Test Docking Move,
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 15 (AP) Soviet and American engineers have made the first tests of a docking mechanism to be used in the joint space mission planned for the last half of 1975.

title: Sports of The Times
description: MIAMI, Dec. 15Under a warm sun, with thick puffy clouds moving quickly along the flat horizon of green leafy trees, the unbeaten Miami Dolphins were going through their last hard practice before tomorrow's game. In white jerseys without numbers, the offensive unit was simulating the plays of the Baltimore Colts against the defensive unit, which wore aqua jerseys. Fifty yards downfield, behind the defense, Coach Don Shula, in an orange shirt and blue shorts, watched the defense intently. When something dis pleased him, his voice barked.

title: New England Resists Land Development Pressures
description: MONTPELIER Vt., Dec. 15 That little place in the country may become a fad ing dream for many urban residents because of reaction to the explosive pressures for land development in the upper New England states.

title: POLICE END DRIVE AGAINST PEDDLERS
description: The police suspended their weekold drive against street venders of hot dogs yesterday after a mayoral aide described the order for seizure of the pushcarts and the arrest and daylong detention of the vend ers as too sweeping.

title: WEST TEXAS FIVE FACES L.I.U. TODAY
NEW JERSEY
description: TRENTON, Dec. 15  Con spicuously displayed sanitary inspection notices  white for pass, yellow for maybe, pink for an at least temporary clos ingmade their initial appear ance today at restaurants as New Jersey began to implement the country's toughest state wide health code for retail food establishments.

title: 2,100 Pupils Out of Classes In Brooklyn School Boycott
description: The Board of Education re ported that only 469 pupils of 2,566 registered in three of Brooklyn's elementary schools that have been affected by a boycott attended school yester day.

title: In Japan, 6 O'Clock Niusu for Children
description: TOKYO, Dec. 15Have you ever flicked on your television and sat down to watch the news of the miseries of the world only to have your children grumble: News? Aw, do we have to watch that stuff again?

title: Patents of the Week
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 A 14yearold boy invented a simple way to show his father's age on a birthday cake. He managed to do it with one candle displaying three colors. John Henry Kumm, now 17 and a high school sen ior in Severna Park, Md., will he be granted Patent 3,706, 523 next week for the one candle device, which is called Resistage. Three years ago, when the invention was made, the boy's father, Wil liam H. Kumm, was 39. In stead of using 39 candles or spelling out the number, the inventor drew on the inter national electronic compo nent code found on resistors in radios and television sets. He had run across the code while putting together a ra dio delivered in kit form.

title: Jersey Study Urges Full Legal Gambling
description: TRENTON, Dec. 14  The chairman of the Legislative Gambling Study Commission announced today that it had voted to recommend that the gambling prohibition in the State Constitution be elimi nated and that the Governor and the Legislature be empow ered to legalize any form of gambling.

title: Merger News
description: Iowa Beef Processors, Inc., announced yesterday it had en tered into preliminary negoti ations with Missouri Beef Pack ers, Inc., on the possibility of combining the two companies.

title: BLAZERS TRIUMPH OVER JETS BY 64
description: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 15 (AP)Bryan Campbell and Mi chel Plante rapped in two goals each tonight and carried the Philadelphia Blazers to a 64 victory over the Winnipeg Jets.

title: Carrier Midway to Make Her Home Port in Japan
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (UPI) The Pentagon announced to day that the carrier Midway, would be based at Yokosuka, Japan, starting next spring. This is believed to be the first time a United States carrier has been assigned a home port overseas.

title: F.D.A. Sets Severe Restrictions on Use of Methadone
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15se vere restrictions on the use of methadone were made public today by the Food and Drug Administration in an effort to exert better control over this widely used substitute for her oin.

title: REV. JOSEPH FINEGAN
description: The Rev. Joseph Henry Fine gan, believed to be the oldest member of the Paulist fathers, died yesterday at a nursing home in the Bronx. He was 88 years old.

title: Dance: Alum Company
description: A very important event took place for the young Puerto Ricanborn dancer Manuel Alum at the new and very agreeable Exchange Theater on Bank Street on Thursday night. His new troupe, the Manuel Alum Dance Company, made its highly successful debut.

title: PLAYOFF AT STAKE FOR 49ERS TODAY
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 15 (UPI)  The San Francisco 49ers shoot for their third straight National Football Con ference West title, while the disappointed Minnesota Vikings play for pride tomorrow when the clubs meet in the final regularseason game of the 1972 season.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (AP)Creditcard companies that issue cards to corporations can now be held respon sible for charges run up after the card is lost or stolen from a corporation employe.

title: Oklahoma State's Smith Named Coach at S.M.U.
description: DALLAS, Dec. 15 (AP) Southern Methodist Univer sity hired Dave Smith of Oklahoma State today as head football coach. Smith was an assistant coach for eight years at S.M.U. until he went to Winnipeg of the Canadian Football League in 1970, where he was offensive coordinator.

title: BRITAIN PUTS OFF REPEGGING POUND
description: LONDON, Dec. 15Britain will not fix a new parity for the floating pound before she enters the European Economic Community next month, An thony Barber, the Chancellor of the Exchequer, told the House of Commons today.

title: F.D.A. Proposes New Rule On Refunds for Unsafe Toys
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (AP) The Food and Drug Admin istration today revived a two yearold proposal guaranteeing refunds to customers who buy dangerous toys or other banned hazardous substances.

title: DOW INDEX POSTS A 2.18POINT GAIN
description: A report that a ceasefire in Vietnam was, imminent sparked a rally in the stock market yesterday, but a denial from Washington halted the buy ing and the market closed on the fence.

title: Antoinette Roberts, a Buyer, Is Bride
description: St. James's Episcopal Church was the setting here yester day afternoon for the mar riage of Miss Antoinette Lewis Roberts, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Alexander Roberts of New York, to Benjamin Brewster, son of Edward Cox Brewster of Easton, Md., and Upper St. Regis, N. Y., and Mrs. John George Jones of Charlottes ville, Va., and New York.

title: News Analysis
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 15It has long been a mockserious journalistic dic tum here that there are no facts in Vietnam.

title: Two in Soviet Visa Battle Reported Seeking Divorce
description: JERUSALEM, Dec. 15 (UPI) Six weeks after Judith Silver Shapiro won her fight for an exit visa from the Soviet Union for her husband, Gavriel, the Shapiros are apparently plan ning a divorce, Jewish Agency officials said today.

title: Security Talks Recess
description: HELSINKI, Finland, Dec. 15 (UPI)The 34nation talks on preparations for a European se curity conference recessed for a month today with no agree ment on how to organize the planned fullscale EastWest ne gotiations. Conference sources said, however, that the ambas sadors representing 32 East and West European nations, plus the United States and Canada, went home for the holidays feeling that progress had been made during the more than three weeks of talks.

title: Judge Suspends Himself Pending Result of Inquiry
description: NEWBURGH, N.Y., Dec. 15 (AP)  City Court Judge Charles Roskoski voluntarily suspended himself from the bench yesterday pending re sults of an investigation into his involvement in an incident at a Newburgh diner early Tuesday.

title: DAILY RECORD IS SET AT OLD GLORY SALES
description: YONKERS, Dec. 15Part 1 of the twoday Old Glory Sale attracted 750 horsemen and horsewomen, who spent $433, 600 for 140 standardbreds at Yonkers Raceway today. The average of $3,097 set a record for a single day's Old Glory winter sale.

title: DOLPHINS CHOICE TO FINISH AT 140
description: MIAMI, Dec. 15Under the microscope of a national TV audience, the Miami Dolphins will attempt tomorrow to be come the first National Foot ball League team to complete an unbeaten 14game season.

title: Marist Wins 3d Straight
description: POUGHKEEPSIE, N. Y. Dec. 15 (AP)Marist scored its third straight victory tonight by de feating Kings Point, 7167. Jim Osika, a junior forward, came off the bench to score 17 points and grab 17 rebounds for the winner. Marist is 52.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Your Dec. 6 editorial Unionized University equates faculty unionism, along with automatic promotion and instant tenure, with an adoption of the public school staffing model, teachers being interchangeable.

title: Getty, 80, Feted on Birthday by Duchess Flute Debut
description: LONDON, Dec. 15  Jean Paul Getty, probably the world's richest man, cele brated his 80th birthday un til early this morning with 200 guests, a phone call from President Nixon, an exchange of cheek kisses with women spanning three generations, and a promise never to marry again.

title: Books of The Times
description: IN MY OWN WAY. By Alan Watts. An Autobiography. 400 pages, Pantheon. $7.95.

title: TRUMAN IMPERILED BY KIDNEY FAILURE
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Dec. 15 Former President Harry S. Tru man, already hospitalized in very serious condition be cause of lung congestion and a weak heart, was threatened to night by kidney failure and in ability to absorb nourishment as his condition further deteri orated.

title: Flute Debut
description: Carol Wincenc, Juilliard trained and currently princi pal flutist of the St. Paul Chamber Orchestra, came back to New York on Thurs day night to make her debut here in Carnegie Recital Hall as a solo artist, sponsored by the Concert Artists Guild.

title: Pacers Sign Johnson
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Dec. 15 (AP) The Indiana Pacers of the American Basketball Associa tion have signed Gus Johnson, an injurytroubled 10year vet eran of the National Basket ball Association. He began practicing with the Pacers today. Johnson was put on waivers by the Phoenix Suns this season after averaging 8 points and 7 rebounds in 21 games.

title: FUTURES PRICES OFF RECORD PACE
description: Trading on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday ended one of the most hectic weeks in the exchange's history, with prices relatively unchanged from Thursday's level.

title: People and Business
description: Major Gen. Jewell C. Max well, who retired from the Air Force on Nov. 1 after more than 30 years of serv ice, joined the Boeing Com pany as a vice president on Nov. 30. According to the aerospace company, he is on special assignment reviewing technical and management program performance.

title: TV: Royal Romance of the Windsors Is Portrayed
description: With its tasteful color, ef fective costumes and make up and plush settings, tele vision's Portrait: The Wom an I Love is a beautiful 1936 tapestry austerely de picting two genteel, literate sweethearts. One is a king. Or was.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: Works by an unusual group of artistsinmates at a maxi mumsecurity prlsonwill go on view Feb. 2 at the National Collection of Fine Arts of the Smithsonian Institution in Washington. The display, en titled From Within, will continue through March 25 and then travel to museums in New York and other cities.

title: WEST TEXAS FIVE FACES L.I.U. TODAY
description: It is a long jump from the Texas Panhandle to Madison Square Garden. Perhaps, sug gested Coach Dennis Walling yesterday, that is one reason why his West Texas State basketball team has never won in the big arena.

title: Soviet Tank Reported Taken
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Dec. 15 (UPI)  Irregular troops spon sored by the Central Intel ligence Agency captured a So viet Made T34 tank east of the Laotian panhandle town of Mu ong Phalane, United States of ficials said today.

title: Market Place: Tracking Down The Ideal Fund
description: The business of evaluating mutual fund holdings is al most as demanding as own ing stocks directly.

title: Northwestern's Agase New Purdue Head Coach
description: WEST LAFAYETTE, hid., Dec. 15 (AP)Alex Agase, the head football coach at Northwestern University for nine seasons, was named head coach at Purdue Univer sity tonight.

title: 37 INDICTMENTS ISSUED ON ATTICA
description: The special Wyoming County grand jury investigating last year's inmate rebellion at the Attica Correctional Facility re turned its first indictments yes terday. But it will be impossi ble, until Monday, to know who or how many were indicted, and on what charges, because all 37 indictments were sealed.

title: Art: German Drawings
description: Geography, rather than tal ent, seems to be the problem with the exhibition German Master Drawings of the 19th Century, now on view at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Like the exhibition of 19th century Italian paintings shown last month at the New York Cultural Center, it represents the art of a cul tural backwater.

title: Unlicensed Mental Therapists Accused of Sexual Abuses
description: Accounts of emotional abuse and sexual exploitation were presented yesterday at a packed bearing into quackery and al leged sexual misconduct by the state's unregulated mental health therapists.

title: Mrs. Sterling Wed to Michael Rea
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 Mrs. Elizabeth Beach Sterling and Michael Moorhead Rea were married here at noon today. The Rev. Dr. Seth R. Brooks, a Universalist minis ter, performed the ceremony at the couple's new home.

title: Boy, 12, Is Shot by Robber On 114th Street in Harlem
description: A 12yearold boy was shot yesterday on a Harlem street after he refused to give his money to a man with a re volver, the police of the West 123d Street station reported.

title: Jersey Restaurants Rated on Sanitation
description: TRENTON, Dec. 15 Con spicuously displayed sanitary inspection notices  white for pass, yellow for maybe, pink for an at least temporary clos ingmade their initial appear ance today at restaurants as New Jersey began to implement the country's toughest state wide health code for retail food establishments.

title: SOME DEPUTIES BALK AT POLYGRAPH TESTS
description: BATON ROUGE, La., Dec. 15 (UPI)The United States At torney Douglas Gonzales said today several of the six deputies suspected by the F.B.I. in the killings of two Southern Uni versity students Nov. 16 had refused to take liedetector tests.

title: the Police Connection
description: With understatement, Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy has characterized as a scandal in the depart ment the theft of heroinwhich yesterday was revealed to total 81 poundsfrom a Police Headquarters annex on Broome Street. Not only is the loss of that quantity of drugs unprecedented for any American lawenforce ment agency, but the crime is conceded to have all the earmarks of an inside job.

title: DEATH OF PHYSICIAN CALLED A HOMICIDE
description: The death or a 74yearold physician who was found bound and gagged in his West Side quarters Thursday eve ning was listed as a homicide due to strangulation, the Medi cal Examiner's office reported yesterday.

title: 21 Die in Explosion
description: Twentyone men were killed and at least 20 were injured yesterday in an explosion and fire at a new coke plant on an island in the Ohio River off Weirton, W. Va. Page 62.

title: BLOOD BANKS' END IN 3 YEARS SEEN
description: Within the next three years, officials of the Greater New York Blood Program predicted yesterday, volunteer blood do nors will be supplying all the blood that hospitals here need for transfusions.

title: America's New Voice
description: During four years as director of the United States Information Agency Frank J. Shakespeare Jr. has irri tated foreigners, demoralized old agency hands and embarrassed American diplomacy with his stridently propagandistic hardline approach to the presentation of American policy abroad.

title: Bridge:2d Bid by Potential Dummy May Give a Clue to Defense
description: When the potential dummy has bid two suits, the second of them is often the one for the defense to lead. A con vincing illustration of this occurred in a recent Von Zedtwitz Knockout Team match in New York.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: While you touched upon extremely valid issues such as pay increases and tenure in your editorial Unionized University, you failed to raise what seems to me to be the most obvious question: If the Board of Higher Edu cation (B.H.E.) and the union both owe their existence to the needs of the students whom they serve, why don't students have a voice in the contract which will shape educational policy for years to come?

title: Brandt Declares He Will Stress Domestic Affairs in 2d Term
description: BONN, Dec. 15Willy Brandt started his second term as Chancellor today with a vow that he would be as down to earth as possible, and indicat ed that he expected to concen trate on domestic policy.

title: YOUNG WORKERS FOUND RESTLESS
description: A oneyear study of young workers, primarily bluecollar employes, concerning their at titudes towards themselves and their fellow workers has dis closed that 20 per cent were dissatisfied with their work life, 20 per cent were happy and 60 per cent ambivalent and resigned to their situation.

title: EXSOVIET TENOR GIVES U.S. DEBUT
description: One of Russia's betterkept cultural secrets over the last 25 years, Mikhail Alexandrovich made his American debut Thurs day night in Town Hall. Al though an immensely popular singer in the Soviet Union (he has received the Stalin Prize. and more than 20 million of his records have been sold), the tenor, who is Jewish, was never allowed an exit visa un til last year. He is currently a resident of Israel and the cantor at the synagogue of Ramat Gam.

title: Key Call Aids Bullets
description: BALTIMORE, Dec. 15 (AP) Wes Unsold's controversial layup with 19 seconds left and his clinching free throws with a second remaining gave the Baltimore Bullets a 9491 Na tional Basketball Association victory over the Houston Rockets tonight.

title: Canadian Hijacker Ordered To Undergo Mental Test
description: MONTREAL, Dec. 15 (Reu ters)The hijacker of a Que becair passenger liner was or dered to undergo a mental examination today when he appeared in court a day after surrendering to police at the international airport here.

title: Sports of The Times
description: MIAMI, Dec. 15Under a warm sun, with thick puffy clouds moving quickly along the flat horizon of green leafy trees, the unbeaten Miami Dolphins were going through their last hard practice before tomorrow's game. In white jerseys without numbers, the offensive unit was simulating the plays of the Baltimore Colts against the defensive unit, which wore aqua jerseys. Fifty yards downfield, behind the defense, Coach Don Shula, in an orange shirt and blue shorts, watched the defense intently. When something dis pleased him, his voice barked.

title: Nixon and Kissinger Meet, But Are Silent on a Truce
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 Henry A. Kissinger met with President Nixon today for the fourth time in two days and conferred individually with other high Administration offi cials on the outlook for negotiated settlement of the Vietnam war.

title: Tennessee, Missouri Win
description: KNOXVILLE. Tenn., Dec. 15 (AP)  Tennessee escaped the clutches of a press defense late in the game and defeated Syra cuse, 8783, in the Volunteer tournament tonight Missouri took advantage of a seldom called lane violation to beat Holy Cross, 6865. The winners meet tomorow night.

title: Medieval Tapestry and Drawings to Be Shown Here
description: The exhibition exchange between the Metropolitan Mu seum and the Louvre is, ac cording to Douglas Dillon, president of the Metropoli tan, the most important loan agreement ever made between two of the world's leading museums.

title: ISRAEL S. FELD, 61, OF RINGLING BROS.
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (AP) Israel S. Feld, who with his brother Irvin owned the Ringling Bros and Barnum & Bailey Circus, died today at his home here after a heart attack. He was 61 years old.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: Records on Federal Program Stolen

title: RiotTom Madagascar Port Is Calmer
description: TAMATAVE, Madagascar, Dec. 15 (Agence FrancePresse) Refugees continued to stream out of this port city today in the wake of three days of tribal rioting, looting and arson.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (AP)In a twopronged cere mony Rumania today became a member of the International Monetary Fund and signed a new cultural exchange pro gram with the United States.

title: Panel Favors a Statewide Integration Plan for Construction Industry Over Present Hometown Efforts
description: Socalled hometown plans to integrate the construction in dustry should be replaced by a single statewide program, an advisory committee to the Unit ed States Civil Rights Com mission said yesterday.

title: Apollo Flight Highlights
description: Following are the high lights of the revised Apollo 17 flight plan. The timetable is subject to change at any time during the mission. Times are Eastern standard.

title: End of Another Season for an Old Titan
description: Reports of Larry Gran tham's retirement always seem to surface at this time of year.

title: FROZEN LIMA BEANS MAKE 2D FAMILY ILL
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Dec. 15 (UPI)A second case in which a family became ill after eating Deerfield Fordhook frozen lima beans was reported today by state health officials.

title: Montessori Society Scores Use of Name on Toys
description: American Montessori Society officials accused toy and game manufacturers of deceptively labeling toys and games Mon tossori even though these products have no connection with the worldwide educational system.

title: Aeros Winncrs, 32
description: ST. PAUL, Dec. 15 (AP) Jack Stanfield scored on a breakaway with 7:10 remaining, giving the Houston Aeros a 32 triumph over the Minnesota Fighting Saints tonight. Stan

title: 3 Price Increases Granted
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (AP) The Price Commission granted preChristmas price increases today to the Mattel Company, a leading toy manufacturer; the Bulova Watch Company, and George A. Hormel & Co. meat packers.

title: UPSTATE RACKETEER GUILTY OF EXTORTION
description: BUFFALO, Dec. 15 (UPI) Two of four men, including the reputed Rochester gambling boss, Frank J. Valenti, were found guilty last night on various counts of conspiracy and extortion in connection with extorting money from a suburban Buffalo contractor.

title: Biggs Is Guide for a Tour of Church Organs
description: E. Power Biggs has nothing personal against Benjamin Franklin, but the emi nent organist says he has misgivings about the episode with the kite.

title: JOHN REARDON SINGS AS STANDIN AT MET
description: John Reardon, who stepped in for an indisposed Cesare Si epi Thursday night to sing his first Don Giovanni at the Met ropolitan Opera, did a com mendable jobespecially con sidering the circumstances. He had never performed the part in Italian before, had not sung it at all since the midsixties (he can't remember exactly when) and had had, to put it charitably, minimal rehearsal.

title: Princeton Six Loses, 32
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Dec. 15 Paul Boudreau, a junior left wing, scored on a breakaway after 2 minutes 37 seconds of overtime tonight lifting the New Hampshire hockey team to victory over Princeton, 32. It was New Hampshire's sixth victory against two losses and two ties. Princeton is 16.

title: 70 Years Late, Woman, 100, Gets Degree at Oxford
description: OXFORD, England, Dec. 15 Dressed in jeans and duffel coats, carrying cardboard suit cases  the proletarian look has not been replaced  the young men and women of Oxford University jammed the platform this morning waiting for trains to take them home for the Christmas break. One young woman pored over a math exam paper; another, for some reason, held a new orange broom.

title: ATTACK FROM SYRIA REPORTED BY ISRAEL
description: TEL AVIV, Dec. 15An at tack from Syria broke a three week lull on the occupied Golan heights today, Israel reported.

title: U.N. Votes a Global Ecology Project Based in Nairobi
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 15The General Assem bly today approved the estab lishment of an ambitious inter national program for safeguard ing the human environment.

title: ISRAEL WEINSTEIN
description: Israel Weinstein, who was a member of the Jewish Welfare Board during World War II and served on the Veterans Admin istration Rating Board until 1957, died yesterday at the Manhattan Veterans Hospital. His age was 83, and he lived at 788 Columbus Avenue.

title: Struck New Haven Papers Stop Payment for Fringes
description: NEW HAVEN, Dec. 15 (UPI) A spokesman for striking pressmen at The New Haven Register and The JournalCour ier said yesterday that the newspaper had stopped paying medical and life insurance premiums for the workers.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: $2.1Million Awarded for Injury

title: ROBIN F. GARLAND
description: SARASOTA, Fla., Dec. 15 Robin F. Garland, former pho tography editor for The Satur day Evening Post, died yester day at his home here. He was 58 years old.

title: Police Say That They Lost 24 More Pounds of Heroin
description: Twentyfour more pounds of heroin impounded during the celebrated French Connection case of a decade ago has been stolen from the Police Depart ment's cluttered propertystor age room in Manhattan.

title: Merger Master Rises in France
description: PARIS, Dec. 15 Antoine Riboud started off selling bottles and ended up in con trol of the company that makes them. Then he went on to make the stuff that goes inside.

title: House Chairman Switches
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (UPI) Representative Olin E. Tea gue, Democrat of Texas, will give up the chairmanship of the House Veterans Affairs Com mittee after 17 years to become chairman of the Science and Astronautics Committee, his office said today. Mr. Teague, 62 years old, will succeed George P. Miller, Democrat of Cali fornia, who was defeated for reelection. Under the House seniority system, Representa tive William Jennings Bryan Dorn, Democrat of South Caro lina, stands to succeed Mr. Teague as head of the veterans committee.

title: Desiree WindischGraetz, Austrian Princess Is Dead
description: Princess Desirde Windisch Graetz, the widow of Prince Franz J. N. WindischGraetz, who was a greatgrandson of the Emperor Franz Josef of AustriaHungary, died Thurs day after a long illness. She was 65 years old and lived at 350 East 57th Street.

title: LOCOMOTIVES SMASH SINKING SHIP'S HOLD
description: The Coast Guard reported yesterday that a freighter with eight locomotives running wild in its hold was sinking in heavy seas about 680 miles southeast of Halifax, Nova Scotia.

title: 21 Die in Explosion
description: Twentyone men were killed and at least 20 were injured yesterday in an explosion and fire at a new coke plant on an island in the Ohio River off Weirton, W. Va. Page 62.

title: Phone Tax to Drop 10%
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (UPI) The Federal telephone excise tax will fall from 10 per cent to 9 beginning Jan. 1, the In ternal Revenue Service said to day. The tax, which covers local telephone service, toll calls and teletype services, will drop 1 per cent a year and finally be phased out in 1982, the agency said.

title: Sam Francis Focus of Whitney Display
description: The career of the Ameri can painter Sam Francis is something of a historical od dity. Now 49 years old, he has been for many years one of the most celebrated ab stract painters on the world scene, yet he is one of the very few American artists of his generation whose repu tation and influence owe little or nothing to New York.

title: Sicily Court's Ban on Newsman Brings Wide Protests in Italy
description: ROME, DCC, 15  Italian newsmen are protesting a court order banning a Sicilian writer editor from practicing the journalistic profession for a year following a conviction on a libel charge.

title: Biggest Disappearance, Say U.S. Drug Officials
description: Officials of the two major Federal agencies involved in seizing and storing contra band drugs said yesterday that they knew of no disap pearances of heroin com parable to those reported by the New York Police Depart meat this week.

title: EQUAL PRICES URGED FOR PIPELINE USERS
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15  The Federal Power Commission staff has recommended for the first time that a major inter state natural gas pipeline stop charging big customers lower average prices tuna are paid by small customers.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Kerr Defends Housing Agency

title: City's Fuel Oil Employes Accept 2Year Labor Pact
description: Employes of the city's major fuel oil companies voted yes terday to accept a new two year labor contract, averting a strike that could have disrupt ed the provision of heat and hot water in the city.

title: Carlton and Phiis Shake On $150,000 Pact for '73
description: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 15 (UPI)In Philadelphia, Steve Carlton is called the fran chise. The lefthanded pitch er, with a 2710 wonlost rec ord, accounted for nearly half of the Phillies' victories in 1972.

title: EARL S. M'NEILL, 79, AD AGENCY CHAIRMAN
description: Earl S. MacNeill, chairman of the board of the Merrill Ander son Company, financial and trust advertising agency, died Thursday at his apartment in the Peter Cooper Hotel. His age was 79.

title: Treasury Is Studying Sale Of LongTerm Bond Issue
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18  The Treasury announced today that it was considering the sale of a longterm bond issue early in January.

title: Bus Hijacker Sentenced To Life by Coast Judge
description: EVERETT, Wash., Dec. 15 (UPI)Cecil Hernandez, con victed of firstdegree kidnap ping and robbery in connection with the hijacking of a Grey hound bus Oct. 6, was sentenced to life imprisonment today.

title: Wyoming Firms Suspended
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (AP) The Securities and Ex change Commission has sus pended trading in two Wyo mingbased firms because of the dissemination of what it described as false information concerning a possibe skincan cer cure.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: MADISON TOWNSHIP, Dec. 15Three days of public hear ings this week on the proposed Toms River spur of the New Jersey Turnpike turned up op position from residents of the affected area who fear more dirt, more noise, more traffic and more people.

title: Ricord Is Convicted of Plot To Smuggle Drugs to U.S.
description: Auguste Joseph Ricord was convicted in Federal District Court here yesterday of conspiring to smuggle narcotics, culminating a twoyear effort by the Government to sever the socalled LatinAmerican connection in international heroin trafficking.

title: Equity Financing
description: The Sierra Pacific Power Company filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission in connection with a proposed offering of 500,000 common shares. The offering, through underwriters managed by Stone & Webster and Dean Willer, is expected next month. The company's stock was down  at 15 on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: AUCKLAND, New Zealand, Dec. 15 (AP)George Archer of Gilroy, Calif., fired a twounderpar 69 today and took sole possession of the lead after two rounds of the $21,000 Auckland golf classic.

title: John Scali, ExNewsman, To Be Named U.N. Envoy
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 President Nixon is planning to name John A. Scali, a former journalist now serving the President as a special consult ant on foreign policy, as United States representative to the United Nations, White House personnel said today.

title: 37 INDICTMENTS ISSUED ON ATTICA
description: The special Wyoming County grand jury investigating last year's inmate rebellion at the Attica Correctional Facility re turned its first indictments yes terday. But it will be impossi ble, until Monday, to know Who or how many were indicted, and on what charges, because all 37 indictments were sealed.

title: ALASKA AWARDED SUBMERGED LAND
description: ANCHORAGE, Dec. 15 (AP) In what has been called a historic first involving un told millions in oil resources, Alaska has been given title to submerged lands in Cook Inlet in a dispute with the Federal Government.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: PARIS, Dec. 15Still banned in Italy, Bernardo Bertolucci's audacious film, Last Tango in Paris, with Marlon Brando and Marie Schneider, had its premiere here today. All the notices were raves, but the critics dif fered in their classification of the film's qualities.

title: L.I.R.R. STILE SHUT; TALKS AT A HALT
description: Snow, rain and slippery high ways added yesterday to the travel troubles of Long Island commuters who are increasing ly frustrated by bleak prospects for settlement of the railroad strike.

title: Dr. Mahmoud Materi, 78, A Founder of Tunisian Party
description: TUNIS, Tunisia, Dec. 15 (Agence FrancePresse)  Dr. Mahmoud Materi, cofounder with President Habib Bourguiba in 1934 of Tunisia's Neo Destour party, died Wednesday night. He was 78 years old.

title: BOYLE IS OUSTED BY MINERS' VOTES AFTER LONG FIGHT
description: SILVER SPRING, Md., Dec. 15 Rankandfile insurgents in the United Mine Workers Union won a decisive victory today in the long struggle to oust the union's president, W. A. Boyle.

title: SIX STUDENTS SHOT AT DANCE IN JERSEY
description: HOBOKEN, N. J., Dec. 15 (AP)Six students at a campus dance sponsored by the Stevens Institute of Technology Chinese Students Association were shot and wounded late tonight when four young men were denied admission into the affair.

title: Chrysler Recalls 149 Cars
description: DETROIT, Dec. 15 (UPI) The Chrysler Corporation said today it was notifying 149 owners of 1973 Plymouth Satellites that their cars needed an inexpensive clip installed to prevent the possibility of loss of control of the car. The starter cable clip on the cars was omitted during assembly, the company said.

title: GUARD ACQUITTED IN INMATE DEATH
description: A city correction officer ac cused of manslaughter in the death of a 22yearold inmate of the prison ward at Kings County Hospital last year was acquitted Thursday night by a State Supreme Court jury in Brooklyn.

title: ACCORD ON INTELSAT TAKES EFFECT SOON
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (UPI)  The Intelsat agree ment on the management of the orbital telecommunications system will be brought into force in 60 days, the State De partment said today.

title: New Truce Demands Rejected by Vietcong
description: HONG KONG, Saturday, Dec. 16 (Reuters)The Viet cong charged today that the United States was trying to prolong the Vietnam war and warned it was ready to fight on until victory.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: AUCKLAND, New Zealand, Dec. 15 (AP)George Archer of Gilroy, Calif., fired a twounderpar 69 today and took sole possession of the lead after two rounds of the $21,000 Auckland golf classic.

title: Peron Is Again Nominated For President by His Party
description: BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 15 Juan Pern's party today re nominated the 77year  old, leader for president of Argen tina, only 23 hours after Mr. Pern had declined the candi dacy and left Argentina.

title: Art: Napper's Illustrations for Novel
description: John Gardner, author of The Sunlight Dialogues, a novel much in the news just now, says that his book is also an attempt to bring back the illustrated novel, and he hopes to counteract objections made by Henry James in a famous letter to his publisher. James's idea mistaken, Mr. Gardner thinks  was that illustrations are at best redundant but usu ally intrusive, since the characters and events in fic tion should be left to the imagination of the reader. James's objections have pre vailed until now.

title: Pickpocket With Conviction
description: Peter Dimitri, 60 years old, of 201 West 101st Street, was held in $10,000 bail here yester day after his 115th arrest for pickpocketing. The prosecutor, Eugene Price, told the court that Dimitri was first arrested before this assistant district attorney was born, and Dimitri's courtappointed law yer John Marotta remarked: As Your Honor can see, he's not very good at what he does.

title: Enlisted Man's General Is Selected by Marines
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (UPI)Sgt. Maj. Clinton A. Puckett has been selected as the next Sergeant Major of the Marine Corps, a post sometimes known as the enlisted man's general, it was announced today. A Marine Corps spokesman an nounced that Sergeant Puck ett would succeed Sgt. Maj. Joseph W. Dailey, who is retiring as the adviser to the Marine commandant on mat ters affecting enlisted men.

title: 21 of 22 Crewmen Rescued After Ship Sinks in Atlantic
description: SAN JUAN, P.R., Dec. 15 (UPI)The Coast Guard re ported today the rescue of 21 crewmen who abandoned the Lincoln Express, a freighter. when the ship broke in half and sank off the Puerto Rican coast yesterday.

title: Warriors Beat Braves
description: BUFFALO, Dec. 15 (AP) A torrid third quarter gave the Golden State Warriors a 12995 victory over the Buffalo Braves tonight.

title: Ulster Gunmen Kill Policeman and PartTime Soldier
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Dec. 15  A policeman and a parttime soldier were shot to death in Northern Ireland to day, bringing to four the num ber of persons killed by ter rorists during the last 24 hours.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: VAL GARDENA, Italy, Dec. 15 (AP)Roland Collombin of Switzerland had the fastest time today in trials for the men's World Ski Cup downhill here tomorrow. Collombin by 21 hundredths of a second. David Zwilling, another Aus registered 2 minutes 07.73 seconds over the 3,750meter (more than 2 miles) course, edging Karl Cordin of Austria Irian, was third. Jim Hunter of Canada was fourth in 2:08.89 and Bob Cochran of Rutland, Vt., fifth in 2:09.07. Mike Lafferty of Eugene, Ore., was 10th in 2:09.72.

title: judge Orders Shield in Coast Court
description: SAN RAFAEL, Calif., Dec. 14  On orders from the presid ing judge, a bulletproof shield has been installed in the Marin County Courthouse where sev eral trials involving convicts from San Quentin Prison are to take place.

title: Antiques: A Happy Quest for Art Deco
description: Until J. Stewart Johnson stepped into the living room of a prominent French fam ily in Lyon, he was convinced that traveling 3,800 miles to buy an EmileJacques Ruhl mann room for the Brooklyn Museum was anything but wild goose chase.

title: TRUMAN IMPERILED BY KIDNEY FAILURE
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Dec. 15 Former President Harry S. Tru man, already hospitalized in very serious condition be cause of lung congestion and a weak heart, was threatened to night by kidney failure and in ability to absorb nourishment as his condition further deteri orated.

title: Gold Napoleons in France Climb to a Record Price
description: PARIS, Dec. 15  It is the traditional refuge for the little guy when he is scared, the trader said as the feverish de mand for Napoleons, the dime sized gold coins resting under so many mattresses in France, lifted the price to a new high again today.

title: End of Another Season for an Old Titan
description: Reports of Larry Gran tham's retirement always seem to surface at this time of year.

title: Business Briefs
description: The General Electric Company announced lated yester day receipt of an order from the Alabama Power Company for two power units with a capacity of 1.2million kilowatts each. They are planned to be operational in 1981 and 1982.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: The Times editorial Unionized Uni versity (Dec. 6) misrepresents the is sues in the negotiations between the Professional Staff Congress and the Board of Higher Education (B.H.E.). The board would abolish the City Uni versity salary system by which an nual increments are earned for service and experience, and substitute a pork barrel by which individuals must nego tiate alone for increases beyond a fixed range.

title: Rangers Set to Rebound Against Stars Tonight
TV: Nureyev and Canadians in Sleeping Beauty
description: This weekend's big produc tion on television is a bal let, The Sleeping Beauty, featuring Tchaikovsky's mu sic and Rudolf Nureyev as guest artist with the National Ballet of Canada, will be pre sented by the Public Broad casting Service tomorrow at 7 P.M.

title: APOLLO SURVEYS SURFACE OF MOON ON FINAL ORBITS
description: HOUSTON, Saturday, Dec. 16 Apollo 17 circled the moon today, surveying its surface with cameras and remotesens ing instruments and preparing for the rocket blast tonight that should start the astronauts on their return journey to earth.

title: Patricia Lev Bride Of Richard Kaplan
description: Miss Patricia Joy Lev, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Lev of New York, was married here yesterday after noon to Richard Sigmund Kaplan, son of Mrs. Louis Kaplan of Miami Beach and the late Mr. Kaplan.

title: Equal Pay for Women Is Ordered in Australia
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Dec. 15 The Commonwealth Arbitra tion Commission, which sets basic wage rates for Australia, ruled today that women must be paid equally with men turning out the same work.

title: Mediation in C.B.S. Strike Is Recessed Until Monday
description: Negotiators for the Columbia Broadcasting System and its striking technicians union yes terday recessed mediation talks in Washington, but will resume them Monday at 1 P.M.

title: John Scali, ExNewsman, To Be Named U.N. Envoy
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15  President Nixon is planning to name John A. Scali, a former journalist now serving the President as a special consult ant on foreign policy, as United States representative to the United Nations, White House personnel said today.

title: British Ford Plans Outlay
description: LONDON, Dec. 15 (Reuters) The Ford Motor Company is to invest $343million on the expansion and modernization of its plants in Britain during the next two years, Ford's British chairman, William Batty, announced today. This is an indication of the confi dence we feel in the future, Mr. Batty told union repre sentatives to ?? he first disclosed the news.

title: Hockey Luncheon Set Here
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Dec. 16 (AP)A luncheon will be held in New York on Jan. 29 to honor Tom Lockhart, found er of the American Hockey As sociation of the United States. The luncheon will be held in conjunction with the National Hockey League alllstar game.

title: 4 Fly to North Vietnam With Gifts for P.O.W.'s
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Dec. 16 Four Americans, includ ing retired Brig. Gen. Tel ford Taylor and folk singer Joan Baez, flew to Hanoi to day carrying some 500 letters and a duffel bag of gifts for American prisoners of war in North Vietnam.

title: Joel Wagoner to Marry Presley Merritt
description: BECKLEY, W. Va., Dec. 16Dr. and Mrs. Charles Wesley Merritt have an nounced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Presley McDonald Merritt, to Joel Morris Wagoner, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alger Loyce Wagoner of Liberty, N. C. A summer wedding is planned here at St. Stephen's Epis copal Church.

title: Like dreams, the finest entertainment known and ragcheap
description: The list of Parker Tyler's publica tions is impressively long, his early writings are now enjoying a small revival, there is every sign that a selfless toil in the vineyards of popular culture is at last yielding some profit in recognition. Yet in what way should productions like Mr. Tyler's be recognized? Accord ing to what law, through what rule of inflexible mercy to the man who is at all events dedicated, should any intelligent public extenuate or indeed accommodate nonsense of the kind purveyed in The Shadow of an Airplane Climbs the. Empire State Building, which has not even the incidental merit of being entertain ingly wrong?

title: Nina Strano and Robert E. Ronzoni Wed
description: Miss Nina Carol Strano, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Salvatore G. Strano of Flushing, Queens, was mar ried yesterday afternoon to Robert Emanuele Ronzoni, son of Mr. and Mrs. Emanu ele Ronzoni Jr. of Port Washington, L.I. The cere mony was performed in the Holy Family Roman Catholic Church in Flushing by the Rev. James F. Fraser.

title: Rev. Oscar Benson, Headed Augustana Lutheran Church
description: The Rev. Dr. Oscar A. Benson, president of the Augustana (Swedish) Lutheran. Church from 1951 to 1959, died Friday in Chicago, where he lived. His age was 81.

title: Mrs. Geraldine Kohlenberg Married to Dr. Louis Zetzel
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 16Mrs. Geraldine Warburg Kohlenberg, widow of Arthur W. Kohlenberg, was married at her home here this eve ning to Dr. Louis Zetzel, clinical professor of medicine at the Harvard Medical School. Rabbi Israel Kazis performed the ceremony.

title: Madrid's Veto in Lawyers' Election Stirs a Storm
description: MADRID, Dec. 16One of the biggest political storms in years broke in Spain today fol lowing the Government's re fusal to allow two of its long time political opponents to run for the presidency of the Ma drid Bar Association.

title: Deborah N. Trench Planning Nuptials
description: NEW CANAAN, Conn., Dec. 16Mr. and Mrs. Archer W. P. Trench have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Deborah Nel son Trench, to Rawdon Moira Crozier Parry, son of Mr. and Mrs. Riohard Parry of Phila delphia.

title: Medical Peer Review
description: The demand for public accountability, now affecting all major areas of American society, has been making significant progress in the medical field, notably with Congress' recent inclusion of a peer review provision in the Social Security law.

title: Panno Given First Prize In Palma Chess Tourney
description: PALMA DE MAJORCA, Spain, Dec. 16 (AP)Oscar Panno, an international grandmaster from Agentina, won the 15round International Palma de Majorca chess tournament today.

title: PROTEST PLANNED AT LIBERTY BOWL
description: MEMPHIS, Dec. 16 (AP) Civil rights groups said today they were planning protests of the most effective and disrup tive sorts at the Liberty Bowl Monday over the suspension of the black Georgia Tech quarter back, Eddie McAshan.

title: Maine Beats F.D.U., 6765
description: ORONO, Me., Dec. 16The University of Maine, leading 3922 at halftime, withstood a secondhalf rally by Fairleigh Dickinson University and won, 6765, tonight.

title: The World
description: On Thanksgiving Day a slight, darkly handsome man arrived at New York's Kennedy airport from Moscow. His name was Valery Chalidze and he was a Soviet physicist  the latest of many Soviet scientists to accept in vitations to lecture or travel in this country. What made his visit unusual was that Mr. Chalidze was also a spokesman of the Soviet Union's small and sorely beleaguered dissident move ment.

title: Legislation Urged to Avert Drug Thefts From Police
description: Two District Attorneys and a judge yesterday urged legisla tion that would enable the Police Department to destroy contraband narcotics quickly and thus avoid a repetition of the recently disclosed thefts of 81 pounds of heroin from the police property clerk's office.

title: A Coed Eton Is Favored, Student Survey Reports
description: LONDON, Dec. 16 (AP) Boys at Eton, Britain's top prep school, want to let in girls.

title: Tati's Terrific 'Traffic':Tati's Terrific 'Traffic'
description: IN "Traffic," Jacques Tati's splendidly funny new film at the 68th Street Playhouse, Mr. Hulot exists almost entirely in the middle distance of the screen as a full-length silhouette. From "Mr. Hulot's Holiday" (1954) and "My Uncle" (1958), we recognize the figure, tall and a little stooped in the way of some tall men who make posture a form of apology. We recognize the pipe, the jaunty hat, the raincoat of the sort that was popular on American campuses in the 1950s, and the pants that seem to reach only to slightly below mid-calf. Tati has never acted with his face and seldom used close-ups of himself, but in "Traffic" the face, which is now 64, is even more vaguely seen than in the earlier filmsits cheerfully bland expression being of less importance and less interest than the outline and movements of the total silhouette.In addition to being exuberantly entertaining (for children, I should think, as well as their generational predecessors), "Traffic" explains the essential comedy of Tati as well as the role played in it by Mr. Hulot, sometimes described rather lamely as an average Frenchman coping with an increasingly dehumanized society. Such a description ascribes a lovability to Mr. Hulot that, I suspect, misses the point. In the past, Mr. Hulot has been made lovable by his association with the free-roaming, tail-wagging dogs of Paris, with garrulous street cleaners, and with little boys whose hearts are abrim with fine, practical jokes.There is no such attempt to impose arbitrary lovability on the figure of Mr. Hulot in "Traffic." We don't see things through his eyes, nor is there any chance for identification with him, as there always is with Chaplin and Keaton characters. Mr. Hulot, instead, exists as a kind of fixed point in a view finder with which we are able to put the rest of the world into properly hiliarious focus. "Traffic" is a very merry sort of film, but the amusement we share is Tati's, not Hulot's, a fact that may seem cold and unsettling to those who insist on mixing two parts of tears with every 10 parts of laughter.It may even be successfully argued that the Mr. Hulot of "Traffic" is quite a different character from the Mr. Hulot of "Mr. Hulot's Holiday" and "My Uncle." The figure is the same, as are the walk (a kind of broad jumper's stride) and the abrupt way in which Mr. Hulot stops to think, as if he'd suddenly found himself at the edge of an Alp. He's still a certified eccentric, but the character who in "My Uncle" seemed to celebrate the joys of nature has become, in "Traffic," an inventor whose product puts him in more or less the same league with the unseen architect who designed the mechanized house in "My Uncle."The product is a fantastically accommodating camper car, a collection of marvelous gadgets that do everything but cut bait and fish. It's the sort of camper, in fact, that might possibly lure M. and Mme. Arpels of "My Uncle" away from their sanitized modern house  all corners, edges, foot paths and electric eyesto spend a weekend in the country polluting with comfort.All of this can be successfully argued, but to do so is to give more importance to the character of Mr. Hulot than is warranted. Tati's later films are not about little guys. They are amazed, amused, even somewhat loving looks at the absurdities produced during the last days of the consumer revolution."Traffic" is about the efforts of Mr. Hulot and his fellow workers at the Altra Company, including a pushy but fondly observed American public relations girl, to get their camper car from the factory in Paris to the International Automobile Show in Amsterdam. Everything goes wrong. They run out of gas. They have flat tires. At one point they must spend a couple of days getting repairs in a small country garage set in the midst of a gigantic auto dump, which is as reassuring as going to a hospital in the middle of a cemetery.These events, however, are just the frames on which Tati places his magnificent gags, some of the funniest of which are simply observations of the great highway community. It's often said that dogs and cats come to look like their masters. In Tati's film, an automobile's windshield wipers take on the properties of the automobile's owner. A tycoon's wipers make positive, decisive thwacks. Those belonging to an elderly driver never quite manage to complete a full sweep. The wipers totter up to a due-north position, then fall back, exhausted.The world Tati sees is slightly mad, full of mimetic rhythms which say less about the dehumanization of society than about the resilience of its members. There is a lovely sequence involving a filling station that insists on giving out big plaster busts of famous personages on the order of Napoleon and Beethoven, even when the cars are packed with parents, children, luggage and pets. Drivers old, young, even-tempered and cranky rise to unexpected heights of politeness when they happen to pile up in a spectacular, multi-car collision. "Is this your hub-cap?" "Oh, thank you. You're too kind."Which, for reasons I need not go into, cues in one of Tati's most imaginative gags, when Mr. Hulot, trying to scale the wall of a house, loosens the ivy so that it all slips a few feet down in one piece, as if it were a hat pulled over the eyes."Traffic" is Tati's fifth feature film, the first being "Jour de Fete (1948), and it is the fourth to be seen here. "Playtime," made in 1967, has, for some reason, never been released in this country. "Traffic" is the very special work of a filmmaker with a unique gift for visual comedy. Like Godard, Tati is also remarkably appreciative of the odd beauty that can be revealed in the shapes, patterns and colors created by the technology of planned obsolescence. For all of the laughter in "Traffic," there are moments when the banal utilitarianism of the super-highway is seen as a work of extraordinary art.

title: TRANSPORTATION
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 16 An experiment to ease con gestion on the San Francisco Oakland Bay Bridge has com pleted a year's trial with mixed success.

title: REDS IN FRANCE END A TRADITION
description: PARIS, Dec. 16In a sharp departure from tradition, the French Communists invited leaders of the Socialists and of a bourgeois party today to speak to their party congress.

title: Belgrade Curbs Some Wages
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 16 (Reuters)  The Yugoslav Government has decided to freeze the salaries of white collar workers and of some other workers for the first six months of next year, it was announced here. The workers affected belong to what the Government describes as the nonproducing sphere of so ciety. The action follbws re cent changes by the Commu nist Government that some Yugoslavs were engaged in profiteering.

title: SCALI'S NOMINATION TO U.N. ANNOUNCED
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (AP) President Nixon formally an nounced today that he would nominate John A. Scali, a for mer diplomatic reporter, to be United States representative to the United Nations.

title: MURPHY PLANS SHIFT IN DETECTIVE GRADES
description: Police Commissioner Patrick ?? Murphy, as part of his con tinuing program of depart mental reform, disclosed plans yesterday to replace the present three grades of detectives with a singlegrade system after the first of the year with a re adjustment of salaries.

title: HOPES FOR PEACE BEGAN IN OCTOBER
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16  Peace was at hand, Henry A. Kissinger told a group of news men crowded into the White House briefing room on Oct. 26. Following is a chronology of events surrounding the Paris peace talks since then.

title: ENROLLMENT FALLS AT SCHOOLS OF LAW
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 16 (UPI) Enrollment of firstyear stu dents in the 149 law schools approved by the American Bar Association dropped this year by 2.9 per cent, but the number of women firstyear law stu dents rose by 27.3 per cent, the association says.

title: Review 1  No Title
description: How do you like your cats' tales rare or well done? No, the choice isn't over a new delicacy out of an angry child's cookbook but rather how you like your ending to a bit of English folklore for ages 5 to 8, MASTER OF ALL MASTERS. The text is the same for both books taken from Joseph Jacobs's English Folk and Fairy Tales.

title: Movie Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Reading Is Taught At Queens Court
description: With the aim of helping young people who have been placed on probation, an un usual education program has been started recently at the new Family Court building in Queens.

title: INVESTIGATORS EASE VIEW OF NAVY STRIFE
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (AP) House investigators disagreed with some of Adm. Elmo R. Zumwalt's new policies as Chief of Naval Operations but they do not think that the Navy dis cipline problem is as serious as they did when they started their inquiry.

title: Enrollment in R.O.T.C. Dips To Lowest Total in 25 Years
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (AP) The Pentagon reported this week that enrollment in Reserve Officers Training Corps pro grams in the nations colleges was the lowest in 25 years.

title: Pipeline Marches Along Despite Protests on L.I.
description: HUNTINGTON, L. I.Despite vigorous opposition from conservation groups and charges of potentially serious environ mental damage construction is continuing on a 26tbile oil pipeline from Holtsville in rural Brookhaven to the heavily popu lated area of Plainview in eastern Nassau County.

title: Pupil Segregation Up in Chicago While Faculty Integration Gains
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 16Chica go's public schools were more tightly segregated this year, as white enrollment continued to drop and more neighbor hoods tilted from white to black.

title: SPOTLIGHT
description: Other than the time I saw him throw the cigarette ma chine down the stairs, I've never seen him furious, a Lafayette College colleague recalled the other day.

title: Bobst Library's Benefactor, 88, Believes Dreams Breed Ideas
description: Elmer Holmes Bobst, whose gift of more than $11million to New York University made possible the dedication of the school's new library yesterday  on his 88th birthday  has shaped his life and career around Vic torian verities and the blue printing of a lifetime's dreams.

title: U.S. Gives $650,300 Grant For South Oyster Bay Park
description: MASSAPEQUA PARK, L.I.

title: Pennington Acts on Exodus
description: PENNINGTONA local civ ic group has taken its first step in the long journey of slowing the exodus of its low income population to the cit ies.

title: Pathmark Cuts Trail for 24Hour Service
description: Long Islanders are taking to the 24houraday super market with the enthusiasm they tend to show toward most major new shopping ventures. If there is some thing they want, Long Island ers will travel many miles to get it.

title: J. L. Crane Jr. Weds Miss Rittling
description: In St. Ignatius Loyola Roman Catholic Church hero yesterday afternoon Miss Catherine Kelly Rittling, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph B. Rittling, was mar ried to James Lowrie Crane Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Crane. Both families are of Buffalo where Mr. Rittling is president of Rittling Dis pensers and Mr. Crane Sr. is assistant, secretary and treas urer of the Manufacturers and Traders Bank.

title: Mao's Tactics Against Lin Detailed in Secret Papers
description: A number of secret Chinese. Communist party documents that have reached the West in recent months describe, among other things, the tactics that Chairman Mao Tsetung adopted to counter what he charged was an attempt by his designated political heir, Lin Piao, to seize power.

title: About Pro Football
description: It, took the Oakland Raid ers a little while to get go ing, but the team winds up its season today at home against the Chicago Bears with the Super Bowl very much in mind. The Raiders' big moment was a thorough trouncing of the Kansas City Chiefs on Nov. 26 and Otis Sistrunk, the young defensive tackle, then said, I don't think we'll lose any more the rest of the season. We'll go right on winning through the Super Bowl. So far Sistrunk has been right and the Bears pose no great problem today.

title: EMIL A. GALLMAN
description: BLOOMFIELD, N. J., Dec. 16 Emil A. Gellman, chairman of the executive committee and former president of the New Jersey Savings League, died last night in Clara Maass Memorial Hospital, Belleville. He was 77 years old and lived here.

title: Kissinger's Statement at News Conference and QuestionandAnswer Excerpts
description: Following is a transcript of the opening statement by Henry A. Kissinger yester day at his news conference in Washington and excerpts from the questionandan swer period that followed, as recorded by The New Yorh Times through the facilities of A.B.C. News:

title: TRANSPORTATION
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 16Safely hid den from view, the law enforcement officer points his gun ht the passing motorist. A squeeze of the trigger, and it's all over for the driver.

title: RALPH ANGIULI
description: Ralph Angiuli, president of Eatwell Provisions, Inc., of Jamaica, Queens, and a realtor, died Wednesday at the Triboro Hospital in Jamaica, after hav ing been injured four days be fore in an automobile accident. He was 46 years old and lived at 51 Hickory Road in Port Washington, L.I.

title: Bullets Stop Warriors, 10599, as Hayes Gets 33 points and 16 Rebounds
description: COLLEGE PARK, Md., Dec. 16 (AP)The Baltimore center, El vin Hayes, outplayed Nate Thur mond tonight and scored a sea son high of 33 points to lead the Baltimore Bullets to their fourth straight victorya 10599 de cision over the Golden State Warriors.

title: Movies; A Joke On Blacks?
description: Na tional Director of CORE

title: News or Dogs
description: With the holidays fast ap proaching, an excellent gift for the dog owner is a book. On the current publishers' lists there is a wide variety, including those that should appeal to the sportsman, the exhibitor, or the pet owner who has just bought a dog and is pondering how to housebreak the pup and get him to do as he's told. If hunting is the reader's forte, he will get help in deciding whether he should turn to the pointing, flushing, retrieving school or follow the trail, tree or sight hounds.

title: Camera World News
description: OWNERS of practically any late model Super 8 movie camera can now make perfectly synchronized sound movies by means of a new motion picture sound system just in troduced by the Optasound Corporation, 116 John Street, New York, N.Y. 10038. Using a special lightweight cassette recorder that is powered by batteries or 110volt house current (it weighs only about four pounds), the system re cords sound on special cas settes at a much lower cost than most previous systems, and it permits frameby frame editing of sound and film without losing synchro nization. The recorder merely plugs into the cameramany new models already have the builtin capability to accept this new system, while most others can be modified by sending them to Optasound (cost, about $20).

title: Schedule of Hearings By Council This Week
description: Following are the public hearings and open meetings scheduled for this week by committees of the City Coun cil. The hearings will be conducted on the second floor of City Hall.

title: Anne Hughes, Finch Alumna, Will Be Bride of Loren Kieve
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Dec. 16 Mr. and Mrs. David Hughes have announced the engagement of their daugh ter, Miss Anne Royall Hughes, to Loren Kieve, son of Dr. and Mrs. Rudolph Kieve of Santa Fe, N. M. The wedding will take place here Jan. 7.

title: Big Song, $8.20, Takes Feature at Lincoln Downs
description: LINCOLN, R. I., Dec. 16 (AP)  Big Song won the $7,500 Winter Handicap today at Lin coln Downs on a muddy track. Big Song covered the five fur long distance in 1:05.

title: 3 in Chinese Gang Held in Shooting of
description: Three members of a gang of ChineseAmerican youths known as the Black Eagles were arrested here yesterday in the shooting of six persons at a dance held by Chinese students Friday night at the Stevens Institute of Technology in Hoboken, N. J.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Movies
description: star of Slaughter

title: Exhibit Rings an Old Tune
description: GLEN ROCKNot one note of music can be heard in the Cramer Gallery at 7 Main Street, across from the rail road station. But the com pact, whitewalled gallery is filled with echoes of the songs that were played and sung around parlor pianos in the years before the phono graph and the radio became the primary sources of popu lar music.

title: 35 on Italian Liner Injured During Heavy Storm at Sea
description: ROME, Dec. 16Eight pas sengers and 27 members of the crew were injured when the Italian liner Cristoforo Colom bo, sailing from New York to Europe, ran into a heavy storm 700 miles off Lisbon Thursday night, it was dis closed tonight.

title: Art
description: THE Eva Hesse exhibi tion, which Linda Shear er has organized at the Guggenheim Museum, is an event of considerable in terest. It brings us the work of a young artist who was deeply involved in the inno vations and experimentations of the nineteensixties. It pro vides us with our first com prehensive account of a bril liant career cut short by death, and at the same time, illuminates some of the diffi cult esthetic questions that acted as spur to that career.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor:

title: Capital of the Southern Mind
description: CHAPEL HILL, N. C.  This is the kind of town where an alderperson (that is, a lady alderman) lofts a helium filled balloon above the main street on a 90foot string to dramatize the visual damage that would be done if the zoning board approved a bank's plan to construct a ninestory building in the center of an otherwise twostory town. She helped get the building cut down to three stories.

title: Christmas Shopping Surge
description: The Christmas shopping season, now coming down to the wire in the nation's stores, was a blur of people and merchandise in motion last week, a fugue of voices, chatter, clatter and cling clanging and zipzapping electronic cash registers. Over all of it drifted a sort of happy haze. In process was a goodmaybe an ex cellentseason.

title: 28,500 Said to Flee China
description: HONG KONG, Dec. 16 (AP) Reliable sources estimated to day that 28,500 persons had fled from China so far this year, more than at any time since 1962, when the estimate was 80,000. The source had no explanation for the increase.

title: Manhattan Triumphs, 5747
description: KINGSTON, R. I., Dec. 16 Manhattan's ballcontrol of fense and the rebounding of Bill Campion in the second half to night carried the Jaspers to a 5747 victory over Rhode Is land.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Commissioner Urstadt was highly critical of the scatter site approach to housing low income families and recom mended instead his scat teredapartment approach. He cited his experience with the capitalgrant program, which has placed 2,300 low income families anonymously among 15,000 middleincome residents, in describing the success of the program dur ing the last six years.

title: Democratic Group Told Unity Is Way To Win Mayoralty
description: Democrats mentioned as pos sible candidates for the mayor alty next year urged the liberal wing of the party yesterday to widen its base and to remain unified in the quest for that post.

title: Italian Tanker Burns
description: LIVORNO, Italy, Dec. 16 (Reuters)The 26,000ton Ital ian tanker Bello caught fire off the northeastern coast of Cor sica today. Her crew of 36, several of them injured, were rescued, port authorities said here.

title: George W. Taylor Dies at 71; Labor Arbitrator and Educator
description: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 16 George W. Taylor, the labor arbitrator and educator who served five Presidents and gave his name to New York State's Taylor Law limiting strikes by public employes, died here last night at his home on Ritten house Square.

title: Postal Service Advises Businessmen to Send by Airmail Instead of First Class
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15The United States Postal Service has spent more than $650,000 since September on an adver Using campaign designed to convince businessmen that they should use airmail postage.

title: Hull Returns to Garden Today
description: He used to zero in on the goalie while burly defense men draped themselves across his back. He once played for a month while his fractured jaw was protected by a catcher's mask. He produced more goals in a shorter pe riod of time than anyone before him. But that, says Bobby Hull, was nothing compared to the pressure I'm putting on myself now.

title: Drama Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR

title: Coins
description: THE second album of monies from many countries carrying the FAO's  message of Food for All has been ap proved by the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations in Rome, it was announced by Ray mond Lloyd, special studies officer. These coins, bearing designs with a food or farm ing motif, are now circulating in more than 40 countries.

title: TRANSPORTATION
description: The Nixon Administration is reportedly giving high level consideration to adop tion of a national policy en couraging construction of ar tificial islands 10 to 30 miles at sea to accommodate huge tankers that would help sup ply the nation's growing energy needs.

title: Movies
description: singer and actress

title: Twins for the Dolces
description: HARRISON, N.Y., Dec. 16 Twin sons were born to Mr. and Mrs. John E. Dolce on Dec. 4 at the New Rochelle Hospital. The children have been named John Coakley and Luke Coakley. Their mother is the former Miss Beth Coakley of Larchmont.

title: Science Expedition To Drill Into Floor Of Antarctic Ocean
description: LA JOLLA, Calif., Dec. 16 (AP)A group of United States scientists plans to spend Christ mas near the South Pole, mak ing man's first effort to dig deeply into the Antarctic sea floor.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: The 1972 Presidential cam paign is history. The song is ended, but the melody lingers on? Although Senator George McGovern was badly defeated, some of the themes he espoused are likely to re main in the harmonious or discordant symphony of the tomorrows.

title: Braves Rout 76ers, 126103
description: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 16 (AP)  Bob Kauffman's 12 points in the second period broke open a close contest to night and the Buffalo Braves rolled to a 126103 victory over the Philadelphia 76ers.

title: Burmese Capital Bypassed by Change
description: RANGOON, Burma, Dec. 8 The 0minute jet flight from Bangkok to Rangoon is a jour ney to the past. While most of Southeast Asia has experienced significant urban growth in the last 20 years, the capital of Burma seems virtually un changed, except that it looks more decrepit.

title: SECOND BAR POSTS 10LENGTH VICTORY
description: MIAMI, Dec. 16 (AP)J. C. H. Bryant's Second Bar, a heavy favorite with the crowd of 10, 565, scored a 10length victory today in the Coral Gables Han dicap at Calder Race Course. The Tropical Park meeting is being conducted at Calder.

title: WALL STREET
description: In the heady atmosphere above DowJones 1,000, Wall Street seems almost drowsy these days as the stock mar ket plods through the classic regrouping phase that came as a surprise to nobody.

title: Truman's Condition
description: Former President Harry S. Truman remained in very serious condition in a Kan sas City hospital yesterday, suffering from lung conges tion, heart irregularity, kid ney malfunction and inability to absorb food. Page 60.

title: Montclair Pastor Wears Two Hats
description: MONTCLAIRPeople with problems often turn to a clergyman for help. If the clergyman is like the Rev. William R. Lutz, they are lucky, for Mr. Lutz not only is an ordained minister but also holds a graduate degree in pastoral counseling.

title: L.I.U. and St. Louis Triumph at Garden
description: West Texas State and St. Louis University, unbeaten Mis souri Valley Conference teams, brought their basketball reputa tions to Madison Square Garden yesterday for a college double header. The West Texas Buf 'loes' puffedup sixgame streak was punctured in the first game by Long Island University. 89 64.

title: The Nation
description: That's one small step for a man, one giant leap for manitind.Neil A. Armstrong, as he became the first man to walk on the moon.

title: Determined GiftGiver Foils Police Sergeant
description: The little old lady cried yesterday when the police re fused to accept her bottle of Christmas cheer.

title: Feminist Leader Favors Action, Not Nebulous Baloney
description: MONTCLAIR What feminists are trying to do, said Deborah Hart, the first state coordinator for the Na tional Organization for Women, is to set ourselves simple, reasonable goals, and then to accomplish them. That's much better than a lot of nebulous baloney.

title: Mrs. Marron Is Wed
description: Mrs. Margaret O'Hara Mar ron, widow of James P. Mar ron, was married here yester day afternoon to Edward J. Quirin, a widower. The Rev. Frederick McKeever per formed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Stephen of Hungary, as sisted by the Rev. Clarke K. Oler, an Episcopal priest. The bridegroom is vice presi dent for university affairs at the Polytechnic Institute of Brooklyn. He retired recently as president of Frederic R. Harris, Inc., an international engineering firm, of which the bride's first husband was vice president.

title: For the President
description: We feared to go to sleep lest we talk indiscreetly. That a dictograph was hidden in the heater was a cer tainty in Billy's mind. So wrote Er nesta Drinker Bullitt in a 1916 diary entry, Billy being handsome wealthy William C. Bullitt of the Phil adelphia Bullitts whom she had mar ried a few weeks before.
