With her, he had just arrived in wartime Ger many as special correspondent for The Philadelphia Public Ledger. Sev enteen years later, in London as mem ber of the United States delegation to the illfated World Economic Con ference, still youthful and handsome (though now bald), Bill Bullitt was a source of annoyance and humilia tion to Secretary of State Cordell Hull because he was constantly searching for dictaphones and spies and generally making himself offen sive and ridicullous.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Koch to Give Away CityFlag Pins

title: Dance
description: THE following might be titled An Anatomy of a Disappointment. That's disappointment, mind you, not disaster. And it all has to do with a 90minute television production of the ballet The Sleeping Beauty, which will be presented on the Public Broadcasting Service tonight at 7 and Christmas Day a 8 P.M.

Bergen Chamber Shifts Goals
description: HACKENSACKThe urban crisis in America has forced vast changes in the structure of Chambers of Commerce. Lakes Tahoe and Donner are safely hemmed in by drive ins, motels, gambling casinos, subdevelopments and pristine acreage owned by the rich.

title: The Talk of Cranford
description: CRANFORDI know I'm out of town when I begin to see street signs on lamp posts, said Frank Cushman, a merchant who has lived in Cranford for a decade. Everything here is so quiet; we don't even make our street signs obvious.

description: After more than three months of intensive study of the Wyckoff Housethe oldest house in New York State and one of the earli est on the Eastern seaboard an architect and two ar chitectual historians are ready to submit a rec ommendation for restoration to the project's architects.

title: Alun Davies Revealed at Last
description: ALUN DAVIES: Daydo (Columbia KC 31469). Finally, a chance to find out who Alun Davies is. He's been dropping hints of himself for years, first as a member of a short lived British pop group called Thursday, and then as Cat Stevens' lead guitarist. The familiar shadowy figure, usually to be found just out side Stevens' spotlight, is that rare kind of accompanist who can add some bit of his own creative personality without drawing any attention away from the star. Cat Stevens is lucky.

title: NEEDIEST CASES STIR MEMORIES
description: Last Jan. 2, 8yearold Juanita Sheppard was killed in an elevator accident in a Greenwich Village welfare hotel.

title: A chilling effect on the press
description: WASHINGTON: Ike Kleinerman, a C.B.S. News producer, took a camera crew through the South recently to develop material for a documentary on the problems of children in America. He hoped to arrange an interview with a mother who could describe vividly how the welfare system, with its prohibitions against payments to families with working fathers, has encouraged the breakup of homes. He finally found just such a woman. She was a welfare client who spoke eloquently from experience of the system's inequities. She agreed to be interviewed on camera, but only with her face averted and with absolute assurances she would not be identified by name. She had been secretly harboring her husband in her home and feared this would be discovered if she spoke out publicly. Although promises to withhold names have traditionally been routine in journalism, Kleinerman called C.B.S. headquarters in New York to check. The matter was referred to the legal de partment, where the judgment was swift. Kleiner man was told not to give the requested assurance. The interview was canceled.

title: Pop
description: DION: Suite for Late Summer (Warner Bros BS 2642). I tried. I really tried hard to find something to like about this album, but by the end of it, I just wanted to scream from boredom. The longest song on Mr. DiMucci's newest LP is only four and a half minutes long but every song seemed to last forever. Per haps it's because they all sound alike and neither Dion's voice nor the arrangements add any hint of life.

title: Why it happened and how it went
description: We were sitting at our desks at B.B.C. Central, preparing the evening news bulletin, when our typewriters flew into the air, the windows shat tered, and we were thrown onto the floor. A buzz bomb had scored a direct hit. Or so we thought until we realized the newsroom was in tact, there were no flames, no smoke. The hit must have been very close.

title: Perspective on Apollo
description: Project Apollo will belong to history when astronauts Cernan, Schmitt and Evans splash down in the Pacific on Tuesday. If all goes well, the most difficult and most expensive feat of exploration in history will then have come to a brilliant conclusion. The quartermillionmile cosmic gulf between the earth and the moon has now been successfully traversed repeatedly.

title: Music
description: THIS is the season of Messiah performances and Messiah singins, and articles about Mes siah, as it has been every year at this time back to 1742, the year that the most popular choral work ever com posed received its premiere. Handel had finished it the previous year, however. Stories about its composition are part of the mythology of music: how Handel received the text from the o'erweening Charles Jennens; how he locked himself into his Apartment and composed the Messiah in 24 days, from Aug. 22 to Sept. 14, 1741; how he was guided by the hand of the Lord; how the manu script, written in a fury of creation (one look at it is ample testimony), is be dewed with tears; how Handel ignored food, ignored sleep, to get his music on paper for the Dublin performance.

title: Jobless Teachers on L.I. Facing a Bleak Future
description: EAST MEADOW, L. LA week ago last Friday, a man who had spent 17 years as a teacher in Long Island schools applied for welfare.

title: The restoration of French cooking
description: LYONS: When your car turns off the autoroute into the outskirts of Lyons, a large billboard announces that you are entering The World Capital of Gastronomy. It sounds grandiloquent, until you try to think of another name to replace that of Lyons (certainly not Paris). With a population of 535,000, Lyons, according to the ratings of that bible of French gourmets, the Guide Michelin, possesses 14 onestar restau rants, three twostar restaurants, and one threestar restaurant (Michelin's supreme category; there are only 12 in all France). The threestar restaurant of Lyons is operated by, and bears the name of, a man considered by many as the major French gastronomic phe nomenon of the last decadePaul Bo cuse. I was on the way to see Paul Bocuse.

title: The Age Of Kipling
description: In The Age of Kipling, edited by John Gross, there are 20 essays dealing with the life and publications of the writer, from his first days to the post mortems pronounced on the body of his literary work after his death. As with all collections pro duced by different hands, this one is uneven in quality and checkered with contradictory judgments. There are some shamefaced confessions of boyhood devotion; some carefully cal culated middle ground positions (very nearly [lifted] out of the minor rank); and some braver as sertions about the moralist who was a very great artist to be com pared with Ben Jonson, Conrad, Yeats, and on to the great bard him self. Such differences of opinion are, to be sure, one of the merits of this book, for the work of Kipling has always received a mixed response. The greater virtue of this volume, however, is that, in five or six essays, the confusion of judgments is pene tratedto get at what Kipling was actually saying beneath the distract ing dazzle of the way he put words together.

title: Is There No Welfare?
description: At this festive season of the year, Mr. Scrooge, said the gentleman, taking up a pen, it's more than usually desirable that we should make some slight provision for the poor and destitute, who suffer greatly at the present time.

title: Recordings
description: SCHUBERT: Lieder, Vol ume 3. DietrichFisch er  Dieskau, baritone; Gerald Moore, piano (Deutsche Grammophon 2720 059, four disks). Is anyone out there keeping up with Fischer  Dieskau? Over the past 25 years this recording phenomenon has made more disks than any other person ality in phonographic history, covering almost every con ceivable style and idiom from Schutz to Henze. Here the indefatigable baritone digs into Schubert's three song cycles, Die schone Mtillerin, Winterreise and Schwa nengesang  a footnote to his earlier mammoth two volume, 25disk traversal of the Lieder.

title: The Nation

Last week, when he made known his intention to extend wageprice controls beyond the scheduled April 30 expiration, the necessity for the program had gained such widespread acceptance that there was hardly an eyebrow lifted.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: The Mail Gets Through
description: CLARKSBURG, W. VA., Dec. 16 (UPI)  Kendall H. Kenney, a retired lawyer, has received a letter from the Clarksburg Community Chest postmarked Nov. 29, 1938, and bearing a two cent stamp. Mr. Kennedy's wife said she would give the letter to their grandson, who collects stamps.

title: NONURBAN LIVING IS GAINING FAVOR
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 The oncemagnetic appeal of great American cities has de clined so steeply that, given a choice, about eight out of ten persons would prefer to live in suburban or rural areas, accord ing to two new national public opinion surveys.

title: Knicks Top Bulls, 9783, For 10th in Row at Garden
Jazz: Ruth Brown Sings Oldtime Hits
description: I never saw Ma Rainey, the great blues singer who gave Bessie Smith some of her early training. But when Ruth Brown takes the stage at the Top of the Gate, I get a feeling that I'm seeing and hearing something of what Ma Rainey projected. Miss Brown has a quietly commanding, presence and, like Ma Rainey, she does everything with a complete and confident sense of au thorlty that reflects her years of experience.

title: Town Waits For Opening Of Hospital Early in '73
description: HACKETTSTOWN  After more than 20 years and nearly $2.4million in actual contributions and pledges, the new Community Hospital here is scheduled to open on Feb. 1. But the opening of the hospital's 12bed ob stetrics unit may be delayed because the hospital corpora tion is still $25,000 short of a $200,000 goal; reaching it would qualify Community for for a Kresge Foundation grant of $100,000.

title: WHALERS WIN, 106, AFTER A WILD FINISH
LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor:

title: Le President on Art
description: This interview with President Georges Pompidou of France is excerpted from Le Monde.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Eastern Europe Opposes West's Bid for a Free Exchange of People and Ideas
description: WARSAW, Dec. 14  The nations of Eastern Europe are mounting a campaign to coun ter the free exchange of peo ple and ideas that the West is proposing as its price for an allEuropean security con ference.

title: Dana Costello Is Bride of Roberto Biadi
description: LOWELL, Mass., Dec. 16 The marriage of Miss Dana Elizabeth Costello to Rober to Biadi, son of Mr. and Mrs. Mario Biadi of Flor ence, Italy, took place here this afternoon. The bride is a daughter of John Harring ton Costello, publisher and president of the Lowell Sun Publishing Company, and Mrs. Costello. The Rev. Wil liam Lynch performed the ceremony in the Immacu late Conception Roman Catholic Church.

title: Law
description: The delicate balance between a de fendant's right to a fair and speedy trial, as guaranteed by the Sixth Amendment, and the public's right to know, as spelled out in the First Amendment, has come in for new buffeting in the past few weeks.

title: $4.60 Bold Place Takes Laurel Handicap Division
Laotian Forces Attacked
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Dec. 16 (AP)A United States spokes man said that a battalion com mander of laotian irregular forces, another senior officer and several soldiers were killed and 20 soldiers were wounded yesterday in a Communist mor tar and rocket attack on their command post near Paksong.

title: SEYMOUR ASKS AID ON BUSINESS CRIME
description: A special booklet telling busi nessmen how to uncover and crack down on white  collar crime was issued here yester day by United States Attorney Whitney North Seymour Jr.

title: TRANSPORTATION
description: BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 11 A longsimmering dispute be tween United States and Argentine civil aviation au thorities has developed into a bitter fight that is disrupt ing the holiday travel plans of thousands of passengers, as well as the mail and cargo services between the two countries.

title: Struck Hospital Functioning
description: PARSIPPANYTROY HILLS, N.S., Dec. 16 (UPI)Patient services were reported normal today at Greystone Park State Psychiatric Hospital despite a walkout by 55 plumbers, car penters and electricians. A hos pital spokesman said most of the members of the American Federation of Technical Engi neers who walked out yesterday to protest the arrest of a plumber on a disorderlyperson charge were normally off duty on the weekends.

title: Belmonte Captures Title In Men's Figure Skating
description: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 16  ?? Belmonte of Cherry Hill, N.J., won the novice men's title today as the South Atlan tic figure skating champion ships ended at the Wissahickon Skating Club. Belmonte had to rally to overtake the early leader, Bruce Kirman of Her shey, Pa.

title: Bolstering Allied Unity
description: Two developments at the recent meeting of NATO foreign and defense ministers in Brussels deserved more attention than they received in this country. In a letter to the gathering, President Nixon promised that the United States would keep its 300,000 troops in Europe if the other allies maintained and improved their forces. And the ten nations making up the Eurogroup within NATO promised to increase their defense budgets by $1.5 billion overall for 1973.

title: Doctors in Canada Face Restrictions On Amphetamines
description: OTTAWA, Dec. 16 (AP)A Canadian drug control program aims at imposing tight restric tions on the prescription of amphetamines by doctors, be cause of fears the socalled pep pills are harmful and may be addictive.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor:

title: The World
description: India and Pakistan, seeking to nor malize relations that were upset by their war a year ago, moved closer last week to their goal of a durable peace on the subcontinent.

title: 600 Soviet Tourists Will Go To the Philippines in March
description: MANILA, Dec. 16 (UPI)The Philippine Board of Travel and Tourist Industry has announced that the first large group of Soviet tourists to visit the Phil ippines is schedules arrive by ship next March.

title: Views of Review
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Gardens
description: WITH children grown and married, many a long  devoted housewife is tempt ed to rest on her laurels (or pines, or balsams,) when it comes time to trim the house for Christmas, and possibly escape to Florida.

title: Uncertainty Marks Discussion of Authorities on Drug Addiction
description: SAN JUAN, P.R., Dec. 14 Some of the nation's leading authorities on drug addiction gathered in the sunshine here this week to air their common concerns, and there was an undertone of malaise and un certainty in much of what they had to say.

title: Adoption Group Changes Emphasis
description: FARMINGDALE, L. I.  A Long Island group that for years sought homes only for adoptable children is now finding temporary homes for children who would other wise be placed in juvenile detention centers.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: Presi dent, Hollywood branch, NAACP

title: Festive Yugoslav Fare at a Flava in Queens
description: If it can be said that Yugoslavia, a country made up of several different cul tures, has a national cuis ine, it is in those dishes which are common to the entire area from the Adriatic to the Persian Gulf. Olives, cabbage, vine leaves, strudel dough, eggplant, lamb all bespeak the Turkish in fluence, centuries old. In ad dition, each Yugoslav nation ality has its own specialties.

title: Ann Behning Snyder Is Affianced
description: HUNTINGTON, L. I., Dec. 16Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Peckwell Snyder Jr. of Lloyd Neck, and Marlboro, Vt., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ann Behning Snyder, to Thomas Cowan O'Marra Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. O'Marra of Dix Hills. A June wedding is planned.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor:

title: The World.
description: When Juan Domingo Pern arrived in Buenos Aires in a specially char tered jet a month ago, after 17 years of political exile, he was confronted by stringent security measures that in cluded thousands of troops, riot police and tanks. When the 77yearold for mer dictator left Buenos Aires last Thursdayon a regularly scheduled flight to Asuncin, Paraguaythe security arrangements were far less elaborate. But the difference in secu rity did not seem to reflect any decline in the controversial role M. Peron plays in Argentina's tangled politics.

title: WASHINGTON
description: HOUJARRAY, France  The other day when Henry Kissinger was in Paris, he had a talk about the money, trade and security problems of the United States and Europe with Jean Monnet. Ever since Colonel House and Harry Hopkins, White House aides have been turning to him for help, and while they don't always take his ad vice, Monnet always has something sensible to say.

title: APOLLO ROCKETS FROM LUNAR ORBIT FOR TRIP TO EARTH
description: HOUSTON, Dec. 16 The astronauts of Apollo 17 began their threeday voyage back to earth tonight as scientists praised the mission's achieve ments and suggested that the moon might not be an alto gether dead world.

title: Scientists to Utilize Computers to Detect Environment Perils
description: Scientists of the World Health Organization are expanding their use of computers to de velop an early warning sys tem to detect environmental health hazards, with the ulti mate aim of building a world wide monitoring and surveil lance system to avoid major dangers.

title: Collector of Rock Scene Faces Crisis
description: Alan Betrock, the publish er of JAMZ, which he describes as the only rock publication that offers com plete discographies, reviews of obscure singles and albums, as well as assorted commentary, trivia, facts, ar ticles, rare pictures, etc., primarily centered on the sixties rock scene, has just issued a fat, closely packed 90page double issue of his magazine that he hopes will give him time to face a cri sis in his life: How to make a living.

title: Architecture in Paris
description: T@HERE is a huge mud dy hole in the center of Paris that is sched uled to become an ul tramodern, multimedia Con emporary Art Centre by De cember, 1975.

title: Hospital In Queens Is Seeking A New Site
description: South Shore Hospital in Far Rockaway, whose merger with Long Island JewishHill side Medical Center is ex pected to be approved by the state this month, will be housed in a new $25million facility within the next five years. The only question is where.

title: Washington
description: WASHINGTONThe pattern of cur rency exchange rates negotiated a year ago at the Smithsonian Institution is regarded here as having worked well on the whole, including the rate es tablished for the dollar.

title: MARKETS IN REVIEW
description: The stock market ascended to a new peak last Monday, and then it dropped back down the slope to rest. Prices, after all, had climbed so fast since midOctober that they were entitled to sink back for a while.

title: Law
description: For those who say you never get something for nothing, consider the gifts offered last week by New York's police commissioner300 extra police men per day, patrolling the streets and keeping the citizenry safe; $6 million saved in overtime payments; new efforts to improve the quality and integrity of arrests.

title: Dowling Building New Center
description: OAKDALE, L. I.  Dow ling College has broken ground for a threestory library and media center topped by a planetarium with a roof that will slide open to accommodate a telescope. One of three projects planned by the small liberal arts col lege, the center will hold Dowling's 74,000volume col lection and provide class rooms and radio, television and film producing facilities.

title: MEANY AND 4 RETURN TO ECONOMIC GROUP
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (AP) The White House announced today that five union officials headed by George Meany, A.F.L.C.I.O. president, had ended a 33monthold boycott of President Nixon's National Commission on Productivity.

title: A Varied Look for Mailboxes
description: BERNARDSVILLEAmong the ordinary things of life, perhaps there is none more ordinary than that common symbol of country living, the rural mailbox.

title: POLICE SAY GUNMEN KILLED ACCOMPLICE
description: A Bronx youth who alleged ly shot two persons in two sep arate holdup attempts in the South Bronx early yesterday was killed when one of three youths who had joined him in the second holdup, apparently shot him in the head by acci dent, the police reported.

title: Mayor to Lead Promenade
description: Vehicular traffic on Fifth Avenue between 34th Street and 37th Street will be barred from 1 P.M. to 5 P.M. today while Mayor Lindsay leads a holiday promenade sponsored by the city and the Fifth Ave nue Association. The prome nade will be repeated next Sun day.

title: Dentist Wins Upset In Great Neck Vote
description: GREAT NECK, L.I.With his upset victory over Mrs. Florence J. Mangan, the in cumbent in the election of Park Board Commissioners here last Tuesday, Dr. Rich ard Winston proved, he said that one determined person can make a difference in local government.

title: Penn Honors McKenzie: Surgeon, Educator, Sculptor
description: R. Tait McKenzie was a man of many parts whose sculpture reflects his ex traordinary abilities in the disparate fields of sports, medicine and art. McKenzie, who died in 1938 at the age of 70, combined the three as no one else has in his mag nificent figures and medals.

title: Verona Plant Has Reason to Wave Flag
description: VERONAWhen President Nixon is sworn, into his sec ond term of office in Janu ary, a flag made by Annin & Co. here will fly nearby. It is a tradition that began with Zachary Taylor's in augural in 1849, and has been followed at every in auguration since.

title: KISSINGER SAYS TALKS HAVE NOT REACHED JUST AND FAIR AGREEMENT
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 Henry A. Kissinger said today that the negotiations between the United States and North Vietnam had so far failed to reach what President Nixon re garded as a just and fair agreement to end the Viet nam war.

title: State Helps Handicapped to Graduate to Regular Schooling
description: UNIONMore than $100 million is being spent in New Jersey this school year to help about 110,000 physically or emotionally handicapped children among the state's million publicschool pu Pils to get a regular edu cation.

title: Hospital Is Proud Of StrokeAid Unit
description: WESTWOOD It's a small place. There are only two bedrooms and a physical therapy center.

title: Music
description: AMERICA may not have the re sources to place gifted young musicians in the right jobs, but that doesn't stop it from trying to train them as well as possible. In the case of the singer looking for a career in opera, the few number of opera com panies in this country make his future look bleak. Yet singers stay ambitious and the companies go on trying to help them prepare themselves should opport unities appear. In this direction there have been interesting announcements from three of our major companies.

title: Movie Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Jan Threlkeld Weds Miss Snyder
description: SUMMIT, N.J., Dec. 16 Miss Lesley Jo Snyder, daughter of Raymond E. Snyder and the late Mrs. Helen Rognon Snyder, was married here this afternoon to Jan Threlkeld, son of Mr. and Mrs. Vern Harvey Threl keld of Irvine, Calif.

title: Mrs. Jessie Pugh, Flier, Dies; Figured in 1932 Murder Trial
description: LONDON, Dec. 16  Mrs. Jessie Pugh, the former Mrs. J. M. KeithMiller, a record holding aviator of 40 years ago and a central figure in a 1932 American murder trial, died to day in a hospital. She was 70 years old.

title: AN AIDE TO PERON GETS NOMINATION
description: BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 16 Juan D. Pern's political move ment split today after nominat ing Dr. Hector J. Campora, Mr. Pern's personal representative, for President of Argentina.

title: Headliners
description: A Lift for the Spirits

title: COMMUTERS BACK L.I.R.R. ON STRIKE
description: Representatives of five com muter groups met yesterday with the management of the struck Long Island Rail Road and said they agreed with man agement that the striking unions demands were way out of line.

title: THO GETS PLEDGE OF SOVIET SUPPORT
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 16High So viet officials today assured Le Duc Tho of unswerving support for North Vietnam's aims after he had briefed them on the latest round in the Paris peace talks with Henry A. Kissinger.

title: Filly Brings $30,000 At Concluding Day Of Old Glory Sales
description: YONKERS, Dec. 16Kalila, a 3yearold pacing filly, which was consigned by Dana Irving, brought the highest bid today as the twoday Old Glory winter sale was concluded at Yonkers Raceway. The daughter of Tar Boy and Maynard's Own, a New Yorkbred, was acquired for $30,000 by David Seidenburg of Manhattan.

title: A RealEstate Man Killed in His Office In the South Bronx
description: The secretary of a South Bronx realestate company was slain yesterday morning as he worked in his office in the Melrose section.

title: The Tops in Pops
description: THE FOUR TOPS: Keeper Of The Castle (ABC Dunhill DSX 50129). If you dug Reach Out I'll Be There, Standing in the Shadows of Love and I Can't Help Myself, the Four Tops album, their first since ending their long association with Motown, could be a dis appointment. The Tops's trademark was always their tough, masculine vigor driven by those tight, dynamic Mo town productions. The Tops sound here is diluted with pop.

title: RED WINGS DOWN MAPLE LEAFS, 41.
description: TORONTO, Dec. 16 (AP)  Marcel Dionne and Billy Col lins broke open a close National Hockey League game with third period goals tonight as the De troit Red Wings posted a 41 victory over the Toronto Maple Leafs.

title: Television
description: REALIDADES, which in English means truths or reali ties, is the title of a 20week series of half hour, primetime television programs, aimed at Puerto Ri can and other Spanishspeak ing people, which made its debut on Channel 13 at 8 P.M. on Tuesday, Oct. 31. The audio flips back and forth from Spanish to English, subtitles are superimposed as they are in art film houses, and radio simulcasts are broadcast over WBNXAM, to try to leap the linguistic hurdles.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: The article For City Hous ing, Build on Big Scale [Nov. 26] by Charles J. Urstadt, the New York State Commission er of Housing and Community Renewal, has produced a sense of incredulity among tenants in Central Park Gar den, a state MitchellLama building.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Police Fire on Battling Class
description: PORT MORESBY, PapuaNew Guinea, Dec. 16 (Reuters)Po lice fired on a crowd of 1,000 warriors in this nation's Chim bu area today to break up a threeday battle between rival clans over land claims, a Gov ernment spokesman reported here. He said that three tribes men were wounded, but not seriously.

title: S. F. SCACCIAFERRO
description: NUTLEY, N. J., Dec. 16Sal vator J. Scacciaferro, a consult ing engineer with the State De partment who retired in 1960, died today at the Clara Maass Memorial Hospital in Belleville. He was 76 years old and lived here.

title: Criminals At Large
description: Douglas Hurd's TRUTH GAME (St. Martin's, $5.95) comes under no easy category. It is not really an espionage book, though it is concerned with highlevel intrigue that hops from the British Prime Minister to an Arabian state. It has little physical action on a mantoman basis, though there is plenty of otherwise convulsive movement.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Art
description: A NEW exhibition organized by Harvard's BuschReisinger Museum, an institution devoted to the study and elucidation of Germanic culture, reached the Metropoli tan Museum Friday as the first stop on an am bassadorial tour. Composed of 93 German mas ter drawings of the 19th century, it is a reminder that the rehabilitation of 19thcentury German art still has a long way to go this side of the Rhine, and furthest of all this side of the Atlantic.

title: Miss Coughlan, W. P. Rogers Jr. Plan Wedding
description: BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Dec. 16The engagement of Miss Cynthia Davis Coughlan to W. Paul Rogers Jr. has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Robert Coughlan, parents of the future bride. Her fianc is the son of Mrs. Rogers and the late Mr. Rogers.

title: Dr. Raymond Haupert, 70, ExPresident of Moravian
description: BETHLEHEM, Pa., Dec. 16 (UPI)Dr. Raymond S. Hau pert, former president of Mo ravian College here and a past president of the Pennsylvania Association of Colleges and Universities, died yesterday at the age of 70.

title: Columbia Wins and Loses
description: Columbia's wrestling team raised its Ivy League wonlost record to 20 with a 2320 vic tory over Harvard at Univer sity Gymnasium yesterday. However, the triangular meet was won by Rhode Island, which defeated the Crimson, 2512, and Lions, 2118.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor:

title: the traveler's world
description: THE ChristmasNew Year holiday season is about to bring us all the joys and discomforts of travel ing when everyone else is travel ing plus the concomittant threat and unforgettable sensation of being over booked. Being the overbookee on a crowded airplane is bad enough, al though the passenger on an American flag international or domestic airline can, under Civil Aeronautics Board rules, squeeze money damages predicated on his ticket price from the carrier if it doesn't get him out on a subsequent flight quickly enough. During the Federal fiscal year 1972, which ended last June 30, the airlines overbooked 80,600 our of 147,375,000 domestic passengers, and internationally 9,200 passengers out of 7million. The C.A.B. is studying the extension of its penalties to foreign flag airlines.

title: Mrs. Drowns Is Wed
description: Mrs. Tatiana Drowne, wid ow of H. Russell Drowne, was married yesterday in the chapel of the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest, to Charles J. Lipscomb of Nantucket, Mass. and Ocho Rios, Jamaica, West Indies. The Rev. Dr. J. Burton Thom as performed the ceremony in the presence of the imme diate families. The bride groom's first wife died.

title: Movies
description: CAN a movie director and a movie critic find true happiness to gether? Yes, if the dreams of Milos Forman, the Czech director of Loves of a Blonde and Taking Off, and Paul Zimmerman, who regularly zeroes in on flicks for Newsweek magazine, come true. The pair have promised to have their screenplay, The Autograph Hunter, in the hands of Paramount Pictures by next March, and if all goes well, Forman should begin direct ing the comedy before the end of 1973.

title: If You Like Theatrical Games
description: IT has been a week of masks. Eugene O'Neill's The Great God Brown, now being revived in rep ertory with Molire's Don Juan at the Lyceum, is a play about masks that must be killed if men are ever to make themselves whole. And Isaac Babel's Sunset, newly mounted at the Chelsea Theater Center of Brooklyn al most 50 years after its appearance in Russia, is a roundabout exercise that spends its eight scenes patiently model ing what turns out to be a mask. Neither piece is what anyone now would call a fulfilled play; both seem games, games of structure and meaning, teasers that ask Button, button, who's got the but ton? while identities are passed from palm to palm and souls crumble in the process. But theatrical games can be varying degrees of fun, if you have any taste for them, and both productions are in part provocative.

title: Nancy Louise Hickox Married To Gilbert Prescott Wright Jr.
description: SEWICKLEY, Pa., Dec. 16 The Sewickley Presbyte rian Church was the setting this afternoon for the mar riage of Miss Nancy Louise Hickox, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Morgan Hickox, to Gilbert Prescott Wright Jr., son of Mr. Wright of Fal mouth, Mass., and the late Mrs. Wright. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Jack M. Maxwell, minister of the church, and the Very Rev. N. R. H. Moor, an Epis copalian.

title: Archer, Tuohy Share Lead In Auckland Golf at 210
description: AUCKLAND, New Zealand, Dec. 16 (AP)George Archer, a United States golf pro, posted a threeoverpar 73 today to sharp the lead after three rounds of the $21,000 City of Auckland golf tournament.

title: German Satellite Launched By the U.S. Space Agency
description: VANDENBERG AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., Dec. 16 (AP)A fourstage rocket lifted a Ger man satellite into polar orbit today, giving the National Aero nautics and Space Administra tion its first perfect year for satellite launchings, officials said.

title: Tenant Group Calls '73 Year for a State Rent Bill
description: FORT LEEThe New Jer sey. Tenants Organization, which says it represents 500, 000 apartment dwellers throughout the state, is gear ing itself for intensive lobby ing in Trenton next month. Its goal: to obtain legislative approval of a statewide rentleveling bill.

title: Winter
description: The further we get from the land, the more we need the reminders of winter. True, winter is snow and ice and bitter cold, and often it is clogged highways and delayed trains and grounded planes. It is all these, for it is primi tive forces cleansing and scarifying the earth. But it is also beautiful and awesome and magnificent. It rounds out the year, makes the year whole, and in a sense it makes whole again the man who lives with it.

title: Policeman Leads Fight to Hold Down Size of Force
description: ELWOODA State Police detective who feels that too much is being spent for police protection led a group of residents here who helped to defeat an ordinance that would have appreciably in cieased the size of the Mul lica Township Police Depart ment.

title: Music
description: ACCORDING to its creators, the aim of Dr. Selavy's Magic Theater is to give the audience literate pleasure. Richard Foreman, who conceived, directed and designed it, and Stanley Silverman, who composed its songs, readily admit that Dr. Selavy, on occasion, falls into the realm of avantgarde musictheater. But they are quick to stress that it is basically a popular work in the best tradition of popular art. In fact, Foreman and Silver man see themselves as continuing and extending a style of musictheater that goes back to Brecht and Weill and Gil bert and Sullivan.

title: Columbia Soccer Coach Announces Resignation
description: Jim Rein has resigned as Columbia University soccer coach, effective June 30. Rein, 28 years old, cited his outside business interests, which do not afford me the opportunity to direct the time and energies necessary to develop the Columbia program.

title: INDIA HAS AVOIDED FAMINE, AIDE SAYS
description: NEW DELHI, Dec. 16Late rains and early warnings about food scarcity have helped India avert what appeared a few months ago to be an impend ing famine.

title: New Special Interest Magazines Flourish
description: I feel sorry for a poor, dear editor at a generalin terest woman's magazine, Edward W. Harbert 2d ob served the other day. I do feel sorry for her, I really do.

title: Miss Virginia Regan Married To Luis C. Dominguez Here
description: Miss Virginia Regan, daugh ter of Mr. and Mrs. John Nicholas Regan of New York, East Hampton, L. I., and Dub lin, was married here yester day at the apartment of her parents to Luis Charles Dominguez, son of Mrs. C. Mathews Dick or Newport, R. I., and the late Vincent L. Dominguez of London.

title: Bomb Is Found Under Car
description: A pipe bomb was dismantled yesterday by the police bomb squad after it was found under a car in the parking lot of Lind Oldsmobile, 5915 Fort Hamilton Parkway, in the Bor ough Park section of Brooklyn. The police said the bomb was in an airline flight bag.

title: MEN'S WEAR
description: When Clark Gable appeared without an undershirt in the 1934 movie It Happened One Night, he threw the male apparel industryand undershirt manufacturers in particularinto a tizzy as men by the thousands stopped wearing undershirts too.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTONDr. Kissinger, do you think peace is at hand? A reporter put the question mischievously to Henry Kissinger when the plane bring ing the White House aide back from his latest talks in Paris landed at Andrews Air Force base last Wednes day night. That's a good phrase, the peace negotiator cracked back, who used it?

title: Stage: Playwriting Debut for Styron
description: NEW HAVEN, Dec. 16A first play by a new play wright is always a tense avent tense for the play wright, tense for the audi ence and, to be honest, tense for the critic. And this ten sion is felt all the more strongly if the playwright is not in fact a young un known, but a distinguished author who is making his playwriting debut.

title: PROF. LESTER F. WEEKS
description: BOOTH BAY HARBOR, Me., Dec. 16Lester F. Weeks, re tired chairman of the chemistry department of Colby College, and a trustee of the college, died Thursday in Thayer Hospi tal, Waterville. Professor Weeks was 84 years old.

title: Poet Heads Russian Basketball
description: SovietAmerican basketball relations may be progressing from the blankety blank verse of Munich to just plain blank verse.

title: AUSTRALIA ACTS ON TRIBAL LANDS
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Dec. 16 In a farreaching reversal of the previous Government's pol icy, Prime Minister Gough Whitlam has moved to turn over ownership of tribal lands to the indigenous people who have used them for centuries.

title: Kerr en The River Niger
description: T@HE RIVER NIGER, now being performed by the Negro Ensem ble Company, is one of the most curious experi ences I have ever had in the theater. Joseph Walker's dia logue is exemplary, knife sharp when adrenalin is meant to flow and gently rhetorical whenever the father of a Harlem family re members that he meant to be a poet. Douglas Turner Ward's intensely personal di rection of his performers is both supple and vigorous, moving them from gang vio lence to boozy midnight philosophizing without ever tripping over a transition. Al most all of the performances, including Mr. Ward's own as the painterfighterpoet who never found a battlefield, are detailed, honest, varied. And the play as a whole has no dramatic tension at all.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTON With all the talk about the growing proportion of Federal Govern ment expenditures that are uncontrollable  some 70 per cent in the present $250billion budgetthere is a rather large item that should be, at least in theory, controllable.

title: Walker Leads Rockets
description: DETROIT, Dec. 16 (AP) Jimmy Walker tossed in 30 points to lead the Houston Rockets to a 123.112 National Basketball Association victory over the Detroit Pistons tonight.

title: Black Movie Boom Good or Bad?
description: Does the recent wave of black moviesfrom Shaft to Super Flyrepresent an important, if longdelayed, recognition of the talent of black artists and of the right of audiences to see movies about blacks? Or do such movies merely offer a new stereotypeblacks as studs, pimps, prostitutes and pushers?

title: Biographer's Choice
description: Biography may be history as Emer son said, or character analysis or literary criticism, among other things; the emphasis is the biographer's choice. Sometimes it's only gossipa wit observed that biography is best when written by an acute enemy. For young readers, the biographer's chief task is to breathe life into a remote famous person and to translate dust history in a way relevant to the here and now.

title: The anatomy of a murder trial
description: An old Marxist once told me there are two kinds of people in the world, the haves and the have  nots, who are constantly fighting each other for dominance. Now this makes sense on the surface, but after six weeks of hanging around the Criminal Court building in New York City, listening to testimony in the case of The People vs. William Phillips, I'm inclined to believe that the old boy overlooked a few things. Take Phillips, the star of the show. Fifteen years ago he was a havenot in every sense of the word: a struggling toolanddie man who craved the lux uries of life but saw no way of getting them at his present trade. Lacking the benefits of a Harvard degree, he had little chance for advancement and years to go before retirement, when someone sug gested he join the police force, like his father be fore him.

title: Mother of Special Interests
description: CHICAGOHave you ever wondered what the American Ladder Institute, the Facing Tile Institute, the Instant Potato Products Association, the National Association of BankWomen, the National Pecan Shellers and Proces sors Association, the Pie Fill ing Institute; the Society of Thoracic Surgeons, and the Sterile Disposable Device Committee have in common?

title: Music:
description: Beethoven's Fidelio, an opera of some difficulty, is an ambitious choice for uni versity production, and the Brooklyn College Opera The ater made a brave showing with the piece at Whitman Hall Friday night.

title: Prof. Lester C. Lichty Dies; Taught Engineering at Yale
description: NEW HAVEN, Dec. 16Les ter C. Lichty, who retired as Robert Higgins Professor of Mechanical Engineering at Yale University in 1960, died Wednes day at his home here. His age was 81.

title: L.I.'s Channel 21 Switches to Color
description: GARDEN CITY, L. I.  WLIWTV, Long Island's only noncommercial television sta tion, gave its viewing audi ence a surprise birthday party Friday. Right in the middle of Sesame Street it turned itself on in full color.

title: Sports of The Times
description: The Cleveland Browns are oppor tunists, said Paul Brown with grudging admiration. They take advantage of the breaks and make miraculous finishes.

title: Art
description: PICASSO is one of the most quot able artists alive. Many of his most quotable and oftenquoted remarks have dealt with the sub ject of art. Dore Ashton, the art critic, has now compiled an anthology of Pi casso's stray obiter dicta, Picasso on Art (189 ?? $8.95, hardcover; $3.50, paper). Published by the Viking Press as part of its valuable series, The Documents of Modern Art, it includes a sampling of Picasso's views on mod ern art, nonfigurative painting, art and eroticism, and the old masters, that ranges from the extraordinary to the rather pedestrian.

title: The Kwai Bridge: The Reel and the Real
description: KANCHANABURI, Thailand where once it whistled The Colonel Bogey March, the sound track now reverberates to the big explosion. Debris hurtles sky ward. The Japanese train plunges down ward. It is the Academy Awardwinning movie The Bridge on the River Kwai, which is popping up on TV these days, and William Holden and Alec Guinness have managed to destroy the bridge. But that was in the movie. The real bridge on the River Kwai was never destroyed, not even damaged. It still stands on the edge of the Thai jungle about three miles from this peaceful town and it has become something of a tourist attraction.

title: TWO HOTELS OFF CITY RELIEF LIST
description: Teams of city inspectors last week completed unannounced visits to five more singleroom occupancy dwellings, and Dep uty Mayor Edward K. Hamilton disclosed that two of them were still ineligible to house welfare recipients.

title: Education
description: The famous monkey trial of 1925 resulted in the conviction of John T. Scopes, a young biology teacher, for violating a Tennessee law barring the teaching of Dar winian evolution. Since then his position has been accepted general ly, and proevolution teaching is the norm in American schools.

title: News of Boating; A Man of Steel (And Assorted Metals)
description: Wilt Chamberlain was stopped the other day as a 7foot airline hijacking sus pect, but that is nothing compared to the plight of Ron Larsen, the 39yearold unlimited hydroplane pilot. When Larsen boards an air liner, metal detectors buzz every time. No, he's not carrying a gun or a bomb. Lar sen must explain each time; it's the metal parts he carries inside his body, souvenirs of as sorted highspeed crackups in those speedboats.

title: FISHING CONFLICT AT CRITICAL STAGE
description: BOSTON, Dec. 16  Foreign fishing fleets, whose trawlers harvest tons of fish from the Continental Shelf off the North east coast of the United States, are slowly pushing independent New England fishermen off the deep sea lobster beds.

title: Dennison Replaces Larson As Football Coach at Akron
description: AKRON, Ohio, Dec. 16 (UPI) Jim Dennison, Associate head football coach at the Univer sity of Akron, was named head coach tonight.

title: Jane Paley Marries
description: Miss Jane Paley, an Eng lish teacher at the Dalton School, and Donald Cayc, a fashion photographer, were married here last night by Rabbi Edward Klein in his study. The bride is the daugh ter of Dr. and Mrs. David H. Paley of Pompano Beack Fla. Dr. Paley formerly was director of medicine at Grand Central Hospital here. Mr. Cayce is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Claudis Cayc of Tulsa, Okla. His father is an execu tive with International Busi ness Machines Corporation.

title: COAST STAKE WON BY KNIGHTLY DAWN
description: SAN MATEO, Calif., Dec. 16 (AP)Laffitt Pincay Jr. rode Knightly Dawn to a three length victory today in the 1 1/16mile $115,700 California Juvenile Stakes at Bay Meadows.

title: Dance
description: IWAS outraged by the Erick Hawkins Dance Company the first time I saw it 10 years ago. Nothing had prepared me for what was happening on stage. Or rather, for what was not happening in the seemingly uneventful Haw kins dances.

title: Bocuse on gastronomy Translated by Trammels K. Price
description: Not long ago, the Rhone Aipes edition of the French weekly magazine L'Express interviewed Paul Bocuse. Here are some excerpts, re printed with permission:

title: Chess: Outlandish or Not, Suttles Aims at a Grandmastership
description: Duncan Suttles has a chance to become the second grandmaster in Canada's his tory. By scoring an excellent 96 in the Church's Fried Chicken International Tour nament in San Antonio, Tex., the Vancouver mathemati cian achieved the norm for the first leg of the title. Since International chess rankings are determined on a 30game basis, he must repeat the performance within the next three years to join Dan Yanofsky of Winnipeg in the grandmaster ranks.

title: Movie Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: A world they never knew
description: The first day 14yearold Harry, who is mentally retarded, refused to get off the bus. For the four hours that the other children were busy at the center, Harry's teenage counselor, David, stayed with him, talking quietly to the fright ened boy. On the second day David was finally able to persuade Harry to come into the center. But it would be two more days before Harry would toss a volley ball back to David, and more than a week before he would join the other boys in playing ball and trying out the parallel bars.

title: FISHING CONFLICT AT CRITICAL STAGE
description: BOSTON, Dec. 16 Foreign fishing fleets, whose trawlers harvest tons of fish from the Continental Shelf off the North east coast of the United States, are slowly pushing independent New England fishermen off the deep sea lobster beds.

title: DRUG FEARED SENT IN BODIES OF G.I.'S
description: BALTIMORE, Dec. 16 (AP) An eightyear smuggling con spiracy brought heroin into the United States inside the bodies of soldiers killed in Vietnam, according to testimony from military and customs men in Federal court here.

title: Eileen Shields Wed To Bruce L. Whyte
description: Miss Eileen Shields, daugh ter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Alfred Shields of Jamaica Es tates, Queens, was married yesterday afternoon to Bruce Lincoln Whyte, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Lincoln Dodge Whyte of New York. The Rev. Thomas E. Ambrose performed the ceremony in the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More. He was assisted by the Rev. Daniel Fitzpatrick.

title: The Last Word
description: She had been sitting in Jackson Square when it happened, writes Eliza beth Spencer in her New Orleans novel, The Snare (reviewed on Page 6). And the things that happen in New Orleans are not quite like those that happen any where else. Or so a good many genera tions of novelists and others have told us.

title: Woman, 80, and Blind Man Rescued in Brooklyn Fire
description: Firemen using ladders res cued five persons, including a blind man and an 80yearold woman, from a burning frame building in the Bushwick sec tion of Brooklyn early yester day.

title: NORTH STARS WIN FROM RANGERS 51
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Dec. 16The Minnesota North Stars, winning their 10th straight home game, pulled away from New York on two secondperiod goals by Murray Oliver tonight and whipped the Rangers, 51, in a National Hockey League game.

title: Jersey Gross Output Figured
description: TRENTON, Dec. 16 (UPI) The state's Economic Policy Council predicted today that New Jersey's gross state prod uct will reach $50billion in 1973a $4billion increase. In its annual report to Governor Cahill, the council estimated that total personal income in New Jersey would rise by $3.4 billion to $41.4billion. On a per capita basis, the council ex pects personal income to aver age $5,600 next year, with an average household income of $18,000.

title: Anna Schoellkopf Bride Of Walter S. Lacher 2d
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 Miss Anna Portner Schoell kopf, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Horton Schoell kopf Jr., was married here this afternoon to Walter Scott Lacher 2d, son of John H. Lacher of Aiken, S. C., and the late Mrs. Lacher. Canon Charles Martin performed the ceremony in the Bethlehem Chapel at the National Cathe dral (Episcopal Cathedral of SS. Peter and Paul).

title: A Jersey Anthropologist Seeks to Avert Damage to Digs
description: MADISONThe president of the Metropolitan Area Archeological Survey has an nounced increased activity by his organization to combat damage to archeological ma terials in New Jersey, New York and Connecticut.

title: The World
description: CAIROI don't know what I think. I only know that one day soon I'll either be very happy or very angry, a Cairene of modest and nonpolitical background said last week summing up many Egyptians' feelings of inde cision, pentup emotion and vague ex pectation.

title: School Board Will Star on TV
description: WILLINGBORODr. Peter J. Romanoli, the television personality? Or how about Marcel F. Gilbert, the news analyst?

title: Spice Shop in HoHoKus
description: HOHOKUS  Electrical engineering may seem like a far cry, from a lifelong in terest in herbs and spices, but Clifford Schaefer has managed to combine both into two profitable busi nesses. By day, he is presi dent of an electronics surplus conern; on weekends, he helps his attractive Swedish born wife, AnnaLisa, operate Herb 'n Spice, a shop de voted to importing the rarest of herbs and spices avail able.

title: Will an AllStar Cast Help Tommy?
description: A LOT of people will he looking forward to this superstar, grand spectacular version of the Who's rock opera, Tom my, and a lot of people will undoubtedly buy it (Ode SP 99001, two disks). And most of them, one suspects, will be disappointed.

title: Post Takes 5th Straight
description: NEW BRITAIN, Conn., Dec. 16C. W. Post, led by Ed Fields, tonight defeated previ ously unbeaten Central Con necticut, 7664. The victory was the fifth in a row for the Pio neers after two opening losses. Fields, a 6foot6inch center, scored 23 points and dominated in rebounding.

title: Drama Mailbag
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: British Bar Links to Bookies: Betting's Just Not Thing to Do
description: LONDON, Dec. 16There will be no more betting shops on British golf cours es: Administrators of the game have decided it's just not the thing to do.

title: Shelter Aids Troubled Girls
description: EAST BRUNSWICKAfter taking all she could from an alcoholic father, 15 yearold Mary T. packed her few belongings and ran away from home. She was appre hended three days later.

title: CENTROWITZ IS 2D TO M'NIFF IN RUN
description: Howie McNiff upset favored Matt Centrowitz in the two mile run yesterday in the Bish op Loughlin games as the schol astic indoor track season opened at the 102d Engineers Armory, on 168th Street in Manhattan.

title: British Order the Slaughter Of 416 More Infected Hogs
description: LONDON, Dec. 16 (AP)  Authorities discovered a new outbreak of swine vesicular disease today and ordered that a herd of 416 hogs be killed.

title: Gilmour Captures Driving Honors at Westbury as the Season Ends
description: WESTBURY, L.I., Dec. 16 Because big drops in attend ance and in the mutual handle were anticipated, attention was focused tonight, at the closing of the local harness racing campaign, on the winner of the year's driving championship at Roosevelt Raceway.

title: Bridge
description: A player who reaches a really horrendous contract has three options open to him: he can sink into a guilty gloom generated by his own over bidding; he can prepare a postmortem attack on his partner's outrageous optimism; or he can set about trying to make his ridiculous contract while humming a tune from Guys and Dolls.

title: Friday's Fights
description: New YorkEduardo Santiago, 129 pounds, Puerto Rico, out pointed Felix Figuera, 131, Puerto Rico, 10 rounds.

title: Cowboys Activate Rookie
description: DALLAS, Dec. 16 (AP)The Dallas Cowboys of the National Football League activated Ralph Coleman, rookie linebacker, to day to replace Chuck Howley, who was lost for the season with a knee injury.

title: Television
description: ALL the wrinkles deepen into focus as the photographer moves closer and closer, snapping away steadily while Will Geer chuckles and warns how it is with old men: Give 'em an admiring audience and even strong minded fellows like Mark Twain and Carl Sandburg will take to blueing their long white hair. It's not enough for them to be men of distinction, they want to look it too.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTONNothing like it had ever happened in the labor movement before. The seemingly entrenched lead ers of the 82yearold United Mine Workers Union, inheritors of the mantle of John L. Lewis, had been swept from office in an extraordinary, Governmentsupervised election.

title: The World
description: UNITED NATIONSAction to curb international terrorism was regarded by many diplomats here as one of the most important issues to come before the current General Assembly. Secre tary General Kurt Waldheim pushed hard on the question. And to most people in the Western world it was a problem that had to be dealt with severely by the community of nations.

title: Indonesia Ratifies Pact
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Dec. 16 (AP)President Suharto has ratified an agreement between Indonesia and Australia on the seabed boundary between the northwest coast of Australia and the Indonesian island of Timor, the Mining Department said yesterday. The agreement, signed Oct. 9, says that the Australian border extends ap proximately 200 miles from the coast, which leaves Indonesia with an area extending 160 miles from Timor.

title: Butcher Is Slain in Ulster Shop; 7 Wounded by Belfast Gunmen
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Dec. 16 (UPI)Gunmen killed a 26yearold butcher today, raising the death toll to 665 in more than three years of Ulster violence between Roman Cath olics and Protestants and the British Army.

title: Freed P.O.W.'s Carry Psychic Scars of War
description: SAN DIEGO, Dec. 16When Lieut. David Matheny drove home for lunch the other day, he saw that his wife's car was gone. He turned around and left without even going in.

title: Wines of Cyprus Face Economic Threat in the Common Market
description: LIMASSOL, Cyprus, Dec. 10Lawrence Durrell wrote of Cyprus as a land of bitter lemons. Today the island is facing a case of sour grapes.

title: Saigon Reporting An Enemy BuildUp Near Bienhoa Base
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sunday, Dec. 17 (AP)A South Vietnamese general reported a North Vietnamese troop build up yesterday near Bienhoa air base, which has been shelled by enemy gunners for two suc cessive days.

title: Iran and Japan Plan Plant
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 16 (AP) Iran and Japan today signed a $40million agreement to build a new petrochemical plant at Bandar Shahpur on the Persian Gulf near a present existing $300million plant.

title: Jones Boy ls the Best
description: ST. LOUIS, Dec. 16 (UPI) Bert Jones, Louisiana State quarterback, was named the Sporting News college player of the year as the weekly pub lication announced its allAmer ica offensive and defensive squads today. Chosen on the basis of professional scouting reports and recommendations, the picks included the Heisman Trophy winner, Johnny Rodgers of Nebraska.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: PRESIDENT NIXON will ask Congress to extend wage and price controls beyond April 30. Business leaders want modifications. Business inventories rose by $1.2 billion in October, bringing total stocks to $192.,9billion.

title: An Army Discharge Is Finally Corrected
description: FRESNO, Calif., Dec. 16 (AP)A Fresno man given an Army discharge contain ing an error more than three years ago has finally re ceived a corrected discharge and a check for $1,580.88 after what Representative B. F. Sisk, Democrat of Califor nia, described as more than two years of bureaucratic bungling  red tape  and undue harassment.

title: World News Briefs
description: TUNIS, Dec. 16President Habib Bourguiba of Tunisia to day publicly turned down pro posals by the Libyan head of state, Col. Muammar elQad dafi for a union of their two countries soon.

title: Drama Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Inquiry Pressed After Autopsy Fails
description: HONESDALE, Pa., Dec. 16 The Wayne. County coronor, Robert Jennings, said here to day that a futile autopsy last Tuesday on the body of a boy who died almost 10 years ago would not end his attempt to verify the cause of the boy's death.

title: First Woman Mayor Of Willimantic Resigns
description: WILLIMANTIC, Conn., Dec. 16 (UPI)Florence MacFar lane, a school teacher who was elected the first woman Mayor of this community in her first try for public office, has resigned.

title: New style, new personaa performance
description: For some time Richard Poirier has been elaborating a species of liter ary and cultural criticism that exam ines ongoing changes in artistic role and procedure. His notion of the performing self (the title of a re cent book of his essays) seems to me extremely useful in that it seeks to overcome our traditional dichotomy between self and creation, mind and artifact, by examining how the divi sion no longer holds up securely in practice. From action painting to autobiographical pop music to thea ter of selfexposure, we have been made less able to distinguish being from process in the arts; and litera ture, too, Poirier argues, is becoming more a matter of performance, an expression of the self no longer divid ed into the part that creates and that which lives.

title: Planners Approve 2 Projects In Bfooklyn
description: For two groups of Brook lynites last week's annual madness in the Board of Es timatethe period when the City Planning Commission commingles capital budget hearings with other sessions ended in happiness.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: PLANE CRASH KILLS SIX NEAR BUFFALO
description: A small twinengine plane lost power shortly after taking off in a heavy snowstorm early yesterday from Greater Buffalo International Airport and crash ed into two houses, killing three on the plane and three on the ground.

title: Movie Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: 5 G.O.P. Senators Eye '76 Nomination
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 With an air of innocence that belies their competing political ambitions, a number of Repub lican Senators have begun pre liminary jousting for the Presi dential nomination in 1976.

title: 8 in Row for Celtics
description: PORTLAND, Ore., Dec. 16 (AP)The Boston Celtics regis tered their eighth straight vic torya 123116 verdict over the Portland Trail Blazers to night. Dave Cowens, with 33 points and 17 rebounds, led the Celtics.

title: Baruch Defeats Hunter
description: John Adams and Bill Robin son combined to lead Baruch to victory over Hunter, 7667, last night at the losers' gym. Baruch, now 41, built a 20 point lead in the first half and was never headed. Hunter is now 3 and 3.

title: Bay State Aide Resigns
description: BOSTON, Dec. 16 (AP)  Milton Greenblatt, Massachu setts Commissioner of Mental Health for more than five years, has submitted his resignation to Gov. Francis W. Sargent. Mr. Greenblatt said he was nego tiating for a professional ap pointment at Harvard.

title: Athens to Free Some Political Prisoners but Bars Early Return to a Democracy
description: ATHENS, Dec. 16Premier George Papadopoulos an nounced today the release of a few political prisoners, but he ruled out any return in the near future to elected, repre sentative government here.

title: NEEDIEST CASES STIR MEMORIES
description: Last Jan. 2, 8yearold Juanita Sheppard was killed in an elevator accident in a Greenwich Village welfare hotel.

title: Namath Will Play on Shaky Legs Cleveland Has Chance for Title
description: All things considered, Leroy Kelly would rather spend the next couple of weeks in Cleve land and that's not just a takeoff on W.C. Fields's epitaph about the city of Philadelphia.

title: Accused Slayer Gives Up From Locked Bank on L.I.
description: MINEOLA, L. I., Dec. 16A man wanted in connection with the murder of his three small children last Monday in North Carolina gave himself up to the Nassau County police early to day from inside a locked bank.

title: Susan F. Grant Of Time Weds
description: MORRISTOWN, N. J., Dec. 16 Miss Susan Frances Grant, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thompson Doane Grant of Morristown and South Bristol, Me., was married here this afternoon to Gerhard Krause Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Krause of Nanuet, N. Y.

title: Army Ahead of Schedule For AllVounteer Force
description: BOSTON, Dec. 16 (AP)The United States Army is slightly ahead of schedule in recruiting men to serve in the allvolun teer force, with a target date of July 1 for eliminating the draft.

title: Unconventional Luxury Housing Rising in Bergen
description: HACKENSACKA design system evolved by the Mas sachusetts Institute of Tech nology with a grant from United States Steel is being used for residential construc tion for the first time in the East in erecting a 20story apartment building on Over look Avenue and Beech Street here.

title: Letters
description: TO the Editor:

title: Inmates Learn Sculpture
description: JERSEY CITYWhen Sis ter Madeleine, president of Englewood Cliffs College in Englewood Cliffs, asked fac ulty members this fall to vol unteer as instructors in New Jersey correctional institu tions, Charles Vukovitch of fered to teach a sculpture class. Mr. Vukovitdh is chair man of the fine arts depart ment at the college; the re quest for volunteers came from the New Jersey Depart ment of Higher Education.

title: Ohio State Routs Butler
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 16 (UPI)Ohio State, led by Allan Hornyak with 25 points, pulled away after the first 10 minutes for an 8655 victory over Butler tonight. The victory was the third in five starts for Ohio State.

title: Ellen Kramer Bride of Fellow Lawyer
description: Miss Ellen Kramer and Ste phen P. Sawyer, lawyers, were married here yesterday afternoon at the Carlyle by Chief Judge Stanley H. Fuld of the State Court of Appeals. The bride is in the Appeals Bureau of the City's Corpora tion Counsel. Her husband is on the staff of Maurice H. Nadjari, the state's special prosecutor investigating local curruption in the criminal process.

title: News of the Rialto
description: HAD enough? Enough of those plotless rock musicals that have besieged Broadway since Hair? George Axel rod and Joshua Logan and a lot of other people feel that way. So, this morning's tale concerns one effort to return to the musicals of yore in which, to put it plainly, boy meets girl, boy loses girl, boy gets girl.

title: IN THE NATION
description: Dr. Kissinger's astonishing news conference was clearly aimed at put ting the blame on the North Viet namese for the impasse now reached in the Paris negotiations. This pos sibility had been telegraphed last week when an American spokesman in Paris said the Communist side was dike the highpressure salesman who tries to obtain immediate signature of an incomplete contract.

title: ENVIRONMENT GROUP GETS HALF OF A FINE
description: MANCHESTER, N. H:, Dec. 16 (AP)For the first time in state history an environmental group has been awarded half of the fine imposed on a pollution violator it helped bring to court.

title: About Motor Sports
description: First, there is the conven tional rally that emphasizes precise navigation (Left at graveyard, increase average speed 12 per cent). Then there is the highspeed inter national affair like the Monte Carlo, the East African Sa fari and, in this country, the Press On Regardless, where the premium is on driving ability.

title: The Nation
description: NEW ORLEANSThe nation was treated last week to the spectacle of a Deep South state moving out ahead of the Federal Government in fixing the blame for a fatal confrontsktion be tween white policemen arld black students.

title: Drama Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Janice Rogers Is the Fiancee Of R. M. Schell
description: MAMARONECK, N. Y., Dec. 16  Miss Janice. Lynn Rogers, a senior at Smith College, plans to be married in June to Rowland Marshall Schell, a graduate of Am herst College.

title: The World
description: When rotund young JeanClaude Duvalier succeeded his late father, Francois (Papa Doc) Duvalier as Haiti's President in 1971, there was specula tion that the Caribbean island's long era of brutal repression might soon end. The new President, Baby Doc he's now 21was said to be more interested in fast cars than in slow torture for political enemies.

title: Dance
description: I Tis more than twenty years since I first saw Mrinalini Sarabhai, the Indian dancer who came with her Darpana Company to the Brooklyn Academy of Music two weeks ago. She doesn't seem to have aged at all, and still looks perfectly charming and fragile. It was altogether an exotic week in dance. The Batsheva Dance Company of Israel returned to the New York City Center for a two week engagement that ends tonight. And for searchers for less out of the way pleasures, at the New York State Theater Balan chine's The Nutcracker opened its Christmas occupa tion. (Couldn't the company think of a different Christmas ballet once in a while? I realize that everyone has to see The Nutcracker once in a lifetime, but pretty soon will have done.)

title: Movies
description: author of Dutchman and Slave Ship.

title: Draatma Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Columbia U. Agrees to a Loan In Move to Save The Spectator
description: Dr. William J. McGill, the president of Columbia Univers ity, announced yesterday that he had reached agreement with The Columbia Daily Spectator over the terms of a loan de signed to prevent the 95year old publication from folding.

title: COLTS 14TH VICTIM
description: MIAMI, Dec. 16With a 160 victory over the Baltimore Colts that displayed their vari ety of talents, the Miami Dol phins completed today the first unbeaten and untied 14game regularseason schedule in Na tion Football League history.

title: Fordham Repels C.C.N.Y., 7357
description: Undefeated Fordham Univer sity overcame a 3426 halftime deficit against a surprising City College squad to beat the Beavers, 7357, last night in the loser's gym.

title: Movie Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: ALASKA MAY FACE LIFE  STYLE UPSET
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (AP) A potential major pertur bation of the economy and life style of Alaska could result from construction of the trans Alaska oil pipeline, says a study prepared for the consortium that is planning the pipeline.

title: Movie Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: World News Briefs
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Dec. 16 After 18 months of direct military rule, Thailand will have a new 20man cabinet and an appointed 299member na tional assembly, Field Marshal Thanom Kittikachorn an nounced today.

title: Miss Sayers Becomes Bride
description: At Temple EmanuEI last evening, Miss Barbara Beth Sayers, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore R. Sayers of New York, was married to Dr. Kenneth Braun, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Braun of Pound Ridge, N. Y. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi Nathan A. Perilman.

title: Inmates Help Harvest Holly
description: MILLVILLE  Prisoners, college students and senior citizens are working together to harvest holly on a 55acre farm that its owner, Amer ican Holly Products, calls the largest orchard of its kind in the world. The orchard is situated off Route 49 at a point three miles east of town.

title: OccupancyTax Crackdown Is Begun in Times Square
description: Times Square peep shows, massage parlors, pornographic bookstores and hotels used by prostitutes are being investi gated by the city to determine if their owners are paying their share of occupancy taxes.

title: REV. JOSEPH FINEGAN
description: The Rev. Joseph Henry Fine gan, believed to be the oldest member of the Paulist fathers, died on Friday at a nursing home in the Bronx. He was 88 years old.

title: Princeton Is Beaten
description: HUNTINGTON, W. Va., Dec. 16 (AP)All five Marshall starters scored in double fig ures as the Thundering Herd overpowered Princeton, 7864, tonight and won its Memorial invitation tournament. Law rence McCray scored 28 as secondranked Florida State whipped Baylor, 8567, for third place.

title: Drama Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Ritchie Davis Wed To Lance M. Dow
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Dec. 16 Miss Ritchie Davis, a junior designer with the Boston en gineering firm of Jackson & Moreland, was married here this afternoon, to Lance Mer rill Dow, an architectural draftsman in Boston.

title: Los Angeles Times Denied Delay on Tapes Hearing
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (AP) A Federal judge has denied a motion by The Los Angeles Times and two of its reporters to delay a hearing on an order requiring The Times to produce tapes of interviews with a Gov ernment witness in the Water gate breakin case.

title: Concert Series Not Offbeat to Children
description: WESTWOOD  The musi cians had scarcely finished taking their bows at the reci tal presented by the Young Concert Artists of Bergen County when scores of youngsters swarmed on stage, each vying for a closer look at the sleek, ebony harpsichord.

title: Music
description: Bracing, at times abrasive sonorities were unleashed at the Hunter College Playhouse on Thursday night, when the Dorian Woodwind Quintet performed the Premtere of Lukas Foss's Cave of the Winds, a piece that incor porates multiphones.

title: Danger Seen in Delaying Dam Repairs
description: WAPPINGERS FALLS, N. Y. Portions of the old Wappin gers Lake Dam are collapsing as the state and village argue over paying the repair bill.

title: Collombin Breaks Speed Record In Taking World Cup Downhill
description: VAL GARDENA, Italy, Dec. 15 (AP)Roland Collombin of Switzerland became the fastest Alpine ski racer in history to day, downhill and took the lead in the World Cup standings with a downhill victory here.

title: Ithaca Six Wins by 111
description: ITHACA, N.Y., Dec. 16 (AP) Tom Villa and Bob Driscoll scored three times each as Ithaca peppered the Penn State goal with 58 shots en route to an 111 hockey victory today.

title: Races Are Over, but OTB Lingers With PipedIn Music
description: While the racing season here wound up yesterday, industrial psychologists prepared to tell the Offtrack Betting Corporation what kind of music horse players might like to bet by.

title: BOYLE LOST POST BY 14,000 VOTES
description: SILVER SPRING, Md., Dec. 16The Labor Department completed today the ballot count that will end the 10year rule of W. A. Boyle over the United Mine Workers of Amer ica and give control of the troubled union to insurgents.

title: Music:
description: Helen McKeown chose an attractively unhackneyed pro gram for her Carnegie Recital Hall debut Friday night, and left this listener wishing that her intelligent musicality had been partnered by an equiva lent degree of technical ex pertise.

title: Patricia Neale To Be the Bride Of Navy Ensign
description: MOUNT KISCO, N. Y., Dec. 16Mr. and Mrs. Rich ard L. Neale have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Patricia Wes ley Neale, to Ens. Daniel Good Van Chief Jr., U.S.N., son of Delegate and Mrs. Van Chief of Esmont, Va. The wedding is planned for June 2.

title: Sylvia's Souvenirs
description: WE'RE at a plush restaurant where the maitre d' and a waiter battle to strike the first match for Sylvia Sidney. I can do it, says Sylvia Sidney, shrugging off both. She lights her cigarette and orders a Bloody Mary because it's Sunday and asks about the newspaper clipping I have in front of me. I give it to her. The headline reads Times Square Tintypes and the date is Nov. 30, 1930. She holds it close to her face, squints, puts it down. Out come the glasses, they slip over her nose, she spots a longago photo of a bobbed and beautiful Sylvia and mutters, Jesus!

title: Beth Louise Holman Is Married
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 16Miss Beth Louise Hol man of Larchmont, N. Y., a senior at Radcliffe College, and Stephen Kearns Sawyier, who attends the Harvard Graduate School of Far East ern Languages, were married here today. The nonsectarian service took place in the Me morial Church at Harvard.

title: Playing With Fire at a Volcano's Rim in Hawaii
description: VOLCANO, HawaiiA dangerous game of brinkmanship is being played here by tourists on a precarious ledge atop Mauna Ulu, the world's most accessible ac tive volcano.

title: Graham Greene On Film
description: Readers of Graham Greene may sometimes suspect that he brings out the worst in them. Revelling in his memoirs last year, I briefly won dered if there was something wrong with me: how could another person's deep depressions be so enjoyable? Then I realized that he must enjoy them himself  and his pleasure is terribly contagious. The voluptuous gloom in most of his books satisfies the pessimist that lurks in many hopechests. (Of course it pleases the occasional sadist too.) And optimists can celebrate his insistence on his own lifelong failureFor a writer  success is always temporary, suc cess is only a delayed failureby admitting that we'd all love to fail like him.

title: Struck Hospital Functioning
description: PARSIPPANYTROY HILLS, N.J., Dec. 16 (UPI)Patient services were reported normal today at Greystone Park State Psychiatric Hospital despite a walkout by 55 plumbers, car penters and electricians. A hos pital spokesman said most of the members of the American Federation of Technical Engi neers who walked out yesterday to protest the arrest of a plumber on a disorderlyperson charge were normally off duty on the weekends.

title: Movies
description: screen writer of Georgia, Georgia.

title: Increased Ceiling on StateAssisted Mortgages Is Expected to Spur Home Buying
description: TRENTON  In a move designed to encourage the purchase of homes in New Jersey, the state's Mortgage Finance Agency has in creased from $28,000 to $32, 000 the appraisedvalue limit on singlefamily residences. This will allow more people to become eligible to obtain loan through the agency's program.

title: Churches In Roselles Set Up Fund For Needy
description: ROSELLEBuying a tank of oil for an elderly couple, getting groceries for a fam ily caught between jobs, in stalling a telephone for a heart patient whose welfare check is meagerthese are among the small emergencies that church people here hope to handle with their new DollarAMonth Emergency Fund.

title: REMEMBER THESE: THE CITY'S NEEDIEST
description: HERE are more stories of the needy, for whom The Times re news its annual appeal today. They are stories of your neigh bors, trapped by circumstances so over whelming that they can no longer, cope with their misfortunes unaided. As in the case of the handicapped youngsters whose story is told at the bottom of this page, life holds little but fear and loneliness for the many thousands whom the appeal helps.

title: Nationalization Planned
description: NEW DELHI, Dec. 16 (Reuters)  Fakruddin All Ahmed, India's food and Agri culture Minister, said today the Government planned to com plete nationalization of the wholesale rice and grain trade by April.

title: U.S. Agency Plans Bike Safety Drive For Grade Schools
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16The National Safety Council has de veloped a bicycle safety pro gram for children designed to be administered through the na tion's elementary schools.

title: Javits and Others See Nixon Vote Here as Sign G.O.P. Can Take City Hall
description: Senator Jacob R. Javits and some other influential Republi cans have interpreted the heavy vote for President Nixon in New York City last month as a sign that the Republicans can capture the mayoralty next year.

title: TRANSPORTATION
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 The Army Corps of Engineers is planning a dredging proj ect along the Atlantic coast lines of Delaware, Maryland and Virginia that would create a continuous 145mile waterway, 6 feet deep and 100 feet wide, from Delaware Bay to Cape Charles, Va.

title: M. C. Schuller, Yale '73, Fiance Of Miss Waters
description: SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., Dec. 16  Mrs. Lewis W. Waters Jr. of South Hadley and Southwest Harbor, Me., has announced the engage ment of her daughter, Miss Candace Waters, to Michael Callaway Schuller. His par ents are Mr. and Mrs. Thomas C. Schuller of Beirut Lebanon, and Southwest Har bor.

title: Newark RentStrike Chiefs Facing Court
description: NEWARK  Like a falling star, the nation's longestrun ning public housing rent strike is heating up as it reaches its apparent end.

title: Drama Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: L.I. Rabbis Discuss Kosher Standards
description: Mass marketing may have its good points, including faster service and lower prices, but for adherents to kosher dietary laws, the lack of the personal touch isn't the only thing missing. Regu lation sometimes is too.

title: The World.
description: TOKYO  Premier Kakuel Tauaka of Japan was less than his usual boun cy self last Monday as he surveyed a large white signboard with the names of his party's candidates for the na tional Diet in Sunday's election. The red roses above the names of the Lib eral. Democratic winners were at least 10 fewer than he had expected. We must reflect on this, he said.

title: Letters
