description: To the Editor:

title: $25Million N.Y.U. Library Is Dedicated
description: After years of controversy, delay, planning, promotion and construction, New York Uni versity yesterday formally ded icated its Elmer Holmes Bobst Library and Study Center, a $25million edifice of Medici magnificence overlooking Wash ington Square Park.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Drama Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: The opposition in Chile Said Castro to Allende: II you don't get those people under control, the revolution is not going to succeed. We were never up against anything like this in Cuba.
description: The first step in the revolution by the work ing class is to raise the proletariat to the position of ruling class, to win the battle of democracy.

title: Roberta Renchard to Be Wed on Dec. 31
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 Mr. and Mrs. George Wilimot Renchard of Washington and Tucker's Town, Bermuda, have announced the engage ment of their daughter, Miss Roberta Stapleton Renchard, to Robert Elliott Freer Jr., executive assistant to the general counsel of the De partment of Transportation here. The wedding is planned for Dec. 31.

title: Miss Virginia Mitchell Is Bride of Peter Dimsey
description: In the chapel of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church hers yesterday afternoon, Miss Virginia Mitchell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Peter Mitchell of Westfield, N. J., and Silver Bay, N. Y., was married to Peter Swains Peel Dimsey. He is the son of Mrs. Geoffrey Whitting Dimsey of Winchcombe, Gloucester shire, England, and the late Lieut. Col. Geoffrey Whitting Dimsey, British Indian Army, retired.

title: Temple Quintet Triumphs Over Rutgers, 75 to 66
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Dec. 16Temple scored 9 con secutive points at the start of the second half tonight and went on to defeat Rutgers, 7566. John Kneib led the Owls with 21 points, while Gene Armstead was the Rutgers lead er with 25.

title: A CITY PLAN TO ALTER PRIMARY LAW GAINS
description: A city proposal to advance next year's primary election runoff to a date four weeks after the primary has won the approval of Republicans and Democrats on the Joint Legis lative Committee on the Elec tion Law, a Board of Elections official said last night.

title: Miss Bishop Is Betrothed
description: BEDFORD, N.Y., Dec. 16  Mr. and Mrs. Barnaby John Howard of Bedford have made known the en gagement of Mrs. Howard's daughter, Miss Cynthia Chambers Bishop, to David Vaillant Orbison, son of Mr. and Mrs. Tucker Orbison of Lewisburg, Pa. The couple plan to be married June 10 in Mount Kisco.

title: BAYSIDE SWIMMER WINS 3 GOLD MEDALS
description: Peter Groner, a Bayside High School sophomore, won three gold medals in the Public Schools Athletic League individ ual swimming championships at Queens College yesterday. Groner won the 200yard and 400yard freestyle events and anchored the winning 400yard freestyle relay team. Two other swimmers from Bayside's undefeated team won two gold medals each. Doug Landau and Keith Miniaci were on the winning 200yard med ley relay team. Landau also won the 100yard breaststroke and Miniaci was on the 400 yard freestyle relay team.

title: Lawyer in Key Albany Post
description: John F. Haggerty of Queens now holds one of the more laborious, exacting jobs in New York politics.

title: Like all Russian writers, he reports to his own God
description: This Russian doctor and mathema tician, in the States for 30 years (and evidently in a state for those decades as wella state of internal exile, a tyranny tempered by epi grams: tainted meat plus spices that is civilization), is a kind of un exploited international resource. Vas sily S. Yanovsky is the author of 10 novels, though he has no readership. Fortunately he has had one great reader, Auden, who wrote an intro duction to No Man's Time, Yanov sky's first novel to appear in English, in 1967, when the author was 60. (Others have been published in France and Italy. In Russia, he is a closed book.)

title: Surprises Marked Legislative Session
description: TRENTON  The 1972 legislative session that has just concluded turned out to be the major political sur prise of the year in New Jer sey.

title: Education
description: A typical course description in the traditional college catalogue runs like this: A laboratory course in experimental psychology. The application and evaluation of prin ciples of scientific research methods to both traditional and current psychological problems.The only specifics: the instructor's name and the time the course meets.

title: The Nation
description: The case of the celebrated French Connection of more than a decade ago had never been officially closed by the New York Police Department. So the 97 pounds of heroin seized in connec tion with it had been kept over the years in the department's cluttered propertystorage room in Manhattan.

title: Like dreams, the finest entertainment known and ragcheap
description: He gives her class and she gives him sex, quipped Katharine Hepburn about Fred and Ginger when asked to analyze their elegant success. What no one bothered to do until Arlene Croce's The Fred Astaire & Ginger Rogers Book was to lay open the meticulous planning that went into their cocareers. It was a theatrical match made by chance, but the union survived through skill.

title: Francis G. Ross Weds Mrs. Elizabeth Ehlers
description: Mrs. Elizabeth Garvin Ehlers of Oyster Bay, L. I., widow of Henry Ehlers Jr., was married here yesterday at noon to Francis Graham Ross of New York and Key Biscayne, Fla., a widower. Canon Henry A. Zinser per formed the ceremony in St. Thomas Episcopal Church.

title: Democrats
description: WASHINGTONFor Robert Strauss, an affable, littleknown Dallas lawyer, his election last weekend as national chairman of a divided and headless Democratic party represents an un usual personal opportunity. But the party election that deposed Mrs. Jean Westwood after four brief, uneasy months as chairman was, above all, symbolic act. It was a public announce ment by the men who control the Democratic partysometimes a nar row majoritythat they were wash ing their hands of Senator George Mc Govern.

title: Lakewood Pondering The Future Of Pinelands
description: LAKEWOOD Town offi cials are deliberating the fu ture of 150 acres of pine forest that used to be the campus of St. Gabriel's Col lege, which was closed two years ago. In fact, the fate of the land has become the foremost dilemma for all the environmentally concerned towns in Ocean County.

title: Issues in the L. I. R R. Dispute
description: PARTICIPANTS  The Long Island Rail Road and 12 unions representing 5,000 carmen, teamsters, clerks, elec trical workers, sheet metal workers and other nonoperating employes, as well as some supervisors.

title: How Bergen Aged Stay Active
description: HACKENSACKThe Vol unteer Bureau of the Bergen County Voluntary Action Center has received a one year Federal grant of $33, 778 to help elderly people not only to remain active themselves but also to help others.

title: Why Stewardesses Are Up in the Air
description: Determined to permanently ground their image as emptyheaded, whorish sexpots, leaders of Stewardesses for Women's Rights met with the founder of the Stewardess AntiDefamation Defense League in New York last week.

title: THUMBS UP VICTOR IN CATAMOUNT SHOW
Noel Groeschel Marries Miss DeMeo
description: The marriage of Miss Catherine DeMeo, a regis tered nurse in the compre hensive care program at the Brookdaie Medical Center in Brooklyn, to Noel Molloy Groeschel, a second vice president with Reynolds Se curities, Inc., took place yesterday afternoon. The Rev. James G. Cregan per formed the ceremony in St. Sylvester's Roman Catholic Church, Brooklyn.

title: Moon Tops Columbia
description: Connecticut, despite 32 turn overs, beat Columbia, 7162, at University Gym last night. The visitors extended a 64 lead to 184 during a threeminute stretch early in the game. After that, the Lions could get no closer than 8 points.

title: The Nation
description: The case of the celebrated French Connection of more than a decade ago had never been officially closed by the New York Police Department. So the 97 pounds of heroin seized in connec tion with it had been kept over the years in the department's cluttered propertystorage room in Manhattan.

title: Notes: Where Next?
description: THEY may not come to overshadow the countries of Western Europe as established tourist destinations but a number of developing lands are making strong bids to attract more visitors. If the amount of money being spent is any criterion and it has been in the past, then a look at some United Nations statistics should give an idea where tourists will be heading in the next few years. In general, the greatest growth is expected in Mexico, the Medi terranean, the Caribbean, Southeast Asia and Oceania.

title: Brooklyn Bar Celebrates Its Centennial
description: The Brooklyn Bar Associa tion, which was born in a righteous burst of indigna tion triggered by the reports of court corruption in the Boss Tweed scandal, has weathered the vagaries of the law for one hundred years. Now, winding up the celebration of this centennial, the association is looking for ward to the next 100 years and striving to improve the administration of justice in Brooklyn.

title: Tokyo
description: TOKYOThe Smithsonian realign ment of currencies a year ago, in which the Japanese revalued the yen 16.88 per cent, has worked out fine from the Japanese point of view.

title: Parley Assails Curb on Federal Funds for Air Pollution Research
description: RIVERSIDE, Calif., Dec. 16 Deep concern over a Federal contraction of funds for air pollution research funds has been expressed at a twoday conference here by a United States Senator, a Congressional staff lawyer and University of California scientists.

title: Figures on Housing in Trenton
description: More than threequarters of the 35,000 homes in Tren ton were built before 1940. In fact, at the time of the 1970 census, 80 per cent of Trenton's homes, or 28,490, dated from 1939 or earlier.

title: Letters:
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Bus Comes in Handy on an Airlift
description: MOUNT SNOW, Vt., Dec. 16Nature blew a mixed bag at 14 airminded ski en thusiasts last night. It balked the first attempt for sched uled air service between an Eastern metropolis and a ski area. But it atoned for it by dumping more than a dozen inches of muchneeded snow on this Green Mountain re sort.

title: Sports of The Times
description: MIAMI, Dec. 16If the last shall be first, Earl Morrall some day might be thought of as the first of the crewcut football players. He is as different now as Joe Namath was four years ago when the New York Jets' quarterback cultivated a Fu Manchu moustache and let his hair droop underneath the back of his helmet. Dozens of National Football League players wear their hair longer than Namath does now. But nobody in the N.F.L. wear it shorter than Earl Morrall does. Four or five years ago, the 38yearold quarterback of the Miami Dol phins says, long hair was the sign of the rebel, of the individualist. But now it's more a style thing.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Building a Monetary System
description: Finance ministers of the major industrial powers, meet ing at the Smithsonian Institution in Washington, reached agreement on Dec. 18, 1971, on a new pattern of exchange rates intended to restore order in the international monetary system. A year later, correspondents of The New York Times appraise the results from their respective capitals.

title: Arts Abroad
description: LONDON  He leaped across the stage of the Ald wych Theater I am ashamed, he shouted at the audience. I am disgusted. Then a woman ran onto the stage weeping and began tearing up the set. A chorus from the audience shrieked: Get out, get out.

title: Miss Fflug Sets Marks
description: INZELL, West Germany, Dec. 17 (Agence FrancePresse) Monika Pflug set two West German speedskating records today. She covered 1,000 meters in 1 minute 29.34 seconds and 3,000 meters in 5:8.9.

title: 10,219 at Garden Watch Hull's Jets Edge Raiders
description: It took Bobby Hull time to get moving yesterday. But when he bulled down his alley, straightarming anyone in his way, it was like old times as he displayed those electric rushes that earned him the sobriquet of the Golden Jet.

title: British Report the Capture Of I.R.A. Leader in Ulster
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland; Dec. 17 (UPI)  British troops captured another highranking member of the militant previ. sional wing of the Irish Repub lican Army during the week end, army sources reported to day.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Your Dec. 15 editorial  and National Parks and recent news sto ries eloquently summarize the impend ing tragedy which our national parks system faces.

title: Strike Halts London Papers
description: LONDON, Dec: 17 (AP)A 24hour protest strike by mech anical workers over a fine im posed on their union halted production of all London news papers today. Similar tieups are planned for other sections of the nation throughout the Week.

title: Sports of The Times
description: As the second half started, a burly customer with a face like broken crockery arose from his seat at the 50 yard line and stripped to the waist, exposing a fetching tract of meat to God's great outdoors. The chill factor had been figured at 15 below zero when the game started but now the stands were in shadow and an invigorating autumn snap was in the air.

title: SISTER M. AUGUSTINE
description: Sister Miriam Augustine O'Connell, administrator of the New York Foundling Hospital from 1954 to 1957 and earlier director of its adoption depart ment, died Saturday at the hos pital. Her age was 83.

title: Personal Finance
description: You've probably seen the ads: We seem to be the only bank in town that thinks $8,000 of your money is worth investing.

title: Watch on the Media
description: More than five years after, the Free dom of Information Act became Federal law, it is still difficult for journalists, historians and researchers to obtain information freely. The idea behind the law was to take the rubber stamp marked Confidential out of the hands of bureaucrats and open up Public records, opinions and policies of Federal agencies to public scrutiny. It hasn't worked that way.

title: U.S. Enters Durnping Case To Set a Price Principle
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 The Justice Department has made a rare intervention in an antidumping case before the Tariff Commission, with the aim of inducing the commis sion to establish firmly an im portant principle in cases of this kind.

title: N.F.L. Playoff MatchUps
description: Here is the schedule of the National Football League's four division playoff games next weekend. The teams' won losttied records are in parentheses. All starting times are Eastern Standard Time. Winners will meet for the confer ence champlonships on Dec. 31 and qualification for the Super Bowl on Jan. 14.

title: CYRUS F. SMYTHE
description: Cyrus F. Smythe, who retired as a claims attorney for the New York Telephone Company in 1958, died Saturday in Aus tin, Tex., where he lived. His age was 79.

title: Metreveli Defeats Dibley in Net Final
description: ADELAIDE, Australia, Dec. 17 (AP)Alex Metreveli of the Soviet Union won his third straight South Australian men's singles tennis title today when he rallied to beat Colin Dibley of Australia, 75, 57, 67, 76, 62, in a match that lasted near ly three hours.

title: OTB Wheel Is Only One in Town
description: With the local thoroughbred and harness racing seasons over, offtrack betting becomes the only parimutuel wheel in town today.

title: Court Ends Strike at Two Hotels in Puerto Rico
description: DORADO, P.R., Dec. 17A twoday wildcat strike by 1,200 employes of the Cerromar Beach Hotel and the Dorado Beach Hotel ended today when the management of the two luxury hotels obtained a court order against the walkout.

title: Santa Loses the Job Because He's a She
description: UTICA, N.Y., Dec. 17 (AP) Santa was dismissed from the job at a shopping center near here over the weekend, because the manager said, she sounded too much like a girl.

title: Mr. Nixon's Game Plan
description: Now that President Nixon II has swept out and largely replaced the Administration of President Nixon I, there remains little mystery about his new game plan. The indicators point clearly to White House retreat from progressive social action.

title: Alaina Reed, a Young Singer, Helps New Club Open in Style
description: A new supper club, an ad junct of a new restaurant called Reno Sweeney at 126 West 13th Street, has opened with a flurry of musical excel lence. The music takes place in the restaurant's Paradise Room, which was the garden of a predecessor restaurant and retains a garden atmos phere, even though it is now roofed over.

title: Polish Aide Tasting Life Outside U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Doc. 17A few weeks ago, Poland's Deputy Foreign Min ister, Stanislaw Trepczynski, acyakened early in a student dormitory it Stanford Univer sity, looked around with satis fation at the room decked with popart posters and Pho tographs of coeds and had a happy thought: I'll have plenty, to tell my sons.

title: Carole White Wed To G. G. Green 3d
description: RYE, N.Y., Dec. 17 Miss Arnelda Carole White, daugh ter of Mr. and Mrs. F. Clifton White, was married here this evening to G. Graham Green 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gazexer G. Green Jr. of New Braunfels, Tex.

title: Last Australian Soldiers In Vietnam Fly Home
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, Dec. 18 (Reuters) A fully laden C130 Hercules transport took off from Tan Son. Nhut air base today, carrying home about 60 Aus tralian soldiers and ending Australia's role In the Viet nam war.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: LONDON, Monday, Dec. 18 British officials said tht if Pres ident Amin's speech meant na tionalization of British trading interests in Uganda, Britain would press for prompt and adequate compensation.

title: Italy Takes Court Tourney
description: MONS, Belgium, Dec. 17 (Agence FrancePresse)  Italy won the SHAPE basketball tournament today by beating Greece, 9678, in the final. The Italians had eliminated the United States in the previous round.

title: Tourism in Spain at Record
description: MADRID, Dec. 17 (UN) Earnings from tourism in Spain broke all records in 1972, the Minister for Information and Tourism, Alfredo Sanchez Bella, said today. He said that 31 million persons visited Spain in 1972, which represented direct foreign exchange earnings of $2.6million.

title: Metreveli Defeats Dibley in Net Final
description: ADELAIDE, Australia, Dec. 17 (AP)Alex Metreveli of the Soviet Union won his third straight South Australian men's singles tennis title today when he rallied to beat Colin Dibley of Australia, 75, 57, 67, 76, 62, in a match that lasted near ly three hours.

title: Molasses Kills 7 in India
description: NEW DELIHI, Dec. 17 (UPI) A thick layer of molasses that burst out of an underground tank Friday in Gangavati in Mysore state, 400 miles south east of Bombay, trapped and killed seven persons, the Press Trust of India said today.

title: Rhodes Scholars Named; Scope of Award Widened
description: The Rhodes Scholarshipthe litist academic institution founded 70 years ago by the will of Cecil Rhodes, the British colonizer  is broadening its scope to take in student lead ers who are not all perfectly wellrounded establishment oriented, athletic, brainy and wellconnected individuals.

title: 121 L.I. Stores Get BlueLaw Citations
description: The Nassau and Suffolk County police issued 121 sum monses yesterday to operators of stores in Nassau and the western part of Suffolk, accus ing them of selling wares in violation of the Sunday blue laws.

title: Islanders' Futility Is Extended As They Lose to Flames by 40
description: ATLANTA, Dec. 17 (UPI) The Atlanta Flames defeated the islanders, 40, tonight, the second time Phil Myre had shut out the New Yorkers.

title: Solzhenitsyn Would Take Loan From American
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 17 (Reuters) The Soviet Union's Nobel Prizewinning novelist Alek sandr I. Solzhenitsyn today de scribed his financial situation as desperate and said he would accept a loan from an American author who had of fered to help him.

title: Rockets Beat Cavaliers
description: CLEVELAND, Ohio, Dec. 17 (AP)  The Houston Rockets, behind by 28 points in the third quarter, beat the Cletre land Cavaliers, 110109, tonight in a National Basketball Asso ciation game.

title: What Next on Peace? Some Key Questions
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17  Henry A. Kissinger, in his news conference yesterday, gave the Administration's rationale for the failure so far to achieve a negotiated settlement of the Vietnam war. Mr. Kissinger's presentation answered some of the questions that have arisen recently, left others unanswered, or in dispute and raised some new ones. What follows is an effort to clarify what is known, what is not known, and what can only be surmised.

title: New Jersey Notes
description: NEWARK, Dec. 16Where does Santa Claus come from? Not from the frozen North, but from the ranks of the elderly, the unemployed and perhaps surprisinglycol lege youths in seatch of tem porary work.

title: 2 VICTIMS OF FIRE WERE ALSO SHOT
description: The charred bodies of two halfbrothers found by firemen Friday night in a burnedout truck in the East New York section of Brooklyn each had a bullet wound in the back of the head, the Medical Examin er's office reported yesterday.

title: Airport Attacked
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Monday, Dec. 18 Thirtyone Soviet made rockets fell on the airport at the royal capital of Luang Prabang early today, damaging several combat planes and a fuel depot.

title: Wooden Out of Hospital
description: SANTA MONICA, Calif., Dec. 17 (UPI)John Wooden, the U.C.L.A. basketball coach, was released today from Saint John's Hospital where he had been under treatment for a mild heart condition.

title: Levitt Charges Schools Waste Transport Money
description: State Controller Arthur Levitt charged yesterday that the city's Board of Education was six years' delinquent in ac counting for state funds spent for pupil transportation and that the board had wasted mil lions of dollars on unneces sary transportation costs.

title: CITY AIMS TO CURB LANDLORD ABUSES
description: The city is drafting new reg ulations aimed at putting the burden on landlords to prove that they are properly main taining their apartment build ings in case of tenant com plaints of harassment.

title: CONGRESS SEEKS NEW BUDGET ROLE
description: WASHINGTON; Dec. 17 The members of a special new Congressional committee cre ated to devise ways that Con gress could ?? more con trol over Govarnment spending ate ?? new procedures for accomplishing the task.

title: 2 Share New Award in Chemistry
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (AP)Prof. Robert B. Wood ward, a Nobel Prizewinning chemist of Harvard Univer sity, and Prof. Roald Hoff mann of Cornell University were named today to share the American Chemical So ciety's new $40,000 Arthur C. Cope Award for outstand ing contributions to organic chemistry.

title: Hog Embargo Is Eased
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Dec. 17 (AP)A weeklong embargo on swine movement in the state due to hog cholera was eased today. Pigs and hogs may now be shipped from Pennsylvania farms directly to instate slaughterhouses, but interstate shipments will require a special state permit and a total em bargo remains in force for feed er pigs and breeding stock.

title: Six Die in Ontario Crash
description: CANFIELD, Ontario, Dec. 17 (UPI)Six persons, including two children, were killed today when the car in which they were driving was struck by a freight train at a rural railroad crossing.

title: CAIRO PRESS ASKS CENSORSHIP'S END
description: CAIRO, Dec. 17The Egyp tian press syndicate appealed to the government today for the immediate lifting of censor ship on newspapers except in military matters involving na tional security.

title: Dissension Hampers Work Among South Jersey Poor
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Dec. 17 The official antipoverty agency for New Jersey's two southern most countiesCape May and Atlanticis being rent by in ternal dissension so fierce that both of the state's United States Senatora and the re gion's Representative have asked for a Federal inquiry.

title: British Report Less Fallout
description: BERLIN, Dec. 17 (UPI)  East Germany established dip lomatic relations at the am bassadorial level today with Tunisia and Cyprus, A.D.N., the aEst German press agency, said. It said that diplomatic re lations with Tunisia took effect immedaitely and that relations with Cyprus would come into force on Thursday.

title: Show Stirs Hope and Fear for Crafts
description: PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 17 Wiley Blevins is almost 80 now. Born a deafmute, or phaned at 13, Mr. Blevins has eked out a living all these years by making chairs in the traditional handhewn man ner of his native Appalachia.

title: Black Hawks Blank Kings
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 17 (UPI) Goals by Cliff Koroll and Pit Martin and excellent goaltend ing by Tony Esposito gave the Chicago Black Hawks a 20 victory over the Los Angeles Kings tonight. Esposito stopped 22 shots as he preserved his second shutout.

title: CONGRESS SEEKS NEW BUDGET ROLE
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 The members of a special new Congressional committee cre ated to devise ways that Con gress could assert more con trol over Government spending are developing radical new procedures for accomplishing the task.

title: 'Heartbreak Kid':Elaine May's 2d Effort as Director Arrives
description: Elaine May's "A New Leaf," her first film as a director, was a charming, slightly nutty film with some awkward moments in it. "The Heartbreak Kid," her second, is a first-class American comedy, as startling in its way as was "The Graduate." It's a movie that manages the marvelous and very peculiar trick of blending the mechanisms and the cruelties of Neil Simon's comedy with the sense and sensibility of F. Scott Fitzgerald.It begins as a rather familiar New York Jewish comedy about the marriage of Lenny (Charles Grodin), a wide-eyed, completely self-absorbed young man who sells sporting goods, and Lila (Jeannie Berlin), who makes the (it turns out to be) terrible mistake of saving herself for Lenny until their wedding night. "Was it as good as you'd thought?" Lila asks in the dark of their Virginia motel room. "Exactly," says Lenny. "Exactly or better?" Lila insists. "Better!" he cries in desperation.As Lenny recalls their wedding trip later: "I had my doubts in Virginia. . . . I was pretty sure in Georgia."Most of their honeymoon takes place in Miami Beach, where Lenny, wearing his matching swimming trunks and beach shirt, meets and falls wildly in love with a beautiful blond WASP from Minnesota named Kelly (Cybill Shepherd). Lila, who has gotten fearfully sunburned their first day, stays in their hotel rooma loud, reproachful voice inside a mound of Solarcaine."The Heartbreak Kid," which opened yesterday at the Sutton, is the story of Lenny's efforts to unload Lila and to pursue Kelly to Minnesota. It suggests Fitzgerald's "Winter Dreams" updated to 1972, but now the poor boy from the wrong side of the tracks is a New York Jew, and the unattainable Judy Jones is, ironically and perhaps tragically, all too attainable.The film succeeds in being equally merciless to the unfortunate Lila, who eats Milky Ways in her wedding bed and dribbles egg salad down her chin at breakfast, and to the magnificent-looking Kelly, whose idea of wit is the snarling retort: "How do you expect me to think when I'm listening?" Not even Fitzgerald, I think, would have had the chutzpah to have his Judy Jones say to a man who'd just divorced his wife for her: "Gee! I'm really flattered!"The film, adapted by Neil Simon from a story by Bruce Jay Friedman, is full of more recent echoes, especially in the performance of Jeannie Berlin, Miss May's daughter, who looks, sounds and acts exactly as her mother did as recently as yesterday. It recalls the great performing years of Nichols and May, as does so much of the dialogue, especially when Lenny, dining with Kelly's parents in their huge, clapboard ice palace in Minnesota, tries to say nice things about the "plain" food. Food in New York, he expains, "is exotic but not honest. There's nothing dishonest about these potatoes. There's no deceit in that cauliflower. . ."Charles Grodin inevitably recalls Dustin Hoffman in "The Graduate," but I hope he won't be faulted for it. It's a perfpmance of completely controlled enthusiasms and puzzlements. As the object, of his unreasonable passion, Miss Shepherd succeeds in the fairly unusual feat of being lovely, bitchy and funny, all more or less simultaneously, and Eddie Albert in the comparatively small role of her father, is a model of superbly comic, quite understandable outrage."The Heartbreak Kid" occasionally goes for laughs without shame (which is what has always bothered me about Simon's brand of New York comedy), but behind the laughs there is, for a change, a real understanding of character  which is something that I suspect, can be attribued to Miss May. The film is an unequivocal hit.

title: Bridge: Roth's Team Paces Field Into Finals of Swiss Event

description: PHOENIX, Ariz., Dec. 17 (AP) The Phoenix Suns held high scoring Nate Archibald to 26 points tonight and defeated the Kansas CityOmaha Kings, 112 102.

description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (Reu ters)The General Accounting Office said in reports released today that there was over building of hospitals and nurs ing homes in at least six cities.

description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17The negative turn in the Paris peace negotiations provoked a com mon reaction of disappointment among Senators today, but it was still unclear whether the disappointment would lead to renewed criticism of the Administration's Vietnam policies.

ENROLLMENT CUT IN DAYCARE SEEN

description: Murray H. Finley, the new president of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America, says that the union, which pio neered in the battle against the clothing industry's sweat shops 50 years ago, is making gains in what has been de scribed as a classic organizing struggle in El Paso, Tex.

title: GROS, ITALY, WINS SPECIAL SLALOM
description: MADONNA DI CAMPIGLIO, Italy, Dec. 17 (UPI)Piero Gros of Italy, starting from the third group, won the first special slalom of the Alpine ski season and captured the lead in the World Cup.

title: Rhodes Scholars Named; Scope of Award Widened
description: The Rhodes Scholarshipthe litist academic institution founded 70 years ago by the will of Cecil Rhodes, the British colonizer  is broadening its scope to take in student lead ers who are not all perfectly wellrounded, establishment oriented, athletic, brainy and wellconnected individuals.

title: Santa Loses the Job Because He's a She
description: UTICA, N.Y., Dec. 17 (AP) Santa was dismissed from the job at a shopping center near here over the weekend, because the manager said, she sounded too much like a girl.

title: City Suspects Error Led To RevenueSharing Cut
description: David A. Grossman, the city's Budget Director, said yesterday that there might be a miscalcu lation in the Federal revenue sharing allocation to New York City, which he said appeared to be getting $60million to $70 million less than it should.

title: HEARINGS TO OPEN ON ARMS PROJECTS
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17A Congressional subcommittee will open four days of hearings tomorrow on four of the na tion's most controversial de fense projects, all plagued by cost overruns.

title: Helicopter Debris Is Found in Gulf; 8 Men Are Missing
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla:, Dec. 17 (AP)Debris floating in the Gulf of Mexico about 50 miles southwest of here has been identified as parts of a Coast Guard helicopter that crashed after rescuing four fishermen from a sinking shrimp trawler, searchers said today.

title: 'Pete 'n' Tillie,' Comedy, Opens at Baronet
description: Is anybody getting a little tired of Carol Burnett and Walter Matthau? The television queen is all over the home box and has been for some time. Matthau,expertise included, is certainly coming at us thick and fast.Expecting an obvious, strictly-for-laughs showcase in "Pete 'n' Tillie," which opened yesterday at the Baronet, one viewer received the jolt of his Christmas season. This is the wittiest, warmest and most ingratiating movie to appear in a long time, with a beautifully sustained and muted edge of sadness.A happy suspicion is that the producer-scenarist, Julius J. Epstein, having latched onto a novel ("Witch's Milk") by Peter De Vries, a proven humorist, has stuck closely to the dialogue, which is priceless, and the theme, togetherness.Pete 'n' Tillie (miserable title) are two wryly unyouthful San Francisco realists who meet at a party and like each other almost in spite of themselves. They bed down, wed, raise a fine little boy and undergo a numbing family crisis whose restrained, touching treatment is the most admirable thing about the film.For once, a basic comedy absorbs tragedy without an embarrassing ripple. There are more surprises, such as the graceful direction of Martin Ritt, usually plloting much grittier stuffastutely, of course. Then there is Geraldine Page, as Miss Burnett's Iah-de-dah chum, whose brief, mortified pantomime inside a police station is the funniest thing we have seen on film all year. In other roles, Ren Auberjonois, Barry Nelson and little Lee H. Montgomery are also excellent.You won't believe Miss Burnett, with no television mugging and those chipmunk teeth either swallowed or in full retreat. She is grand, even in one bit of tearful ferocity that would tax a Bernhardt. Matthau has given weightier performances but none more disarming. To one viewer, Christmas is already merrier with "Pete 'n' Tillie" and company on the scene.

title: AT HOME ABROAD
description: LONDON, Dec. 17The spread of cynicism in the United States, the loss of faith in the political process, can be traced back in significant part to the election of 1964. A good many peo ple felt afterward, whether or not they articulated the thought, that they had been the victims of a deception. Lyn don Johnson had run as the peace Candidate, won in a landslide and then quickly slipped the country into war.

title: TV: Format for the Arts
description: On television, the arts, popular and serious are not nearly so rare as solid information about arts and artists, Devising a format to get behind the arts is, evi dently, difficult. Two exam pies can currently be found on public television: The atre and Film '727A Year end Project, and a saries ef eight weekly discussions be tween June Wayne, artist lithographer, and assorted persons connected with the fine arts.

title: 3 Children Give $3.92 to Neediest

He was with Montreal in the Cana dian Football League this season, and began his pro career with the Dallas Cow boys in 1965.

description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (AP) The United States Public Health Service said today that in 1972 various foreign coun tries enacted laws against cigarette advertising, voted for health warnings on cigarette packages and increased budgets for antismoking education.

title: COURTS IN DISPUTE ON MENTALLY ILL
description: NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 17  Conflicting decisions by two Federal judges concerning the rights of the mentally ill have reached the first stage of an appeal. A decision by the Count of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit is expected in six weeks to three months.

description: Miss Laurie Benjamin and Eric M. Siegmeister were married yesterday evening at the Hillcrest Jewish Center in Jamaica, Queens. Rabbi Israel Moshowitz performed the ceremony.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, Dec. 17, Several black student groups at Rutgers College, angered by allegedly racist incidents on, campus, have requested an in vestigation of what they say is the continued functioning of institutional racism at Rut gers.

title: 7 Turnovers Help Pittsburgh to Conquer Chargers by 242
description: SAN DIEGO, Dec. 17 (UPI) Pittsburgh's defense set up short touchdown runs by John Fuqua and Franco Harris and a touchdown pass to Ron Shanklin as the Steelers won their first National Football League division championship in 40 years today with a 242 triumph over the San Diego Chargers.

title: HARVARD CREWMEN WIN NILE REGATTA
description: LUXOR, Egypt, Dec. 17 (Reu ters)Harvard University won the third Luxor regatta today beating Cambridge University, the runnerup by two seconds at this ancient Egyptian capital on the Nile. Luxor is 420 miles south of Cairo.

While major parks serve large numbers of people and whole com munities may have a stake in their survival, a small park may sometimes have only a few close friends who too often prove no match for the bulldozer forces promising new taxratables arrayed against them.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Your Dec. 7 editorial concerning the additional allocation of funds by the New York City Board of Education is completely unfair to the officials in volved. What is more important, how, ever, is that it implies that the addi tional allocation resulted from the boy cott in District 4.

description: SYDNEY, Australia, Dec. 17  Final counting in the Au stralian parliamentary election, completed last night, has given the Labor party a majority of nine in the House of Represent atives. The lead will be reduced to eight when the party pro vides a Speaker.

description: BOSTON, Dec. 17 (AP)Don Herriman scored three goals today so the Philadelphia Bla zers beat New England, 63, in a World Hockey Association game. The Whalers' home un beaten streak ended at 14 games.

description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17  The White House announced today that Henry A. Kissinger's deputy, Gen. Alexander M. Haig Jr., was flying to South east Asia to brief the leaders of South Vietnam, Laos, Cam bodia and Thailand on the current impasse at the Paris negotiations.

description: Once she plied the Grand Banks in search of fish and then she brought the mails to the Magdalen Islands way up beyond Prince Edward Island In the bay of St. Lawrence, and now, in her 39th year, she sits at the South Street Sea port, serving as, a school of sur vival bound for San Francisco.

title: Giants Head for Homes With a Feather in Hats

description: Dr. Frances Shostac, an ob stetrician long associated with the New York Infirmary, died yesterday at her home, 279 Wyoming Avenue in Maple wood, N.J. She was 89 years old.

title: Bruins Top Flyers Again

The victory extended the Bruins unbeaten string against the Flyers since 1969 to 19 victories and two ties.

Uriah Heep, the headliner, has recently put out two records called Demons and Wizards and Magician's Birthday. Pub licity for Elf, the group that opened the proceedings, deliber ately evokes fairy tales and speaks fondly of its magical music. But the only real magic on stage Saturday was provided by the middle act, Manfred Mann's Earth Band.

title: Airbag Proponents Sense Victory Despite a Delay
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 Advocates of the airbag safety device are more encouraged than disappointed over a Fed eral court order that could post pone the date that passive re streints will be mandatory on new passenger cars.

title: PicturePostcard Swiss Town Votes to Keep Cars Far Away
description: GENEVA, Dec. 17The res idents of Zermatt, the picture postcard village at the foot of the towering Matterhorn in southwestern Switzerland, had a change of heart today when they voted to keep the auto mobile away from their door step.

description: MEXICO CITY, Dec. 17 (Reu ters)Two fishermen drowned in what officials called Mexico's worst hurricane for 50 years and a merchant ship with 13 crew aboard was still missing in the Gulf of Mexico today, 24 hours after radio contact was lost.

title: Article 4  No Title
description: HOUSTON, Dec. 17 (UPI) The Houston Aeros and Los Angeles Sharks played to a 44 deadlock tonight despite a 10 minute suddendeath overtime. Gary Beneruzzo scored the tying goal for the Sharks at 15:08, forcing the overtime.

title: B'NAI B'RITH SETS RETIREMENT PLAN
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 B'nai B'rith and the National Council on the Aging have be gun an effort at preretirement planning for the middleaged, preparing a person in his fifties to cope with problems of social isolation that can con front him when he retires.

title: Carols and Chattering Teeth Heard on Fifth Avenue Promenade
description: Voices of carolers, amplified music for rockandroller skat ing, the chattering of teeth and the patter of warmbooted feet filled Fifth Avenue yesterday during a fourhour ban on ve hicular traffic for the third an nual Holiday Promenade.

title: 'Avanti!,' Another Billy Wilder Farce, Stars Jack Lemmon
description: For nuance-loving Italians, "Avanti!" means, among other meanings, "Come In!" "Let's Go!" and "Forward!" As the latest comedy directed by Billy Wilder and starring Jack Lemmon, which opened yesterday at the Trans-Lux East and 85th Street, it also translates as intermittently funny, charming, cute and, unfortunately, over-long.In transporting Samuel Taylor's short-lived, 1968 Broadway farce about an American tycoon's entanglement with amore and bureaucracy in Italy, Wilder, Lemmon and I.A.L. Diamond, Wilder's long-time writing teammate on such superb antics as "Some Like It Hot," fitfully charm us but they haven't moved forward at any great comic clip.They have warped some parts of the playwright's plot to give us a fairly reasonable flow of giggles and an occasional guffaw about Mr. Lemmon and Juliet Millsthe tycoon and the plump British lasswho have come to Italy to reclaim the bodies of his father and her mother. And, they've switched the scene from Rome to Ischia, the sunny spa where it was shot in colors warm enough to enchant anyone enslaved to frozen winters and the workaday world.But a viewer is aware almost from the start that the seemingly proper deceased pair, killed in a car accident, were more than casual acquaintances. And it takes an awfully long time for the principals to discover that fact, do their filial duty and finally arrive at a similar, discreet, amorous understanding.There is enough red tape here to handcuff even as powerful a conglomerate king as Jack Lemmon, who thinks he'll be flying back to Baltimore, business, golf and his wife and kids in a jiffy. He handles it all in satisfyingly familiar, confused, frenetic style, despite lead coffins and ransom for the bodies snatched by a local vintner, who knows a good touch when he sees one. And there's a blackmailing photographer who also gums things up by being shot by his Sicilian girl friend.Of course, there's the wise, blond, decorative Miss Mills, whose weight worries don't keep her from getting him to take more than a moment to dine with wine and candlelight, indulge in a moonlight, nude dip and, eventually, a boudoir interlude.Above all, there's a fine job turned in by Clive Revill, as the suave, knowledgeable, carefree hotel manager, who's as helpful with cadavers as he is with lovers, bureaucrats, blackmailers and body snatchers."Italy is not a country," Miss Mills says ecstatically, "it's an emotion." But emotion wears thin fairly quickly in "Avanti!" despite its share of shtick, zany local color and flip cracks.

title: West Siders Score City on Housing
description: Neighborhood groups and leg islators, who are determined to insure an economic mix on the West Side, are reacting bitteriy to the city's failure to live up to an agreement that would limit to 30 per cent the number of lowincome residents in the majority of new apartment buildings in the West Side Ur ban Renewal Area.

Fisher, son of Mrs. Jack Fisher of Yonkers and the late Mr. Fisher. Rabbi Robert S. Widom performed the cere mony, assisted by Cantor Henry Weintraub.

To gether with Claudio Arrau, Artur Rubinstein, Vladimir Horowitz and Wilhelm Kem pff, he is one of today's most respected senior cus todians of the keyboard classics, and yesterday after noon in Philharmonic Hall he gave the sort of recital one hopes and expects from such a distinguished artist: three undisputed masterpieecs played with rare insight and integrity.

description: Mrs. Joan Lewisohn Simon and David G. Crowell were married here yesterday morn ing. Criminal Court Judge Ernst Rosenberger performed the ceremony at the bride's home.

title: 4 States, Stirred by Citizens' Groups, Are Cleaning Up Connectictut River
description: EASTHAMPTON, Mass., Dec. 17Encouraged by progress forced by Federal laws and citi zen agitation, optimistic reports are filtering out of the Con necticut River Valley of the reversal of a century of misuse and pollution.

title: The War's Urban Toll: Cities Are Now Slums
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 17The war damage in South Vietnam that is most noticeable and will take long est to repair is not the millions of bomb craters and defoliated acres of jungle, but the effect on citiesmost especially this city, the capital.

title: City's Medicaid Plan to Switch To Use of GenericName Drugs
description: Next spring New York City will start a program to use chug products sold under their generic names, instead of brandname products, for the 1.5 million people in the Medicard program. Drugs sold under generic names are cheaper, but not less effective, than brandname products.

title: Simpson Takes First Rushing Crown
description: Coach George Allen, a zealot when it comes to a winning attitude and momentum, used several of his secondline players in finishing out the Na tional Football League season yesterday, and Allen's Washing ton Redskins lost their second straight game, beaten by the Buffalo Bills, 2417. The lethar gic Redskins had clinched a division title and a playoff po sition two weeks ago.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: PRINCETON, Dec. 17The growth of regional ballet is one of those unpredictable but welcome phenomena that no one can adequately explain of understand. In the last 15 years, untroubled ballet schools all over the Country have decided to found their own companies, give seasons and willingly take on the headaches that make majorcompany admin istrators long for a simpler life.

title: Newsmen Robbed on Coast
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 17 (AP)Thieves broke into adja cent 18thfloor rooms at the Fairmont Hotel last night, tak ing cash and property belong ing to Wes Gallagher, general manager and president of The Associated Press, and Peng Ti, an official of Hsinhua, the Chi nese press agency, the police said.

title: A Designer Who Stays Away From Those Safe Fashions
description: Her boss loves her (since her first line was shown on Seventh Avenue in Septem ber, it has booked a million dollars worth of business. Retailers tend to thapsodize about her (the clothes she designs are as far from dowdy as they are from bi zarre).

title: Mayoral Aide in Newark Says He Took MissingJob Records
description: NEWARK, Dec. 17A box of records purportedly showing ir regularities in the federally fi nanced Public Employment Pro gram, missing since last week, was returned to authorities to night in the back room of a Springfield Avenue bar.

title: Theater: Children by Michael McGuire Opens
description: A woman is dying on a farm in the American Middle West. She is beautiful, the wife and favorite model of an artist. She has had children; she has had lovers. The two children and the most impor tant of her old loversa for mer student of the artist are gathered in the farmhouse for her death.

title: 3 Locomotives Lost in Sea
description: ST. JOHN'S, Newfoundland, Dec. 17 (Reuters)Three loco motivs were lost yesterday when they plunged overboard from an abandoned freighter being towed to port here. Capt. Tjerk Straatman of the tug SmitLloyd 103, which was towing the freighter Rumba, said in port today that the loco motives were three of eight lashed to the deck of the ship, which was abandoned in heavy seas late last week by her 18 man crew.

title: CITY FINDS HOMES FOR 130 CHILDREN
description: Foster or adoptive homes have been found for 130 re tarded, abused or abandoned children who have remained hospitalized unnecessarily be cause of the lack of therapeutic or residential facilities, the city's Health Services Adminis tration disclosed yesterday.

description: A new clash between State Welfare Inspector General George F. Berlinger and city welfare officials developed yes terday when the state chief Charged that more than 1,000 relief recipients, mostly narcot ics addicts, had been put on permanent welfare rolls last September without checking their eligibility.

title: ABANDONED MINE THREATENS TOWN
description: WHEELING, W. Va., Dec. 17 A hill of yellow mud leads to the mouth of the abandoned mine, where an old lantern, some logs and sticks lie in a pool of water turned copper color by the acid seeping from the Echo Mine.

title: Credit Markets
description: Intensifying pressure in the money market seems likely to dominate interestrate develop ments during the next two weeks, a period of seasonal slack for new bond offerings.

title: Is Film Deep Throat Obscene? Trial in Manhattan Opens Today
description: A nonjury trial to determine whether the film Deep Throat is obscene opens in Manhattan Criminal Court today, two days after a jury in Binghamton, N. Y., ruled that it was not.

title: Luba Lisa, 31, ActressSinger, Killed in Vermont Plane Crash
description: Luba Lisa, a television per sonality, was one of four per sons killed in the crash of a light airplane in a snowstorm Friday night near Colchester, Vt., according to local police. She was 31 years old.

title: ARTHUR BEANE
description: Arthur Beane, a teacher for 25 years and athletic director at the New Canaan (Conn.) Country Day School, died Sat urday in Center Sandwich, N. H. He was 59 years old and lived in New Canaan.

title: VATIGAN'S PAPER FOCUSES ON DEVIL
description: ROME, Dec. 17A twopage special section on the Devil in today's issue of the Vatican newspaper L'Osservatore Ro mano was interpreted as a re flection of deepening concern by Pope Paul VI over demonic aspects in the presentday world.

title: Patient Dolphin Fans Hold That Ticket Line
description: MIAMI, Dec. 17 (AP)  Several hundred fans stayed on line all night to purchase tickets this morning for the Miami Dolphins' Christmas Eve American Football Con ference playoff game against The Cleveland Browns.

title: Books of The Times
description: There are 34 stories here, and not one that I can believe in. Whenever you raise the question of John O'Hara's talent, there are always older men who get a faraway look in their eyes and say: Son, ho really knew what it was all about. Nobody could tell it the way O'Hara could, etc. I won der about these men. Do they defend them because these stories glamorize in some curious way their own uneventful youths? Or is it possible that in those days people were simply less aware of their behavior, less selfconsciousso that now they can't tell a true picture of their generations from a false one.

title: Camp Offers a Haven for 1,000 of Bowery's Homeless
description: CHESTER, N. Y.The first things visitors often notice at Camp La Guardia are the dozens of fat, dirty and friendly dogs sprawled around this home for 1,000 elderly alcoholics.

title: PhippstoPitts Clicks Twice for Scores
description: The Cleveland Browns did their part to win the American Football Conference Central Di vision title yesterday by finish ing off the New York Jets, 2610, before 45,084 persons in Shea Stadium.

title: NIXON APPOINTEE NAMED IN A SUIT
description: DALLAS, Dec. 17 (AP)  William P. Clements Jr., chosen by President Nixon to be No. 2 man at the Pentagon, is a de fendant in a civil suit charg ing a conspiracy to hide mil lions of dollars in alleged prof its from an Argentine oil deal.

title: Marchais Named Chief By French Communists
description: PARIS, Dec. 17 (Reuters) The French Communist party ended its 20th congress today by unanimously electing Georges Marchais, as secre tary general.

title: Archibald Protege Is Part of Arsenal Of U.S.C. Quintet
description: While Nate Archibald rested Saturday night from his hectic efforts to become the first National Basketball Association player to win the scoring and assist championships, his pro tg, Vic Kelly, one of the smallest players in college basketball, added to his repu tation.

title: Joanne Lehman Wed To John David Baer
description: PITTSBURGH, Dec. 17  Miss Joanne Lehman and John David Baer were mar tied here at noon today in the home of the bride's par ents, Mr. and Mrs. Alan George Lehman. Justice Thomas Pomeroy of the Pennsylvania Supreme Court, performed the ceremony.

title: Nancy Tepper Bride of Leonard M. Fisher
description: FALL RIVER, Mass., Dec. 17Miss Nancy Jean Tep per, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. A. Ira Tepper, was married here this afternoon to Leo nard Martin Fisher, son of Mr. and Mrs. Milton Fisher of Springfield. Rabbi Moishe Babin performed the cere mony in Temple BethEl. Cantor Israel Barzak, as sisted.

title: Cole Wins Rhodesia Golf
description: BULAWAYO, Rhodesia, Dec. 17 (AP)Bobby Cole of South Africa shot an eagle on the last hole for a oneunderpar 71 today and won the $14,000 Rhodesian Masters golf tourna ment by four strokes from Cobie Legrange.

title: DAMAGE IS HEAVY
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, Dec. 18North Viet nam accused the United States today of resuming the air war north of the 20th Parallel with a heavy raid around Haiphong.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Heroin Thefts Called a Setback

title: George Cukor Brings Graham Greene's 'Travels With My Aunt' to the Screen
description: The directorial career of George Cukor goes back to 1930 and now comprises 49 films. Of the important veteran Hollywood directors, only Hitchcock remains as active, or nearly as active, and perhaps no one has remained so intelligently, so decently in touch with the ongoing enterprise of commercial movie-making."Travels With My Aunt," the newest Cukor, opened yesterday at the Plaza Theater, and it is anything but a valedictory work. Indeed, it is specifically about the necessity of living through and beyond "the accumulation of memories" (a phrase from the movie), no matter how comfortably pious or wickedly romantic or falsely alluring they may be."Travels With My Aunt" takes its title, much of its dialogue, many of its situations and almost all its characters from a fine Graham Greene novel that, in the long run, it does not so closely resemble. The characters include Henry Rulling, a retiring London bank manager; his exuberant Aunt Augusta, well into her '70's, with passions modified but unextinguished; Zachary Wordsworth, Augusta's black and very loyal lover, and Tooley, an affectionate American hippie traveling east on the Orient Express.East is where everyone else is travelingto the aid of the kidnapped Mr. Visconti, the charming unspeakable love of Aunt Augusta's youth. Of Visconti we see very little, except in Aunt Augusta's memories and in the small parts of him (an amputated finger here, an ear there) that show up along the route.In type, the film is a comedy adventure-mystery, and ostensibly its aim is to save Mr. Visconti, while there is still some of him left. But its real aim is the revitalization of Henry, sunk deep into his dahlias and conventional middle age. This is achieved, but not so simply as you might imagine. And the great charm of "Travels With My Aunt" is the surprising emotional complexity it manages in terms of its light tone and its nutty, endlessly involved plotting.Such emotional complexity depends a good deal on richness of characterization and delicacy of human contact, and in this the film sometimes succeeds and Sometimes doesn't. Alec McCowen does marvelous things as Henry, a man of hopeful, untapped resources, and his scenes with Tooley (Cindy Williams, not the world's greatest actress) suggest exactly the quality of tender awe that seem the film's most viable feeling.Maggie Smith, playing a woman twice her age, seems to have surrounded her character rather than to have inhabited it. She is wonderfully gotten up and made upeven to the most refined shade of carrot-red dye in her hairand she is ;energetic enough for any five ordinary performers. But it is the energy of caricature rather than personality, and Aunt Augusta is sufficiently an original not to need any eccentricities added on.But the film is full of privileged moments, lucid, controlled and graceful, and any of them might serve to epitomize the style and the meaning of the valuable cinema of George Cukor.

title: Miss Roberta Sackett Bride of Robert Dillon
description: MANHASSET, L. I., Dec. 17 At Temple Judea of Man hasset tonight, Miss Roberta Sackett, a teacher in New York, was married to Robert W. Dillon, a fourthyear stu dent at the New York Medi cal College. The Rev. Dr. Robert Gordis performed the ceremony.

title: Drug Program Intended to Save Not One But Two Generations
description: I really didn't want my baby. I didn't want to take care of her. I used to stay up nights crying; I just felt my life had stopped. Actually, 22yearold Diane McDaniel's life as a drug addict with a daily compulsive hunger for heroin did not stop at all for six months after the birth of her daughter, Tamiko, now 2. I used more drugs then than I had in the previous twoandahalf years I was on drugs, Miss McDaniel recalled the other day.

title: HBomb Power Ahead?
description: Back in the 1950's, there were high hopes that an un limited supply of cheap, pollutionfree power might come from harnessing the thermonuclear reaction that makes possible the hydrogen bomb. The energy was to be obtained by fusion of atoms of heavy hydrogen deuterium and tritiumrather than by splitting uranium atoms as in conventional atomic plants of the sort that now exist here and elsewhere. But the early confidence weakened badly during the 1960's as the many problems involved proved to be more intractable than at first expected. Expectations that fusion power would be a significant energy source by the 1980's had to be de ferred to the 1990's and then to the 21st century.

title: CENSUS ESTIMATE AT CENTURY'S END CUT BY 20 MILLION
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17The Census Bureau issued a new, strikingly low, set of projections of future population size today, giving formal weight to the probability that the nation has entered its slowest period of population growth since the Depressin.

title: Too Big and Too Late
description: School construction in New York City has slavishly followed a pattern of too big and too late. The schools are too late being built and they are too big when they finally come off the assembly line.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: Leaders of the Newark Roman Catholic Archdiocese stated their support over the weekend for the nation's longest rent strike, in Newark.

title: TRUMAN DISPLAYS MORE ALERTNESS
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Dec. 17 Doctors treating former Pres ident Harry S. Truman said to day that he seemed slightly more alert than he was yester day but that he was still in very serious condition.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: FORT WORTHRow do you tell your friends they have been had? Find ing the enemy so embarrassed pre sents no problem. Just hurl ridicule at the poor boobs, fooled again. But how do you say to the respected leaders of your movement that on one particular but important issue, heav ily encrusted with emotion, they have been deceived?

description: CHESTER, N. Y.The first things visitors often notice at Camp La Guardia are the dozens of fat, dirty and friendly dogs sprawled around this home for 1,000 elderly alcoholics.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: NEWARK, Dec. 17An in creasing number of Portu guese have migrated to this city in recent years, adding to the stability and cosmo politan charm of the Iron bound section, a colorful, 910acre workingclass pock et here that has managed to resist corruption, riot and decay.

title: Miss Yu Bride Of a Physician
description: The marriage of Miss ChungJa Yu, a nurse on the staff of Trafalgar Hospital, to Dr. Cassim Mohammed Jad wat, director of the depart ment of anesthesiology at Mary Immaculate Hospital at the Catholic Medical Center of Brooklyn and Queens, took place here yesterday after noon.

title: Job Help for Veterans
description: U.S.O. means a show at a remote fire base in Viet nam. U.S.O. means a place to go offbase to write let ters, listen to records, get a hamburger. Through World War II, the Korean War, the Berlin crisis and now the conflict in Southeast Asia, U.S.O. has meant all this and more to those serving far from home. Now, after 31 years of providing for the recreation, welfare, and mo rale needs of men and women in uniform, U.S.O. extends its services to the returning veteran.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: It is with amazement that I have heard on our radio today about Mar garet Truman's statement in her new book that her father, President Tru man, had received a letterbomb, or more than one, from the Stern Group.

title: Tricycles Termed Unsafe In Study for Government
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (UPI) Standard tricycles are un stable and unsafe for children because poor design lets them roll over and pitch backward under normal use, according to an engineering research study made for the Government.

title: Flight to the City Adds to Haiti's Burdens
description: PORTAUPRINCE, Haiti, Dec. 15Haiti, badly underdevel oped and still thought of as a rural country, is experiencing major urban problems as pov ertystricken peasants flock to this capital.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
ASTRONAUT STEPS OUTSIDE APOLLO TO RETRIEVE FILM
description: HOUSTON, Dec. 17Like the barnstorming wing walkers of yore, Comdr. Ronald E. Evans took a floating walk outside the Apollo 17 space craft today as it sped away from the moon and toward earth.

title: Oilers on Top, 31
description: EDMONTON, Alberta, Dec. 17 (UPI)Rusty Patenaude's third period goal proved the winner in the Alberta Oilers 31 vic tory over the Ottawa Nationals tonight.

title: Car Salesman Slain
description: SANTA MONICA, Calif., Dec. 17 (UPI)An apparently dis gruntled owner of a used foreign car confronted the salesman who recently sold him the sedan and shot the man to death today in a small office near the showroom, the police reported. The victim was Rob ert T. Welch, 36 years old, of Playa del Rey.

title: Giants Win Finale; Playoffs Saturday
description: Professional football's reg ular schedule ended yester day as the Giants upset Dallas, 233, and the Jets lost to Cleveland, 2614.

title: N.A.A.C.P. May Picket Libeity Bowl
description: MEMPHIS, Dec. 17 (AP) Iowa State, seeking to end a fivegame streak without a vic tory, and Georgia Tech, beset with racial troubles, tangle to night in the. Liberty Bowl. Blacks have vowed to picket the game.

title: Pot, Legalization of, Conservative Division
description: It is easy to denigrate, any cause by the technique of putting it alongside other, nobler causes. Thus a decade or so back Mr. John Roche elegantly dis missed the fear of guilt by association as ranking, by his hierarchy of fears, between Fear No. 25 and Fear No. 27, the former being Mr. Roche's fear of college presidents, the latter his fear of being bitten to death by piranhas. The trouble with the technique is that it does not make room for act hoc pre occupations: for individuated concerns. Somewhere, somebody is being eaten by piranhas, or is worrying about that possibility. Somewhere, somebody less secure than Professor Roche actually worries about the disposition of his college president. Surely that is the point, namely that an obliging com munity should be willing to devote it self to Matters that do not rise to the status of eschatology. For instance, the crazy pot laws.

title: Nixon Said to Weigh Steps To Put Pressure on Hanoi
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 President Nixon is considering a number of diplomatic and military measures designed to put pressure on North Viet nam to reach an early cease fire agreement, wellplaced Ad ministration officials declared today.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: You published a retort to Marya Mannes' OpEd article on abortion that misrepresented the facts concerning adoption.

description: Elizabeth Susser, 10 years old, and her brothers, Andrew, 7 and Robbie, 5, added up their resources last week and sent (with some adult help) a total of $3.92 to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. All the Sussers live in HastingsonHudson, .N. Y.

title: TAMS WIN, 125 118, FROM COUGAR FIVE
description: MEMPHIS, Tenn., Dec. 17 (AP)The Memphis Tams, beaten in two previous games with the divisionleading Cou gars, raced to a 125118 victory over Carolina tonight.

title: Ralph Stanley Back In Bluegrass Style With Mountain Boys
description: Ralph Stanley is one of the greats of bluegrass music, and he doesn't come to New York that often. So his appearance yesterday afternoon at the New York University Law School, under the auspices of the Blue grass Club of New York, took on the nature of a special occasion.

title: XRays Set For Morris Of Dolphins
description: MIAMI, Dec. 17Limping stiffly on a right ankle dam aged in his prolonged but un successful attempt to gain 1,000 yards for the season, Eugene (Mercury) Morris of the Miami Dolphins disclosed today that Xrays will be taken as a precaution.

title: Astor Foundation Gives $775,000 More to Library
description: Mrs. Vincent Astor, as presi dent of the Vincent Astor Foun dation, announced yesterday a $775,000 grant to the research libraries of the New York Pub lic Library, thereby adding to the foundation's earlier $225, 000 grant and making a total of $1million for the year.

title: Green Light for Kadar
description: Hungary, in public, is steadfast behind the Soviet for eignpolicy line, but makes substantial departures from Kremlin orthodoxy on the economic front. Earlier this year Moscow was sharply critical of Janos Kadar's modest moves toward the kind of economic reforms decentralized management, incentives, market controls undertaken more than a decade ago by Yugoslavia.

title: Nixon Said to Weigh Steps To Put Pressure on Hanoi
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 President Nixon is considering a number of diplomatic and military measures designed to put pressure on North Viet nam to reach an early cease fire agreement, wellplaced Ad ministration officials declared today.

title: UGANDA TAKES OVER FOREIGN CONCERNS
description: KAMPALA, Uganda, Monday, Dec. 18 (AP)President Idi Amin anounced early this morning the takeover of all foreignowned tea plantations here, and eight of Uganda's biggest commercial concerns, seven of them British and one American.

title: Black Student Groups Demand Inquiry on Racism at Rutgers
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Dec. 17  Several black student groups at Rutgers College, an gered by allegedly racist inci dents on campus, have request ed an investigation of what they say is the continued function ing of institutional racism at Rutgers.

title: Giants Top Cowboys, 233; Snead Erases Tittle Mark
description: DALLAS, Dec. 17The New York Giants completed a win ning season on a high note to day, walloping Dallas, 233, for their eighth victory in 14 games.

title: NOW Accounts Stir Banking Officials
description: A revolution in banking may be brewing in Massachusetts, which well could have national repercussions.

title: Banker Shies at Some Glamour Issues
description: The trust departments of banks have the rcputation of buy ing and holding prominent growth stocks. But one banker who takes exception to this strategy is Charles F. O'Hay, senior vice president and director of investment research at Provident Na tional Barth in Philadelphia. Mr. O'Hay, 40, gained experience in Wall Street at a bank and two investment firms before going five years ago to the Philadelphia bank, which currently man ages $2.6billion in trust and pension accounts. His forecast of the stock market's action for 1973 also differs from the prevail nig view on Wall Street. Mr. O'Hay was interviewed last week by Vartanig G. Vartan of The New York Times.

title: MRS. J. A. BOGARDUS
description: Mrs. Elinor Strong Bogardus, widow of J. Arthur Bogardus, former chairman of the board of the Atlantic Mutual Insur ance Company, died Saturday in White Plains Hospital. She was 69 years old and lived at 8 Stonehouse Road, Scarsdale, N. Y.

title: Shock of 1971 Killings Has Led To Basic Change at San Quentin
description: TAMAL, Calif., Dec. 12 Almost 16 months have passed, but the impact of the killings here on Aug. 21, 1971, still hangs heavy over the complex of ugly aging buildings that make up San Quentin Prison.

title: Questions on Vietnam
description: Henry A. Kissinger's an nouncement that the Vietnam peace talks had failed to reach a just and fair agree ment has raised, many unanswered questions. An article attempting to answer some appears on Page 3.

title: MILLER DEBATES COAL EXECUTIVE
description: ITMANN, W. Va., Dec. 17 The presidentelect of the Unit ed Mine Workers union and the president of the nation's largest operator of underground coal mines held an impromptu de bate on life and death in the mines here today at the site of the latest mine disaster, which killed five men and burned three others yesterday.

title: Cooke, Forgoing Vietnam Trip, Says Mass for Ill Children Here
description: The patients in the pediatrics ward of a large East Side hos pital received a visit yester day from Cardinal Cooke, who celebrated a special mass, and a message of good cheer from the President of the United States.

title: Bomb Rips Argentine Hotel
description: PARANA, Argentina, Dec. 17 (Reuters)A bomb planted by Montoneros, urban guerrilla supporters of former President Juan D. Pern, last night de stroyed 14 rooms in the Inter national Hotel in this city 235 miles northwest of Buenos Aires, police sources said. Four hotel employes were seriously injured when they jumped from windows after an anonymous telephone caller had given warning of the imminent blast.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: There is a determined, alarming effort today by: Marshall Tito and hardline members of his party to reestablish state control over the uni versities of Yugoslavia, which have, since 1952, enjoyed a remarkable degree of autonomy.

title: L.I.R.R.'s Bright New Era Is in Peril
description: The Long Island Rail Road strike, now in its 19th day, has clouded over what even the most cautious people on the line were beginning to hail as a bright new era.

title: XRays Set For Morris Of Dolphins
Issue and Debate
description: One of the least under stood elements of the Nixon economic controls program, which was initiated Aug. 15, 1971, is a restriction on the profit margins of the nation's businesses.

title: Pope Voices Sadness Over Peace Impasse
description: ROME, Dec. 17Pope Paul VI voiced sadness and bitter ness today over the fact that peace is not yet mature in Indochina.

title: Clear skies Lend Brilliance to a Cold and Windy Weekend Here
description: High winds and low tem peratures in the New York area produced a weekend of unusually clear skies and in vigorating  if sometimes numbingweather.

title: 'Gilbert and Sullivan Ends Tour of U.S.
description: With gusto and abundant high spirits, The World of Gilbert and Sullivan came to Alice Tully Hall, the Saturday matinee and evening perform ances closing out the group's 55concert, 30state American tour. Of the great Gilbert and Sullivan operas, only The Sorcerer and Trial by Jury went unrepresented (though we did get a lively duet from Sul livan and Burnand's Cox and Box as a bonus), and the various solo and ensemble numbers were assembled in se quences that kept the pacing brisk, the balance good be tween familiar and compara tively rarefied material.

title: Youth Orchestra's 10th Season Opens With a Daring Program
description: In the few seasons he has been music director of the Youth Symphony Orchestra of New York, Isaiah Jackson has been nothing if not daring in his choice of works for the young instrumentalists to play. The orchestra opened its 10th season with a concert at Car negie Hall Saturday afternoon, and, as usual, the program con ceded nothing to the players' youth and inexperience.

title: A Haitian Festival Unfolds Here
description: The similarities between Hai tian and black American cul tures were shown in a Haitian Cultural Festival yesterday that took a musical trip through the cities and mountains of the black nation.

title: Hunter Five Tops Yeshiva; Haggins Stars for Winners
description: Ron Haggins led Hunter to a 6554 Knickerbocker con ference victory over Yeshiva University yesterday. Haggins grabbed 12 rebounds, and led Hunter with 11 points.

title: Hunter Five Tops Yeshiva; Haggins Stars for Winners
description: Ron Haggins led Hunter to a 6554 Knickerbocker Con ference victory over Yeshiva University yesterday. Haggins grabbed 12 rebounds, and led Hunter with 11 points.

description: The Long Island Rail Road strike, now in its 19th day, has clouded over what even the most cautious people on the line were beginning to hail as a bright new era.

title: Senator to Push for Funds To Assist Hemophiliacs
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (AP) Legislation to provide finan cial assistance for the estimated 100,000 hemophiliacs in the nation will be introduced in the next Congress by Senator Har rison A. Williams, Democrat of New Jersey.

title: A FARMERS' GROUP OUSTS DISSIDENTS
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Dec. 17 Though the American farmer is one of the world's great in dividualists, he tends to sub scribe to the theory that unity is strength when it comes to winning a fair return for hard labor under a hot sun.

title: U.S. Blamed for Impasse
description: HANOI, North Vietnam, Mon day, Dec. 18 (Agence France Presse)  The official North Vietnamese party, newspaper to day blamed Washington for failure of the private talks in Paris between the United States and North Vietnam.

title: Red Wings Triumph, 64
description: DETROIT, Dec. 17 (AP) Mickey Redmond tallying one goal and setting up three others, led the Detroit Red Wings to a 64 victory over the Minnesota North Stars to night.

title: Jazz: A Club Reappears
description: The steady resurgence of jazz in New York has taken another step with the reopen ing of one of the city's more celebrated jazz rooms of the nineteenfifties and early six ties, the Five Spot. It is now called Two Saints, a name derived from its address, 2 St. Mark's Place, but the room is essentially the same as it was when Joe and Iggy Termini, who ran the Five Spot, gave up jazz five years ago and closed its doors to devote themselves to a pizza stand and a lunch counter that adjoined the club.

title: People and Business
description: The General Electric Com pany made it official yester day with the announcement that Reginald H. Jones had become chairman and chief executive officer. Ever since he was named president in June, Mr. Jones, who is 55 years old, was expected to succeed to the top post up on the resignation of Fred J. Borch.

title: Decision Was Hedged
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18  The Federal Reserve's Open Market Committee voted in September to try to slow the rapid growth of the nation's money supply and other mone tary aggregates, but it hedged its decision with several con ditions.

title: Andrea L. Boissy Is Bride in Florida
description: WINTER PARK, Fla., Dec. 18Miss Andrea Lane Boissy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alphonse N. Boissy Jr. of Orlando, formerly of Green wich, Conn., was married here this evening to Robert Randolph Lyon Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Lyon of Winter Park.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: TRENTON, Dec. 18 (AP) A former State Senate ma jority leader, John A. Wad dington of Salem, has an nounced his candidacy for the Democratic nomination for Governor.

title: High Court to Rule on the Impact Of Freight Costs on Environment
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18  The Supreme Court agreed to day to decide whether the In terstate Commerce Commis sion must consider potential injury to the environment be fore it raises railroad freight rates.

title: Soviet to Let Jewish Writer Leave Without Paying Tax
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 18 (AP)  Viktor Perelman, a Soviet Jew ish journalist whose efforts to leave for Israel were supported by Senator Hubert H. Hum phrey here earlier this month, was informed today that he could depart without paying an education tax.

title: Cambodian Air Stricks Reported
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Dec. 18 (Reuters)Cambodian planes have bombed suspected concentrations of Vietnamese Communist troops within 16 miles of Phnom Penh, a mili tary command spokesman said today. He said T28, fighter bombers struck last night and this morning, mainly against targets 12 miles northeast of the capital.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: TRENTON, Dec. 18  The New Jersey Supreme Court ruled today that liedetector tests could be admitted as evidence in a criminal trial provided that the defendant and the prosecution unequivo cally and voluntarily agree to its use.

title: Britain Adds $36Million for Ulster Jobs
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Dec. 18The British Goyern ment initiated a $36Million ec onomic aid plan today to help cut Northern Ireland's unem ployment rate, currently run ning at 7.2 per cent, or twice the national average of the United Kingdom.

title: 2 ARCHITECT FIRMS AGREE ON MERGER
description: Kahn & Jacobs, one of the city's oldest architectural firms, has agreed to merge with Hell muth, Obata & Kassabaum, a St. Louisbased architectural firm, officials of the two com panies announced yesterday.

title: White House Drafts Tough Rules On Contents of TV Programing
description: The White House has drafted tough new legislation that would hold individual television stations accountable, at the risk of losing their licenses, for the content of all network material they broadcast, including news, entertainment programs and ad vertisements.

title: Move Was Anticipated
description: Moody's, Investors Service yesterday raised its evaluation of New York City's credit by one notch to A from Baa1.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: BUXTON, N.C.A stiff northerly wind whined across the vast, shallow reaches of Pamlico Sound, churning up two and three foot waves, as we drove south along North Carolina's Outer Banks toward Buxton and Cape Hatteras.

title: PHONE COMPANY SEEKS INCREASES OF $306MILLION
description: The New York Telephone Company asked the State Pub lic Service Commission yester day to authorize $306million a year in new revenues.

title: Monticello and OTB Gear for Snowfall and Windfall
description: MONTICELLO, N. Y., Dec. 18Winter carnival or freak scene?

title: GERHARD KUNTSCHER, DEVISED BONE PEGS
description: GLUCKSBURG, West Ger many, Dec. 18 (AgenceFrance Presse)  Dr. Gerhard Knt scher, who developed osteosyn thesis, died yesterday of a heart attack here. His age was 72.

title: ELDERLY FACE LOSS OF RENT SUBSIDIES
description: Sorne 2,000 to 3,000 elderly people in publicly aided hous ing here stand to lose six months of retroactive rent sub sidies because their housing companies have not par ticipated in a program that would grant them, the city said yesterday.

title: U.S.INACTIOR SEEN ON MINORITY JOBS
