description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 The Nixon. Administration has reportedly all but abandoned efforts to force Federal con tractors to hire more blacks, other minoritygroup workers and women.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Your recent news story on cotton pesticides stirred up some memories. In 1956 I was an employe of the United States Department of Agriculture in Tucson, Ariz., assigned to a pollina tion project on eighty acres of cotton.

title: Issues in the L.I.R.R. Dispute
description: PARTICIPANTSThe Long Island Rail Road and 12 unions representing 5,000 carmen, teamsters, clerks, elec trical workers, sheet metal workers and other nonoperating employes, as well as some supervisors.

title: When I Was Younger
description: I cherish the dreams of my child hood the eager, passionate dreams which once burned in fiery ardor and now are snuffed out. I dreamed of being a teenager, of rocking and roll ing like the Beatles of old, and of twisting like Chubby Checker. Full of sixthgrade fervor, I dreamed of some day being able to vote and was pre pared to march for peace and freedom. It is too late however: the Beatles have disbanded, Chubby Checker is older and has developed a bit of paunch, and today's youth now cheer for mountebanks and demagogues.

title: Jose RolzBennett Dies at 54; Former U.N. Under Secretary
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 18Jos RolzBennett, a former Guatemalan diplomat and United Nations UnderSec retary, died this morning in Guatemala City, Mr. RolzBen nett, who was 54 years old, had left the international staff in January, 1971, for reasons of health.

title: Peace Is Possible, Pope Tells Leaders
description: ROME, Dec. 18  Pope Paul VI, in a message to world lead ers, said today that peace is possible, and an international duty, and called for a stronger United Nations as mankind's best guarantee against war.

title: No Youth Center in Spuyten Duyvil, So Youngsters Construct Their Own
description: It is hardly the most ele gant of Buckminster Fuller's brainchildren, but the young people of Spuyten Duyvil have their own center now, and they built it themselves.

title: G.M. Chief Asks U.S. to Alter Controls
description: DETROIT, Dec. 18  Rich ard C. Gerstenberg, chairman of the General Motors Corpor ation, said today that there was now an urgent need to begin Phase Three of the wage price control program as a wellconceived transition to an early and orderly termination of control and a return to the discipline of the competitive market.

title: Boyle Quits a Month Early, to Get $50,000 Pension
description: W. A. Boyle, who was de feated for reelection as presi dent of the United Mine Workers Union, resigned here yesterday at a meeting of the union exec utive board at the Roosevelt Hotel.

title: The Dance
description: Two choices always face the young choreographer to develop his work within the confines of a traditional esthetic or to expand the ar tistic limits of the discipline. Over the weekend, Laura Dean and Dance Company tried the latter and Manuel Alum's Dance Company stuck with the former  to show how it could be done both ways.

title: White House Drafts Tough Rules On Contents of TV Programing
description: The White House has drafted tough new legislation that would hold individual television stations accountable, at the risk of losing their licenses, for the content of all network material they broadcast, including news, entertainment programs and ad vertisements.

title: Virginia Tech Tops Ohio State
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 18 (UPI)Virginia Tech, paced by Allan Bristow, held off Ohio State's late surge tonight for a 6762 victory. It was the fourth victory in five games for the Gobblers, while the Buckeyes, struggling to gain their expect ed form, are now 33.

title: Red Cross Names Swede To Head Indochina Relief
description: GENEVA, Dec. 18Olof Stroh, secretary general of the Swedish Red Cross, will have overall charge of the relief operations that the interna tional Red Cross is planning across Indochina should a cease fire end military operations, it was announced today.

title: ALBERT FLEGENHEIMER
description: Albert Flegenheimer, a beet sugar industrialist, who retired several years ago as chairman of the Michigan Sugar Com pany of Saginaw, died Saturday in Doctors Hospital. He was 82 years old and lived at 300 Cen tral Park West.

title: L.I. Migrant Farm Workers, Backed by Union, Fighting Evictionl
description: RIVERHEAD, L.I., Dec. 18 The I. M. Young Company, the second largest potato process ing concern in the East, is at tempting to evict 38 people who are taking part in what is believed to be the first mi grant farm workers' strike on Long Island.

title: CONTRACT AWARD
description: The National Steel and Ship building Company said yester day that it had received a $51.5million Navy contract for the construction of a fleet oiler. The company is jointly owned by the Kaiser Industries Corpo ration and MorrisonKnudsen, Inc.

title: MinorityHiring Gains
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (UPI) Federal employment of mi noritygroup members was on the increase in a 12month pe riod before President Nixon ordered the abolishment of ra cial hiring quotas, the Govern ment reported today.

title: Bank in Queens Held Up
description: Three armed men wearing ski masks held up a St. Albans Queens, bank yesterday and escaped with $9,000 the police reported. The three entered the National Bank of North Ameri ca branch at 20502, Linden Boulevard shortly after 2:30 P.M. and drew pistols. One stood at the door, preventing anyone from leaving, a second held a gun to the bank guard's head, and the third vaulted the counter and scooped up the money front four cash drawers.

title: B'NAI B'RITH ADOPTS $18MILLION BUDGET
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18The board of governors of B'nai B'rith, concluding its annual meeting here, adopted today an $18.77million budget for B'nai B'rith programs in 1973, a 6 per cent increase over the pres ent year and the largest in the 129year history of the Jewish service organization.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: TRENTON, Dec. 18The State Banking Department warned New Jersey financial institutions today that they had no business asking prospective home buyers if they practiced birth control when deciding whether to grant couples a mortgage loan.

title: Inmates Donate Holiday Meal
description: WALPOLE, Mass., Dec. 18 (AP)More than 400 prisoners at the Walpole State Prison have pledged to go without Christmas dinner so that the food may be distributed to the needy, elderly and the sick, according to Ann Brandon of the Massachusetts Lawyers Guild.

title: Equity Financing
description: A rights offering of 760,926 Class A common shares by the Florida Telephone Corporation has been filed with the Securities and Exchange Com mission. The utility was offering shareholders the right to purchase one additional share for each seven shares held at the close of business of Jan. 24. The underwriters were led by Kidder Peabody & Co.

title: PRINTER HARD HIT BY LIFE'S CLOSING
description: OLD SAYBROOK. Conn., Dec 18The demise of Life maga zine has struck hard at the R. R. Donnelley & Sons plant here, where the magazine has been printed and bound and mailed to subscribers in the eastern part of the United States for a dozen years.

title: Communists Hint Bombing May Bring Breakoff in Paris Talks
description: PARIS, Dec. 18The Viet namese Communist delegations indicated tonight that remain ing private contacts with the Americans in Paris may be broken off now, that bombing of the North has resumed.

title: White House Disputes a Report Of Washington Post Exclusion
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18The White House and The Wash ington Post were arguing today about the significance of a Post reporter's being excluded from three social events during the weekend.

title: OBSERVER
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18  News item: More newsmen will be going to ?? soon as government prosecutors take advantage of new power given them by the courts to command more cooperation from the American press.

title: Thai King Appoints Marshal Premier, Assembly Meets
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Dec. 18 (Reuters)  King Phumiphol Aduldet tonight appointed Field Marshal Thanom Kittikachorn as Thailand's new Premier.

title: J. HENRY WENDT
description: MONTCLAIR, N. J., Dec. 18 J. Henry Wendt, a retired district financial manager for the Graybar Electric Company in New York, died today after a heart attack in Mountainside Hospital. He was 70 years old and lived at 415 Claremont Avenue.

title: APOLLO ON COURSE FOR SPLASHDOWN IN PACIFIC TODAY
description: HOUSTON, Tuesday, Dec. 19 The Apollo 17 astronauts sped closer to the earth today, on course and ready for their scheduled splashdown this afternoon at 2:24 P.M., Eastern standard time.

title: John MayaII Wins Ovation for Jazz Close to Its Roots
description: Ovations come cheap in pop ular music; their frequency is enough to dampen one's ves tigial faith in esthetic populism But the ovation for John May all and his latest group Sunday night (or actually around 2:30 yesterday morning) at Carnegie Hall was deserved indeed.

title: Pennsy Will Open Station At Mt. Vernon Tomorrow
description: A new consolidated Mount Vernon station will replace the Prospect Avenue and Co lumbus Avenue stations of Penn Central's New Haven line tomorrow.

title: Cambodian Air Strikes Reported
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Dec. 18 (Reuters)Cambodian planes have bombed suspected concentrations of Vietnainese Communist troops within 16 miles of Phnom Penh, a mili tary command spokesman Said today. He said T28 fighter bombers struck last night and this morning, mainly against targets 12 miles northeast of the capital.

title: Bombs Away
description: The best hope for peace in Indochina since 1954 hes been severely shaken by a hail of American bombs on Haiphong and the outskirts of Hanoi in a turn from negotiation once again to confrontation. Whatever else the resumed bombing of North Vietnam above the 20th Parallel may accomplish, it is not likely to hasten and could indefinitely postponethe just and fair agreement that Henry Kissinger has said is the Presi dent's objective.

title: DRIMMER BID FAILS, FIRST SURETY SAYS
description: BURBANK, Calif, Dec. 18 (UPI)The First S rety Corpo ration said today the Delaware Chancery Court, had denied a petition by Horld F. Drimmer of New York to compel First Surety to sell one million shares of its voting preferred stock at $1 a share.

title: Sports of The Times
description: Vince Lombardi didn't say it first, but he gave such a ring of authority to everything he said that most of his observations sounded as though they were pronouncements from on high. Hence listeners nodded sagely when he de clared, Football is an emotional game.

title: Move Was Anticipated
description: Moody's Investors Service yesterday raised its evaluation of New York. City's credit by one notch to A from Baa1.

title: U.S. Production of Steel Declines 0.3% in Week
description: Production of steel in the week ended Saturday totaled 2,721,000 tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute re ported yesterday.

title: MRS. PHILIP BOYER
description: Mrs. Josephine Bond Flagg Boyer, widow of Philip Boyer, a banker and stockbroker, died yesterday in Ossining, N.Y. She was 85 years old.

title: Street Calls Stock Reaction Emotional
description: Wall Street reacted yester day with words of caution in response to the disclosure of breakdown in the Vietnam peace talks and the subsequent selloff in the stock market.

title: B52's Pound Hanoi Area 9 Miles From City Center
description: HANOI, North Vietnam, Tuesday, Dec. 19  American B52's bombed the northeast suburbs of Hanoi last night for the first time while fighter bombers carried out an all night raidthe heaviest and longest yetagainst the city, it was announced.

title: A NEW TARGET LIST
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 The Nixon Administratiod in nounced a resumption of full scale bombing and mining of North Vietnam today, and the White House warned that Such raids will continue until such time as a settlement is arrifed at.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, Dec. 18 New Brunswick High School was closed at 9 A.M. today as a result of a protest by 300 black students over the suspen sion of a black English teacher.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Getting in and out of New York by car has long since become a re fined form of torture. In recent years the difficulties have extended well be yond the threehour rush hour to most of the day because of the cur tailing of available lanes on major access highways due to repairs and services of all types.

title: PHONE COMPANY SEEKS INCREASES OF $306MILLION
description: The New York Telephone Company asked the State Pub lic Service Commission yester day to authorize $306million a year in new revenues.

title: Police Say French Connectio Heroin Was Overstated by 15 Pounds in 1962
description: A discrepancy of 15 pounds between the amount of heroin reported seized by detectives in the famous French Connec tion case of 1962 and the amount then impounded for safekeeping came to light yes terday.

title: Couple in StolenArt Case Get Writ Against Vergari
description: WHITE PLAINS, Dec. 18A couple from Rye, N. Y., today obtained a court order requir ing District Attorney Carl A. Vergari of Westchester County to show why he should not be forced to prosecute two men who arranged the return last week of $600,000, worth of stolen art works.

title: About Pro Football
description: Mercury Morris's sore ankle will be all right and the Miami Dolphins' medical staff decided to forego an Xray. The Pittsburgh Steel ers were getting an obscure reserve, Al Young, ready to take the place of Frank Lewis at wide receiver. Lewis has a broken collar bone. Jack Pardee and Larry Brown, held out of Washington's last game, were expected to be running hard at the Redskin practice today.

title: Deception or Naivete?
description: By their own wards, President Nixon and Mr. Kissin ger were either deceptive or naive in their preelection assurances to the American people about the imminence of peace in Vietnam. This is the sorry conclusion from the White House negotiator's remarkable briefing last Saturday.

title: YOUTHS HELPING DEFEND ELLSBERG
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 18  It reminds one of those hastily put together offices of the Mc Carthy and McGovern cam paigns. But here the young workers in blue jeans are not soliciting votes; they are study ing the Pentagon papers.

title: People in Sports: Auburn Hurt
description: Randy Walls, a sophomore quarterback who led Auburn to nine victories in 10 games with his passing and running, will not play in the Gator Bowl against Colorado on Dec. 30.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: It is with the greatest outrage that I read the Nov. 28 OpEd article The Unknown Soldiers by Robert B. John son Jr. It is hard to remain silent in the face of such unfairness. The When did you stop beating your wife? tone of the article is a personal insult to me as a military man.

title: EDMUND FAIRCHILD
description: NEWPORT BEACH, Calif., Dec. 18 (AP)Edmund Fair child, former Midwest director of Fairchild Publications, Inc., of New York, died here, Thurs day. He was 73 years old.

title: Issue and Debate
description: The dispute that flared into the open earlier this fall in Brooklyn's Community School District 18 over the admis sion of a group of black and Puerto Rican children from a Brownsville housing project has now developed into a major controversy over junior high school zoning in the district.

title: EXM'GOVERN AIDE FILES FOR BACK PAY
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (UPI) A former aide to Senator George McGovern said today that he and two other persons had filed formal complaints for alleged nonpayment of salaries during the Presidential cam paign.

title: Mrs. Leonard Lemberger, 47; Led A.S.P.C.A. Publications
description: Mrs. Janice Paprin Lember ger, publications editor of the American. Society for the Pre vention of Cruelty to Animals, died Sunday at the Long Island Jewish Medical Center in New Hyde Park, after a long illness. She was 47 years old and lived at 13701 83d Avenue, Kew Gardens, Queens.

title: A Walter Kissinger Enterprise Competes for Soviet Contract
description: Walter B. Kissinger, 48year old brother of Henry A. Kis singer, the President's adviser on national security affairs, may be on the verge of an international coup of his own.

title: Undersea Poseidon Fired
description: CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Dec. 18 (AP)The Navy nuclear submarine Lewis & Clark fired a Poseidon rocket today while cruising submerged about 30 miles off Cape Kennedy.

title: Downgrading the U.N.
description: The above title appeared over an editorial on this page last week, commenting on President Nixon's removal of George Bush as United States Ambassador to the United Nations in order to make him Chairman of the Republi can National Committee. We repeat it with sorrow, as a headline comment on Mr. Nixon's nomination of John A. Scali to replace Mr. Bush at Turtle Bay.

title: Advertising:
description: The next company presi dent to become the star of a television commercial will be Fredirck C. Ross of the B. F. Goodrich Tire Company. That's Goodrich, not Good year, and if you can just re member that difference you'll make Mr. Ross very happy.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: With his holier  than  thou, peda gogical attitude and his flippant ref erences to Aristotle and Verlaine, F. R. Buckley tried in his recent OpEd article, The Second Generation, to charm his readrs into believing the myth that has been created about the youth movement and flung in its face from its ineeption to the present: namely that it is dead.

title: Notes on People
description: Chancellor Willy Brandt of West Germany celebrated his 59th birthday in Bonn. Help ing Mr. Brandt celebrate were the Dilsseldorf Male Choir and Vice Chancellor Walter Scheel. With a touch of humor, Mr. Scheel gave Mr. Brandt a coin minted during the 19year joint rule in the 17th century of Dukes Ru dolf August and Anton Ulrich. The coin bore the motto Duobus Fulcris Secu rius, which can he trans lated to It is surer to rule on the basis of two. Mr. Scheel also joined the choir as it sang When the Lilacs Blossom Again for Mr. Brandt. The gift from the head of Mr. Brandt's politi cal opposition, Rainer Barzel, seemed simpler: 59 roses.

title: DEL FORNO DISPLAYS GUITAR PROFICIENCY
description: Anton Del Forno, a native of New Jersey and a recent grad uate of the Mannes College of Music, is a classical guitarist of accomplishment, even though the first half of his Carnegie Recital Hall program Sunday night had its uncertain mo ments.

title: Boycotts at 3 Brooklyn Schools Called Off and Pupils Go Back
description: Boycotts at three elementary schools in Brooklyn's Browns ville section have ended and attendance is returning to nor mal, officials in Community School District 23 said yester day.

title: U.S. Jets Hit Hanoi Area In 9 Waves Through Night
description: HANOI, North Vietnam, Tues day, Dec. 19  The Hanoi re gion was attacked by nine waves of United States bombers during the night.

title: WILLIAM KORN
description: William Korn, president of the J. H. Taylor Construction Company and the J. H. Taylor Management Corporation, 31 Union Square, died yesterday in his home at 875 Park Avenue. His age was 88.

title: 3 Seized in Subway Deaths Of Boy, 13, in Coney island
description: Three youths were arrested and charged with homicide in the death of a. 13yearold Brooklyn boy who was killed by a subway train in the Coney Island section last Thursday, the police reported. The death previously had been reported as an accident.

title: AUSTRALIAN CABINET CHOSEN BY WHITLAM
description: CANBERRA, Australia, Dec. 18 (Reuters)  Gough Whitlam, the new Prime Minister, named his Cabinet tonight.

title: BROOKLYN MAN DIES IN APARTMENT FIRE
description: A 69yearold Brooklyn man died and his wife seriously in jured last night when fire swept through the bedroom and living room of their apartment in an 8family tenement at 250 Keap Street in the Williamsburg section.

title: New Talks Planned in L.I.R.R. Strike
description: Both sides in the Long Is land Rail Road strike, now in its 20th day, reviewed their positions yesterday in prepa ration for a resumption of joint talks later this week.

title: WASTE OF MILLIONS IN RELIEF CHARGED
description: State Welfare Inspector General George F. Berlinger charged yesterday that the city's Human Resources Ad ministration was wasting more than $404million a year by de lays in removing ineligibles from welfare rolls and by lax ity in the way it made rent security deposits.

title: JewishChristian Relations Are Theme of Geneva Talks
description: GENEVA, Dec. 18  Jewish and Christian leaders agreed at a fourday meeting here to con tinue to consult in an effort to to define and remove hin drances to understanding, the World Council of Churches an nounced today.

title: PRICES TO INCREASE ON POLYESTER YARN
description: Hoechst Fibers, Inc., a sub sidiary of the American Hoechst Corporation, an nounced yesterday that It would raise prices on its poly ester filament yarns, effective Jan. 1.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Morales Wins at Garden
description: Pedro Morales pinned Ray Stevens in their heavyweight wrestling exhibition before a crowd of 20,906 last night at Madison Square Garden.

title: Haig Arrives in Saigon For Talks With Thies
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday Dec. 19 (Reuters) President Nixon's deputy na tionalsecurity adviser, Gen. Aleicaridei M. Haig Jr., ar rived in Saigon today for talks with President Nguyen Van Thieu, a United States Embassy spokesman reported.

title: Raids Termed Heaviest
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, Dec. 19 (AP)  Hun dredsof United States war planes, including B52 heavy bombers, resumed attacks last night above the 20th Parallel of North Vietnam. United States officials said the planes made the heaviest raids of the war against the Hanoi  Haiphong area.

title: AMEX AND OTC SHOW DECLINES
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthe counter market closed sharply lower yesterday as trading de clined.

title: Property Tax Reform Enthusiasm Lags
description: Enthusiasm for propertytax reform in the metropolitan area's suburbs has turned to confusion and doubt in the last few months as advocates of re form have begun to move be yond defining the problem to suggesting solutions.

title: 1734 Violin Given Israel by Szeryng
description: Israel has all kinds of Phantom jets and tanks but it struck me last summer in Jerusalem that the people who have given the world the greatest number of great fiddlers didn't possess a sin gle important musical instru ment for the benefit of its gifted sons, Henryk Szeryng said the other day, shaking his head in disbelief.

title: Kings Top Blazers, 11395; Archibald Scores 30 Points
description: KANSAS CITY, Dec. 18 (AP)  Nate Archibald scored 30 points and had 15 assists to night as the Kansas City Omaha Kings overpowered the Portland Trail Blazers 11395, in the National Basketball As sociation game.

title: Third Day of Heavy righting Is Reported Around Quang Tri City
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, Dec. 19 (AP) Heavy fighting was reported yesterday for the third day in the north ernmost part of SOuth. Vietnam near Quang Tri city.

title: Red Cross Names Swede To Head Indochina Relief
description: GENEVA, Dec. 18Oiof Stroh, secretary general of the Swedish Red Cross, will have overall charge of the relief operations that the interna tional Red Cross is planning across Indochina should a cease fire end military operations, it was announced today.

title: New Disclosure Rules Proposed by the S.E.C.
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18  The Securities and Exchange Commission proposed today major new disclosure require ments for corporate earnings reports, affecting accounting policies used and reporting of Federal taxes.

title: Shakeups Are Part of Drive to Streamline H.E.W.
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18  Elliot L. Richardson, the Sec retary of Health, Education and Welfare, has chosen for a Christmas card this season what might be regarded as one official's view of the Federal bureaucracy's most troubled de partment.

title: RISE IN COST SEEN FOR RAIL CORRIDOR
description: Transportation Secretary John A. Volpe said yesterday that a yearold blueprint for easing Northeast Corridor travel problems with vastly improved highspeed train service would cost about 40 per cent above the original $500million esti mate.

title: PLEA BACKS YOUTH JAILED FOR DRUGS
description: Pleashave been addressed to Governoe Rockefeller for the release by Christmas of Jef frey Smith, who was sentenced in the summer of 1969 to 7 to 15 years in prison for two half ounce sales of marijuana. The pleas come from a committee of legislators, Public officials and lawyers.

title: Moscow Lowers Priority On Goods for Consumers
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 18The Soviet leadership today an nounced a dramatic reordering of economic priorities at the expense of the consumer after a serious crop failure this year. An economic plan for 1973, presented to the Su preine Soviet, or parliament, called for a sharp cutback in the rate of growth of con sumer goods production, re versing a trend of recent years.

title: U.S. Says Departure of 300 Leaves 24,900 in Vietnam
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 18 (Reuters)  American troops strength in Vietnam dropped by 300 men last week to 24,900, the United States Command re ported today. A command spokeman said that the depart ing troops were soldiers and air men.

title: A NEW TARGET LIST
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18  The Nixon Administration an nounced a resumption of full schle bombing and mining of North Vietnam today, and the White House warned that such raids will continue until such time as a settlement is arrived at.

title: State Job Curbs on Outsiders Spur Conflict in India
description: VIJAYAVADA, India, Dec. 13 Venkeni Ramaiah, a local law yer, sat on the balcony of his twostory house in the main bazaar in this city in the south east watching the procession below.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: NEWARK, Dec. 18 Two leaders of the threeyearold publichousing rent strike here pleaded guilty today to con tempt of court charges and heard a judge accuse them of trying to become martyrs.

title: ARMY SAYS DRUG USE INCREASES IN EUROPE
description: HEIDELBERG, West Ger many, Dec. 18 (AP)The Unit ed States Army's European commander issued statistics to day that showed a sharp in crease over last year in the number of soldiers found to be using drugs.

title: Foe Said to Attack In Laos
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Dec. 18 (Reuters)  United States sources here reported today that North Vietnamese forces staged a rocket and infantry attack on the southern Laotian provincial capital of Saravane yesterday. But, they said, the attack was repulsed. No casu alty figures were available.

title: Jersey Central Commuter Runs To End Unless State Pays More.
description: NEWARK, Dec. 18  Federal Judge Anthony T. Augelli gave the Jersey Central Railroad per mission today td eliminate pas senger service after Jan. 21 on its Jersey Shore and Mairi line if the state did not increase its aid substantially.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, Dec. 19 (AP)  Hun dreds of United States war planes, including B52 heavy bombers, resumed attacks last night above the 20th Parallel of North Vietnam. United States officials said the planes made the heaviest raids of the war against the Hanoi  Haiphong area.

title: Yugoslav Political Prisoners Listed at 101 by Prosecutor
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 18 (Reuters)One hundred and one Yugoslays are still being detained after having, been de prived of liberty in the last 10 weeks on suspicion of commit ting a political dereliction or excess, the Yugoslav public prosecutor, Panta Marina, said in an interview published to day.

title: MRS. SAMUEL GATTEGNO
description: YONKERS, Dec. 18Mrs. Dorothy Berkowitz Gattegno, former president of the Bronx Municipal Hospital Auxiliaries and the widow of Dr. Samuel Gattegno, a dentist and pro fessor of dentistry at Colum bia University died today while being taken from her home, 257 Devoe Avenue, to Lawrence Hospital. She was 72 years old.

title: Manila Reports Accord With Moslem Dissidents
description: MANILA, Dec. 18 (AP)  Brig. Gen Guillermo Pecache, deputy chief of staff for home defense, told newsmen today that a peaceful settlement had been reached between Moslem dissidents in the southern Phil ippines and the armed forces.

title: WORLDWIDE CODE ON INVESTING SET
description: PARIS, Dec. 18The Inter national Chamber of Commerce an organization with 10,000 members in 43 countries, has just come out with an interna tional code of investment con duct that is designed to promote confidence between investors and governments.

title: Retarded, Forgotten
description: Over a span of almost thirty years as a New York policeman and Con gressman, I recall the sight of a single encounter above all others. It wasn't a dramatic shootout with a hardened criminal, or a meeting with a President of the United States, or the witnessing of a historic groundswell for human liberty In Northern Irelandnone of the things that might be expected.

title: TRENTON WARNS FINANCIAL GROUPS
description: TRENTON, Dec. 18The State Banking Department warned New Jersey financial institutions today that they had no business asking prospective home buyers if they practiced birth control when deciding whether to grant couples a mortgage loan.

title: School Aide Named
description: CENTRAL FALLS, R.I., Dec. 18 (AP)Robert C. Courte manche, superintendent and di rector of schools for the Epis copal Diocese of Long Island, has been named superinten dent of schools here, according to a spokesman for a com mittee seeking to fill that post.

title: City Begins Regular Medical Checks on 800 Animals
description: The city began making regular house calls yesterday to check on the health of the 800 mammals, birds and rep tiles in the three municipally owned zoos. The visits are being made by pathlogists from the New York Medical College.

title: Market Place: Pan Am Offers   An Explanation
description: The anxiety over the fu ture of Pan American World Airways apparently was tem pered a bit at a packed due diligence meeting held in the auditorium at Lehman Broth ers headquarters yesterday.

title: Foe Said to Attack In Laos
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Dec. 18 (Reuters)  United States sources here reported today that North Vietnamese forces staged a rocket and infantry attack on the southern Laotian provincial capital of Saravane yesterday. But, they said, the attack was repulsed. No casu alty figures were available.

title: Haig Arrives in Saigon For Talks With Thieu
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, Dec. 19 (Reuters) President Nixon's deputy na tionalsecurity adviser, Gen. Alexander M. Haig Jr., ar rived in Saigon today for talks with President Nguyen Van Thieu, a United States Embassy spokesman reported.

title: TopLevel Action Asked On SingleRoom Menace
description: Community organizations representing Manhattan's West Side, from lower Manhattan to Morningside Heights, unani mously adopted last night a resolution calling for a task force of top city officials to deal witnthe problem of single roomoccupancy facilities and their adverse effects on neigh borhoods.

title: HomeConstruction Rate Stayed High in November
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (Reu ters)  The pace of new home construction remained at a high level in November. Assistant Commerce Secretary Harold Passer said today that housing starts for the full year would total about 2.4 million, 15 per cent higher than last year.

title: 12 INMATES NAMED IN ATTICA CHARGES
description: WARSAW, N. Y., Dec. 18 Twelve convicts or former con victs were led, shackled, into court today to face the first charges growing out of the Attica prison uprising of 1971. The charges included murder, kidnapping, assault and at tempted arson.

title: IN THE NATION
description: The United States pulled 300 troops out of South Vietnam last week, low ering its strength there to 24,900, the smallest total since February 1965. Those with long memories and ironic minds will recall that February 1965 was the month when President John son began the bombing of North Viet nam in an effort to force the Hanoi Government to agree to American terms in the lethal dispute over the future of Indochina.

title: TRUMAN ASSERTS HE IS ALL RIGHT
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Dec. 18 Former President Harry S. Truman, semiconscious for the last eight days, regained enough strength this morning to tell medical attendants that he felt all right.

title: About Pro Hockey
description: One of the first laws of ex pansion teams is: If Some thing can go wrong, it will. And so the Islanders, with the National League's poorest mark, now must play without their leading scorer, Germain Gagnon, and their most ex perienced player, Ron Stew art. Gagnon has a broken left ankle. It not only happened at a meaningless time with 31 seconds remaining against Philadelphia on Saturday nightit happened in a meaningless cause. The Islanders lost. In the same game, Stewart appeared after sitting out eight contests with a knee injury. On his second shift on the ice, he hit some one in the corner and broke what doctors describe as the long bone in his right shoul der.

title: WilkesBarre Festive Despite Woes
description: WILRESBARRF, pa., Dec. 17The Christmas spirit is Muted in WilkesBarre thig season, but it is clearly present nonetheless.

title: Penn State Triumphs, 4944
description: KENT, Ohio, Dec. 18 (AP) Penn State defeated Kent State, 4944, tonight. Leading Penn State scoring was Ron Brown with 13 points. Dwight Kenner scored 13 for Kent State.

title: College Sports Notes
description: Grambling and North Caro lina A. and T. will become the first predominantly black colleges in a Holiday Festival basketball tournament when they play in the opening games of the 21st annual festival at Madison Square Garden Dec. 26.

title: U.N. Adopts ArabAfrican Measure on Terrorism
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 18  The General Assem bly tonight decisively adopted its Legal Committee's resolu tion on international terrorism, over the opposition of many Western powers.

title: Proxmire and Lockheed Praise G.A.O.'s C5A Study
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18  Senator William Proxmire, Democrat of Wisconsin, long a critic of the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation's costly C5A trans port plane project, found him self in partial agreement with the company today.

title: Castro Flying to Soviet
description: MIAMI, Dec. 18 (AP)Pre mier Fidel. Castro led a delega tion of Cuban officials who flew to Moscow to participate in ceremonies commemorating the 50th anniversary of the founding of the Soviet Union. The departure was announced over the Havana radio in a broadcast monitored to Miami.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: Joe Szombathy, the veteran Syracuse football re cruiter, seemed a bit surprised to bump into Rice Univer sity's young backfield coach, Steve Goldman, in the athletic office at East Paterson High School last Wednesday. Gold man had dropped in unannounced, armed with a road map and a film projector.

title: Marshal Named Thai Premier; New National Assembly Meets
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Dec. 18 (Reuters)  King Phumiphol Aduldet tonight appointed Field Marshal Thanom Kittikachorn as Thailand's new Premier.

title: Court Officers See Deep Throat In Unusual Fifth Avenue Setting
description: The oity's obscenity case against the film Deep Throat began yesterday in a screening room on Fifth Avenue as Criminal Court Judge Joel J. Tyler and court officers viewed the movie in evidence.

title: Iran Bank in London Set
description: The Bank of America and Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company announced yesterday that they have agreed to join with eight foreign commercial banks in forming the Iran In ternational Investment Bank, Ltd., to be based in London. The new financial institution will assist Iran in attracting for eign capital for government and private development projects, and is expected to have initial capital of about $12million.

title: College Sports Notes
description: Grambling and North Caro lina A. and T. will become the first predominantly black colleges in a Holiday Festival basketball tournament when they play in the opening games of the 21st annual festival at Madison Square Garden Dec. 26.

title: DISPUTE ON TRUCKS POSTPONED IN E.E.C.
description: BRUSSELS, Dec. 18 (UPI) A dispute about trucks between the six present members of the Common Market and the three new members was postponed today until next year.

title: BIDEN'S WIFE, CHILD KILLED IN CAR CRASH
description: WILMINGTON, Del., Dec. 18 (UPI) The wife and infant daughter of Senatorelect Jo seph R. Biden Jr., Democrat of Delaware, were killed today in a traffic accident in nearby Hockessin.

title: Advocate of Birth Control Wins Dismissal of Charge
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18An Arlington, Va., County court dismissed today a disorderly conduct charge against William R. Baird, the birth control ad vocate, stemming from a pro abortion demonstration during a national conference of Roman Catholic bishops in Arlington in October.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The Detectives Endowment Association called on City Council president Sanford D. Garelik, yesterday to hold hearings to prevent Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy from eliminating the ranks of firstgrade and secondgrade detective.

title: Jets' Coach Hopes to Retain His General Manager Post
description: Weeb Ewbank said yesterday he planned to remain as the Jets' coach just one more year.

title: Miller Satisfied
description: WASHINTON, Dec. 18 (UPI) Mr. Miller said today that Boyle's resignation was an action that's certainly war ranted. He said he appreciated efforts by Mr. Pnakovich and the other temporary officers to make the transition to the newly elected officers go smoothly.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: NEWARK, Dec. 18The City Hall aide who admitted taking records said to shim irregulari ties in the federally financed public employment program was discharged four days be fore the incident, the assistant business administrator of New ark said today.

title: APOLLO ON COURSE FOR SPLASHDOWN IN PACIFIC TODAY
description: HOUSTON, Dec. 18The Apollo 17 astronauts sped closer to the earth tonight, on course and ready for their scheduled splashdown at 2:24 P.M., Eastern standard time, to morrow.

title: Moscow Lowers Priority On Goods for Consumers
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 18 The Soviet leadership today an nounced a dramatic reordering of economic priorities at the expense of the consumer after a serious crop failure this year. An economic plan for 1973, presented to the Su prerne Soviet, or parliament, called for a sharp cutback in the rate of growth of con sumer goods production, re versing a trend of recent years.

title: The Theater: Rainbow
description: The progenies of Hair have not enjoyed a great track record. It is therefore all the more pheasant to re port that the latest of that tribe, Rainbow, which opened last night at the Orpheum Theater, is a dis tinct success. It has the style, manner and energy of Hair, as well as its chaotic organization and its sim plistic view of a far from simple world.

title: A Summary of Supreme Court Actions
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 The Supreme Court took the following actions today:

title: Spanish Lawyers Urged To Fight an Official Veto
description: MADRID, Dec. 18  The Madrid Bar Association, in censed at Government inter ference with its projected elec tions, appealed to all Spanish lawyers today to rally to it against official aggression.

title: Newman Stars in Huston's Yarn, 'Judge Roy Bean'
description: The passage of time, if not actual circumstances, has thrust the mantle of freebooting greatness upon Roy Bean, the Kentucky-born (circa 1825) scalawag who, in the 1880's, settled in what was then Vinegaroon, Tex. Bean immediately styled himself pudge and then set about to being law and order to the lands west of the Pecos, principally by hanging those passers-by (a lot of whom were outlaws) who had any money or property to bequeath him.At least that's the legend that John Huston, the director; John Milius, the screenwriter, and Paul Newman, the star, Have turned into the elaborate, tall-tale Western that opened here yesterday. "The Life and Times of Judge Roy Bean" is six parts movie carnical, complete with a performing bear, and one part somber chronicle about the promise and disillusion of an especially giddy American Dream.Any movie that dares cover so much ground and draw attention to its historical significance, has to be out of its mind in this day and age. It leaves itself wide open to charges of pretentiousness. Yet "The Life and Times of Judge Roy Bean" is so entertaining and so vigorously performed, especially by Newman in the title role, that its pretensions become part of its robust, knock-about style.Although the real-life Roy Bean died in 1903, Mr. Milius's screenplay is purposefully vague about dates and eras. The film seems to cover the entire history of Texas as reflected in the growth of Vinegaroon, which we see first as a single barroom-whorehouse for outlaws, set in a wasteland of almost comic bleakness, then as a prosperous frontier town, a booming oil community and, finally, after the literally catacylsmic fall of Roy Beau (who takes the town with him) as a dusty museum in a way-station now known as Langtry, Tex., named for the Judge's most famous pen pal, Lily Langtry.Mr. Huston himself shows up in one of the many loosely connected episodes that make up the film's structureplaying (over-acting might be more accurate) a mountain man whose chief purpose in the film is to present Bean with the grizzly bear who is a major character. That is, until the night the bear, who cadges drinks at the bar, makes a mistake of breathing what Bean describes as his "bear-foul breath" on a portrait of the idolized Miss Langtry.Some of the other characters who pass through the film, rather like specialty acts, include Bad Bob the Albino, played by Stacy Keach in a platinum wig that makes him look like Carroll Baker in "Harlow" and the Reverend LaSalle (Anthony Perkins), an itinerant preacher who, on the soundtrack, tells us why he made Judge Bean bury the outlaws the Judge had just shot (". . . because Christ died for all. It was His choice, not mine.").Tab Hunter turns up as one of the judge's first victims, an outlaw with a terrible stutter and just the slightest sense of injustice in the face of his imminent hanging. "I'm no worse and probably better than the men who are doing this to me," he tells us in voice-over narration. Ava Gardner, looking beautifully worn by life, appears in the film's curious epilogue in which the fabulous Jersey Lily stops by to see the whistlestop that has come to bear her name.There are times when it seems as if the film wanted to imitate Newman's extremely successful (at the boxoffice) "Butch Cassidy and the Sun Dance Kid." Stuck smack in the center, in a sequence of ersatz lyricism, is a schmaltzy song sung by Andy Williams for no particular purpose other than to give the movie a song to be advertised by. Most of the time, however, "Roy Bean" is a series of improbably genial adventures, to be interpreted only as solemnly as one sees fit.

title: Chess: Were the Russians thicken, Or Just Ducking Trouble?
While the Patients Talk, the Psychiatrists Stitch Away
description: WASHINGTON, D. C.  Psychi atrists have Joined the large number of men and women hooked on needlework. But they aren't stitching away to relax after a hard day's work. The doctors do their needlework at the office, while their patients are on the couch.

title: 5 Win Patterson Awards
description: The Alicia Patterson Founda tion announced yesterday the award of fellowships to five journalists for travel and study in 1973. They are: John E. Bas kin, special assignments writer for the Wilmington (Ohio) NewsJournril; Susan Brownmil ler, freelance writer; B. J. Phil lips, freelance writer; Boyce C. Rensberger, science writer for The New York Times, and Gail M. H. Sheehy, contributing edi tor of New Yorker magazine. The fellowships were made pos sible by a $1million bequest by Alicia Patterson, who edited and published Newsday in Gar den City, L.I., for nearly 23 years before her death in 1963.

title: GRAIN FUTURES ARE OFF SHARPLY
description: Profit taking was evident yesterday as prices of wheat and soybean futures dropped the daily limit of 10 cents a bushel in most deliveries on the Chicago Board of Trade. Corn prices dropped about 8 cents a bushel, also the daily limit.

title: Advertising:
description: When Miles Laboratories' Nutritional and Hygiene Products division decided to achieve a better balanc ing of billings among its agencies, it made a winner out of TathamLaird & Kudner.

title: GRIFFITH IS LOSER IN DISPUTED BOUT
description: PARIS, Dec. 18 (AP)Jean Claude Bouttier won a second shot at Carlos Monzon's mid dleweight title tonight when the Frenchman was declared the victor over Emile Griffith of Now York, who was disquali fied in the seventh round for hitting low.

title: Costlier Ring
description: Before and since wageprice controls, inflation's bite has been deeper for New Yorkers than for other Ameri cans. That melancholy fact of metropolitan life makes doubly cheerless the prospect that telephone bills in this city and state may take another big jump.

title: U.S. Reminds Aliens of Rule On Registration in January
description: The United States Immigra tion and Naturalization Service yesterday issued its annual no tice to aliens that they must register during the month of January.

title: 5 Former Officials Accused Of Kickbacks in Louisiana
description: ALEXANDRIA, La., Dec. 18 (AP)W. W. McDougall, a for mer Louisiana commissioner of administration, and four former state representatives were in dicted by a Federal grand jury today on charges involving kickbacks paid on state insur ance policies.

title: Cardinals Drop Hollway; Khayat Let Go by Eagles
description: Bob Hollway, head coach of the St. Louis Cardinals, and Ed Khayat, his counterpart for the Philadelphia Eagles, were dismissed yesterday. The Eagles also lost their general manager, Pete Retzlaff, whose resignation of three weeks ago was ac cepted by the team's owner, Leonard Tose.

title: Denial by Clements
description: DALLAS, Dec. 18 (UPI)  William P. Clements denied to day that his drilling company was involved in any conspiracy to hide $7million in profits on an Argentine oil well contract.

title: TRUCKTICKETING BY POLICE UPHELD
description: A Federal judge has refused to halt a police campaign of issuing traffic ticket against trucking companies allegedly connected with organized crime in the city's, garment dis trict.

title: Man Killed at Miami Wedding
description: MIAMI, Dec., 18 (AP)One man was killed and five per sons wounded today when an argument over a cigarette led to a gun battle during a wed ding party, police said. The wounded bridegroom, 34year old Jorge Llanes, was charged with seconddegree murder in the death of Jose Rivera, Police Sgt. Ken Harrison said. In ad dition to Mr. Llanes, four others were wounded, including Maria Lugo, 41, sister of the bride. Others injured were Juan Rodriguez, 27; Carmen Buzainz, 30; and Gilberto Pulido, 34.

title: WALTER EPHRON
description: Walter Ephron, who operated the Ephron Gallery at 123 East 57th Street, died last Thursday in Flower and Fifth Avenue Hospital. He was 77 years old.

title: DR. BLAKE TO SEEK PRESBYTERIAN POST
description: The Rev. Dr. Eugene Carson Blake, the recently retired gen eral secretary of the World Council of Churches, has agreed to run for moderator of the General Assembly of the United resbyterian Church, in the U.S.A.

title: COURT BACKS AID TO ILLEGITIMATES
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18  An illegitimate child has as much right to Social Security benefits earned by his father as legitimate offspring have, the Supreme Court ruled today.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: In his Dec. 5 letter the Rev. A. Fin ley Schaef stated: The mythology I live by is as follows: God is my Fa ther. Earth is my Mother. Mankind is my Brother. Death is my sister. Then, after reversing his metaphors, he asked: Can we find a suitable mythology to encompass the breadth of life which is not chauvinistic?

title: Dayton Routs Auburn, 10663
description: DAYTON, Ohio, Dec. 18 (AP)  The University of Dayton outscored and outrebounded Auburn tonight and won, 106 63. Auburn made only six of 35 shots in the first half.

title: Signs OneYear Pact for 5th Season as Giants' Pilot
description: Alex Webster signed yester day to coach the New York Giants for another season, his fifth. He signed a oneyear con tract by preference and custom.

title: BUILDING BOUGHT BY HARLEM GROUP
description: The Herlem Commonwealth Council has bought out a white realty company's half interest in an $8million Harlem office building what officials con sider a sign of the financial health of the federally financed black and Puerto Rican com munity development corpora tion.

title: Beame Hails Upgrading
description: The city would have saved $40Million in cumulative in terest coats in selling $1.1bil lion of its bonds in 1972 if its credit rating had been raised at the start of the celendar year, Controller Abraham D. Beame said yesterday. This would have been the total saving over the life of the issues, some of which do not come due until the next century.

title: Across 110th Street Is Given Premiere at Loews in Harlem
description: A bit of the glitter of a movie premiere came to 125th Street in Harlem last night as Harlem ites and many of the actors in the film, Across 110th Street, turned out for a benefit show ing at the Loews Victoria Theater.

title: Nixon Aides Discuss Some Decontrol
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 Two Presidential advisers dis cussed with 10 business repre sentatives today the possibility of excluding companies or whole industries from manda tory price controls if they keep price increases in 1973 within the Administration's target.

title: Miss Parker Wed to Alan B. Abramson
description: MILLBURN, N. J., Dec. 18  Miss Patricia Parker, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Abel Parker of South Orange and Miami Beach, was mar ried here this evening to Alan Barrett Abramson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Manville H. Abramson of Great Neck, L.I., and Palm Beach, Fla. Rabbi Jacob Philip Rudin performed the ceremony at Chanticler.

title: Manhunt Disrupts IRT
description: City and Transit Authority police searched the West Side IRT subway tunnel in midtown for more than an hour last night after receiving a report that a man with a gun was seen underground. The report proved unfounded. Power was turned off on the Seventh Ave nue line between Pennsylvania Station and 72d Street from 10:37 to 11:45 P.M. Passengers were given transfers to bus lines during the shutdown.

title: Merger News
description: The BritishAmerican Tobac co Company, Ltd., the world's largest manufacturer of tobac co products, announced yester day in London that it had obtained effective control of International Stores, Ltd., a British, grocery chain.

title: CHICAGO BANK SUED BY STIRLING HOMEX
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 18 (Reuters) The First National Bank of Chicago said today it had been served with a classaction com plaint filed in the Federal Dis trict Court here asking a judg ment of $170million.

title: Jersey Central Commuter Runs To End Unless State Pays More
description: NEWARK, Dec. 18  Federal Judge Anthony T. Augelli gave the Jersey Central Railroad per Mission today to eliminate pas senger service after Jan. 21 on its Jersey Shore and main line if the state did not increase its aid substantially.

title: Crime in Business
description: The war against crime will be advanced significantly if business executives and leaders in the professions take seriously the admonition of United States Attorney Whitney North Seymour Jr. to be both vigilant and ruthless in searching out bribery, tax evasion and other corrupt practices.

title: Irked Customer Set Afire
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Dec. 18 (UPI)A service station attend ant, angry because a customer complained about an inopera tive vending machine, doused the man with gasoline from a pump yesterday and set him afire with a cigarette lighter. The customer, Joseph Adams, 27 years old, was in critical condition today with second and thirddegree burns over 60 per cent of his body. The atten dant, Pickney Steen, 45, was charged with assault to murder and held under $45,000 bond.

title: TV: For the Consumer
description: There is no nonsense about Betty Furness, bless her, or a twohour, nonsponsored pro gram called Consumer on the Warpath, being televised tonight at 9. Bless WORTV, too.

title: People in Sports: Auburn Hurt
description: Randy Walls, a sophomore quarterback who led Auburn to nine victories in 10 games with his passing and running, will not play in the Gator Bowl against Colorado on Dec. 30.

title: HIGHRISK DRIVERS HELD SUBSIDIZED
description: ALBANY, Dec. 18 (UP)The New York State Insurance De partment says that drivers in the assigned  risk insurance pools are being subsidized by the rest of the state's driv ere.

title: FOOD TALK
description: Around the holiday season even those who rarely lift a spoon invite guests for every thing from a cup of cheer and tidbits to a formal din ner party. To ease the burden for the less accomplished there are several new serv ices and aids to try.

title: U.S. Says '73 Oil Import Quotas Will at Least Match '72 Levels
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (AP) The Nixon Administration, in a move to ease winter fuel shortages, announced today that the 1973 oil import allocations would be at least as large as the 1972 allocations.

title: PIER PANEL SHOWS UNDERWORLD FILM
description: More than 20 New York and New Jersey lawenforcement officials attended a private screening of a Waterfront Com mission film yesterday showing 11 days of comings and goings of underworld figures at 100 Madison Street on the Lower East Side.

title: Property Tax Reform Enthusiasm Lags
description: Enthusiasm for propertytax reform in the metropolitan area's suburbs has turned to confusion and doubt in the last few months as advocates of re form have begun to move be yond defining the problem to suggesting solutions.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Some 2,000 to 3,000 elder ly tenants in publicly aided housing could lose six months of retroactive rent subsidies because their housing com panies have not participated in the program that would confer them, the city said.

title: Turkish Workers Abroad Are Crucial to Economy
description: ISTANBUL, Turkey, Dec. 15 Turkey's main export has be come migrant workers, whose paychecks abroad are being counted on by planners here to build domestic industries.

title: UNIT ON CHARTER IN VISIT TO QUEENS
description: Balancing box lunches on their laps, members of the state com mission on revision of the New York City Charter bounced through a fivehour bus tour of Queens yesterday, with Borough President Donald R. Manes pro viding running commentary.

title: Majors of Iowa State To Coach Pitt Football
description: MEMPHIS, Dec. 18 (AP) Johnny Majors of Iowa State announced tonight after his team lost the Liberty Bowl football game to Georgia Tech that he would accept the head coaching job at the University of Pittsburgh.

title: White House Says Nixon Knew of Lawsuit When He Nominated William Clements for Defense Post
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 The White House acknowledged today that President Nixon was aware at the time he nomi nated William P. Clements Jr. as Deputy Secretary of De fense that, Mr. Clements was a defendant in a civil suit charging conspiracy and fraud.

title: Creighton Tops Santa Clara
description: OMAHA, Neb., Dec. 18 (AP) Creighton surged ahead early in the second half to take an 8673 victory over Santa Clara tonight. The Bluejays held Mike Stewart, 6foot10inch stand out for Santa Clara, to 6 points.

title: Beame Hails Upgrading
description: The city would have saved $40million in cumulative in terest costs in selling $1.1bil lion of its bonds in 1972 if its credit rating had been raised at the start of the calendar year, Controller Abraham D. Beame said yesterday. This would have been the total saving over the life of the issues, some of which do not come due until the next century.

title: Business Briefs
description: PARIS, Dec. 18 (AP)Gold hit record highs today in trading on the Paris and Zurich free markets, while the dollar strengthened against most major currencies in Euro pean interbank dealings.

title: LAVELLE'S RAIDS ARE HELD PROPER
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (AP)A House subcommittee says the unauthorized Amer ican air strikes ordered by Gen. John D. Lavelle against North Vietnam last winter were not only proper but es sential.

title: American Enka Expands
description: The American Enka Com pany, a unit of Akzona, Inc., announced yesterday that it would expand its annual ca pacity for nylonfilament car pet yarn by 50 million pounds over the next two to three years.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: A suspended New York City patrolman was indicted by a Hudson County grand jury yesterday on charges that he shot and struck a National Boy Scout executive after their cars collided in the Lincoln Tunnel.

title: Wide Abuses Alleged in Texas Border Control
description: EAGLE PASS, Texas, Some border patrolmen and immigration inspectors here say that control of the border be tween Texas and Mexico has almost broken down and urge that a Federal grand jury in San Diego investigate what they say are widespread abuses in the immigration procedures in Texas.

title: books of The Times
description: Mmmmm slurp! The Great American Ice Cream Book. What expertise I bring to this one, I thought. After all, how many, reviewers actually logged an average of 100 miles It day one summer long ago, selling Good Humors to the hungry masses along the coast between New London, Conn., and Westerly, R. I.?And studiously learned of various, ethnic preferences for flavors like Chocolate Cake, Texas, Pecan Crunch and Bana na Split on a Stick? And in fair weather dreamed up good new fla vors: Cantaloupe Ice, Plum Pudding & Hard Sauce, Kotton Kandy & Krackerjack (this was long before Baskin  Robbins, you must realize); and in foul, foul: Hotdog & Relish, Spam 'n' Scrapple, Brussels Sprouts and Dust? And having sustained himself on ice cream alone through many a 12hourday, was billed at the end of the summer $467 (minus my 25 per cent commission) for merchandise consumed (which, if not a record, must certainly rank among the alltime top 100)? And still drools a little when he hears those bells? Expertise, no?

title: A SAVINGS BANK IN BOSTON FAILS
description: For the first time since the nineteentwenties, a mutual savings bank has failed and has had to be taken over by another institution.

title: Divisions in Mine Workers' Union Already Appear to Be Dissipating Following Election of President
description: EBENSBURG, Pa., Dec. 18 If the first few days are any indication, the bitter division in the United Mine Workers may have begun to dissipate with the election of Arnold R. Miller as union president.

title: MORE WELFARE AID TO CHILDREN IS SET
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (UPI) Welfare aid must be provided to some college students up to age 21 in needy families receiv ing funds in the Aid to Fam ilies with Dependent Children (A.F.D.C.) program under new rules proposed today by the Department of Health, Educa tion, and Welfare.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Dec. 18  The controversial new $120million Sydney Opera House got an acoustical A plus from musicians and critics last night following the first fullscale perform ance under audience Condi tions in the uncompleted building. Scheduled for offi cial opening next October, the large white building, whose exterior is shaped to look like huge sails against the backdrop of Sydney her bor, has been plagued by de lays and mounting costs since construction began in 1959.

title: WaiAniwa of New Zealand Is First in OneTon Cup Sail
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Dec. 18 (UPI)Australia and New Zea land dominated the fourth race of 270 miles in the world One Ton Cup yachting champion ships today off Sydney Heads. The New Zealand yacht, Wei Aniwa, skippered by Chris Bou zaid, won the event by 7 min utes 12 seconds.

title: 12 INMATES NAMED IN ATTICA CHARGES
description: WARSAW, N. Y., Dec. 18 Twelve convicts or former con victs were led, shackled, into court today to face the first charges growing out of the Attica prison uprising of 1971. The charges included murder, kidnapping, assault and at tempted arson.

title: Setback on Vietnam Spurs 13.99 Fall in Dow Index
MAX GLASER
description: Max Glaser, a real estate broker here and a former mem ber of the planning board of Harrison, N.Y, where he lived on Muchmore Road, died yester day in Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 65 years old.

title: U.S. INACTION SEEN ON MINORITY JOBS
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 The Nixon Administration has reportedly all but abandoned efforts to force Federal con tractors to hire more blacks, other minoritygroup workers and women.

title: Boston College, Dartmouth Win in E.C.A.C. Hockey
description: BOSTON, Dec. 18 (AP)Bos ton College defeated Merri mack, 41, and Dartmouth edged New Hampshire, 54, to night in the opening round of the Eastern College Athletic Conference Christmas hockey tournament at Boston Garden. The winners will meet in the final Wednesday night.

title: Part of the Colosseum Is Reopened to Public
description: ROME, Dec. 18 (Reuters) The Colosseum, closed for three months as a threat to public safety, was partially reopened today in time for the Christmas tourist rush.

title: Bridge:Exciting Finish Again Marks Swiss Team Championships
description: Exciting finishes are the rule rather than the excep tion in Swiss team champion ships, and the concluding event of the Greater New York Bridge Association's winter regionals at the New York Hilton Sunday followed this pattern.

title: Neediest Offer a Way To Say Care
description: Until we find a better way to take care of the less for tunate, Eli Fogel told the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund yesterday, I for one will continue to help.

title: The Screen
description: Images, which has opened at the Columbia I Theater, was shown at the 10th New York Film Festival. The following excerpts are from Howard Thompson's review, which ap peared Oct. 9, 1972, in The New York Times.

title: Business Briefs
description: BRUSSELS, Dec. 18 (AP)The permanent staff of the European Common Market's Executive Commission decided today to suspend their strike and return to work pending a ruling on their claims by the European Court of Justice.

title: U.S. and Soviet Will Recess Geneva Talks on Arms Curbs
description: GENEVA, Dec. 18The Unit ed States and the Soviet Union agreed today to meet on Thurs day and then to recess the cur rent opening round of their new effort to curb the nuclear arms race.

title: Hallmark Group Stock Shift
description: Shareholders of Hallmark Group Companies, Inc., ap proved a reclassification of the common stock to effect a one fortwo reverse split at yester day's annual meeting In Dallas. As a result, the 5,353,081 com mon shares presently outstand ing will be reduced to 2,676,542 common shares outstanding. The company is in the devel opment and management of mobile home parks, commercial real estate, film production, advertising, public relations and fundraising consultation.

title: 5 WAR FOES HELD IN RAIL SABOTAGE
description: YORK, Pa., Dec. 18 (AP) Five antiwar activists were ar rested by the state police today for allegedly sabotaging rail road equipment near a factory that makes bomb casings used in the Vietnam war.

title: Third Day of Heavy Fighting Is Reported Around Quang Tri City
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, Dec. 19 (AP)  Heavy fighting was reported yesterday for the third day in the north ernmost part of South Vietnam near Quang Tri city.

title: Catagories of Ratings By Moody's Described
description: The following are the designations assigned by Moody's to municipal credits:

title: U.S. Says Departure of 300 Leaves 24,900 in Vietnam
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 18 (Reuters)  American troop strength in Vietnam dropped by 300 men last week to 24,900, the United States command re ported today. A command spokeman said that the depart ing troops were soldiers and air men.

title: Man in the News
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 In 1959, John Alfred Scali, a reporter for The Associated Press, was in Moscow cover ing the trip of Richard M. Nixon, who was Vice Presi dent then. During this trip Mr. Nixon had his famous kitchen debate with the Soviet Premier, Nikita S. Khrushchev, and the other day, a friend of Mr. Scali's re called the event as he and mil lions of other Americans had seen it on television. There was Vice President Nixon and Khrushchev in the center of the picture with John Scali on the edge of the picture: As the talk between Nixon and Khrushchev got more heated, you could see John squirming nearer the two men to take better notes until John ended up right between them with his pic ture in all the papers.

title: Nadjari Studies Allegations Of ParkingTicket Fixing
description: The involvement of some leg islators in Possible parking ticket fixing is under investiga tion by the special state prose cutor, Maurice Nadjari, who was appointed by Governor Rockefeller to look into possi ble corruption by the police, judges and prosecutors.

title: Business Briefs
description: BRUSSELS, Dec. 18 (Reuters)The Commission the European Economic Community in the Common Market's biggestantitrust case, today announced fines totaling 9 million European Units of Account ($9.75mil lion) against 16 of the community's leading sugar refiners.

title: Egypt Pressed by Libya on Unity
description: TRIPOLI, Libya, Dec. 12The Libyan Government, to the sur prise of many here, is driving a tough bargain in its negotia tions with Egypt on union be tween thetwo countries.

title: Fashion Takes On a Sparkle All Its Own
description: Not all the glitter will be on the tree this Christmas. Some of the glow will be on the backs of women wrapping the packages to be set beneath the tree. And some will be hidden in tissue paper in the packages them selves.

title: Awesome Dexterity Of Rogoff, Pianist, Fires His Recital
description: Given the right repertory, Ilan Rogoff would appear to be an important artist. The Israeli pianist, who played Sunday evening at Tully Hall, has as fleet a set of fingers as anyone might wish. He can make them do almost anything he wants, too  rattle off cascades of notes at impressive speed, move within the most extreme dynamic range at will and arti culate tricky phrasings with ex hilarating accuracy.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: I am glad you finally got around to doing an article on the poor Jews in the city (Her Crowd, OpEd Dec. 4). For too long this minority's problem has been allowed to be ignored be cause a great many people still believe in the old myth that all Jews have money. If anything, this is a tragic problem for the Jews, and while many continue to be ignored by their chill dren, I very much resent Mr. Cowan's unbalanced generalization. I am, how ever, grateful to him for focusing on this subject and bringing attention to it. Needless to say, I am ashamed as a Jew that we have allowed this to hap pen even in one case.

title: Lindsay Will Seek to Hold Political Power Whether or Not He Runs Again
description: Mayor Lindsay, at a secret meeting yesterday with Alex Rose, head of the Liberal party, made it clear that whether or not he runs for reelection next year, he intended to try to re main a very powerful political force in the city and state.

title: Basketball Ratings
description: The top team, with points figured on a 2018161412 10987654321 basis (first place votes in parentheses) and won lost records and total points:

title: Edgar A. Kniffin Dies at 67; ExHead of Peerless Photo
description: Edgar Aldrich Kniffin, re tired president of Peerless Photo Products, Inc., died Sat urday in St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 67 years old and a resi dent of St. James, L. I.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18Despite the devaluation of the dollar, which increased the cost of travel in many foreign countries, the number of Americans traveling abroad this year has continued to soar, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: ELECTORS AFFIRM NIXON'S VICTORY
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (AP) President Nixon was formally reelected today as the Electoral College performed its constitu tional duty amid renewed cries for abolishing it.

title: PHILIP CLAYTON, BRITISH CHAPLAIN
description: LONDON, Dec. 18The Rev. Dr. Philip Clayton, founder of Toc H, a servicemen's welfare organization that was created in the fields of Flanders in World War I, died here Friday night at the age of 87.

title: TV: 51st State Focuses on a Brooklyn Politician
description: When it's good, which it still is more often than not, Channel 13's The 51st State can be very, very good. An outstanding illus tration was offered on last Wednesday's edition of the news magazine, which is presented nightly at 7 and 10:30 and again the following morning at 7.

title: Court Rejects Jersey Plea On Taxi Driver in Riots
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (UPI) The Supreme Court refused today, to hear the State of New Jersey's appeal in the case of a former taxi driver whose 1967 arrest touched off street riots in Newark.

title: Yale, Northeastern in Final
description: NEW HAVEN, Dec. 18Yale and Northeastern scored de cisive victories tonight to ad vance to the final of the Yale hockey tournament. Yale de feated Middlebury, 51, after Northeastern had routed Ameri can International, 123. Yale and Northeastern meet tomor row night in the final.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: TRENTON, Dec. 18Robert L. Clifford, State Institutions and Agencies Commissioner, said today that proposals to modify Governor Cahill's parole reform bill would destroy the flexibility of the measure.

title: Ga. Tech Tops Iowa State In Liberty Bowl, 31 to 30
description: MEMPHIS, Dec. 18 (AP) Jim Stevens, filling in for Eddie McAshen, who was suspended, threw three touchdown passes tonight as Georgia Tech upset Iowa State, 3130, in the Lib erty Bowl football game. A twopoint conversion attempt by Iowa State failed with a minute 36 seconds left.

title: Hills Adding L.I. Markets
description: Hills Supermarkets, a divi sion of Pueblo International, Inc., will open five supermar kets on Long Island today. In cluding the store opened last week in Newburgh, N. Y., the latest openings bring the total number of stores in the Hill chain to 75.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: TRENTON, Dec. 18A spe cial prison task force recom mended today that at least three separate facilities be con structed within the state prison system to house 125 thardcore, incorrigible inmates.

title: Rodriguez Leads L.I.U. To Victory Over C.C.N.Y.
description: Rubin Rodriguez scored 25 points as Long Island Univer sity defeated City College, 64 53 last night in the losers' gym. City got off quickly and led, 2520, with 5 minutes 10 seconds left in the first half. L.I.U. then scored nine straight points and took a lead it never relinquished. At halftime the Blackbirds led, 3129.

title: NEW THAI PREMIER NAMES HIS CABINET
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Dec. 19 (Reuters)  The new Premier, Field Marshal Thanom Kittika chorn, announced a 27man Cab inet today, with key posts go ing to military officers.

title: Business Briefs
description: ZURICH, Switzerland, Dec. 19 (AP)Yesterday's clos ing gold price of $65466.40 an ounce on the Zurich free market, erroneously reported as an alltime high, was effect far below the highestever level.

title: U.S. Court Upsets City's Law On Licensing of Movie Houses
description: The city's law for licensing film theaters was declared un constitutional by a Federal judge yesterday in the case of a 42d Street theater that was accused of showing obscene films.

title: Man Dead, Second Hurt, In WelfareCheck Quarrel
description: FREEPORT, L. I., Dec. 19 (AP)  A woman has been charged with stabbing one man to death and wounding another during an argument over how to spend the remainder of welfare check. The police re ported.

title: Trail Blazers 109100 Victors
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 19 (UPI) Sidney Wicks and Geoff Petrie combined for 55 points tonight to lead the Portland Trail Blazers to a 109100 victory over the Chicago Bulls.

title: Radakovich Reverses Field
description: CINCINNATI, Dec. 19 (AP) The University of Cincinnati announced today that Dan Radakovich, a University of Colorado assistant coach who last week was named head coach at Cincinnati, had backed out of the job.

title: 35 Indicted in on Order Theft Of 500 Luxury Cars in 3 States
description: NEWARK, Dec. 19  A Fed eral grand jury has indicted 35 alleged members of five inter locking autotheft rings ac cused of stealing more than 500 luxury cars on order over the last two years in New York State, New Jersey and Pennsylvania.

title: Redskins' Brown Unanimous Choice As N.F.C. AllStar
description: Larry Brown, the Washington Redskins' running back, was the only player to be selected unanimously yesterday to the United Press International Na tional Football Conference all star team.

title: Howfield and Snead Win Conference Titles
description: The Jets' Bobby Howfield led the American Conference in scoring while the Giants' Norm Snead captured honors as the statistical passing leader of the National Con ference in the National Foot ball League season which concluded on Sunday.

title: Thuy Puts Blame on U.S.
description: PARIS, Dec. 19North Viet nam's envoy placed full re sponsibility on the United States today for failure to reach a ceasefire after almost a month of intense negotiations, but he carefully avoided saying there had been a rupture in the talks.

title: 1972 Extraordinary Charge Seen by Kaiser Resources
description: Kaiser Resources said yester day that it will have an extraor dinary charge of about $7.4 million, or 74 cents a share, against 1972 earnings. Kaiser Resources is 75 per cent owned by the Kaiser Steel Corpora tion, which is in turn 58 per cent owned by the Kaiser In dustries Corporation.

title: SteelersRaiders: Match up in Youthful Vim
description: Will there be a Super Bowl team on the field in Pitts burgh this Saturday when the Steelers take on the Oakland Raiders in the first of the National Football League's four playoff games? The win ner there can expect to take on next the undefeated Mi ami Dolphins, heavily favored (12 points) over Cleveland on Sunday, for the American Confer ence champion ship Dec. 31 and a Super Bowl berth. Bear in mind that the Dolphins beat only two teams that ended the season with winning rec ords: the Giants and the Kan sas City Chiefs.

title: Farr Is Denied Release
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 19 (AP) Federal District Judge Ro bert J. Kelleher officially denied today Mr. Farr's appeal of his contempt of court con viction as the reporter spent his 23d day in jail with no immediate prospect of release.

title: Networks See Some Gains in Communications Draft
description: Key provisions of the Nixon Administration's draft bill to amend the Communications Act of 1934 would give broadcasters two important and longwanted concessions, while at the same time imposing on individual sta tions increased accountability for the content of programs fur nished them by networks.

title: Return From the Moon
description: Astronauts Cernan, Schmitt and Evans returned safely to earth yesterday in a splashdown that marked the bril liantly successful end of one of the most successful series of scientific experiments in history. Less than four years ago men had never even been in the vicinity of the moon. Now about two dozen men have orbited the satel lite, and a dozen have walked and ridden on its surface. Hundreds of pounds of lunar rock and soil have been brought back to earth for study, while instruments planted on the moon give daily reports of lunar condi tions, and will do so for years.

title: Business Briefs
description: The Nixon Administration is planning to introduce legislation early next year that would allow savings and loan associations and mutual savings banks to offer checking accounts, credit cards and consumer loans, the president of the American Bankers Association predicted yesterday.

title: Chinese Acrobats Delight Chicagoans
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 19The Shenyang Acrobatic Troupe of China flashed across the cavernous stage of the Civic Opera House last night, leav ing an overflow audience breathless and charmed.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: HOME FOLKS The per formers and audiences that will he filling Alice Tully Hall, Broadway and 65th Street, from tonight through the end of the year (except this Saturday, Sunday, Mon day) are not the sort that usually get to Lincoln Cen ter, either to see or be seen. Con Edison is sponsoring a Community Holiday Festi val starring talents from New York neighborhoods and drumming up audiences from the sane areas.

title: Thuy Puts Blame on U.S.
description: PARIS, Dec. 19North Viet nam's envoy placed full re sponsibility on the United States today for failure to reach a ceasefire after almost a month of intense negotiations, but he carefully avoided saying there had been a rupture in the talks.

title: Vienna Voices Irritation Over Yugoslav's Speech
description: VIENNA, Dec. 19 (Reuters) Chancellor Bruno Kreisky accused Yugoslavia today of saberrattling in a sharpen ing dispute over minority rights on Austria's southern border.

title: Kissinger's Deputy Meets Thieu, Then Lon Nol
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 19Henry A. Kissinger's deputy, Gen. Alexander M. Haig Jr., conferred with the leaders of South Vietnam and Cambodia today, with the an nounced purpose of explaining the state of the peace talks.

title: What Ails Knicks on Road? Early Diagnosis: Not Much
description: PHOENIX, Dec. 19  The Knicks take exception to the idea that playing on the road gives them special problems, an idea gaining circulation because they had lost five of their last six road games.

title: Long Beach, Jacksonville Win on Coliseum's Court
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., Dec. 19 Long Beach State played a bas ketball game tonight that had all the earmarks of a scrim mage, and not even a good one at that.

title: Bush in U.N. Tribute
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 19In his final address to the General Assembly, George Bush paid tribute today to Mr. Truman.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Advertising:
description: A spokesman for CampbellMithun called from Minne apolis yesterday to report that the agency had resigned the account of Wilson, the meatpacking enterprise.

title: Tufts Plans Afro Program
