description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (AP) Investigations of beef prices at four food chains will result in refunds totaling $19,277 at two of the chains and price reductions at all four, the Cost of Living Council said today.

title: CHARLES A. VOLK
description: NORWALK, Conn., Dec. 19 Charles A. Volk, chief of the Norwalk Fire Department from 1937 to 1962, when he retired, died last night at his home, 5 Dairy Farm Road. His age was 86.

title: THROAT LAWYER CALLS FOR EXPERTS
description: The defense attorney in the Deep Throat obscenity trial argued yesterday that a judge needs the expert help of psy chiatrists and critics to deter mine whether material is porno graphic and cannot make such a determination by himself.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: IRVING, Tex., Dec. 19 (AP)  Hayden Fry signed a four year contract today to become head football coach at North Texas State University and the former Southern Methodist mentor said, Some day we will be bigger and stronger than S.M.U.

title: Monticello Crowd Is Small, but Bets Are Big
description: MONTICELLO, N.Y., Dec. 19  Any coward can bet with OTB in New York City and then watch his money at home on television.

title: HARRY B. JENNINGS
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Dec. 19Harry Bogert Jennings, retired business executive, died today at his home, 64 Old Church Road. He was 85 years old.

title: Back to the Stone Age
description: With the opportunity safely to disengage American military personnel and prisoners from the Vietnamese conflict now rapidly receding, President Nixon has resort ed once more to naked force to try to obtain his own larger objectives in Southeast Asiaobjectives which are neither realistic nor essential to this country's secu rity interests. However much Hanoi may be responsible for disrupting the negotiationswhich is a highly dis puted pointcivilized man will be horrified at the re newed spectacle of the world's mightiest air force merci lessly pounding a small Asian nation in an abuse national power and disregard of humanitarian principles.

title: A Very Practical Gift
description: Children grow so fast it's almost impossible to buy them something practical that will last. United States Savings Bonds are practical. Children never outgrow their need for secu rity. And there is a bonus in terest rate on all United States Savings Bondsfor Series E bonds, 5 per cent when held for five years 10 months. That extra onehalf of 1 per cent, payable as a bonus at ma turity, applies to all these bonds issued since June 1, 1970, with a comparable im provement for all older bonds.

title: NoGo Commuting
description: The commuter is more harried than hurried these days. The deficitridden Long Island Rail Road has not run for three weeks because train crews won't cross picket lines established by striking nonoperating employes. He is presenting himself to Germany and Europe now as a downtoearth, onestepata time politician, and his inauguration maintained this modest approach.

title: Apollo Scissors Still Missing

As the spacecraft was headed back to earth, some officials expressed concern that the scissors, mis placed in the cabin during the flight, could hit one of the astronauts during splashdown. But the scissors did not appear, and a space official, asked after splashdown what became of them, laughed and said, I don't think anybody knows.

title: Black Gunn,' With Jim Brown, Arrives
description: Black machismo, militancy and black-white gang warfare, surefire ingredients of some recent black films such as, say, "Trouble Man," again are the loud keynotes of "Black Gunn," which arrived at the DeMille yesterday. But despite the occasional rationalizations of Jim Brown, its tough titular star and others, "Black Gunn" ultimately is no more constructive sociologically than its frequent fireworks and bloodletting.Gunn, you see, owns Gunn's Club, a money-making castle of a black nightclub in Los Angeles's high-rent district. He drives a white Rolls-Royce and has an adoring girl friend and, as a man well aware of the power of money, a cool disdain of the white Establishment Until, that is, his young brother (Herbert Jefferson Jr.) is rubbed out after he and his Black Action Group rob the syndicate of its loot and incriminating payoff records.But the ensuing chases, fights and carnage through slums and affluent Los Angeles sites are also interspersed with a confusion of points of view. Gary Conway, as a bland white Congressman, finally disavows the mob after appearing to be its man all along. Jim Watkins, as a black detective, is hated by the militants and Jim Brown, who suddenly switches to acceptance of the black, harried cop's brand of law and order when the shooting stops.Jim Brown's search-and-destroy tactics often destroy his shirt to expose him as a fine figure of a man. He's as tough as the legendary football star he was, laconically certain of his views on black power and tender with his decorative, if fearful, girl, Brenda Sykes.Martin Landau, Keefe Brasselle and Bruce Glover, as the white syndicate's top strongarms he mows down, are simply one-dimensional goons, as is Stephen McNally, their chief. Only physically impressive are Luciana Paluzzi, as a fancy moll; Timothy Brown, as Jim Brown's aide; Bernie Casey, as an activist leader, and baseball's Vida Blue.Robert Hartford-Davis, the British director and author of the original idea for the story, with which he's making his American debut, has concentrated on speed and violence. These, like the gory, fiery final shoot-out, certainly help a viewer forget the minimal talk about social injustice.

title: Hit Man' Life Styles Vie for Spotlight
description: A friend of mine who saw "Hit Man" at a screening the other night had the curious experience of finding that although the plot was very complex and virtually incomprehensible, he nevertheless always knew what was going to happen next. Later, he realized that he had seen it all before, in a film called "Get Carter," which starred Michael Caine and played here last year."Get Carter," set in Newcastle, was a murder mystery having to do with the seamier insides of the pornographic movie business. "Hit Man," which opened yesterday at several local theaters, keeps the murders and the dirty movies, but the action is now in Los Angeles, and everybody's skin is black.I shan't go into the story, which I could describe completely and still leave you unenlightened. But it obviously owes a lot to the Raymond Chandler tradition of detective fiction. In "Get Carter" (which I have not seen) the debt is apparently well paid by way of explicit nostalgic allusion. In "Hit Man" the debt is simply ignored. Its interest is life style rather than literary style, and as it turns out, that is interest enough.There have been very few recent movies quite so pleasantly involved with their locationsfrom improbable mansions to seedy cottages, from skyscrapers to one-man (or one-woman) motels, from the home-made surrealism of Watts Towers to a suburban game preserve full of sullen lions and tigersand very few movies so aware of the kinds of unpretentious entertainment that merely being on location can offer. The dialogue, equally divided between inuendo and insult, and almost wholly unrepeatable in this newspaper, is a kind of personality play of great resourcefulness and skill. And the personalities, highly individualized and often lovely, seem the creation of people actively concerned with making themselves interesting.Everybody in "Hit Man" is fairly sexy, but the women are sexier than the men (thank God) and the sexiest of all is Pamela Grier, who plays Gozelda, a skin-flick actress of evil ambitions and overwhelming presence, until she is consumed by a hungry tiger in the game preserve. As her more worthy antagonist, Bernie Casey keeps enough cool for half a dozen movie heroes. The rest of the cast is good, and a few, Lisa Moore as the motel keeper Laural Garfoot and Sam Laws as the used-car dealer Sherwood Epps, are pretty close to wonderful.George Armitage's direction is often sloppy around the edges, but precise and well observed with whatever matters. A student in the Roger Corman on-the-job-training film school, he has made such unreviewed glories as "Private - Duty Nurses" and "Night Call Nurses." He seems a real film maker, with a fine sense of excitement and of relaxation in the medium, and I hope he goes far.

title: Tass Reports From Hanoi: Heavy Civilian Casualties
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 20Tass, the Soviet press agency, reported from Hanoi today that the latest American air raids there had caused heavy civilian casual ties and destroyed thousands of homes.

title: BERRIGAN FREED AFTER 39 MONTHS
description: DANBURY, Conn., Dec. 20 The Rev, Philip Berrigan walked out of Federal prison here today after 39 months, and said he was determined to work within the limits of his parole to bring an end to the war in Southeast Asia.

title: Bridge: A Technicality Breaks Tie For Player of the Year Here
description: An ingenious paradox wor thy of W. S. Gilbert devel oped Sunday at the conclu sion of the annual contest for 1972 New York Player of the Year. The title is awarded to the player whose high fin ishes in New York and Long Island tournaments win him most master points in the year.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: TRENTON, Dec. 20 (AP) The New Jersey Transporta lion Department said today that it would announce in a few clays details of emergency service in the event of a strike next Wednesday by the men who service the PATH trains.

title: American Grain Ship Unloaded at Fast Clip in Soviet
description: ODESSA, U.S.S.R., Dec. 20 (UPI)  Enough American wheat to make 80 million loaves of bread began pouring into Russian boxcars today from the first American ship to arrive with grain this year.

title: Senate Leaders Differ
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (AP) The Republican leader of the Senate said today that Presi dent Nixon's bombing decision should be supported, but his Democratic counterpart said that it would only prolong the war.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: U.N. Defeats Bid to Bar Rental Of Space in New Building Here
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 20  Diplomats who would like to see more United Nations activities shifted from New York lost a hardfought campaign this week to block the world organization from renting additional office space here.

title: F.C.C. STUDY CITES DANGER FOR CATV
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20A Federal Communications Com mission advisory committee that conducted a study of cable television has warned that cer tain potential owners of cable systems were a great danger to the growth and development of the new industry.

title: Aide to Long Says Nixon Plans Slash in City and State Grants
description: BATON ROUGE, Dec. 20 (AP)President Nixon plans to make heavy cuts in Federal grants to state and local gov ernments next year, a spokes man for Senator Russell B. Long, Democrat of Louisiana, says.

title: Super Matchup: White House vs. N.F.L.
description: President Nixon, whose play suggestions to football coaches are treated as harm less interludes in his other wise serious business, has devised a play that could turn into serious business for the National Football League.

title: Sabres Win, 63
description: BUFFALO, Dec. 20 (AP)The Buffalo Sabres got two goals apiece from Richard Martin and Hugh Harris and whipped the Vancouver Canucks, 63, to night for their eighth straight National Hockey League vic tory.

title: Charges of TrafficTicket Fixing Under Investigation by Nadjari
description: An intensive investigation, said to involve legislators, city officials and other politicians in widespread fixing of traffic tickets in Brooklyn and Man hattan is being conducted by the special state prosecutor, Maurice H. Nadjari.

title: ENVIRONMENT JOB WILL BE RETAINED BY RUCKELSHAUS
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 William D. Ruckelshaus, who has sometimes differed vigor ously with other Nixon Admin istration officials on environ mental questions, will stay on as administrator of the Environ mental Protection Agency, the White House announced today.

title: Citibank Adding Unit
description: The First National City Cor poration announced yesterday that it planned to expand its portfolio investment advisory service by establishing a new wholly owned subsidiary in San Francisco. The advisory service will be called Citicorp Invest ment Management, Inc.

title: PENTAGON SAYS BOMBINGS WRECK MILITARY TARGETS; IT DENIES TERROR RAIDS
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20The Defense Department said today that the intensive American bombing of North Vietnam in the last two clays had caused very significant damage to a broad range of military targets.

title: 2 Airport Guards Shot
description: A Vietnam veteran who had been confined for mental illness shot and wounded two Federal security officers yes terday at Kennedy Interna tional Airport before being captured, the police said. De tails on Page 70.

title: Newark Council Rejects Kerr As First Black Police Director
description: NEWARK, Thursday, Dec. 21Newark's City Council, voting 5 to 3 along racial lines, early today rejected Lieut. Edward L. Kerr as Newark's first black police director in a tumultuous fiveandahalfhour meeting.

title: Stock Prices Off Again On Stalemate in Vietnam
description: Stock prices continued to decline yesterday in reaction to stalemated peace efforts and a resumption of fullscale bombing and mining of North Vietnam. Statistically, the market was a virtual replay of Tuesday's performance. The DowJones industrial average slipped 4.36 points to 1,004.82 and declines outpaced ad vances on the New York Stock Exchange by a 9to5 ratio.

title: Old German Buildings Burn
description: LUNEBURG, West Germany, Dec. 20 (Reuters)Fire swept through the old part of this medieval town early today, destroying 16thcentury build ings and causing damage esti mated at omre than $325,000.

title: Much European Criticism
description: LONDON, Dec. 20 (AP) President Nixon's bombing de cision produced criticism today in much of Europe and espe cially in the Nordic countries. In Finland, where criticism of United States policies in Vietnam has been muted in the past, Foreign Minister Ahti Karjalainen declared: It is es pecially difficult to understand on what arguments the vast bombardment of the North Vietnamese territory has been based.

title: Dartmouth Six Wins
description: BOSTON, Dec. 20 (AP)  Dartmouth struck for three goals in the first period and went on to an 85 victory over Boston College tonight in the firstplace game of the Christ mas hockey tournament at Bos ton Garden.

title: Polish Tell of Attack
description: WARSAW, Dec. 20 (Reuters) A Polish freighter was sunk and three Polish seamen were killed in an American bombing attack on the North Vietnamese port of Haiphong today, the Polish press agency reported.

title: Miss Proell Sets World Cup Ski Mark
description: SAALBACH, Austria, Dec 20 (AP)  Annemarie Proell of Austria captured the 19th World Cup ski race of her ca reer today, breaking the record of 18 set by JeanClaude Killy of France.

title: CRIMINALS BARRED AT HOTEL BY WRIT
description: A sweeping court order that bars anyone convicted of pros titution, drugpushing or other crimes from living in a single roomoccupancy building at 9 West 102d Street was issued yesterday.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: The Neuberger Museum at the State University of New York's College at Purchase has received an important collection of constructivist art, consisting of 150 paintings, sculptures, collages, mobiles and assemblages, from Mr. and Mrs. George Rickey. Mr. Rickey is a wellknown con structivist sculptor and his torian of the movement. The collection, part of which has circulated among American museums over the last two years, includes works by Al bers, Baschet, Calder, Cast ellani, Corbero, Riley, Fon tana, Gabo, Max Bill, Kan dinsky, lIerbin and Vasar ely.

title: GUNMEN IN ULSTER KILL 8, INJURE 5
description: LONDONDERRY, Northern Ireland, Thursday, Dec. 21 (AP) Gunmen killed eight men and wounded five yesterday in one of Northern Ireland's bloodiest days of the year.

title: New Zealand Yacht Takes OneTon Cup in Australia
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Dec. 20 (Reuters)  A New Zealand yacht, WaiAniwa, skippered by Chris Bouzaid, was declared winner today of the interna national OneTon Cup Blue Water Classic.

title: Pope Deplores Bombing
description: ROME, Dec. 20Pope Paul VI today deplored the resumption of United States bombing deep in North Vietnam and called for patient negotiations to seek peace.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Property Clerk Office Called Unbelievable
description: One day in 1971, as Gene L. Grupposo recalls it, he an swered a classified advertise ment in a newspaper offering a salary of $17,600 to some one with avid civic some thing.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Noted Pakistani Politician Is Shot to Death in Lahore
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, Dec. 20 Khwaja Mohammed Rafiq, a prominent politician, was shot dead today by unknown assail ants in Lahore, capital of Pun jab Province.

title: Britain to Give Bahamas Independence in July '73
description: LONDON, Dec. 20Britain agreed today to end almost 200 years rule in the Bahamas and to grant the islands independ ence next July.

title: Business Briefs
description: BRUSSELS, Dec. 20 (UPI)The European Common Market's last meeting before its enlargement from six to nine nations ended at dawn today after an allnight dispute over whisky, wine and beef.

title: Algeria Executes Kidnapper
description: ALGIERS, Dec. 20 (Agence FrancePresse)  A kidnapper and bank robber was executed by a firing squad here early today. President Houari Bou mediene yesterday rejected a plea for a reprieve by the prisoner, Ahmed Rachem.

title: Concessions by Both Sides Reported Urged by Nixon
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, Doc. 21Official South Vietnamese sources said today that President Nixon had urged both North Vietnam and South Vietnam to make con cessions toward a peace settle ment.

title: HANOI iS BLAMED
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20The Defense Department said today that the intensive American bombing of North Vietnam in the last two days had caused very significant damage to a broad range of military targets.

title: Market Place: Beauty Salons: A Test for Avon
description: Not so many months ago, the people at Avon Products decided to venture into a tough new businessbeauty salons.

title: Astronaut to Visit Jordan
description: AMMAN, Jordan, Dec. 20 (Agence FrancePresse)  Col. James B. Irwin, the American astronaut, is due here tomor row as the guest of the Jor danian government. He will give talks about space travel and visit tourist spots.

title: Mrs. Cahill's Father Dies
description: PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 20 (UPI)Belford Myrtetus of Col ingswood, the fatherinlaw of Gov. William T. Cahill, died to day. He was 85 years old. Mr. Myrtetus was employed for many years by the Franklin Sugar Company of Philadelphia and, after his retirement, was with Holman Builders in Col lingwood. Besides Mrs. Cahill, he leaves his wife, the former Regina Blake; a son, 17 grand children and 18 greatgrand children.

title: More Degrees Here Than a Thermometer
description: News of Dogs

title: Mrs. JenningsJohnson Is Married
description: In the Friar's Chapel of St. Vincent Ferrer's Roman Catholic Church yesterday afternoon, Mrs. Anne Jen ningsJohnson, a stockbroker on leave of absence from Hardy & Co., was married to William Dawes Miller, a vice president of the Anaconda Company. The ceremony was performed by the Very Rev. Paul C. McKenna, pastor of the church.

title: U.S. REPORTS LOSS OF A FOURTH B52
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, Dec. 21A United States military spokesman dis closed this morning that a fourth B52 Stratofortress was struck by antiaircraft fire and crashed late last night as what is believed to be the heaviest bombing of the war apparently continued in North Vietnam.

title: WHEAT FUTURES STAGE RECOVERY
description: After several sessions of sharply declining prices, wheat, corn and soybeans jumped in price yesterday in futures trad ing on the Chicago Board of Trade.

title: Grants May Be Cut
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20In formed Administration officials said today it was plausible to assume that some categorical grant programs to state and lo cal governments would be lead ing candidates for paring in the budget decisions President Nix on was making.

title: Doctors Give Nixon a Top Rating in Checkup
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20  President Nixon flew to Key Biscayne today for a brief Christmas vacation after receiv ing an excellent rating in his annual physical examination.

title: Tapes Demanded by Jury
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 20 (AP) Jim Mitchell, a reporter for radio station KFWB, has been ordered by the county grand jury to produce tapes and notes of recent interviews he con ducted related to bail bond practices.

title: In Capitals, Bombing Draws Protests, Some Support
description: As waves of American planes continued to sweep over North Vietnam, new protests were voiced in many parts of the world yesterday against Presi dent Nixons decision to re sume the heavy attacks, but there were also some expres sions of support.

title: Concorde Flight Plans
description: PARIS, Dec. 20 (AP)  Air France announced today pre liminary plans for its first Con corde supersonic airliner serv icetwo flights a day to New York, two over the North Pole to Tokyo and six a week to South America. But the direc torgeneral, Pierre Cot, did not forecast any date for the open ing flights.

title: Hicke Stars for Flames
description: ATLANTA, Dec. 20 (AP) Ernie Hicke scored two goals tonight to lead the Atlanta Flames to a 53 victory over the Toronto Maple Leafs and into a fourthplace tie in the West Division.

title: Notes on People
description: At his last news confer ence as chief United States delegate to the United Na tions, George Bush discussed his selection as chairman of the Republican National Committee and the appoint ment of John Rail, a former television newsman, to re place him at the United Na tions.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: Dennis Weiglein, the for mer state trooper who was convicted of misconduct for his part in the alleged brand ing of a youth last February, was given a sixmonth sus pended sentence today by Judge William E. O'Connor Jr. in Ocean County Court.

title: Opposing Coaches Named For W.H.A. AllStar Game
description: Jack Kelley of the New Eng land Whalers and Winnipeg's team of Bobby Hull and Nick Mickoski will be the opposing coaches for the World Hockey Association AllStar Game on Jan. 6 in Quebec City, the league announced yesterday.

title: C.B.S. and Strikers Reach Tentative Pact in 6th Week
description: The Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service an nounced late last night that negotiators for the Columbia Broadcasting System and its striking technicians' union hadContinued on Page 71, Column 2 reached tentative agreement on a new contract.

title: Price Changes
description: Price increases in residual fuel oil and zinc, two major commodities, were announced yesterday.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: KNICKS SET BACK ROCKETS, 12412
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Dec. 20 Willis Reed, struggling to re gain his offensive power, hit a comeback high of 26 points. Dave DeBusschere, recovering from a Phoenix headache, was right with him with another 26 points. The Knicks took it from there to beat the Houston Rockets, 124102, in the Con vention Center Arena tonight to end a fivegame losing streak on the road.

title: Lilly's Back Spasms Send Cowboy Tackle to Hospital
description: DALLAS, Dec. 20 (AP)Bob Lilly, allpro defensive tackle of the Dallas Cowboys, was taken to Baylor Hospital to night after suffering back spasms during practice.

title: Manila Suspends Curbs on Debating New Constitution
description: MANILA, Dec. 20President Ferdinand E. Marcos today or dered a suspension of martial law restraints on debate on the proposed new constitution.

title: JACQUES DUAL, PLAYWRIGHT, 82
description: PARIS, Dec. 20  Jacques Deval, the playwright of boule vard fame, died here yesterday at his home from hemiplegia. He was 82 years old.

title: N.C.R. TO REPORT A LOSS FOR 1972
description: The National Cash Register Company, directed by a new president and financial vice president, announced yesterday that it would cut its 1972 earn ings by $60millionits second big writeoff in two yearsand report a loss for the year.

title: Personal Income Up
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 Personal income rose strongly further in November after a big jump in October, the Com merce Department reported to day.

title: Moscow Rejects Request
description: LONDON, Dec. 20  The So viet Union today refused a British request to help trace the origin of Russianmade rocket launchers being used by Irish Republican Army terrorists in Northern Ireland.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, Dec. 20 After defying orders to end a cafeteria sitin and report to their classrooms this morning, five New Brunswick High School students were arrested and taken to the Middlesex County youth center for deten tion.

title: Ellsberg Calls Use of Subpoena Illegal
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 20  The Government was accused in the Pentagon papers easel today of illegally using a grand jury subpoena issued in Boston to give the Federal Bu reau of Investigation leads in investigating the case here.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: NEWARK, Dec. 20The ne gotiating committee sent into Rahway Prison by Governor Cahill after the Thanksgiving riot a year ago reported today that the Governor had not made adequate progress in re solving the problems uncov ered at that time.

title: Syracuse 7362 Victor
description: SYRACUSE, N. Y., Dec. 20 (AP)  Syracuse, with three men in double figures, defeated Penn State, 7362, tonight for its 24th consecutive homecourt victory.

title: British Urban Planner Uneasy Over Change
description: LONDON, Dec. 20  Sir Cohn Buchanan is Britain's most eminent urban planner. His business is to devise large changes in the appear ance of thingsbut change torments him.

title: US, INDICTS EIGHT IN SALE OF STOCK IN NURSING HOMES
description: Federal charges of a massive stock fraud that allegedly cost investors $200million were filed yesterday against top of ficials of a bankrupt nursing home corporation, officers of a major brokerage company and partners in a national account ing firm.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: 2d Catholic Church to Close School

title: U.S. GAINS SEEN IN WORLD TRADE
description: PARIS, Dec. 19The United States has improved its com petitive position in world com merce by 11 to 12 per cent over the last two years, a fac tor that should eventually lead to an $8billion improvement in its balanceofpayments ac counts, according to interna tional economic authorities.

title: British Plan Legislation
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Dec. 20  A British Govern ment commission today recom mended major changes in the judicial system in Northern Ire land to combat terrorism.

title: RANGERS TRIUMPH OVER BLUES BY 54
description: ST. LOUIS, Dec. 20 (AP) Pete Stemkowski scored two goals tonight and assisted on the clincher by Bruce Mac Gregor as the New York Rang ers downed the St. Louis Blues, 54.

title: SAIGON REPORTS ON TWO BATTLES
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, Dec. 21 (UPI)  Heavy ground fighting was re ported yesterday on South Viet nam's northernmost front, with two battles fought near Quang Tri city.

title: U.S. Tobacco Elects New Chief Executive
description: Directors of the United States Tobacco Company yes terday elected Milton Rothen berg as chairman and chief executive officer and Louis F. Bantle as president and chief operating officer, effective Jan. 1.

title: 23 RIGHTS WORKERS LOSE COURT APPEAL
description: NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 20 (AP)  In an 11to4 decision the United States Court of Ap peals, for the Fifth Circuit said today that 23 civil rights work ers arrested in Mississippi on what they called pretext charges must stand trial in state courts.

title: Last of Australians Home From Vietnam To Muted Welcome
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Dec. 20 The last Australian troops in Vietnam came home today to muted welcome, ending a 10 year commitment that had divided the nation.

title: Cambodia Endorses Move
description: Special to The New York TimesPHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Dec. 20The Cambodian Gov ernment today endorsed the re sumption of fullscale bombing of North Vietnam by the United States as a necessary step to force Hanoi to adopt a more conciliatory attitude at the negotiating table.

title: American Can and Soviet Sign Technology Accord
description: The American Can Company announced yesterday that it had signed a threeyear ex change agreement with the So viet Union covering container and packaging technology.

title: EUROPE TO JOIN POSTAPOLLO PLAN
description: BRUSSELS, Dec. 20Repre sentatives of 12 nations at a European space conference agreed today in principle to participate in the American postApollo program and also to support a French plan to build a European booster rocket.

title: To Her, a Holiday Feast Represents a Gift, Too
description: Christmas won't be Christ mas without food in great, heaping, abundant masses. And who should know better how to make a banquet than a native of Rome's Trastevere district, where the very streets are restaurants and every night is a moveable feast?

title: Equity Financing
description: The Peoples Gas Company filed with the Se curities and Exchange Commission in connection with a public offering, expected on or about Jan. 16, 1973, of 1,350,000 shares of common stock. The First Boston Corporation will head an under writing group, The company's stock closed on the New York Stock Exchange at 37, down ??.

title: Live Radioactive Pellet Exposed for Five Hours
description: A tiny radioactive pellet was exposed for about five hours at First Avenue and 93d Street yesterday because of a kink in a small cable of an Xray device that work men were using to test the weld on a 30inch under ground gas main.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: TRENTON, Dec. 20  The director of the state's new restaurant inspection program said today that preliminary in dications were that about 39 per cent of the restaurants in spected were being given con ditionally satisfactory ratings, indicating that some unsanitary conditions existed.

title: Music: Sharp Contrast
description: Offhand, it would be diffi cult to think of two 20th century chamber music works more startingly un alike in philosophy, tech nique, mood and sound than Messiaen's Quatuor pour la Fin du Temps and George Rochberg's new Electrika leidoscope. The Aeolian Chamber Players brought the two together in a concert at Town Hall on Tuesday night, and the contrast between them was so radical as to be almost shocking.

title: Adelphi Trounces Hunter
description: GARDEN CITY, L. I., Dec. 20Don Galloway scored 33 points, 21 in the first half, as Ade1phi overpowered Hunter tonight, 9462, at Woodruff Hall. Galloway made 15 of 20 field goal attempts leading the Panthers to a blazing 63.4 per cent shooting average.

title: Meets That Premier Today
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Dec. 20 (AP)General Haig arrived. in Bangkok from Vientiane to day.

title: Pensioner, 81, Can't Forget Neediest
description: Corinna Marsh of 12 East 31st Street sent The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund a check yesterday with regret that it represented only half of her usual $10.

title: Salt Lake City Interested In Holding Winter Games
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Dec. 20 (UPI)Mayor E. J. Garn says Salt Lake City is still inter ested in the 1976 Winter Olym pic Games; but not without fi nancial assistance.

title: Two Airport Guards at Kennedy Shot; Veteran Seized in Struggle on a Ramp
description: A Vietnam veteran who had twice fled Rockland State Hos pital after confinement for men tal illness shot and wounded two Federal security officers at Kennedy International Air port yesterday with a gun grabbed from one of the guards, the police reported.

title: RENT LAW SCORED AT HEARING HERE
description: Tenants and landlords joined yesterday in denouncing the city's Maximum Base Rent Law, but they disagreed over its re tention, in speeches at an all day hearing before the City Council.

title: Old German Buildings Burn
description: LUNEBURG, West Germany, Dec. 20 (Reuters)Fire swept through the old part of this medieval town early today, destroying 16thcentury build ings and causing damage esti mated at omre than $325,000.

title: Business Briefs
description: Roy D. Chapin, chairman of the American Motors Cor poration, Detroit, predicted yesterday that 1973 industry car sales would approach 11 million units compared with the record 10.7 million units sold in 1972. Demand for cars in the first quarter of the 1973 model year has continued strong, he said.

title: LAKERS TURN BACK BULLETS, 96 TO 90
description: BALTIMORE, Dec. 20 (AP) Jim McMillian and Wilt Cham berlain led a fourthquarter Los Angeles surge tonight as the Lakers pulled away for a 9690 National Basketball Association victory over the Baltimore Bullets.

title: F.P.C. Aide Recommends Rise in Natural Gas Rates
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (UPI)  The Federal Power Commission announced today an initial decision that could lead to rate increases for nat ural gas of up to IS per cent in the rich Permian Basin area of Texas and New Mexico.

title: Cahill Bars a Subsidy Rise Asked by Central Railroad
description: TRENTON, Dec. 20  Governor Cahill rejected de mands by the Central Railroad of New Jersey for a tripling of its annual state subsidy today and indicated that he and the Legislature were prepared to let the bankrupt railroad aban don its New Jersey passenger service next month.

title: The Boss Said Buy  and They Certainly Did
description: PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 20  Soon after the doors opened for business yester day, the millionaire president and the seven female em ployes of First Fidelity Mort gage Corporation vanished from the office into the warm, drowsy morning.

title: Delayed Candidacy of Warren Spahn
description: Sports of The Times

title: India and Pakistan Report Their Armies' Withdrawal
description: RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, Dec. 20 (AP)The chiefs of staff of the Indian and Pakistani armies have reported that their forces have withdrawn from occupied territory and returned to their International borders a joint statement said tonight.

title: People and Business
description: Who's minding the Securi ties and Exchange Commis sion? That's the question some Wall Streeters are ask ing these days when they turn their eyes towards Washington and count the seats at the fiveman S.E.C.

title: Chess:
description: No Nei, who, with Efim Geller and Nikolai Krogius, made up Boris Spassky's analysis team for his ill fated world championship match with Bobby Fischer in Reykjavik, says Spassky often likes to play second best moves in the openings. He thereby avoids the battle of pregame preparation waged in so many tourna ments these days, hoping to find in the neglected greater scope for spontaneity and originality.

title: Retiring Prof. Hook Gives Class His Views
description: Prof. Sidney Hook of New York University did some thing in the classroom yes terday that he has prided himself on assiduously avoid ing during his 45 years as a teacher of philosophy. He gave his own opinions.

title: Mincher Quits Baseball
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Dec. 20 (UPI)Don Mincher, 34year old first baseman of the Oak land A's retired today after 11 years in the majors. He had a career batting average of .249.

title: U.S. INDICTS EIGHT IN SALE OF STOCK IN NURSING HOMES
description: Federal charges of a massive stock fraud that allegedly cost investors $200million were filed yesterday against top of ficials of a bankrupt nursing home corporation, officers of a major brokerage company and partners in a national account ing firm.

title: Carol Robinson Bride Of Dr. Arthur Perlman
description: At the Park East Syna gogue last evening, Miss Carol Robinson, a psychi atric social worker, was married to Dr. Arthur M. Perlman, a psychiatrist. Rab bi Arthur Schneier performed the ceremony.

title: BERRIGAN FREED AFTER 39 MONTHS
description: DANBURY, Conn., Dec. 20 The Rev. Philip Berrigan walk ed out of Federal prison here today after 39 months, and said he was determined to work within the limits of his parole to bring an end to the war in Southeast Asia.

title: Four Seasons Nursing Centers Stock Rode Classic Wall St. Roller Coaster
description: Four Seasons Nursing Cen ter of America hurtled into prominence in 1968 and col lapsed just as swiftly in 1970. In between, it was a darling of Wall Street.

title: Advertising:
description: After 14 years, the Sun Oil Company is moving its $8.5 million account out of the William Esty Company and into Wells, Rich, Greene.

title: FRANK HALE DIES; PLAYHOUSE OWNER
description: Frank J. Hale, owner and producer of the Royal Poinciana Playhouse in Palm Beach, Fla., died there yesterday, according to word received by associates here, He gave his age as 72.

title: Freedom in Contempt
description: A number of persons, some with close connections to the White House, were arrested and charged with a variety of criminal acts in the Watergate case of polit ical espionage. But a newspaper editor who participated not in the crime, but in its exposure, is the first actu ally sent to jail in the aftermath of the incident.

title: Mrs. King Sportswoman of Year
description: Billie Jean King was bub bling over with, joy, and it had nothing to do with an other tennis championship or another lucrative prize. In fact, there wasn't a tennis court in sight and it wasn't even tennis weather.

title: ATTICA PRISONERS SCORE TREATMENT
description: WARSAW, N. Y., Dec. 20 Fourteen prison inmates and former convicts accused of crimes in the 1971 Attica prison uprising charged today that they were suffering unfair pun ishment in the form of exces sive bail, segregated cells and lack of medical care.

title: Colts Discharge Sandusky And Five Assistant Coaches
description: BALTIMORE, Dec. 20 (AP) Joe Thomas, the Baltimore Colts' general manager, saying he wanted a new approach, a new look, announced today that he had dismissed the head coach, John Sandusky, and the other five members of the coaching staff.

title: 500 End Dock Strike
description: SAVANNAH, Dec. 20 (AP) About 500 striking longshore men returned to their jobs to clay after receiving Christmas bonus checks. A spokesman for the International Long shoremen's Union said that the men walked off their jobs yes terday when they failed to re ceive their bonus check, which averaged about $150.

title: Blind Stationer, Robbed 5 Times, Gets New Alarm
description: A group of people stood in the rain yesterday outside of Sarah Greenberg's newspaper stationery store at 1242 Am sterdam Avenue, across the street from Columbia Univer sity. One of her customers saw the crowd, rushed over and asked: What happened? An other mugging?

title: DR. MAURICE O'SHEA, SURGEON, DIES AT 69
description: Dr, Maurice Culmer O'Shea, physician and surgeon, died yesterday of heart failure in St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 69 years old and lived at 108 East Std Street.

title: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 20Gen. Alexander M. Haig Jr. met for half an hour today with President Nguyen Van Thieu. It was General Haig's second meeting with Mr. Thieu since he arrived here yes terday.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Now that the Long Island Rail Road has been on strike for more than a week I have a growing conviction that this facility is superfluous. Commuters (my husband is one) are experiencing little difficulty in getting to Manhat tan by other means of transportation. The buses that are provided for Nas sau and Suffolk commuters should re main a permanent facility, and the longdiscussed use of the third lane of the Long Island Expressway should now be implemented. As far as the tracks of the railroad are concerned, either cement them over or use them for an extension of the subway system.

title: Film Critic Says Deep Throat Could Expand Sexual Horizons
description: Prof. Arthur Knight of the University of Southern Cali fornia testified in Manhattan Criminal Court yesterday that the hardcore pornographic film Deep Throat had redeeming social value because it might encourage people to expand their sexual horizons.

title: Soviet Urges Speedy Truce
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 20The So viet Union reiterated today its call for a speedy signing by Washington of the ceasefire accord negotiated in Paris last October.

title: As Lenin Saw It
description: MOSCOW  MarxismLeninism is based on the fact that boundaries of the working class are extended as the social division of labor grows and scientific and technological progress accelerates, As the cooperative char acter of the laborprocess becomes more and more marked, Karl Marx wrote, so, as a necessary conse quence, does our notion of productive labor, and of its agent the productive laborer, become extended. The in creased importance of trades demand ing skills and of intellectual factors in the laborprocess, as in present social production as a whole, is no surprise for scientific socialism.

title: City PeepShow Law Disputed, As Lawyer Cites Court Ruling

description: TRENTON, Dec. 20 (AP) Joseph F. Steliga of Trenton was named today as acting ombudsman for the New Jersey prison system, including the prisons in Trenton, Rahway and Leesburg.

title: LONG BEACH FIVE WINS FINAL, 9770
description: UNIONDALE. L.I., Dec. 20 Unbeaten Long Beach State, the nation's sixthranked col lege basketball team, added the Nassau Coliseum's tournament to its list of conquests tonight and followed a familiar pattern in defeating Jacksonville, 9770.

title: Tass Reports From Hanoi: Heavy Civilian Casualties
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 20Tass, the Soviet press agency, reported from Hanoi today that the latest American air raids there had caused heavy civilian casual ties and destroyed thousands of homes.

title: Article 4  No Title
description: MILWAUKEE, Dec. 20 (AP) Kareem AbdulJabbar scored 44 points and grabbed 21 re bounds tonight as the Milwau kee Bucks pulled away in the second half for a 123104 vic tory over the Portland Trail Blazers. The Bucks increased their Midwest Division lead to three games with their fifth consecutive victory.

title: For 'Gamma Rays,' Another Opening . . .
description: Beatrice Hunsdorfer (Joanne Woodward) is the classic gum-chewing, chain-smoking, whisky-swilling, snappy retorting American mother-frump, equally beloved by certain playwrights and by actresses, especially actresses who like to get their hands, feet, hair, body and teeth into a role.Beatrice is a mess. When we first see her in Paul Newman's film version of Paul Zindel's Pulitzer Prize-winning play, "The Effect of Gamma Rays on Man-in-the Moon Marigolds," she's at the local variety store trying on wigs. Should she buy a black Gina Lollobrigida type, perhaps? A red Afro? She finally picks a spectacularly ill-fitting platinum-blond one that recalls the life and times of Carole Landis.It's difficult to believe that Beatrice, even as dumb as she's supposed to be, could have anything in mind but laughs when she puts it on. Which is one of the basic problems with frump plays as serious drama. How much of the time do we laugh at the frumps, and how much of the time with them?Mr. Zindel's play, it seemed to me, never quite made up its mind. Beatrice never stopped talking and much of what she said was funny in the manner of the insults of a quick-witted drag queen. The play wanted us to be shocked by Beatrice's various cruelties to others as well as to herself; yet it also wanted us to feel pity. For me, however, Beatrice, has always been less a character than a theatrical clich.It isn't life that's stacked the cards against her, but, first, the playwright and now the film-makers.Beatrice lives in a rundown neighborhood in a rundown city (actually Bridgeport, Conn., which isn't all that run down) and keeps her rundown car in the rundown driveway. When she walks through her house, she's up to her hips in domestic debris, including rabbit droppings. She dreams of putting her family, as she describes it, back on the map by opening a tearoom specializing in cheese cake.Beatrice, as is usually the case in this sort of drama (which might better be called domestic disappointment than domestic tragedy), inhabits a world abandoned by men. Her husband is dead, and the men she does come upon are unfeeling creeps, though Beatrice is not the sort of woman to evoke more than passing lust.She has two teen-age daughters, one of whom, Ruthie (Roberta Wallach), is run down to the point of apparently being an epileptic. The other daughter, Matilda (Nell Potts), is the surprising mutant suggested by the title, a sweet, inquiring intelligence, whose winning of the highschool science prize prompts what dramatic development there is in the film."The Effect of Gamma Rays" is not a stupid film. The talents of everyone connected with it are unmistakable, including those of Mr. Newman, a director of plain, straight style. It's just that the basic material calls for a kind of second-rate bravura performance from everyone, from the production designer to the actors. There's no way to underplay it.At times I had the feeling that Miss Woodward was auditioning for the role of Sadie Thompson, and that Miss Wallach was occasionally in competition. Only Nell Potts (in private life, the daughter of Miss Woodward and Mr. Newman) is allowed to perform at something like a reasonable pace. It's a lovely, solemn performance in a film that otherwise succeeds in being simultaneously too barren and too busy, like Beatrice herself.

title: YankMet Series by '73 on Special Baseball Agendal
description: Major league baseball club owners have been summoned to a meeting in Chicago Jan 11 and 12 to discuss interleague competition and adoption of designated pinchhitterforthe pitcher rule.

title: The 45 Percenters
description: A formal study, complete with detailed traffic sur veys, has produced the unsurprising statistic that as many as 45 per cent of all private vehicles parked in Manhattan are parked illegally. The Traffic Action Com mittee, organized by a number of business groups in the city, points out that New York's vital midtown arteries have become hardened with the bumperto bumper steel of stationary vehicles, some at curbside, some doubleparked, some even tripleparked and block ing centerlane traffic.

title: OTC AND AMEX SHOW DECLINES
description: Stocks on the overthecoun ter market and the American Stock Exchange declined for the third consecutive session yesterday in increased trading.

title: OFFICIALS CERTIFY MINERS' ELECTION
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20  The Labor Department today formally certified to United States District Judge William B. Bryant the victory in the United Mine Workers' election earlier this month of Arnold R. Miller, the rankandfile insur gent challenger to the former president, W. A. Boyle.

title: FUNDS POST RISE IN REDEMPTIONS
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (Reu ters)Mulual fund redemptions exceeded sales by $258million in November, as sales rose only slightly while redemptions soared to a sevenmonth high, the Investment Company Insti tute reported today, In October net redemptions totaled $27 million.

title: ISRAEL TO ACCEPT KAHANE AS CITIZEN
description: JERUSALEM, Dec. 20 (AP) The Interior Ministry agreed today to grant citizenship to Rabbi Meir Kahane, leader of the militant Jewish Defense League.

title: TRUMAN DOCTORS TRY NEW METHOD
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Dec. 20 (AP)Former President Harry S. Truman remained in very serious condition tonight, and doctors tried a new approach to reduce the level of poison in his bloodstream caused by deteriorating kidney functions.

title: Radioactive Pellet Lost, Police Evacuate Area
description: Workmen using an Xray device to test the weld on an underground gas main at 93d Street and First Avenue yes terday afternoon accidently lost a tiny radioactive pellet, prompting the police to evac uate buildings and close off streets.

title: 9 KILLED AS JETS COLLIDE ATO;HARE
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 20A North Central Airlines DC9 jet, tak ing off in heavy fog, hit a Delta Air Lines Convair 880 to night at Chicago's O'Hare In ternational Airport.

description: Resumed negotiations in the Long Island Rail Road strike broke up after little more than an hour last night, with the parties agreeing that no prog ress had been made toward a settlement.

McLaughlin of Suffolk Superior Court reduced a death penalty sentence today to life imprisonment and there by denied a motion for a new trial sought by William M. Gilday, 43 years old, convicted of murder in the shooting death of a policeman during a bank holdup.

description: PEKING, Dec. 20China ac cused the United States today of having committed a new barbarous crime with its in tensified bombing of North Vietnam and declared that it would never succeed in impos ing peace terms unacceptable to Hanoi.

title: Dreams Are hat a Feminist Group's Plays Are Made Of

title: Charity Outmoded?
description: When disaster occurs and fire or flood sweeps over part of a community, it is the government's responsi bility to declare an emergency, fight the catastrophe and relieve the misery. But at the immediate moment of need, the help that counts most to the individual distress comes usually from more fortunate neighbors.

title: Canisius in 10771 Rout
description: LORETTO, Pa., Dec. 20 (UPI) Mel Montgomery scored a gamehigh 26 points and Mike Macaluso added 22 tonight as Canisius outclassed St, Francis, 10771. Canisius took the lead for good with four minutes gone in the game in posting its second victory against two losses.

title: Violin Debut
description: The flow of fine perform ers from Japan to this coun try never seems to end. Tues day night at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, Hamao Fuji wara made his New York re cital debut and proved to be still another firstclass violin ist to come from across the Pacific. A pupil of Toshiya Eto in his native country and of Joseph Fuchs at the Juil liard School here, he won third prize in last year's Queen Elisabeth Internation al Music Competition in Bel gium.

title: Haiti Says She Will Free 72
description: SANTO DOMINGO, Domin ican Republic, Dec, 20 (UPI) The Haitian Government radio has announced the release of 72 political prisoners in the second amnesty granted by President JeanClaude Duvalier in the last month. The broad cast yesterday, monitored in this neighboring republic, said the amnesty had been an nounced by the Haitian Infor mation Minister, Fritz Cinas.

description: District Attorney Eugene Gold of Brooklyn called on New Yorkers yesterday to sup port cable campaign on be half of Soviet Jews urging am nesty for 47 prisoners of conscience.

title: People in Sports: After 12 Years, Kilmer Is AllStar
description: It took 12 topsyturvy years and an injury to the firststring quarterback, but Billy Kilmer yesterday finally made the allstar team. He was named the National Con ference's No. 1 quarterback for the Pro Bowl on Jan. 21 by a coaches' Doll. The 33 yearold Kilmer started the National Football League campaign as the Washington Redskins' quarterback, but after a loss to New England, Sonny Jurgensen replaced him.

title: A.B.C. Warns N.B.C. on '76 Olympics
description: The American Broadcasting Company yesterday warned the National Broadcasting Company not to do anything which might interfere with its con tract for television rights for the 1976 Summer Olympics in Montreal.

title: ROSE CHALLENGED ON LINDSAY ROLE
description: Two Liberal party county chairmen yesterday openly challenged Alex Rose, the party's state leader, and de clared that they would fight any attempt to renominate Mayor Lindsay on the Liberal line next year.

title: First Things First
description: President Nixon, we are delighted to learn, is a veritable tiger when it comes to at least one aspect of the First Amendment. Those who have shared our doubts about the President's devotion to the public's right to know will take comfort from the announce ment that Mr. Nixon is ready to use all his clout to fight a blackout of information in Washington and three other major cities.

title: ALEXANDER UNINSKY
description: DALLAS, Dec. 20 (AP)Alex ander Uninsky, wellknown Rus sian concert artist who was professor of piano at Southern Methodist University, was found dead at his home here last evening. He was 62 years old.

title: Parish Case Slated Jan. 4
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 21 (UPI) Don Parish linebacker of the Denver Broncos, was ordered today to appear in Superior Court Jan. 4 on a charge of possessing cocaine. Parish was arrested at Los Angeles Inter national Airport Nov. 13 after a search of his possessions al legedly turned up a vial con taining 13 grams of cocaine valued at $1,170.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The State Insurance Department scheduled a public hearing for Jan. 11 on a rate increase application filed by United Medical Service, the Blue Shield plan covering the 17county New York metropolitan area.

title: City Council Panel Scores OTB On Use of Provisional Employes
description: Mrs. Aileen Ryan, chairman of a City Council committee investigating alleged abuse in the hiring of provisional em ployes by city agencies, con tended yesterday that the Offtrack Betting Corporation was seeking in its hiring to establish an autonomy not an swerable to city and state Civil Service commissions.

title: Pentagon Won't Halt B52 Attacks Despite Losses
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 Defense Department officials said today that B52 bombers would continue to be used against heavily defended tar gets in the Hanoi area despite the heavy losses of the last three days.

title: Connecticut Youth Is Held On Counterfeiting Charge
description: ORANGE, Conn., Dec. 21 (AP)A West Haven youth was arrested today in connec tion with counterfeit $10 bills that have been circulating across Connecticut, the police said.

title: Playoffs: 3 Close Games And Dolphins vs. Browns
description: About Pro Football

title: 2 Antipoverty Workers Cleared Of Contempt in Balking Senators
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (AP) The United States Court of Appeals cleared two former Kentucky antipoverty workers yesterday of contempt of Con gress for refusing to turn docu ments over to a Senate sub committee investigating riots.

title: Encounter
description: PLAINFIELD, N. J.  Ivan stopped short and reached up his baby arms to the little boy passing on the sidewalk. A smile of embarrassed pleasure lit up the boy's face as he lifted and cuddled my oneyearold son.

title: WHEAT FUTURES RISE DAILY LIMIT
description: Prices of March and May de livery wheat rose the 10cent abushel daily limit yesterday in active trading on the Chi cago Board of Trade. Prices closed at upthelimit levels, Ibut still ran about 13 cents a bushel below contract highs made recently.

title: STEEL REVAMPING IS SET IN BRITAIN
description: LONDON, Dec. 21The Gov ernment announced today a major modernization plan for the nationalized steel industry that will require the invest ment of $7.05billion over the next decade and the trimming of 30,000 jobs from the present labor force of 210,000.

title: Spencer's Tally Gains Deadlock in Nassau, 44
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., Dec. 21 Finally displaying attacking poweralthough usually fail ing to put home the puck de spite a wideopen netthe Is landers skated to a 44 tie tonight with the Vancouver Canucks.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: CAIRO, Dec. 21 (AP)Harvard's rowing team regis tered a fourth victory on the Nile River today, racing against the combined opposition of Yale, Oxford, Cambridge and teams from two Egyptian universities.

title: Hanoi Charges Insolence
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 21 (AP)  North Vietnam said tonight that it would not he intimidated by a reported ulti matum from President Nixon to sign a peace agreement or face continued heavy air and naval attacks.

title: The Triboro Trick
description: The political cynicism or the state legisiative reappor tionment that produced an impossibletorepresent tri boro Congressional district several years ago is about to be repeated on the local level, In expanding its mem bership from 37 to 43 seats, the City Council has pro posed a new triboro Councilmanic district. This proposal runs counter to every criterion of good government well as to the rationale that led to expansion of the Council in the first place.

title: Tams Defeat Chaparrals
description: DALLAS, Dec. 21 (AP)  George Thompson scored 36 points and guided the Memphis Tams to a 131118 triumph over the Dallas Chaparrals to night.

title: Dr. Scribner Steps Down
description: Chancellor Harvey B. Scribner will relinquish the top leadership post of the city's school system al the expira tion of his contract on June 30 because he believes that a widening gap of confidence has been created between him and the Board of Education. The decision, though an honorable one characteristic of this straight forward public figure, is nevertheless extremely regret table, all the more so because it could have been pre vented.

title: CityBacked Private Drive on Midtown Crime Opens
description: Business executives and union leaders, strongly backed by Mayor Lindsay and police officials, opened a drive yesterday against mid town crime that is designed to involve thousands of workers and residents as an auxiliary police army. With walkietalkies and code num hers, the policetrained volun teers will watch streets, lobbies, corridors, offices and elevators, and report imme diately to the police any in dication of a crime. The start of the campaign against crime, to which a coalition of 100 prominent businessmen has pledged an open check book, was announced at a news conference in the West 35th Street police station, where a wide assortment of locks was displayed. Mayor Lindsay, in praising the cam paign, which may be extended to other parts of the city, said, The war on crime can only be effective if we have the strong involvement of the public in every way.

title: Former Rhodes Scholar Headed Study Group
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 The study group of the De partment of Health, Education and Welfare that turned out the Work in America study was headed by Dr. James O'Toole, formerly the coordi nator of field investigations for the President's Commis sion on Campus Unrest.

title: Middleton Helps Brooklyn Beat C.C.N.Y. Five, 7770
description: Ed Middleton scored 34 points and led Brooklyn College to a 7770 basketball victory over City College at C. C. N. Y. yes terday. The victory was the eighth for Brooklyn in 10 games.

title: 2 Germanys Sign Their Treaty; Reshaping of Border Next Step
description: BERLIN, Dec. 21The two Germanys signed their treaty on basic relations today, for mally ending more than two decades of mutual enmity.

title: CHARTER HEARINGS ENDED IN QUEENS
description: Residents and officials of Queens aired widely varying views on the structure of city government before the State Charter Revision Commission yesterday as the state body concluded its hearings in the borough.

title: Julie Harris Styles Mrs. Lincoln From the Heart Out
description: Dressed for the part of that Cosmopolitan Girl, she swings into Ruby Foo's Rest aurant on West 52d Street in a sporty leatherandred fox coat and laced white boots, a crocheted wool cap on her straighthanging pale red hair. She wears also an applegreen turtelneck, topped with a shrink sweater and a necklace of charms, and a midi skirt of green and purple plaid.

title: 11 IN CONGRESS URGE ANTIBOMBING STAND
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (AP) The House Democratic cau cus will he asked at its Jan. 2 meeting before the opening of the new Congress to go on record against the renewed bombing of North Vietnam, it was announced today.

title: Antiblackout Suit Dismissed for a Day
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (AP)  A suit challenging the local television blackout of Sunday's National Football League play off game between the Green Bay Packers and the Washing ton Redskins has been redrawn and a new hearing set for to morrow afternoon, the plaintiff, Robin Ficker, said today.

title: 30 STATES SEEKING WELFARE HEARINGS
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 Thirty states asked the Federal Government today to hold pub lic hearings before the Depart ment of Health, Education and Welfare reduces aid to state welfare programs.

title: Business Briefs
description: LONDON, Dec. 21 (AP)The British Government tightened its credit squeeze still further today, ordering banks and finance houses to turn over to the Bank of England another 2 per cent of all money deposited with them.

title: Transistor's 25th Birthday Is Marked
description: Twentyfive years ago to morrow the universe began to grow much smaller with the age of electronic minia turization.

title: People in Sports: Jets Honor Team Critic
description: John Biggins, the Jets' run ning back who blasted his teammates earlier in the sea son for relying too much on the arm of Joe Namath, has been selected by his mates as the team's most valuable player for 1972. Namath, the Jets' M.V.P. in 1968 and 1969, finished second in the ballot ing conducted by the News paper Enterprise Association.

title: Music: Berlioz's Christ
description: Since the Little Orchestra is recapitulating its past accom plishments in celebration of its 25th anniversary season, the performance of Berlioz's L'Enfance du Christ that it gave at Philharmonic Hall on Wednesday night was cer tainly to be expected.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: JERSEY CITY, Dec. 21 City officials said today that they were stunned by the American Can Company's an nouncement that it would move its aerosolcan operations to Edison in Middlesex County beginning April 1.

title: Strauss Journeys To Meet Wallace On Unity in Party
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Dec. 21 The Democratic National Chairman, Robert Strauss, met for an hour today with Gov. George C. Wallace, and after ward at the Alabama Gover nor's Mansion seemed to leave the door ajar for Mr. Wallace as a possible Democratic Presi dential nominee in 1976.

title: Comment by Grumman
description: BETHPAGE, L. I., Dec. 21 A spokesman for the Grumman Corporation said today that the loans about which Senator Proxmire complained were es sentially advance payments for work being performed for the Navy.

title: Inaugural Events to Put Accent on Youth
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 A large contingent of Ameri ca's youth will troop into Washington for President Nixon's second inauguration next month. Some will come by special invitation only. The others will come to protest Government policies.

title: Roberta Peters's Mother Dies
description: Mrs. Ruth Hirsch Peterman, wife of Sol Peterman, a shoe company executive, and moth er of Roberta Peters, Metropoli tan opera soprano, died yester day in Doctors Hospital. She was 65 years old and lived at 315 East 86th Street.

title: Wednesday's Fight

title: AllOut Attack Reported
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Dec. 21 (Reuters)The Cam bodian command said today that. North Vietnamese forces began an allout attack last night on Kompong Thom, the provincial capital 77 miles north of here that has been under siege since Dec. 7.

title: Underground Nuclear Test
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (Reu ters)The United States con ducted today a weaponsrelated underground nuclear explosion at its test site in Nevada, the Atomic Energy Commission an nounced here. It was in the range of 20 to 200 kilotrons which is the equivalent of up to 200,000 tons of TNT.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: MIDDLETOWN, N.J., Dec. 21  Residents of New Jersey shore communities, led by Rep resentative James J. Howard, voiced opposition tonight to an Army plan to build a deep water facility to receive crude oil from tankers 13 miles off Long Branch.

title: Jobs Are for Fathers of Welfare Children
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21The Work in America study is sued today by the Department of Health, Education and Wel fare has a proposal to end the, welfare mess: Guarantee de cent, wellpaying jobs to the fathers of all children whose mothers are on welfare. At the same time, stop trying to force welfare mothers to go to work.

title: Film: 'Jeremiah Johnson':Robert Redford Stars as Man of Legend
description: "Ride due west as the sun sets; turn left at the Rocky Mountains . . ." And following these directions, young Jeremiah Johnson begins his search for "bear, beaver and other critters worth cash for trapping." It is to become a lifetime journey, a total redefinition of the man. It takes him into a beautiful, awesome, often terrifying wilderness  a wilderness that is curiously full of people, many of them dead.Jeremiah achieves his own position in the wilderness. He loses track of time. He gets a wife, a squaw, and loses her too  slaughtered by Crow Indians. He makes a kind of spiritual contact with the mountains that surround him (there is no making peace with them), though he lives in such intimacy with trouble that he no longer knows what trouble is. Eventually he wins fame in defending himself from Crows, and his very enemies come to revere himthough whether as one of the immortals or as a man they consider already dead, nobody can say. Thus he becomes a legend in his own time.The quality of legend pervades Sydney Pollack's "Jeremiah Johnson," which stars Robert Redford in a role that must be very real to his own mind and feelings. It is a very attractive role, and Redford plays it with a reticence and directness that also seem as much a part of the man as of the performance. That it does not succeed entirely is perhaps less the fault of the actor or of the conception than of a screenplay that tends to be ponderous about its imponderables and that every so often sounds as if it might have been written by the authors of the Bible.The action takes place some time in the 19th century, though after which war, it is difficult to say. To replace the more usual affairs of men, the film concentrates on the power of nature, or the powers that simple men can wrest from nature, and, almost unavoidably, it keeps giving the impression of a literary interpretation of its materials. This is not the only impression, but it is the one underlined by the rhetoric of Pollack's film-making  by his heavy montage, his treatment of landscape, his calculated merging of people and places through interminable lap dissolves.But for all its involvement with academic cinema art, "Jeremiah Johnson" is full of compensations. There are momoments of great beauty and terror and deeply earned pathos. There are as well such not-so-incidental pleasures as John Rubinstein's lovely and serviceable musical score, and a cast of excellent supporting actors.And at a rather important level I can only honor a movie that introduces a French-speaking Indian chief named Two-Tongues Lebeaux (Richard Angarola), or that offers one old trapper (Will Geer) a chance to reverse Shakespeare's most famous stage direction, as he enters, pursued by a bear."Jeremiah Johnson" opened yesterday at Loew's Tower East Theater.

title: Miss Berger Married To Josef Mittlemann
description: Miss Marsy Beatrice Ber ger, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Seymour A, Berger of Old Westbury, L. I., was married here yesterday evening to Josef Mittlemann, son of Mr. and Mrs. David Mittlemann of Forest Hills, Queens. title: Bergman's New Cries and Whispers
description: Set in a tranquil autumn park is a handsome 18th century Swedish manor house, every room of which is decorated in a shade of red. Walls, rugs, draperies, even the blankets in the bed rooms. Depending on the light, the red may look as dark as dried blood or as brilliantly scarlet as a new azalea. The time is the turn of the century, at the end of a long night. Agnes (Harriet Andersson) awakens, moves her head fretfully from side to side on the pillow, then gets out of bed and goes to her desk. In her diary she writes: It is early Monday morning and I am in pain.

title: Veedem Leaves Racing Post
description: BOSTON, Dec. 21 (AP) Thomas J. Veedem is stepping down as general manager of Suffolk Downs, the track's own ers announced today. Joseph E. Cresci, the president of Ogden Recreation Corporation and Suf folk Downs, said. Veedem would be succeeded by Edward J. Sull ivan. Cresci said Veedem would stay on in a consulting capacity.

title: Still, Life
description: RIDGEFIELD, Conn.As I walked up the woodroad away from my car, parked arbitrarily in the middle of the lane, the grass between the ruts crunched beneath my boots. Though it would be sere and pale brown after the sun struck it, it was now frosted white with tiny icy crystals and snapped under my weight, and left behind me a procession of unsteady footprints. First snow had come in November, early, a transcient phenom enon, prelude to the genuine winter of the Litchfield Hills that was soon so come. On my right, blackened ar butus leaves testified to the brief visitation, but a patch of wintergreen leaves, catching the introductory rays of sunlight, displayed their promise of life everlasting, pledging red berries in spring.

I., Dec. 21 The Breakers, famous New port mansion built by Cor nelious Vanderbilt in 1895, was purchased today by the Preservation Society of New port County from the heirs of the late Countess Szechen yi, the former Gladys Vander bilt, for $365,000. title: The Screen:Borodin's 'Prince Igor' Comes From Soviet
description: The dichotomy between movies and opera is obvious, but let's cheerfully note that the different media have been effectively welded in the 1969 Soviet-made "Prince Igor," which had its local premiere yesterday at the Regency. The Borodin opera, a staple onu the Russian boards but rarely done here, evolves as an eye-catching, event-filling, vintage folk adventure in film term that neatly complements the music, singers and dancers.The libretto of the opera (last staged here in 1969) basically may be a stylized, certainly unfamiliar mlange of battles between 12th-century Russian and Oriental chieftains and of court intrigue and romance. But with stilted, archaic English lyrics and a workmanlike script, the opera is projected in fairly cohesive sequences on screen.The acting principals are attractive professionals, who are only rarely hammy, even in closeups. And the use of what to untrained ears are fine vocalists to do their singing off-screen seems natural and logical, especially with the expert help of the Kirov Opera chorus, ballet and orchestra to back them up.Contributing lively, if serious, portrayals are Boris Khmelnitsky, as the proud, unconquerable Prince Igor, Bimbibulat Valayev, as his generous captor; I. Morgoyeva, as that Oriental chieftain's pretty daughter who falls in love with Igor's son; and Nelly Pshennaya, as Igor's steadfast princess.Under the direction of Roman Tikhomirov (he also filmed "Eugene Onegin" and "Pique Dame"), Borodin's score (themes of which were used in Broadway's "Kismet") and the Polovtsian Dances, come across tunefully and vividly. In using an imposing array of athletic Oriental dancers, as well as the ballet, it becomes an especially vigorous, strikingly exotic display.The camera, or course, is not bound by the confines of an opera house proscenium. And the varied action, filmed in pastel shades, is sweeping and colorful against backgrounds of steppes, rivers, a primitive town and clashing horsemen.As a movie, "Prince Igor" naturally is not standard screen fare. But it entertainingly succeeds in avoiding the static, stagy look of many previously filmed operas.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: ROME, Dec. 21The pub lic prosecutor's office at the Rome criminal tribunal to night ordered immediate sei zure of Bernardo Bertolucci's film Last Tango in Paris on the ground of obscenity.

title: MORE DRUG LOSSES EXPECTED IN TALLY
description: Law enforcement officials said yesterday that far more drugs had been stolen from the New York Police Department than the 169 pounds of heroin and 131 pounds of cocaine reported to date.

description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (AP) An Immigration and Natural ization Service hearing officer has ruled that three Cuban fishermen seeking asylum en tered the United States without proper documentation and are excludable, the State Depart ment reported today.

description: DFNVER, Dec. 21 (AP) There are nine repeaters on the official 1972 Professional Foot ball Writers of America AllPro football team issued today, but the younger kids are taking over the block on the defensive line.

description: RINDGE, N. H., Dec. 21 Dr. Douglas Sloane, founder of the interfaith openair Cathe dral of the Pines here, died to day in a nursing home in Peter borough. He Was 32 years old and lived here.

The Episcopal ceremony was per formed by the Rev. Dr. Cotesworth Pinckney Lewis and the Rev. Gardner Un derhill of Christ Episcopal Church in Waverly.

description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 21 (UPI)Two men identified as members of the Jewish De fense League pleaded not guilty yesterday to charges of bomb ing an Arab's apartment build ing last September. Robert S. Manning and Philip C. Zweig, both 20 years old, entered the pleas following their surrender on grand jury indictments re ??ed last Friday.

title: Notes on People
description: Herve Alphand, who was France's Ambassador to Washington from 1956 to 1965, is retiring Monday as Secretary of the Foreign Min istry in Paris. The 65year old Mr. Alphaud and his wife, Nicole, were prominent in Washington social life during their years there. Mr. Alphand will be succeeded in the Quai d'Orsay post, the highest in the French Foreign Service, by Geoffroy Chodron De Courcel, now the Ambassador to Britain and a World War II aide de camp to Charles DeGaulle.

title: Business Briefs
description: BRUSSELS, Dec. 21 (AP)Diplomats from 14 West European countries today signed the final documents to enable them to start forming a single freetrade area on Jan. 1. It will be the world's most powerful trading group.

title: PLEASURE PROVIDED BY CLARION CONCERT
description: The Clarion Concert of early and midbaroque music Tuesday night at Tully Hall provided for almost unalloyed pleasure. What alloy there was could be attributed to some weakness among the solo singers, partic ularly at the lower end of the scale; some occasional thickness of choral tone and some into national insecurity from the old wind instrumentsalthough in the last instance, their sensuous color more than made up for that.

title: U.S. Officials Seek Cause Of Jet Collision in Chicago
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 21  Fed eral safety officials, investigat ing the second major airline crash in Chicago in 12 days, listened today to tape record ings and searched the charred wreckage of a North Central Airlines DC9 in which nine persons died last night.

title: A Clarification

Mr. Shevell purchased 7,850 shares, increasing his holdings to 310,387, including 3,800 shares in a custody account for children.

description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21  A changing American work force is becoming pervasively dissatisfied with dull, unchal lenging and repetitive jobs, and this discontent is sapping the economic and social strength of the nation, a Government report said today.

description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 Miss Linda Lee Young, daugh ter of Mr. and Mrs. James Young of Jackson, Miss., was married here this evening to Heathcote W. Wales, son of Mrs. John Nelson Steele of New York and the late Well ington Wales, who was a member of the editorial board of The New York Times and a former editor of the edi torial page of The Knicker bocker News in Albany.

title: Influenza Outbreak In Critical Period For Impact on U.S.
description: ATLANTA, Dec. 21 (UPI) The next few weeks will be critical in determining the impact of an influenza out break across the nation, the Federal Center for Disease Con trol says.

title: Ash Is Confident in Role as Nation's New Budget Chief
description: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif.  Roy L. Ash took up his new duties as the White House's new money manager Dec. 11 fully aware that his reputa tion as a businessmangenius had been tarnished in some quarters and thoroughly con vinced that the criticism was unjust.

title: JOB DISINCENTIVES CITED IN U.S. STUDY
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21A Congressional committee pub lished new evidence today on the major disincentives to work that come about, almost unin tentionally, in the array of Fed eral programs designed to help the poor.

title: New Orders Spurt For Durable Goods; Profits Are Revised
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21  New orders for durable goods spurted in November to a rec ord level of $37.81billion, the Commerce Department re ported today.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: The Queens Playhouse, the borough's new nonprofit theater in Flushing Meadows Corona Park, which opened its doors only two months ago, has curtailed its season for lack of funds. Claiming close to 2,000 subscribers, Joseph S. Kutrzeba, the theater's founder and producer, cited as his problems low ticket prices, which started at $2.95; unanticipated higher operat ing costs, an unusually wet November and a lack of iden tification with Queens resi dents.

title: DAVID DUSHOFF, 61, BUILT LATIN CASINO
description: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 21 (AP) David Dushoff, coowner and driving force behind the Latin Casino, one of America's swank iest nightclubs, died late last night at Hahnemann Hospital. He was 61 years old.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: The Rhetoric of Peace
description: PARISIt is with dismay that we read that most Americans think that the war in Vietnam is almost over and that Mr. Nixon is making every effort for peace. Our daily news from Viet nam tells of suffering at its worst in ten years, yet the human reality of the war continues to be ignored not only by governments and warmakers, but by most men and women in the United States.

description: To the Editor:

description: ATLANTA, Dec. 21  Dr. Horace Mann Bond, educator and father of State Representa tive Julian Bond, died today in a nursing home at the age of 68.

title: ALLEGED PIMP SEIZED LEAVING LIMOUSINE
description: A 29yearold man described by the police as a member of the top echelon of pimps in the city was arrested early yes terday as he emerged from his chauffeurdriven Cadillac limou since to enter the Brasserie res taurant, at 100 East 53d Street.

title: RedBiooded Bach By Virgil Fox Has An Evangelical Air
description: One came away from Virgil fox's Carnegie Hall appearance Wednesday night with the dis tinct feeling that the event should have been reviewed by the religion editor. Certainly the organist's Bach programs are as much crusades as con certs, the music enveloped in swirling lights, evangelic ser mons and inspirational anec dotery that attracts young people in droves and leaves them cheering for more, even after half dozen encores.

description: BOSTON, Dec, 21 (AP) Mike Walton and Ken Hodge scored two goals each, all in the fivegoal Boston third pe riod, in pacing the Boston Bruins to an 81 rout of the Detroit Red Wings in a Na tional Hockey League game to night.
