description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (AP) A group of professors said this week that the freedom of American colleges and univerti ties was endangered by a grow ing tendency to rely on the police and courts when trouble occurred on the campus.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: William Eberle in GATT has followed George Shultz in the I.M.F., so the United States is once again in the familiar position of proposing to the worldespecially the main industrial nations major new steps in interna tional economic cooperation.

title: New Novel
description: East Falls, a gilded Connecti cut suburb, is a beehive of literary celebrities who see much too much of one another. This especially applies to Luke Kelly and Clifford Marshall, a pair of novelists in the run ning for the National Book Awardor, as it is called here, The American Medal for Lit erature.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor: Mr. Robert Daley in his Po lice report on the TV cops (Nov. 19) errs in a quite fun damental manner. He failed to note that the TV series he criticized, for their failure to adhere to reality, are enter tainment programs. These are dramatizations based loosely on events which are not so outrageously beyond the realm of reality as to be totally impossible yet are not meant, on the other hand, to present things strictly as they are. Things as they really are, from what Mr. Daley tells us of the policeman's world, are often boring, repetitive and full of drudgery. These are not the ideal qualities of an en tertainment program. I do not propose to defend the cop shows as good entertainment, but rather only to point out that this is their category. The type of program Mr. Daley is looking for falls under the heading of documentary and perhaps if he chose to chide television for its failure to deal with the police in that light he would have a good argument.

title: Charles Atlas, the BodyBuilder And Weightlifter, Is Dead at 79
description: Charles Atlas, the advocate of weightlifting whose adver tisements showed a 97pound weakling sprayed with sand by a bully, died tonight in Long Beach (L. I.) Hospital. He was 79 years old.

title: TV Mailbag
description: My 4yearold has come to understand and accept that characters on television are not real people, only actors earning their living by play ing make believe. Why is it, then, that millions of adults are seemingly ignorant of this rather simple fact? I refer to the Ideas espoused in Aljean Harmetz's Maude article (although I suspect it is a calculated puton).

title: Hawks Overtake 76ers
description: ATLANTA, Dec. 23 (AP) Pete Maravich poured in 42 points and Lou Hudson added 31 tonight as the Atlanta Hawks pulled away from the Philadelphia 76ers in the fourth period to post a 124112 vic tory.

title: Lefkowitz Offers Proposals To Help Frustrated Voters
description: Attorney General Louis D. Lefkowitz disclosed a package of legislative proposals yester day aimed at helping frustrat ed and discouraged voters.

title: Authors Peddle Their Best Sellers From a Pushcart
description: Some of the nation's best selling authors joined yes terday to peddle their books from a colorful but wet push cart and bookstalls on Fifth Avenue.

title: Horse Racing
description: The attendance at the two major tracks operated in the metropolitan area by the New York Racing Association suffered a considerable falloff during the year, the decrease attributed mainly to the activities of the New York City Offtrack Betting Corpo ration.

title: Writer Who Fought A Subpoena Wins; Grand Jury Ended
description: TUCSON, Ariz., Dec. 23A United States appellate court has ruled in favor of a free lance writer who had been re sisting a Federal grand jury subpoena for almost a year and a half.

title: Mater Christi Wins Sixth In School Tourney Opener
description: Mater Christi extended its undefeated streak, but Jack son's streak ended in opening round games of the first Christ mas high school basketball tournament at St. John's Uni versity Alumni Hall yesterday.

title: TAMS EDGE NETS IN LAST SECONDS
description: MEMPHIS, Dec. 23With the score tied at 103all and 41 sec onds remaining, Randy Denton converted two free throws to bring the Memphis Tams a 105 103 victory over the New York Nets tonight.

title: Jersey Mayor Is Arrested
description: MOUNT HOLLY, N. J., Dec. 23 (UPI)Mayor Howard W. Reed of Springfield Township was arrested on a charge of drunken driving early today after having been involved in a twocar accident, according to the police. Mr. Reed, whose oneyear term as Mayor is due to expire Dec. 31, refused to take a breath test, the police said, The 48yearold official was released on a $250 per sonalrecognizance bond pend ing a hearing in municipal court Jan. 16.

title: ISRAEL GIVES FIGURE ON CONVICTED ARABS
description: TEL AVIV, Dec. 23 (AP) Israel has convicted 1,610 Arabs from the occupied territories on charges of sabotage and work ing with guerrilla organizations since the 1967 war, according to a Defense Ministry spokes man.

title: Medicine
description: Secanols, Tuinals, Quaaludes, sopors the heart of a new vocabulary for the drug culture. For within the past year there has been a dramatic change in drug abuse patterns. A report re leased two weeks ago by Senator Birch Bayh's Subcommittee on Juvenile De linquency confirmed what street people and police officials have known for some timedowns are rapidly be coming the nation's number one abused drug.

title: Order for Dakota Guard
description: BISMARCK, N.D., Dec. 23 (AP)The North Dakota Na tional Guard has been told by the Pentagon that it needs 20 black recruits in the next year to balance its ranks racially. But the state headquarters cal culates that there are only 20 blacks in the state that it could recruit. The last black National Guardsman in North Dakota left a year ago.

title: 1 Killed, 2 Hurt as a Truck Jumps Barrier and Hits Car
description: A Queens motorist was killed and two persons were injured on the BrooklynQueens Ex pressway yesterday morning when a westbound truck went out of control, jumped a di vider barrier and struck an eastbound auto head on.

title: LETTERS
description: Paul H. Mazur's article (Taxing Money Earned by Money, Dec. 17] challenged the validity of the phrase I wrote for Senator George McGovern's campaign that money made by money should be taxed at the same rate as money made by men. It appears to me that Mr. Mazur seems to have missed the point of that phrase.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The New Jersey Insurance Commissioner, Richard Mc Donough, said yesterday he had asked Blue Cross to pre pare a report on differences in hospital  insurance rates between North and South Jersey.

title: MRS. GUSTAVE AUFRICHT
description: Mrs. Maria Hegge Aufricht, wife of Dr. Gustave Aufricht, a plastic surgeon, died Friday in Lenox Hill Hospital. She was 67 years old and lived at 1001 Park Avenue, in Mamaroneck, N.Y., and La Costa, Calif.

title: Chess:
description: The term positional chess generally describes a type of play in which one minimizes direct attack and defense and instead maneuvers to im prove one's own position and to hamper the opponent's de velopment. Since a chess game is ultimately decided by attackby checkmateposi tional chess can only be re garded as a phase that pre cedes attack.

title: A Rise in LongTerm Facilities for the Elderly Frustrates Rockaway Residents
description: Rockaway residents are voicing increased frustration over the construction of new longterm healthcare facili ties that will increase the peninsula's existing beds by four times within the next three years.

title: News of the Camera World
description: NEW volume has been added to the Life Li brary of Photography series, published by TimeLife Books and distrib uted by Morgan and Mor gan, Inc. Entitled Caring for Photographs, and priced at $9.95, this volume was writ ten to serve as a compre hensive illustrated guide to photographers who want to insure maximum life for their pictures. The book starts with the premise that careful and proper processing is the key to permanence, and it de scribes and illustrates the var ious methods involved. The first chapter also discusses means for restoring old and faded pictures, as well as techniques to prevent older pictures that have started to fade from getting worse. Oth er treatments that are also outlined are the retouching and copying of damaged photos, archival processing of negatives and prints, storage and filing of negatives and transparencies, mounting and framing of prints, and the proper organization of print and side exhibits.

title: Receiver Evicts 30 at SingleUnit Site
description: One morning last May, Lloyd E. Dickens, a realestate oper ator, walked into a fivestory tan brick converted tenement at 450 West 58th Street, intro duced himself to the superin tendent, then started a roofto cellar inspection of the prem ises.

title: Auto Racing
description: George Folimer turned motor racing's equivalent of the hat trick by winning two Sports Car Club of America cham pionshipsthe CanAm for unlimited sportsracing cars and the TransAm for 5liter sedans. Folimer happened to be at liberty when Mark Donohue was in jured while testing a Porsche 91710, turbocharged and modified by Roger Penske and perfected by Donohue's de velopment. Penske called on Follmer to carry on, and the Californian breezed on to an easy championship, ending the fiveyear domination of Team McLaren.

title: Tennis
description: For the first time in almost two dec ades, a pair of American tennis players, Stan Smith and Mrs. Billie Jean King, reached the top spots on the inter national tennis ladder in the same year.

title: Coins
description: THE numismatic hobby enjoyed a great year in 1972 and all indications are that 1973 will be bigger and bettereven if Santa Claus forgets collectors on his rounds tonight.

title: The real Lady Day
description: Billie Holiday was on television, part of The Sound of Jazz, on a Sunday afternoon in Decem ber, 1957, less than two years before her death. The program, which was coming live from C.B.S. studios on Manhattan's West 57th Street, was going well and about to move into Fine and Mellow. Billie, perched on a high stool, faced a semicircle of musicians who were all standing except for one, Lester Young. Prez (as Billie had nicknamed him long before) was sick. He had been so weak that most of his solos during previous segment with Count Basie's band had been split among other reedmen. Now Prez was slumped in a chair, his eyes averted from Billie, whom he had not spoken to for some time. I didn't know the reason for their discord, but throughout the rehearsals they had ignored each other.

title: Nuptials for Camille A. Moffatt, Penn Senior, and H.L. Bertram
description: POTTSTOWN, Pa., Dec. 23 The Alumni Chapel at the Hill School was the setting here this afternoon for the marriage of Miss Camille Ann Moffatt, a University of Pennsylvania senior, to Henry Lawrence Bertram, a senior at Yale. The ecumenical ceremony was performed by the Rev. George P. Hiller, a Roman Catholic priest, and the Rev. John W. Riegel, an Episcopalian clergyman and assistant chaplain at Hill.

title: Europe Reacts to Bombing With Increasing Protests
description: LONDON, Dec. 23Western Europe is reacting to the Amer ican bombing of North Vietnam with growing protests and a mixture of sadness, disgust and anger.

title: World News Briefs
description: OSLO, Norway, Dec. 23 A Norwegian jetliner crashed today in rugged forest in the Asker area west of Oslo, killing 35 of the 45 people aboard, rescue headquarters reported. There were seven survivors and three were missing. The plane belonged to the Norwegian domestic airline Braathens S.A.F.E.

title: World News Briefs
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Dec. 23  Black African guer rillas fired rockets at a farm near the Mozambique bor der today, wounding a white farmer and his nineyearold daughter.

title: THE MAYOR PLANS NEW TRAFFIC UNIT
description: Mayor Lindsay, who aides said became furious one day last week when his limousine became stalled 15 minutes by traffic congestion on an East Side block, has decided to seek legislation to create a force of civilian traffic officers and to expand the ticketing powers of meter maids.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: THE GLOOM and uncertainty lately created by the stalemate in the Vietnam peace negotiations and the sudden resumption of heavy American bombing in southeast Asia have marred what could have been a truly joyous season in the business and economic world.

title: President Park, Named to a 4th Term, Promises to Spur Korean Unification
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Dec. 23 President Park Chung Hee was officially reelected Presi dent of South Korea by the National Conference for Unifi cation today and pledged to seek peaceful reunification of Korea as soon as possible.

title: Music: Judy Collins at Carnegie Hall
description: The persistence of Judy Collins, with her gentle, folk flavored innocence, should be enough to give our more apo calyptic pop prophets just a little cause for hesitation. For there she was, before a rapt, soldout Carnegie Hall audi ence Friday night, providing pleasure to a Nixon genera tion that we are sometimes told is traumatized past hope on downers and hard metal rock.

title: The Nation
description: He said he harbored no regrets or resentments and he raised his hand in salute to the convicts he left behind, who could be seen waving from their cells. The Rev. Philip Berrigan was free after 39 months in Federal prison.

title: Sally Treitrnan Plans Nuptials
description: HEWLETT, L. I., Dec. 23 Dr. and Mrs. Arnold Treit man of Hewlett and Montego Bay, West Indies, have an nounced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sally Jane Treitman, to Richard Eisenberg, son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Eisenberg of Elmont. The couple plan a March wedding.

title: A City Aide Fiddles While on Sick Pay, And Officials Burn
description: CLEVELAND, Dec. 23City officials who burned when they learned that Joseph Rabb had fiddled in New Orleans while on citypaid sick leave may have the last word next month.

title: Industrialist Gets Post With Einstein Medical
description: Michael Singer, an indus trialist, has been elected chairman of the board of overseers of the Albert Ein stein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University.

title: PAUL BALSAM DEAD; A JUSTICE IN QUEENS
description: Supreme Court Justice Bal sam of Queens died Friday in San Antonio, Tex., where he was visiting his son, Maj. Alan Balsam, an Air Force doctor. Justice Balsam, who was 67 years old, lived at 10128 97th Street in Qzone Park, where he had made his residence through out his life.

title: Morgan Barry, Allen Morton To Be Married
description: GREENS FARMS, Conn., Dec. 23Miss Elisabeth Mor gan Barry, who is known by her middle name, plans to be married here Feb. 3 to Allen Salisbury Morton. Their en gagement has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. John F. Barry Jr., parents of the bridetobe.

title: Here's to me and my generation Mr. Burgess makes a Christmas toast
description: Christmas is traditionally a season for putting off guilt. Guilt is in order for nearly all the year, but it should start to diminish about St. Lucia's Day and be thoroughly dissolved in spirits on Christ mas Eve. December 26th is the feast of the first Christian martyr, Stephen, who was stoned to death, and guilt canand usually does, along with crapulencecome back with a thud on that date. But Christmas is all about handing over the burden of collective guilt (whose record is what we call history) and personal guilt (autobiography) to an avatar who is well qualified to look after it. And so what I write now is not to be read after Christmas Day, and perhapsas it represents a kind of giftit should not be opened before Christmas Day.

title: P.O.W. Casualties Reported
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 23 (AP) Tass, the Soviet press agency, reported from Hanoi today that American air strikes over the North Vietnamese capital had inflicted casualties on Ameri can pilots held prisoner there.

title: Leafs Defeat Hawks, 53
description: TORONTO, Dec. 23 (UPI) Paul Henderson scored two goals to lead the Toronto Maple Leafs to a 53 victory over the Chicago Black Hawks tonight.

title: Excerpts Showing Heschel Philosophy
description: The following are excerpts from Rabbi Abraham Heschel's work that expounded his reli gious philosophy on various subjects:

title: Nancy Brown Fiancee
description: CHATHAM, NJ., Dec. 23 Mr. and Mrs. George Mercer Brown have announced the engagement of their daugh ter, Miss Nancy Ellen Brown, to F. Thomas Baldus, son of Mr. and Mrs. Clemens Baldus. Both families are of Chatham. Miss Brown is a junior at Vassar College. Her fianc is a senior at Seton Hall Uni versity.

title: Sharp Drop Is Shown in Jailing Of Heroin Users in Brooklyn
description: A sharp decrease in the num ber of heroinusers admitted co the Brooklyn House of De cention has been noted by of ?? of the Department of Correction.

title: Going against 100,000 years of biology
description: Cathy and Wayne N. are in their late 20's, have been mar ried five years, and are child less. The last time a member of Cathy's family asked, When are you going to start a family? her answer was, We're a family!

title: Elizabeth Janet Bonan Is a Bride
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Dee. 23  Miss Elizabeth Janet Bonan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Seon Pierre Bonan of Greenwich, was married here this afternoon to Paul Augus tin BertinBoussu, son of Mrs. Amid BertinBoussu of Amiens and Morzine, France, and the late Mr. BertinBoussu.

title: Free to Be ...You and Me
description: SOCIETY is constantly doing ideological back flips on the subject of male  female roles. When I was a child, I was encouraged to believe that I could be anything I was strong enough or smart enough to be. On the other hand, I was also told that any potential husband who saw me bending over to drink straight from the cold water tap, instead of using a glass, would immediately wonder whether I was the right girl for him.

title: Vanderbilt Club Slates An Adolph Rupp Day
description: NASHVILLE, Dec. 23 (AP) The Vanderbilt Quarterback Club will stage an apprecia tion day next months for the retired Kentucky basketball coach, Adolph Rupp, who is now president of the Mem phis Tanis of the American Basketball Association.

title: Her Books Run for Her
description: ELIZABETHWhat did a beautiful young American ballerina do for an encore in 1913 when, at the age of 19, she had already danced at the famous Folies Bergeres in Paris?

title: Eating and Drinking Our Way to Detente
description: Remember 10 or 12 years ago, when the John Birch Society placed cards in supermarkets urging cus tomers not to buy hams or other products imported from Communist Poland?

title: B52 Vindicates Its Role, Air Force Aides Assert
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 23Air Force officials believe that the aging B52 has, in the last few days, redeemed its role as a strategic bomber capable of penetrating the Soviet Union.

title: Kellogg Grants $600,000
description: BATTLE CREEK, Mich., Dec. 23 (AP)Utah State University has received a commitment of $600,000 over four years from the W. K. Kellogg Foundation in Battle Creek to fund a con tinuing education program on rural development.

title: Badillo and Dinkins Request Them for Mayoral Race
description: In a politically significant move, David Dinkins, president or the Board of Elections, and Representative Herman Badillo, a leading Democratic mayoral contender, are seeking to have hundreds of judges assigned to polling places in the mayoral primary next year so that ques tions of voter eligibility can be immediately resolved.

title: Maude's Abortion
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Art Student in Buffalo Found Strangled in His Apartment
description: BUFFALO, Dec. 23  A 23 yearold Brooklyn man who had just completed his courses for an art degree at the State Uni versity College at Buffalo was found strangled early today in his secondfloor apartment about four blocks from the cam pus.

title: TRUMAN IN COMA; HEART IS FAILING
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Dec. 23 Former President Harry S. Truman's condition was re ported to be slightly improved but still critical tonight after earlier reports had described him as completely unrespon sive and in extremely criti cal condition.

title: Boxing Coach Named
description: Dr. Benjamin Benjamin of Guilderland, N.Y., was named coach of the United States box ing team yesterday for the ninth World Maccabiah Games in Israel next summer.

title: Waldheim Voices Concern
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 23 (Reuters)  Secretary General Waldheim said today that he was greatly concerned at the continued United States bombing of North Vietnam.

title: Glitter Is Growing On Silver And Gold
description: Silver and gold. To some they conjure tinsel on the Christmas tree and gilt paper for wrapping. The poetic may think of starlight on snow and the glow of sun set. To others silver is the flatware on the dining table and gold is the wide band of a wedding ring.

title: What was marginal and provincial is now experimental
description: Now that the Nigerian Govern ment has done such an effective job of creating the illusion of success ful restorationand the rest of the world has forgotten the Nigerian Civil War and Biafrait may come as a surprise that in one area at least the recovery has been almost nonexistent: the arts. Prior to the war, the flowing of West African literary expression was almost to tally dominated by Nigerian artists. Since the beginning of the war, however, things have become con siderably altered.

title: TRANSPORTATION
description: Back in the days when Willy Loman, the tragic fig ure from Arthur Miller's play Death of a Salesman, was traveling around his sales territory, life on the road for most businessmen was a de pressing succession of sooty railroad coaches, gravel voiced conductors and small town rooming houses, made tolerable by a belt of bour bon before dinner.

title: Miss Walters Engaged
description: CINCINNATI, Dec. 23  Mr. and Mrs. Philip G. Walters have announced the engage ment of their daughter, Miss Virginia Walters, to Charles Randall Egan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Edward Egan Jr. of Geneva, N.Y. Miss Walters is a granddaughter of the late Dr. Raymond Walters, who was president emeritus of the University of Cincinnati.

title: Dress Code Upheld
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., Dec. 23 (AP) School districts have the right to deny students admis sion to class if their hair is too long, the State Supreme Court ruled Thursday. The court said that Mingus Union High School District in Prescott had the right to establish its own dress cude, which provides that side burns on boys be neat at all times, and hair shall be off the forehead, collar and ears.

title: Peter Doelgerto Marry Miss Victoria Milbank
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Dec. 23Mr. and Mrs. Jeremiah Milbank Jr. have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Victoria Mil bank, to Peter Woodbury Doelger, son of Mr. and Mrs. William E. P. Doelger of Palm Beach, Fla.

title: Richard Neville Weds Miss Palmer
description: Miss Audrey Palmer, daugh of Paul Palmer of Geneva and Mrs. Vernon Newell of Tucson, Ariz., was married in Mexico yesterday to Richard Neville, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Edwin L. Neville of Conway, N. H. Fidel Hernan dez, a Justice of the Peace in Rosarito, Baja California, per formed the ceremony in his office.

title: Nancy Brocks Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. William Ar thur Brocks of the Bronx have announced the engage ment of their daughter, Miss Nancy Brocks, to Mark Bruck mann, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Bruckmann of Mar shall's Creek, Pa. Miss Brocks is a student at the College of Mount St. Vincent, Riverdale, the Bronx. Her fiance, a grad uate of Manhattan College, attends the Fordham Law School. An August wedding is planned.

title: LAWYER SLATED TO BE I.R.S. CHIEF
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., Dec. 23The White House appears ready to appoint George D. Webster, a Washington tax lawyer active in Republican politics, as Commissioner of Internal Revenue.

title: Thuy Asserts U.S. Raised Objections Of Thieu in Talks
description: Xuan Thuy, head of the North Vietnamese delegation to the Paris peace talks, said in an interview last week that before the negotiations broke down Henry A. Kissinger had raised in the private talks all the public demands made by President Nguyen Van Thieu of South Vietnam, the American Broadcasting Company reported last night.

title: CLEVELAND RULES ON BLACK POLICE
description: CLEVELAND, Dec. 23 A judge in United States District Court has ruled that the city of Cleveland may hire 188 new policemen but that at least 18 per cent of them must be black or have Spanish surnames.

title: COMEDIE GOES ON, IN THEATER OR OUT
description: PARIS  The Year of Moliere began last weekend about where Moliere's shows startedin a public garden though the reason was modern social strain rather than nos talgia for the court manners at which Molire poked fun.

title: Headliners
description: Giving the Bastard a Break

title: A Trunk of Theater for Children
description: GLEN RIDGE  What its founders hope will eventually become a professional New Jerseyoriented traveling chil dren's theater will have its first production, A. A. Milne's The Ugly Duckling, housed in Christ Episcopal Church here for four days beginning next Wednesday.

title: Andrei N. Tupolev Dead; Soviet Plane Designer, 84
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 23Andrei N. Tupolev, one of the world's leading aircraft designers, iden tified with some of Russia's bestknown military and civilian planes, died today after a long illness. He was 84 years old.

title: Realigned Indian Bureau Planned in Interior Shifts
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 23  Secretary of the Interior Rogers C. B. Morton is considering a department reorganization plan that would give American In dians an Assistant Secretary and compress the Bureau of In dian Affairs into a technical as sistance agency with reduced personnel.

title: An ecologic Tocqueville who came to stay
description: Ren Dubos is a national treasure, even if he does not quite belong to us. Like an eco logical Tocqueville who came to stay, he has been telling us about ourselves as human be ings who also happen to be Americans and inherit a com plex set of relations to particular environments. He has been do ing this over many years, first as a microbiologist and teacher emphasizing the social aspects of disease, then as a writer of a succession of books splendid in the range of their knowl edge, in their civility and style. (He has the French claire rai son without the obnoxious French rationalism.) Though each of his books is a pleasure to read, some have been rather specialized, for example The Mirage of Health, perhaps his best book. Others, like the re cent So Human an Animal, have crossed all the lines of disciplines, to the consterna tion of narrow keen little minds and the delight of the rest. If there is still a question what to call Professor Dubos, philoso pher of earth would be exact.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Vietnam
description: SAIGONDuring the 24 hour pe riod ending at 0800 today, U.S. crews conducted bombing operations against military targets in North Viet nam. With that bland announcement, the American command last week launched the heaviest air attacks of the entire war against the North.

title: 2 RETARDED CASES STIR CONTROVERSY
description: EAST MEADOW, L. I., Dec. 23More than a year after two mentally retarded patients were first admitted to the Nas sau County Medical Center and six months after a State Su preme Court justice ordered that they be sent to a state school, the patients are still in the psychiatric ward at the center here, receiving only a place to sleep, three meals a day and some space to walk around, according to a hospital official.

title: GIFTS FROM AFAR AID THE NEEDIEST
description: Checks from former New Yorkers now living in distant places were recorded yesterday by the New York Times Needi est Cases Fund.

title: Labor Official Appointed
description: BOSTON, Dec. 23 (AP)Gov. Francis W. Sargent this week named Joseph A. Sullivan, presi dent of the Massachusetts State Labor Council, to the state Rate Setting Commission, which oversees contracts between pro viders and consumers of health services.

title: Television
description: FINLEY PETER DUNNE, the Russell Baker of the 1880's, once had his sage Mr. Dooley comment: Thank hivvins we don't git as much guv'ment as we pay for. Nearly 100 years later, Mr. Dooley would have to look for other reasons to thank heav en because nowadays we sometimes get more government than we pay forand not always the kind we need.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: DETROITAfter two years of travel to industrial plants in different parts of the country and numerous con versations with workers, a recurring story sticks in the mind.

title: Son to the Ullmanns
description: A son was born to Mr. and Mrs. Jacob Ullmann of New York and Weston, Conn., on Dec. 4 at Mount Sinai Hos pital. The child has been named David Stuart. Mrs. Ullmann is the former Miss Lucia Figatner. Her husband is technical assistant to the corporate vice president of Union Carbide Corporation.

title: Caroline S. Tankoos Affianced To Marc Brown of Lord & Taylor
description: DARIEN, Conn., Dec. 23  Mrs. William Granniss Tan koos has made known the engagement of her daughter, Miss Caroline Scott Tankoos, to Marc Swit Brown, son of Dr. and Mrs. Herbert. Samuel Brown of Stamford. An early summer wedding is planned.

title: H.M. Holtzmann Weds Mrs. van Berg
description: MAMARONECK, N.Y., Dec. 23Mrs. Carol Eberstein van Berg of Scarsdale was mar ried here this evening to Howard M. Holtzmann. Rabbi Robert A. Rothman performed the ceremony at the home of the bridegroom, a widower.

title: Sales Spree in Toyland
description: Tonight it will all be over. The stores that were still open today will have closed their doors, the final dollars will have been spent and the last presents wrapped. And tomorrow the toys will be given out.

title: Tass Selects Borzov As Sportsman of Year
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 23 (AP) The Soviets press agency, Tass, named the Ukrainian sprinter, Valery Borzov, as sportsman of the year, with the American swimmer, Mark Spitz, second.

title: AT CHRISTMAS REMEMBER THE NEEDIEST
description: ONCE more the Christmas holiday, with its spirit of good fellow ship, is with us. The welcoming wreath upon the door, the glit tering tree, the soft glow of candle lightall are symbols of this day of good will when gifts and cheery greet ings are exchanged among friends.

title: The World
description: When Lynden O. Pindling, a London trained lawyer, came to power in 1967 as the first black Prime Minister of the Bahamas, there was little doubt that he would push the 700 islands to full independence from Britain, whose col ony they had been since 1783.

title: DRIVE FOR MAYOR URGED IN HOUSTON
description: HOUSTON, Dec. 23  Police Chief Herman Short, an admirer of Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama, is receiving scat tered support to run for Mayor here next year.

title: LETTERS
description: In reference to Juanita Kreps's discussion of unem ployment goals [Facing Up to the Unemployment Prob lem, Dec. 101, it should be made clear that what is re quired to maintain the value of money (for those who have it) is not necessarily a certain per cent unemploy ment, but an equivalent amount of poverty.

title: New Novel
description: Of Men and Angels is a love story involving a pharma cist and a veterinary surgeon. If this seems prosaic, let me put it this way: Of Men and Angels is a novel about grownups in love. Okay? And it is as full of the yang and yin of the human condition as anything you are likely to read this season of erotic overkill.

title: Court Rules That Cell Violated Rights of Connecticut Prisoner
description: An appeals court has ruled that a Connecticut prison vio lated a prisoner's rights by con fining him in a dark, unhy gienic, barren cell that was below the irreduceable mini mun of decency required by the Constitution.

title: Sentiment Is Increasing to Cite Little Cigars as Health Hazard
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 23Ex tensive advertising and rising sales of cigarettelike little cigars are generating consider able sentiment for mandatory health warnings in the ads and on package labels. Federal ac tion, by legislation, regulation or both, may be in the offing.The Federal Trade Commis sion is considering the advis ability of requiring such warn ings by regulation, and Con gress will soon have before it a bill that would also bar little cigar ads from television and radio.

title: The Nation
description: When the 32 United States winners of the coveted Rhodes Scholarship were announced last week, applicant Eileen Lach's name was among the missing. The Rhodes Scholar, decreed founder Cecil Rhodes, in 1902 must be aged 19 to 24and male.

title: Children of G.I.'s Shunned in Vietnam
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 23 (Reuters)  John and Gigi are two children of mixed parentage in one of South Viet nam's numerous overcrowded orphanages.

title: Catholics Tell of Ouster By Malaysian Moslems
description: HONG KONG, Dec. 23 (AP) Three Roman Catholic mission aries have charged that Moslem authorities in Sabah, the Malay sian state in Borneo, deported them to reduce the influence of Christianity.

title: Browns at Miami Today
description: MIAMI, Dec. 23  The Miami Dolphins, the first National Football League team to emerge unbeaten and untied from a 14game regu lar season, will open the money season, as their players call it, against the Cleveland Browns tomorrow in the American Conference playoffs.

title: Bears And Forebears
description: Carruthers is a grumpy bear, but one of the most lovable characters in many a season of children's pic ture books. His stanch friends won der and worry about him in WHAT'S THE MATTER WITH CARRUTHERS? A Bedtime Story by James Marshall (Houghton Mifflin, $4.95). They serenade him with tuba and tam bourine, feed him honey cakes, even take him to an amusement park. Nothing seems to cheer Carruthers till he falls headfirst into a pile of autumn leavesand his friends finally understand his need to hiber nate. Emily and Eugene carry the huge bear to his bed, tuck him in and set the alarm for spring. In genuous line drawings, fresh colors and humorous dialogue make this compassionate tale every bit as de lightful as Marshall's first book, and Martha.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: Golf

title: Ann Meinertz Plans Bridal Next Month
description: GREENLAWN, LI., Dec. 23 Miss Ann Thatcher Mei nertz, a senior at Sarah Law rence College, plans to be married next month to Henry Erben Gaillard Jr., a research analyst with Walston & Co. in New York.

title: Gail Bailin, a Teacher, Fiancee of R. A. Davis
description: SCARSDALE, N.Y., Dec. 23 Mr. and Mrs. Jerome K. Bailin have announced the engagement of their daugh ter, Miss Gail S. Baffin, to Robert A. Davis, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arnold K. Davis of New York and Palm Beach, Fla.

title: Fire at U.S. German Office
description: HEIDELBERG, WEST GER MANY, Dec. 23, (Reuters)  Fires broke out in about nine different parts of a United States Army office building in Frankfurt today, a spokesman at the army's headquarters here said. He said arson was sus pected. The building was empty at the time. Damage was put at between $50,000 and $75,000.

title: The Nation
description: HOUSTONEvery other ending in space flight has been the prelude to a greater beginning. After the Mercury program, involving the oneman cap sules that pioneered earth orbit, came Gemini, the twoman vehicle that tested man and craft for moon flight. After Gemini came Apollo and the reach for the moon.

title: A Hanoi Battalion in Laos Said to Seize Key Bridge
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Dec. 23 Military sources reported today that North Vietnamese troops backed by tanks had captured an important bridgehead in southern Laos only 15 miles from the Thai border.

title: BERKELEY RADICAL FACES OUSTER BID
description: BERKELEY, Calif., Dec. 23 An outspoken black city coun cilman, D'Army Bailey, one of the three radicals elected to. the City Council here in April, 1971, has become the focus of a recall move.

title: Track Names New Manager
description: BOSTON, Dec. 23 (AP)Offi cials at Suffolk Downs have announced the appointment of Edward J. Sullivan as general manager of the race track. Sullivan, of Dedham, Mass., joined Suffolk Downs in 1950 as a publicity director, and was later raised to the position of vice president and assistant general manager.

title: MARKETS IN REVIEW
description: The stock market nosedived last week in a decisive reaction to Henry A. Kissinger's disclosure of a break down in the Vietnam peace negotiations. Heavy selling moved in Monday and continued until Friday.

title: Pop
description: THEY'RE too loud. Their playing is mediocre. They can't singall war cries for a cob webbrained establishment confronted with rock music it can't understand. Most rock bands who make it on the grand scale can pifiy, can sing and know exactly what they're doing with their vol ume controls. The one ex ception is Grand Funk Rail road whose musical deficien cies did not prevent their becoming one of rock's biggest moneymaking enter prises. Since their formation in 1969, Grand Funk Rail road has meant huge sales to Capitol Records (eight gold records meaning sales of a million dollars or more per album) and socko excite ment to their 14 and 15 yearold fans who in 1971 bought out the tickets for a Grand Funk Shea Stadium concert in 72 hours.

title: Landry Calls That Finish a 1001 Shot
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 23  You never know what's going to happen. Pittsburgh proved that earlier today. It's the best comeback I have ever seen by a Dallas team. It's a tribute to our players. We had to just put every thing we had together in two minutes and we did. You can be in that situation 100 times and probably only win one of them.

title: Arthur Daley
description: Sports of The Times

title: Report on Giap Doubted
description: SAIGON, Dec. 23American intelligence officials denied any knowledge today of a report by some South Vietnamese in telligence sources that General Vo Nguyen Giap, the North Vietnamese Defense Minister, had been killed in the Hanoi Haiphong area.

title: St. Peter's Trounced
description: BUFFALO, Dec. 23 (AP) Niagara rolled up the second highest score for a college team in Memorial Auditorium, trounc ing St. Peter's of Jersey City, 11590, tonight. Canisius holds the arena record with 126 points against Catholic Univer sity last season.

title: Stamps
description: ALTHOUGH most nations commemorating Christ and Christmas, in cluding the United States, have adapted paint ings of famous artists from out of the past for their holi day postage stamps, some, including the United States, have utilized more modern concepts to call attention to this holiday.

title: Alan P. L. Binks Is the Fiance Of Mary Kirkpatrick Bigham
description: NEW MARLBOROUGH, Mass., Dec. 23  The Rev. Dr. Thomas J. Bigham has announced the engagement of Ms daughter, Miss Mary Kirkpatrick Bigham, to Alan Penrose Langdale Binks of Nairobi, Kenya, son of Wing Commander Anthony F. Binks, R.A,F., retired, and Mrs. Milks of Benson, Eng land. The wedding is planned for May in Great Barrington.

title: Racial Ideas Change in South Africa's Ruling Group
description: PRETORIA, South Africa, Dec. 18  Perhaps because their story was a poignant one, no people have been more intoxicated with their history than the Afrikaners, the whites, mostly of Dutch descent, who rule South Africa.

title: A Christmas Prayer
description: The people who walked in dark ness have seen a great light; Upon those who dwell in the land of gloom a light has shone. ... For the yoke that burdened them. ... You have smashed. ... For every boot that tramped in battle, every cloak rolled in blood, will be burned. ... For child is born to us, a son is given us. ... They name him Wonder Counselor, GodHero, FatherForever, Prince of Peace. His dominion is vast and forever peaceful ... which He confirms by judgment and justice, both now and forever. (Isaiah 9: 2.7)

title: Boxing
description: In boxing, the fight that didn't happen in 1972 created more conversation than any fight that did.

title: Education
description: Harvey B. Scribner, the New York City school chancellor, seemed in such high spirits last Thursday that a visitor to his of fice might have thought that the Board of Education had just voted not only to renew his contract but also to abolish itself.

title: Mrs. Simian Has Son
description: ENGLEWOOD, N. J., Dec. 23A son was born Dec. 3 to Mr. and Mrs. Luis Alberto Simian in St. Luke's Hospital in New York. Mrs. Simian is the former. Miss Caroline Chapman Escher. Her hus band is with the First Na tional City Bank in New York. The child has been named Maximino Escher.

title: Prayer by the Numbers
description: The Supreme Court has upheld the lower court ruling which declared the military academies' compulsory chapel to be unconstitutional. This action represents an enlightened judicial effort to block the abuse of religion by those who seek to increase the power of the state. In this particular instance, the courts have struck at a traditional but nonetheless distasteful form of such abusethe admixture of religion and military ritual that in the past has so often led to an apparent sanctioning of war itself.

title: Balczo, Miss Gyarmati Cited
description: VIENNA, Dec. 23 (AP) Andras Balczo, a pentathlon star, and Andrea Gyarmati, a swimmer, were voted top ath letes of 1972 in Hungary, the Hungarian press agency MTI reported today.

title: Rabbi Abraham Joshua Heschel Dead
description: Rabbi Abraham Joshua Hes chel, the Jewish theologian and author who became a personal and intellectual force of major proportions on the American religious scene, died early yes terday at his home here at 425 Riverside Drive. He was 65 years old.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTONIn January, 1964, in the first foreignpolicy crisis of the Johnson Administration, antiAmerican riots broke out in Panama over de mands for a new Panama Canal treaty to replace the pact signed in 1903. This month, after nearly nine years of negotiations punctuated by occasional violence, the United States and Pana ma found themselves almost as far apart in their views on a new treaty as at the time of the 1964 riots.

title: FIESTA BOWL WON BY ARIZONA STATE
description: TEMPE, Ariz., Dec. 23 (AP) Arizona State University's 16th ranked Sun Devils, led by Woody Green's four touch downs, defeated the Missouri Tigers, 4935, to capture the second annual Fiesta Bowl to night before a record crowd of over 51,000.

title: Gerald Vogel to Wed Miss Pellino, Student
description: PELHAM, N. Y., Dec. 23 Mr. and Mrs. Paul J. Pellino of Pelham Heights have an noticed the engagement of their daughter, Miss Laurette Pellino, to Gerald J. Vogel, son of Mr. and Mrs. O. Mar tin Vogel of New Rochelle. The wedding is planned for June.

title: LBJ Park Expansion Is Planned, But Some Landowners Resist
description: STONEWALL, Tex., Dec. 23 Battle lines are being drawn along the Pedernales River for the second time in seven years as a few landowners resist ef forts to expand the Lyndon B. Johnson State Park.

title: Truman's Condition
description: Former President Harry S. Truman was described as slightly improved but still in critical condition last night after he had become com pletely unresponsive earlier in the day at a Kansas City hospital, Page 32.

title: IN THE NATION
description: It is not at all unlikely that when Congress reconvenes there will be a long and widely publicized debate over the Pentagon budget; and in the end, it is not too hard to imagine Congress cutting President Nixon's proposed de fense spending by a billion dollars or so, to huzzas on the left and groans on the right.

title: Beavers Snap Streak
description: City College snapped a five game losing streak by rallying for a 7162 victory over Queens College on the losers' court last night. Otis Loyd led the Beavers with 17 points. Queens led at halftime, 3229.

title: You Never Saw This on Ed Sullivan
description: SOME of the things they do are not merely difficult, but even surrealistic. A woman balances with one foot atop another woman's head, and both of them spin five plates on five poles in each hand. Ten women form a pyramid on a bicycle. A man balances on his hands on a flimsy construction of five offbalance tables, while a woman balances with her hands on his shoulders (and balances, on top of her head, six saucers before removing them with her ... feet).

title: Bullets Beat Pistons
description: BALTIMORE, Dec. 23 (AP) Mike Riordan and Elvin Hayes led the Baltimore Bullets in a fourthquarter rally for a 10497 victory over the Detroit Pistons tonight in a National Basketball Association game.

title: New Novel
description: Midway in this fresh and engaging novel, a discontented heroine finds herself in sympa thy with Tolstoy's wellworn observation in Anna Kare nina: All happy families re semble one another; every un happy family is unhappy in its own fashion. At 35, the res tive housewife of the title has a gnawing sense of promise unfulfilled and hopes unreal ized. What she does about it is to enroll in a local junior collegewhere she exchanges her special brand of unhappi ness for another of its infinite varieties.

title: Records and Anticlimax
description: Track and Field

title: Managua Aas Disappeared
description: GUATEMALA City, Dec. 23 (Reuters)  Danilo Arias, a Costa Rican believed to be the first foreign newsman to reach Managua, reported by radio today that hundreds of bodies were lying in the streets.

description: MENLO PARK, Calif., Dec. 23The arrest this week of eight persons on charges grow ing out of the slaying of a prison guard has focused new attention on the selfdescribed revolutionary organization called Venceremos (Spanish for We shall overcome).

title: FLORIDA WATCHED SCHOLAR CLOSELY
description: GAINESVILLE, Fla., Dec, 23 On Feb. 4, 1969, Kenneth A. Megill, a young professor of Marxist philosophy in his third year at the University of Flori da, gave a brief talk on black power.

description: STAMFORD, Conn., Dec. 23 Miss Judianne Longfield and Michael Douglas Coster plan to be married in June in Wooster, Ohio, where she is a sophomore at the College of Wooster and he is a junior.

title: Manufacturers' Event Off the Sebring Board
description: Writing anything about Sebring is a hazardous occu pation: information is in stantly perishable as circum stances change from minute to minute. Moreover, because of Byzantine intrigues, deals offered and withdrawn, ob fuscation, premature an nouncements and inspired ru

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Deck the halls with et cetera
description: One pleasure of the holiday season is watching the house become a celebration in itself. A pleasure for the eye and spirit. Floral designer Stephen Barany created just such a festive mood in this formal living room. He edged the fireplace in garlands studded with walnuts and tiny citrus, topped the mantel with a glorious Della Robbia wreath. For fragrance, he set baskets of pomander balls atop tables throughout the room. Designer David Laurence Roth transformed a small corner (right) into a festive nook for lastminute gift wrapping (his presents come with red and green gingham ribbons and pine cones). He filled a tall urn beside the secretary with branches picked up around his country house, which he stained and shellacked a rich brown and covered with silver bulbs. The wing chair sports a holiday red plaid.

title: Diana Ross: Lady Doesn't Sing the Blues
description: THERE is a swimming pool and a tennis court, an antique chess set, bottles of banana liqueur, and a mirrored piano in the living room. Gazing into the silver piano one can see white walls and 30foothigh ceilings and a tapestry of Marilyn Mon roe by Andy Warhol.

title: Quake Hits Hawaii
description: HONOLULU, Dec. 23 (AP) A small earthquake tremor shook much of Hawaii today, causng minor glass breakage. A spokesman for the volcano observatory said the tremor had occurred about six miles be neath the village of Captain Cook on Hawaii Island's west ern coast. It registered 4.8 on the Richter scale. The only damage was reported in the immediate area of the earth quake where glass items tum bled from shelves.

title: Letters
description: I read your letter (My dear Students, Nov. 19) with a peculiar interest since I am at once in accord with your apprehensions about the thinness of so much of Amer ican higher education and yet deplore your sense of who and what is an American student. I share your sense of outrage at the general depravity of language sometimes found on campuses, but I am disap pointed with what appears to be your feeling that revel ance means Kesey, Vonne gut, and Burgress for the whites and soul food and bongo drums for the blacks.

title: WINGS TRIUMPH OVER CANUCKS, 51
description: DETROIT, Dec. 23 (AP) Mickey Redmond, on a hot streak for the last two weeks, scored his 19th goal of the sea son and assisted on two others today to lead the Detroit Red Wings to a 51 victory over the Vancouver Canucks in a Na tional Hockey League game.

title: Movies
description: THERE is a scene in Peter Medak's film The Ruling Class that, in many ways, character izes the British cinema in general. Peter O'Toole, as a mad English nobleman who believes himself to be Jack the Ripper, rises majestically in the House of Lords, deliv ers a firebreathing speech in support of capital punish ment, and is greeted with a stirring ovation from his fel low aristocrats. The barb is that O'Toole, in his madness, sees his colleagues as a cham berful of rotted carcasses and mosscovered relics, a dun geon of archaic monsters.

title: FOR TV, A SMILE BY PAPADOPOULOS
description: ATHENS, Dec. 20Premier George Papadopoulos, a tight lipped, former army colonel, smiled into the television cam eras several times during the delivery of his annual message to the nation.

title: Miss Tomai, W. J. Heron Jr. Plan Marriage
description: RIDGEWOOD, N. J., Dec. 23  Mr. and Mrs. James Vincent Tomai Jr. of Ridge wood have made known the engagement of their daugh ter, Miss Antoinette Tomai, to William Julian Heron Jr. of New York. He is the son of Mrs. Stephen Corrigall of Estepona, Spain, and Mr. Heron of Mount Kisco, N. Y.

title: Tupolev Dead at 84
description: Andrei N. Tupolev, the air craft designer whose name became synonymous with the Soviet aviation industry, died yesterday at 84. His new supersonic airliner, the TU 144, rivaled only by the BritishFrench Concorde, is expected to go into service in 1975. Details on Page 41.

title: Eight layers in threequarter time
description: Whoever it was who first got the notion of wedding almonds and choco late deserves a Christmas toast from all those who join this cook in con sidering it one of the world's most tantalizing combinations. The recipe on this page combines almonds and chocolate and meringue and apricot preserves in a manylayered torte simi lar to the Emperor Torte that delighted Emperor Franz Josef, founder of the AustroHungarian Empire. This cake could prove to be the peak of seren dipity for Christmastime guests.

description: RICHMOND, Dec. 23 (AP) Jerald A. Finch, 45 years old, will become managing editor of The Richmond News Leader on Jan. 1. The Richmond Neswspa pers announced Wednesday that Mr. Finch, executive city editor of the afternoon daily, would succeed K. Lawrence Gould, who is now general manager and executive editor of the Media General Financial Weekly.

description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (UPI)When a retired secre tary died two years ago, she left custody of her $100,000 estate to Senator Harry F. Byrd Jr., Independent of Vir ginia, for that use or uses which he deems best for the general welfare of, the United States of America.

Few such agencies would have had the daring to take on, in effect, the Bureau Reclamation, the Army Corps of Engineers and all those powerful private interests that benefitout of all pro portion to what they payfrom federally financed water ways, irrigation systems and flood control projects.

They may be perfectly reason able on matters of foreign policy or in tegrated housing, but bring up the sub ject of Montessori vs. Summerhill or breast vs. bottle, and it's a scene out of Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde.

description: HANOI, North Vietnam, Dec. 23The North Vietnamese Vice Minister of Health said tonight that 25 doctors, pharmacists and male and female nurses had been killed at Bach Mai Hospital during American bomb ing raids on Hanoi in the last few days.

description: Stores were jammed with lastminute Christmas shoppers yesterday, but the festive spirit was slightly disrupted by the detonation of two incendiary devices at Bonwit Teller and the igniting of a third device at Bergdorf Goodman.

title: Harry S. Truman
description: Harry S. Truman has never been a fashionable political figure. The lib eralleft patriciate, even when it af fected to admire him, treated him with contempt (the brave little gamecock from Missouri) and today sees him as an architect of the cold war, a company commander who never reasoned why, and certain ly no model for the brave new Demo cratic coalition. No wonder: Harry Truman consistently defied the nos trums of the liberal intellectuals. He did not have charisma and prob ably would not have wanted it. More over, Harry Truman believed in the public, not a congenial sentiment for those who (as Janet Smith recently put it) see majority rule as distinct ly in bad taste. If Harry Truman had lost in 1948 it is hard to imagine his bemoaning the failure of the peo ple to reach his height of moral grandeur. He would more likely have criticized himself with some com ment like if the student failed to learn, the teacher failed to teach. There is more than a little instruc tion in Harry Truman's career for the liberal Democrats of our own times.

title: JUMBO EDWARDS, 66, OLYMPIC ROWING ACE
description: SOUTHAMPTON, England, Dec. 23 (AP)  Hugh (Jumbo) Edwards, double Olympic gold medalist and internationally known rowing coach, died here today. He was 66 years old.

Gray, former pres ident and chief executive offi cer of Pan American World Airways, who had started as one of the airline's original 10 pilots died yesterday of cancer at the ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center. He was 66 years old and lived at 535 Park Avenue and in Greenwich, Conn.

title: Train Kills Stamford Man
description: DARIEN, Conn., Dec. 23A 6Iyearold commuter was struck and killed by a Penn Central express train last night at the Noroton Heights station. The victim was Martin Roth of 27 East Maple Tree Avenue, Stamford, who was attempting, according to the police, to cross the tracks when he was struck by an eastbound express from New York. Mr. Roth was em ployed by a New York garment manufacturing company and had moved to Stamford only two months ago.

Salaries and bonuses for athletes touched heights pre posterous even for these inflated times, yet labor unrest and lawsuits plagued professional games. Such was the sports year of 1972, a year of contrast and contradiction, of triumph and tragedy, of high emprise and sore disappoint ment.
