description: Dr. Samuel Koenig, chairman of the department of sociology and anthropology at Brooklyn College from 1948 to 1965, died Friday in Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 73 years old and lived at 1890 East 21st Street, Brooklyn.

title: HAVLICEK PACES CELTICS' VICTORY
description: PROVIDENCE, R. I., Dec. 30 (UPI)  John Havlicek scored 28 points tonight as the Boston Celtics defeated the Philadel phia 76ers, 117107, in a Na tional Basketball Assciciation game at the Providence Civic Center.

title: Beame Accuses Taxi Agency of Loose Spending
description: The city's Taxi and Limousine Commission was charged yes terday by Controller Abraham D. Beanie with improper and excessive expenditures.

title: Spending and the War Key Issues As Congress Opens This Week
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 30The 93d Congress convenes Wednes day with its members braced for a series of confrontations with President Nixon.

title: China Again Fills Cabinet Post From the Ranks of the Military
description: HONG KONG, Dec. 30In the slow process of filling high Government positions made va cant in China by purges during the Cultural Revolution, the leadership in Peking has named still another man of military background, Fan Tzuyu, to a ministerial post.

title: Roselle Seen Lifting Super Bowl Blackout
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 30  Pete Rozelle, the commission er of the National Football League, indicated today that the television blackout in the Los Angeles area would be lifted for the Super Bowl game there on Jan. 14.

title: Elizabeth Mehlhop Is Bride in Suburbs
description: HASTINGSONHUDSON, N. Y., Dec. 30Miss Eliza beth Mehlhop, daughter of Capt. Donald L. Mehlhop, U.S.N., retired, and Mrs. Mehlhop, was married here this afternoon to Paul Beau mont Willatts, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Henry Willatts of Wimbledon, Eng land.

title: World News Briefs
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Dec. 30A Roman Catholic bakery worker was shot and killed in his automobile as he was leaving work in Belfast today.

title: Dr. M. David Epstein, 67, A Psychoanalyst, Is Dead
description: Dr. M. David Epstein, a psy choanalyst and psychiatrist, who was a preceptor at Mount Sinai Hospital and a lecturer at itsmedical school, died yester day at his home, 49 East 96th Street. He was 67 years old.

title: Air Crash Deaths a Record
description: LONDON, Dec. 30 (AP)An aviation expert said today that provisional statistics showed that more than 1,700 people had died this year on commer cial flights, which would make 1972 the worst year on record. The worst previous year was 1966, when just over 1,000 died.

title: Kingsland Mansion Is Opening Today
description: The Queens Historical So ciety is slowly restoring a 200yearold Dutch colonial home to serve as a multi purpose community museum.

title: U.S. Aides Differ Sharply Over Value of the Raids
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 30  Official Washington seemed un sure today whether the heavy bombing of North Vietnam, which was ordered halted this morning, had helped or hin dered the United States in get ting the Paris negotiations re opened.

title: No Ship Movements
description: No passenger and mail ship arrivals or departures are scheduled for today or tomor row in the Port of New York.

title: SQUIRES CONQUER TAMS BY 120104
description: NORFOLK, Va., Dec. 30 (AP) Julius Erving and Jim Eakins led a thirdquarter surge that propelled the Virginia Squires to a 120104 American Basket ball Association victory over the Memphis Tams tonight.

title: Rice Beats Yale, 7270
description: MILWAUKEE, Dec. 30 (AP) Rice missed three free throws in the last 50 seconds of over time tonight, but hung on to beat Yale, 7270, for third place in the Milwaukee Classic.

title: TRANSPORTATION
description: In Vietnam, an advanced electronic landing system, a versatile departure from pre vious equipment, has been in use for many months to help guide Air Force planes onto rugged strips.

title: Shorter Reviews
description: This immensely readable book presents the story of the Moguls, the descendants of Genghis Khan who conquered and ruled India from 1526 to the early 18th century, as a whirling kaleidoscope, as a tale rich in colorful personalities and bizarre turns of fate and fortune, thick with spiderlike intrigue in which loyalties and centers of power are constantly shifting. Waldemar Hansen's primary concern is the life and times of Shah Jahan (1592 1666), the fourth of the dynas ty, who achieved immorality by building the Taj Mahal. A sensitive, hardworking man, a conscientious ruler and a de vout Moslem, Shah Jahan loved only one of his three wives: Mumtaz Mahal, over whose corpse he built the white mar ble mausoleum. Mr. Hansen does not point out that the edi fice was as much an expression of its creator's megalomania, a translation of his extreme pride and contempt for all, as it was of affection for his wife. This may be because Hansen has struck such a priceless lode of history unfamiliar to English language readers that he had neither the space nor inclina tion to analyze what he has found. The result, however, is a shining piece of expository craftsmanship.

title: Greenwich Nuptials for Patricia Depuy
description: GREENWICH Conn., Dec. 30In St. Michael's Roman Catholic Church here this morning Miss Patricia Ann Dupuy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Warner Moses Depuy of Milford, Pa., was married to David Charles Johnson, son or Dr. and Mrs. Edgar N. Johnson of Wilmington, Del. The Rev. James M. English performed the ceremony.

title: KEY JOBS OFFERED TO LABOR BY NIXON
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 30  President Nixon has offered to put a labor union representative at a high level in every Fed eral Government department, wellinformed White House of ficial has disclosed.
